(c)  A cat that is allowed to run at large by the owner must be surgically altered (nonreproducing cats), must have an identification tag with the owner's name and correct phone number listed on the tag, must be currently vaccinated against the rabies virus, and must not become a nuisance to other citizens in the city. A cat owner who follows these guidelines shall be responsible for any damage caused by such cat. A cat that causes problems or damage off its owner's property shall be restricted to its owner's private property. 
(d)  When an animal control officer has commenced pursuit of an animal running at large, he may continue the pursuit and follow the animal onto any unenclosed private property for the purpose of apprehending it as soon as possible. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1092. - Confinement during estrus. 
    Any unspayed female dog or cat in the stage of estrus (heat) shall be confined during such period of time in a house, building or secure enclosure, and such area of enclosure shall be so constructed that no other dog or cat may gain access to the confined animal. An owner who does not comply shall be ordered to remove the animal in heat to a boarding kennel, veterinary hospital or animal shelter. All expenses incurred as a result of the confinement shall be paid by the owner. Failure to comply with the removal order of the animal control officer shall be a violation of this chapter, and the dog or cat will impounded as prescribed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1093. - Disturbances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner to harbor any dog, cat or other pet animal which, by any sound or cry or other activity, shall disturb the peace, comfort or property of the inhabitants of the neighborhood, and such disturbance is declared to be a public nuisance. The animal control officer may require a written statement from a complainant before issuing a citation for a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1094. - Guard dogs. 
    It shall be unlawful to place or maintain any dog which has been specifically trained to attack in any area for the protection of persons or property unless the dog is physically confined to a specific area or is under complete and absolute control. The area or premises in which a guard dog is confined must be conspicuously posted with warning signs bearing letters not less than two inches high in both English and Spanish. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1095. - Unlawful release from confinement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove from any place of confinement any dog or cat which has been confined as authorized, without the consent of the impounding agency. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1096. - Animal defecation prohibited in certain areas. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the owner or person in control of an animal to negligently allow or permit such animal to defecate on any public property or improved private property other than that of the owner of the animal. That the animal was at large at the time it defecated on any property shall constitute a prima facie evidence that the owner or person in control of the animal allowed or permitted the animal to so act. 
(b)  It shall be a defense to prosecution under this section that the owner or person in control of the animal immediately removed and cleaned up such animal's feces from public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1097. - Trap, neuter, and return program registry. 
    Persons or groups operating trap, neuter and return programs shall register at the Brownsville Animal Regulation and Care Center, providing such information as may be requested. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Secs. 10-1098-10-1120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VACCINATION AND LICENSING OF CATS AND DOGS 

Sec. 10-1121. - Vaccination required. 
(a)  Every owner of a dog or cat three months of age or older shall have such animal vaccinated against rabies. All dogs or cats vaccinated at three months of age or older shall be revaccinated at one year of age and annually thereafter. 
(b)  Any person moving into the city from a location outside the city shall comply with this article within 30 days after having moved into the city. 
(c)  If a dog or cat has inflicted a bite on any person or another animal within the last ten days, the owner of the dog or cat shall report such fact to the veterinarian or city health department, and no rabies vaccine shall be administered until after the ten-day observation period. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1122. - Certificate of vaccination. 
    Upon vaccination, the veterinarian shall execute and furnish to the owner of the dog or cat, as evidence thereof, a certificate upon a form furnished by the city. The veterinarian shall retain a duplicate copy, and one copy shall be filed with the health department. Such certificate shall contain the name, address and telephone number of the owner of the vaccinated dog or cat, the date of vaccination, the type of rabies vaccine used and the number of the rabies tag. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1123. - Tags required for dogs; duplicates. 
(a)  Concurrent with the issuance and delivery of the certificate of vaccination referred to in section 10-1122, the owner of the dog shall cause to be attached to the collar or harness of the vaccinated dog a metal tag, serially numbered to correspond with the vaccination certificate number and bearing the year of issuance and the name of the jurisdiction and state. Such tag shall be worn by the dog at all times. 
(b)  If the original tag provided for in subsection (a) of this section is lost or destroyed, the owner of the dog shall obtain a duplicate tag. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1124. - Proof of vaccination. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or harbors a vaccinated dog or cat to fail or refuse to exhibit his copy of the certificate of vaccination upon demand to any person charged with the enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1125. - Harboring without vaccination. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor any dog or cat which has not been vaccinated against rabies, as provided in this article, or which cannot be identified as having a current vaccination certificate. In addition, the dog or cat may be immediately removed by an animal control officer to the animal shelter for vaccination and released to the owner upon payment for the vaccination and for boarding charges. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1126. - Vaccination required for license. 
    No dog or cat shall be licensed without proof of rabies vaccination as provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1127. - License required. 
    Any owner of a dog or cat which is three months of age or older shall procure a license. License fees shall be paid annually to correspond with the rabies vaccination date. The city commission may designate, through the public health director, veterinarians who may also issue city licenses. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1128. - Licensing fees. 
(a)  The following fees are established and shall be charged annually by the city for the licensing of all dogs and cats three months of age and over within the corporate city limits: 
(1) Licensing of a spayed or neutered dog or cat ..... $4.00 
(2) Licensing of a not spayed or neutered dog or cat ..... $8.00 
(b)  Replacement tags for loss or destruction of original license tag shall cost the same as the original. 
(c)  All veterinarians may issue the licenses required in section 10-1127 for the fees set forth therein. Such veterinarians shall be paid the sum of $1.00 for each $4.00 license issued, and $2.00 for each $8.00 license issued. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1129 - Reserved. 
Sec. 10-1130. - Display of license tag; retention of license receipt and vaccination certificate; duplicate tags. 
(a)  The license tag issued pursuant to this article shall be attached to a collar, harness or other device and shall be worn with the rabies tag by the licensed dog at all times. 
(b)  The original license receipt and rabies vaccination certificate and the license and rabies vaccination tags for cats shall be retained by the owner for inspection by any person charged with the enforcement of this article. 
(c)  If a license tag is lost or destroyed, the owner shall obtain a duplicate tag from the city at the same cost as the original. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1131. - Transferability. 
    Dog and cat licenses are not transferable, and it shall be unlawful for any person to use any license and rabies tag for any dog or cat other than the dog or cat for which such tag was originally issued. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1132. - Use of false or stolen documents. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make use of a stolen, counterfeit or forged license receipt, license tag, rabies vaccination certificate, rabies vaccination tag or other form. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1133. - Microchipping of dogs and cats. 
(a)  All dogs and cats over the age of four months must be implanted with an identifying microchip. Nothing in this section supersedes, eliminates, or alters the licensing requirements of this chapter 10. 
(b)  The microchip requirements of this section shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  A dog or cat with a high likelihood of suffering serious bodily injury if implanted with the microchip identification due to the health conditions of the animal. The owner must obtain written confirmation of that fact from a Texas licensed veterinarian. If the dog or cat can be safely implanted with an identifying microchip at a later date, that date must be stated in the written confirmation. 
(2)  A dog or cat that is kenneled or trained in the city but is owned by an individual that does not reside in the city. 
(c)  An owner who offers any dog or cat over the age of four months for sale, trade, or adoption must provide the microchip identification number in writing and, in the case of a dog, the valid dog license number at the time of the sale, trade, or adoption. 
(d)  When an impounded dog or cat without microchip identification, in addition to satisfying applicable requirements for the release of the animal, including but not limited to payment of impound fees, the owner shall also have the dog or cat implanted with a microchip by a veterinarian (or other person legally qualified to implant microchips in cats and dogs) selected by the owner. The owner shall pay the cost of the city transporting the animal to the veterinarian for the implantation and, when the veterinarian certifies in writing that the microchip has been implanted and all charges of the impound facility have been paid, the animal shall be released to the owner. 
(e)  The fee for the identifying microchip device shall be included in the cost of adopting the dog or cat. 
(f)  The city manager or his designees shall engage in a continuing program to explain and clarify the purposes and requirements of this Article to citizens affected by it, and to guide owners, operators, and managers in their compliance with it. The program may include publication of a brochure for affected businesses and individuals explaining the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2015-971-G, 9-1-2015) 
Secs. 10-1134-10-1144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - [PERMITTING OF FERRETS] 

Sec. 10-1145. - Ferrets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor any ferret within the city, unless a current registration permit has been issued for such ferret in accordance with this section. 
(b)  The owner, keeper or harborer of any ferret within the city shall make application to the director of health department of the city or his representative for a registration permit for such ferret. Such application shall contain information on the ferret's description, date of rabies vaccination, and name, address and telephone number of the owner, keeper or harborer. The owner, keeper or harborer shall also present to the director of the health department of the city or his representative a current certificate of rabies vaccination issued for such ferret in accordance with section 10-1122. 
(c)  The application described in this section shall be accompanied by a fee of $50.00. 
(d)  Upon the owner's compliance with the above provisions of this section the health director or his representative shall register the ferret and issue a metal registration tag, which shall be attached to the ferret's collar, and which shall be worn by the ferret at all times. 
(e)  Registration shall be valid for one year from the date of issue. 
(f)  If a permit tag issued under this section is lost or stolen, it may be replaced by payment of a fee of $15.00 and presentation of the registration permit. If the tag and registration permit are both lost or stolen, a new permit must be purchased at the regular fee. 
(g)  Any false statement in a rabies certification, or application for permit under this section, shall render null and void the permit issued for such ferret and shall subject such ferret to being impounded in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(h)  Any ferret suspected of biting a person shall be placed under quarantine to determine if the animal is capable of transmitting or exposing humans and/or other animals to rabies or be humanely euthanized and appropriately tested for rabies. The quarantine period for ferrets shall be for a period of not less than 30 days after the biting of such person. The place of quarantine shall be at the animal shelter or in quarters supervised by a veterinarian for the period of the quarantine. The ferret may not be quarantined on the owner's premise. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful to have a ferret in a public place unless it is kept in an adequate enclosure or on a leash no greater than six feet in length to control the actions of such animal. 
(j)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor within the city any ferret which has not been neutered. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Secs. 10-1146-10-1160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RABIES CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 46. 

Sec. 10-1161. - Duty to report animal bites. 
    Any person having knowledge that an animal has bitten a human shall immediately report the incident to the public health director, an animal control officer, the state department of health, or his private veterinarian. Every physician or other medical practitioner who treats a person for such bite shall, within 12 hours, report such treatment to the public health director, to the animal control officer, or to the state department of health, giving the name, age, sex and precise location of the bitten person and such other information as the officer or agency may require. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1162. - Report of diagnosed or suspected rabies. 
    Any veterinarian who clinically diagnoses rabies in a dog, cat or other domestic or wild animal shall immediately report the incident to the public health director or animal control officer or to the state department of health stating precisely where such animal may be found. If a known or suspected rabid animal bites or attacks a domestic animal, such incident shall be reported as required in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1163. - Confinement of dog or cat having bitten person. 
(a)  Any dog or cat which has bitten a person shall be observed for a period of ten days from the date of the bite. The procedure and place of observation shall be designated by the investigating officer or responsible agency. Confinement shall be at the veterinary hospital of the owner's choice. Such confinement shall be at the expense of the owner. Stray dogs or cats whose owners cannot be located shall be confined in the animal shelter. The owner of any dog or cat which has been reported to have inflicted a bite on a person shall, on demand, produce the dog or cat for impoundment, as prescribed in this section. Refusal to produce the dog or cat constitutes a violation of this section, and each day of such refusal shall constitute a separate and individual violation. 
(b)  An animal control officer is empowered to issue a citation to the owner of a dog or cat which has bitten a person or for a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1164. - Period of confinement of dog or cat which has bitten person; redemption from impoundment. 
(a)  The impoundment of dogs and cats which have inflicted bites on humans shall be for a period of ten days for observation and shall not be terminated until a licensed veterinarian has declared the animal to be free of rabies. 
(b)  If a dog or cat dies during the observation period, the animal control officer shall cause the dog's or cat's head to be removed and submitted for rabies testing. 
(c)  Any impounded animal on observation may be redeemed after the observation period has ended and upon payment of the license fee where applicable, care and feeding charges, veterinary charges, rabies vaccination charges, and other costs as set by the city commission. If such animal is not redeemed within three days, it shall be deemed abandoned and shall be humanely euthanized. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1165. - Procedures for other than cat or dog bites. 
    Procedures concerning bites from other animals shall be discussed with the public health director, animal control officer, or the state department of health for proper disposition. Any wild animal which has bitten a person should be caught and killed and the brain immediately submitted to a qualified laboratory for rabies examination. Rodents, rabbits, birds, and reptiles are not considered to be transmitters of the rabies virus and should not be submitted for laboratory examination for rabies. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Secs. 10-1166-10-1190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 10-1191. - Animal shelter to be provided. 
    A suitable animal shelter shall be provided for the purpose of boarding and caring for any animal impounded under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1192. - Custody of animals in violation. 
    Animals owned or harbored in violation of this chapter or any other section of this Code or city ordinance or state law shall be taken into custody by an animal control officer or other designated official and impounded. Stray animals shall be similarly impounded. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1193. - Removal from animal shelter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any impounded animal from the animal shelter without the consent of the animal control officer or designated official or agency. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1194. - Disposition. 
(a)  If the owner of an impounded animal is known, immediate notice shall be given to him. Any impounded animal may be redeemed upon payment of the license fee where applicable, care and feeding charges, veterinary charges, rabies vaccination charges and such other costs as set by the city commission. 
(b)  If such animal is not redeemed within three days, it shall be deemed abandoned and may be placed for adoption subject to payment of the license fee where applicable, impoundment fee, care and feeding charges, veterinary charges, rabies vaccination charges where applicable, and such other costs as set by the city commission, or the animal control officer may humanely euthanize the animal. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1195. - Disposition of animal held on complaint. 
(a)  If a complaint has been filed in the municipal court against the owner of an impounded animal for a violation of this chapter, the animal shall not be released except on the order of the court, which may also direct the owner to pay any penalties for violation of this chapter in addition to all impoundment fees. The court may, upon making a finding that such animal is vicious or that it represents a clear and present danger to the citizens or other animals in the community, order the animal to be euthanized in a humane manner. 
(b)  Surrender of an animal by the owner thereof to the city does not relieve or render the owner immune from a decision of the court or from any fees including quarantine fees or fines which may result from a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1196. - Euthanasia of animals upon owner's or citizen's request. 
    The director may accept a dog or cat from the owner thereof for disposal. The disposal of such animals shall be accomplished in the same manner as though the animals had been impounded and not redeemed. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1197. - Sterilization of dogs and cats. 
    In accordance with applicable state law, the director shall establish procedures to ensure that no unsterilized dog or cat is released from the city's animal control facilities except under the terms of a sterilization agreement as required by Chapter 828 of the V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1198. - Redemption rate after impoundment. 
(a)  The person entitled to the possession of any animal delivered to the animal control center shall be entitled to have the animal delivered to him at the animal control center upon presentation of satisfactory evidence of ownership, proof of compliance with any other applicable ordinance or statute governing the release of an animal to such owner, and payment of the following charges and fees as applicable, provided such animal is not infected or reasonably believed to be infected with rabies or any other infectious or contagious disease: 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the following fees shall be charged for the impoundment of an animal in the animal control center. 
(1)  For animals other than dogs and cats and for sterilized dogs and cats: 
(i)  $10.00 for the first impoundment of the animal; 
(ii)  $20.00 for the second impoundment of the same animal; and 
(iii)  $30.00 for the third and each subsequent impoundment of the same animal. 
(2)  For unsterilized dogs or cats: 
(i)  $20.00 for the first impoundment of the animal; a $20.00 refund may be obtained upon proof of sterilization (mandatory for cats) within 30 days; 
(ii)  $40.00 for the second impoundment of the same animal; a $20.00 refund may be obtained upon proof of mandatory sterilization (dogs and cats) within 30 days; and 
(iii)  $100.00 for the third and each subsequent impoundment; a $20.00 refund may be obtained upon proof of mandatory sterilization (dogs and cats) with 30 days. 
(c)  The fees specified about for unsterilized dogs or cats shall apply unless the health officer is able to determine by external examination that the animal has been sterilized or the owner presents a certificate from a veterinarian establishing that the animal has been sterilized. 
(d)  No impoundment fee shall be charged for dogs, cats or other small animals delivered to the animal control center by the owner, or for dogs, cats or other small animals placed in custody of the animal control center because the owner of the animal has been arrested and is the custody of the state or city. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Secs. 10-1199-10-1220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WILD ANIMALS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Regulations regarding keeping of wild animals, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 240.001 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1221 - Generally. 
(a)  In this section, the phrase "wild animal" means lions, tigers, ocelots, bobcats, panthers, cougars, leopards, cheetahs, jaguars, lynxes, servals, caracals, hyenas, wolves, coyotes, jackals, bears, baboons, chimpanzees, orangutans, gorillas, skunks, raccoons, armadillos or hybrids of these species, and any other animal typically found in a zoo with the exception of domestic dogs, domestic cats, livestock, and poultry. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to harbor, have, keep, or possess any wild animal or poisonous reptile within the city limits except in an approved zoo, circus, school, or college for educational purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Secs. 10-1222-10-1260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - COMMERCE IN LIVE ANIMALS 

Sec. 10-1261. - Prohibited sales. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to sell, barter, exchange, or give away or offer to sell, barter, exchange, or give away any live animal from: 
(1)  Any public property; or 
(2)  Any property to which the public has access that does not have a valid certificate of occupancy issued by the city specifically allowing the sale of animals on the property. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the person selling, exchanging, bartering or giving away or offering to sell, barter, exchange, or give away is: 
(1)  Employed by the city animal services department and is acting in that capacity; or 
(2)  An animal welfare, rescue, and/or adoption agency that is a nonprofit entity under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1262. - Breeder permit required. 
(a)  No person shall breed animals without obtaining a permit in compliance with this section. 
(b)  A breeder permit shall be obtained by: 
(1)  Any individual who intentionally or unintentionally causes or allows the breeding of a dog or cat, or makes a dog or cat available for breeding purposes; or 
(2)  Any person who offers for sale or trade, receives any compensation for or gives away any litter of dogs or cats, with the exception of litters taken to the animal shelter. 
(c)  A breeder shall: 
(1)  Breed only one dog or one cat which results in the birthing of a maximum of one litter in a 12 month period; 
(2)  Not offer for sale, sell, trade, receive any compensation for or give way more than one litter of dogs or one litter of cats in a 12 month period, with the exception of litters taken to the animal shelter; 
(3)  Keep records as may be required by the city public health department; 
(4)  Furnish to each buyer or new owner of an animal the breeder permit number of the breeder so that the new owner has proof that the animal has been legally bred; 
(5)  Not offer a puppy or kitten under the age of eight weeks of age for sale, trade, or other compensation or free giveaway, with the exception of litters taken to the animal shelter; 
(6)  Recommend that any animal sold, transferred or given away be examined by a veterinarian within one week of the date of transfer; and 
(7)  List the breeder permit number on all public notices advertising the sale or free give away of litters or individual puppies or kittens. 
(d)  The cost of a breeder permit shall be $50.00; the permit shall be valid for one year from date it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013) 
Sec. 10-1263. - Commercial permits. 
(a)  Except for veterinarians or veterinary hospitals, all commercial animal establishments must have a commercial animal sales permit. This permit shall expire one year after it is issued but may be renewed annually upon inspection and payment of a fee. Temporary permits shall be valid for the duration of an event not to exceed 30 days from the date of issuance. Fees for commercial animal sales permits shall be as follows: 
Pet stores ..... $100.00 
Department stores with pet departments ..... $50.00 
Grooming shops ..... $50.00 
Kennels with fewer than 10 animals ..... $50.00 
Kennels with eleven to fifty animals ..... $75.00 
Kennels with more than 50 animals ..... $100.00 
Animal exhibits ..... $150.00 
Performing animals (temporary) ..... $50.00 
Circuses (temporary) ..... $100.00 
Rodeos (temporary) ..... $100.00 
Petting zoos (temporary) ..... $50.00 
Animal auctions (temporary) ..... $50.00 
Commercial animal activities not elsewhere listed ..... $100.00 
(b)  Permits shall be issued upon application and review that the commercial animal establishment or activity is in compliance with all construction, zoning, and other ordinances of the city governing the conduct of business of the commercial animal establishment. No permit may be transferred or assigned. 
(c)  Any animal exhibit, circus, or rodeo may request permission to possess prohibited animals within the city limits for the duration of the commercial permit. Possession of a prohibited animal pursuant to this section shall be subject to such regulations as may be prescribed by the city public health director including, but not limited to, indemnification of the city for loss, proof of specified levels of public liability insurance, and such other conditions as may be appropriate for protecting and preserving the public safety and welfare. 
(d)  In addition to all other conditions of this section, owners and operators of stables and kennels, except kennels operated by veterinarians, where animals are boarded or grazed for a fee must maintain a register identifying all animals boarded or grazed, the name, address, and telephone number of the owner of each animal with an alternate emergency telephone number, and a written statement by the owner of each animal boarded or grazed either assuming total responsibility for the care and feeding of the animal or transferring such responsibility to the stable or kennel operator, in which case the stable or kennel operator or owner must also provide an emergency telephone number where the stable or kennel owner or operator can be reached if such person is not on the premises. 
(e)  Each commercial animal establishment, even though owned by the same person, must have a permit. Upon a change in location or ownership, a new application for a commercial permit is required. Each commercial animal establishment shall be subject to and open for inspection by an animal control officer during normal business hours. A commercial animal establishment permit shall be conspicuously displayed on the premises covered by that permit. 
(f)  A commercial animal establishment permit may be suspended or revoked by the city manager or the director of public health or their designees for: 
(1)  The refusal or failure of the permit holder to comply with any provision of this article, regulations promulgated thereunder by the director of public health, or any law or regulation governing the safety, welfare, or keeping of animals; 
(2)  Deprivation of necessary food, care, or shelter from animals; 
(3)  Cruel or inhumane confinement or treatment of animals; 
(4)  The existence of unsanitary conditions such that a danger exists for the transmission of disease to animals or to the public; or 
(5)  The existence of conditions which constitute a public nuisance or tend to create a public nuisance. 
(g)  Upon suspension of a commercial animal establishment permit, the holder shall be ordered to correct the violations as determined by the director of public health. In addition to ordering the cessation or correction of the violations, the director of; public health may provide that no animal be placed or accepted by the permit holder until such time as the permit is no longer suspended. 
(Ord. No. 2013-971-E, § 1, 8-20-2013)

Chapter 14 - AVIATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Dropping litter from aircraft, § 46-42; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Zoning around airports, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.001 et seq.; aviation, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 21.001 et seq.; municipal airports, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 22.001 et seq.; aeronautics generally, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 24.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport, owned and operated by the city as a municipal airport, including all the land at such airport which is used or intended for use for the landing and takeoff of aircraft and any appurtenant areas which are used or intended for use for airport buildings or other airport facilities or rights-of-way, together with airport buildings and facilities located thereon. 
    Field area means that area on the landing area side of the terminal building including the U.S. Quarantine Area; baggage handling section; aircraft parking area; shop, hangar, gasoline storage area; runways, taxiways, and perimeter roads; and all areas separated from roadways, sidewalks, buildings and highways by means of fencing, no trespass signs or lack of evidence of provisions of proper facilities for convenient, safe and easy entrance into and around on subject land areas or any other specific area designated by the airport manager as field area. 
    Gasoline tender means any vehicle used for transportation, handling or dispensing of gasoline and oils. 
    Mobile equipment means any non-self-propelled vehicle or device, in which property or persons may be transported. 
    Motor vehicle means all self-propelled vehicles. 
    Nonscheduled commercial air carrier means a nonscheduled commercial aircraft which is duly certificated by the Federal Aviation Administration or other authorized governmental agency, which brings in passengers or freight destined to this city or enplanes passengers or freight departing from and originating in this city. 
    Public area means that area including the various concessions; restrooms; terminal lobby section used for public passageways gathering; waiting and viewing and outside airline ticket and operating offices; kitchens, office areas; tower areas and passageways thereto; roadways and the sidewalks on the side of the terminal building away from the landing area; automobile parking lots and/or general parking areas exclusive of those areas where no admittance or no trespassing signs are visibly placed and exclusive of such areas as are designated as truck parking, taxicab parking, freight and mail loading and unloading areas, ramps and docks. 
    Scheduled trip arrival means the landing and taking off of not more than one aircraft per day for a period of one calendar month or portion thereof of a scheduled airline service which conducts regular passenger service to and from the airport in accordance with and shown on the published timetable of such carrier. 
    Transient aircraft means all aircraft which are neither scheduled commercial air carriers, nonscheduled commercial air carriers, nor aircraft belonging to the government of the United States. 
(Code 1971, § 4-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-2. - Compliance with chapter and orders. 
    All persons on any part of the property comprising the airport shall be governed by this chapter and by orders and instructions of the airport manager relative to the use or occupation of any part of the property comprising the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 4-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - Adoption of federal regulations. 
    The federal aviation regulations promulgated by the Federal Aviation Administration are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part of this chapter as though fully set forth and incorporated in this chapter. Not less than three copies of such regulations are on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(Code 1971, § 4-3) 
Sec. 14-4. - General authority of manager. 
    The airport manager shall at all times have authority to take such action as may be necessary to safeguard the public at the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 4-4) 
Sec. 14-5. - Suspension of operations; notice. 
    The airport manager may suspend or restrict any or all airport operations without regard to weather conditions whenever such action is deemed necessary in the interest of safety. Before such actions are initiated, he shall first notify all persons or organizations concerned with operations at the airport. However, such notice shall not be required in an emergency, but such notice shall be given as soon as possible after such emergency. 
(Code 1971, § 4-5) 
Sec. 14-6. - Inspections by fire marshal. 
    The fire marshal shall conduct frequent periodic inspections of the airport field area and of the public area with regard to handling and storage of all materials, equipment condition and usage in the protection of property and personnel. All recommendations subsequently issued by the fire marshal shall be complied with in full by tenants and personnel without delay. 
(Code 1971, § 4-8) 
Sec. 14-7. - Designation of portions of field area for specific purposes. 
    The airport manager shall have and is given the authority to designate one or more areas at the airport for the purpose of processing and handling aircraft, passengers, baggage and freight arriving from or departing to foreign countries. Such areas shall be plainly marked, and it shall be unlawful for any person to solicit, question or contact such aircraft, its crew or passengers before the completion of the such processing and handling by federal officers is completed and then only by permission of the airport manager. 
(Code 1971, § 4-6) 
Sec. 14-8. - International flights; compliance with regulations. 
    For aircraft landing from or departing to points outside of the United States, the pilot of such aircraft shall, immediately after landing and/or immediately before departing, advise the airport manager that all United States and Mexican federal regulations governing passage through an international port of entry have been complied with. The only exceptions to this rule shall be scheduled air carrier aircraft owned by or operating under the specific orders of a government. 
(Code 1971, § 4-7) 
Sec. 14-9. - Smoking in loading ramp area. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke any form of tobacco or other such substance in a loading ramp area. 
(Code 1971, § 4-9) 
Sec. 14-10. - Admittance to field area restricted. 
    No person, except airmen, duly authorized personnel, passengers going to or from aircraft, or other persons being personally conducted by airmen or airport attendants, shall be permitted to enter the airport field area. 
(Code 1971, § 4-10) 
Sec. 14-11. - Operation of vehicles in field area. 
(a)  Restricted. No vehicle shall be driven in the airport field area without express permission of the airport manager. It shall be the sole responsibility of the operator of such vehicle to keep the control tower informed of his whereabouts in the field area, and under no circumstances shall such vehicle be driven across runways, taxiways, loading or other ramps or the approach zone of the runway in use without visual signals from the tower. 
(b)  Registration required. No person shall operate any motor vehicle on the field area without having first registered the vehicle with the airport manager's office. 
(c)  Entrance. No vehicle may enter the field area through any gate unless specifically authorized to do so in writing by the airport manager. 
(Code 1971, §§ 4-11-4-13) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 14-12. - Repair or maintenance of motor vehicles. 
    No person shall clean or make repairs to a motor vehicle anywhere on the airport other than in a designated shop area, except those minor repairs necessary to remove such motor vehicle from the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 4-14) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 14-13. - Tampering with vehicles. 
    At the airport no person shall move or interfere or tamper with any motor vehicle or put in motion the engine or take or use any motor vehicle part, instrument or tool thereof without the permission of the owner or satisfactory evidence of the right to do so duly presented to the airport manager. 
(Code 1971, § 4-15) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 14-14. - Grounding of gasoline tenders. 
    All gasoline tenders shall be positively grounded while the tenders are being used to service aircraft. 
(Code 1971, § 4-16) 
Sec. 14-15. - Dumping of trash, refuse or garbage. 
    Dumping of trash, refuse, oil, garbage or any other material on airport property is prohibited, except as designated by the airport manager. 
(Code 1971, § 4-17) 
Sec. 14-16. - Registration of home-based aircraft. 
    Every aircraft based at the airport or flying therefrom as its home airport shall be registered with the airport manager's office by the owner of the aircraft with the same number assigned such aircraft by the Department of Commerce of the U.S. government. Any change in the ownership will require a change in the registration. 
(Code 1971, § 4-18) 
Sec. 14-17. - Landing areas restricted. 
    No person shall establish, maintain or operate any landing place for aircraft within the city or territory subject to its jurisdiction, except at the municipal airport or except upon permit issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 4-19) 
Sec. 14-18. - Report from landing aircraft required. 
(a)  The pilots of all commercial, scheduled air carriers or nonscheduled carrier aircraft shall register at the office of the airport manager located on the airport immediately after landing. If such report by the pilot to this office would constitute an extreme delay or inconvenience, such report may be made directly to the airport line service attendant. In any event, however, it is the sole responsibility of the pilot involved to see that such report is expeditiously and properly made. 
(b)  Scheduled air carriers maintaining personnel and offices on the airport are exempted from subsection (a) of this section. Scheduled air carriers maintaining personnel and offices on the airport are exempted from subsection (a) of this section, but will render promptly all such statistical and other periodic reports as may be required of them by the airport manager. 
(Code 1971, § 4-20) 
Sec. 14-19. - Aircraft parking. 
(a)  Generally. Aircraft shall not be parked at the airport except in the area and in the manner designated by the airport manager. 
(b)  Quarantine area. No aircraft shall be parked on that portion of the ramp designated and marked as "U.S. Quarantine Area" or on that portion of the ramp immediately adjacent to the terminal building, except when actually unloading passengers or cargo arriving from abroad or for customs inspection services. 
(c)  Nighttime. No aircraft shall be parked on the field area between sunset and sunrise unless specific permission is granted by the airport manager, in which case each plane shall be parked in a place designated for this purpose and securely tied down. It shall be the sole responsibility of the pilot or aircraft commander to securely tie down his aircraft; any assistance rendered by the airport personnel will be a voluntary gesture intended to accommodate the itinerant, local or other fliers, and under no circumstances should it be construed as an obligation or responsibility assumed by the airport manager. 
(Code 1971, §§ 4-21-4-23) 
Sec. 14-20. - Starting or running aircraft engine. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall start or run any engine in an aircraft unless a competent person is in the aircraft attending the engine controls. Blocks shall always be placed in front of the wheels before starting the engine unless the aircraft is provided with adequate parking brakes. 
(b)  Location. Aircraft engines shall be started or run up only in the place designated for such purposes by the airport manager. 
(c)  Proximity to buildings. At no time shall engines be turned up when hangars, shops, other buildings or persons within the observation area are in the path of the propellers' stream. Engines shall not be started in the hangars. Aircraft engines under no circumstances shall be run up within a minimum distance of 500 feet from the terminal building. 
(d)  Fueling. No aircraft shall be fueled while its engine is running. 
(Code 1971, §§ 4-24-4-26, 4-31) 
Sec. 14-21. - Taxiing speed. 
    Aircraft shall be taxied at a safe and reasonable speed at all times on the airport, but in no event should they exceed ten miles per hour when approaching or taxiing on the ramp. 
(Code 1971, § 4-27) 
Sec. 14-22. - Taxiing into or from hangars. 
    No aircraft shall be taxied into or out of hangars at the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 4-28) 
Sec. 14-23. - Local traffic and taxi patterns. 
    All pilots are requested to check the locally issued traffic and taxi patterns for the airport, copies of which have been issued to all operators. Additional copies can be procured from the chief airport traffic controller. 
(Code 1971, § 4-29) 
Sec. 14-24. - Aircraft taking off without radio. 
    Aircraft without a functioning radio taxiing out for takeoff shall stop at least 100 feet from the runway in use and, when practicable, turn into the wind to run and check the engines, after which the pilot should turn the aircraft or taxi slowly to indicate to the tower controller that he is ready for takeoff. The pilot will then await visual signals from the control tower indicting clearance for takeoff. 
(Code 1971, § 4-30) 
Sec. 14-25. - Aircraft repairs. 
    All repairs to aircraft or engines, except emergency repairs, shall be made in the space designated at the airport for this purpose and not on the area reserved for landing and taking off, unless specifically authorized to do so in writing by the airport manager. No repairs, except emergency repairs to engines, shall be made outside of the hangars. 
(Code 1971, § 4-32) 
Sec. 14-26. - Instruction of students to include chapter. 
    Instructors shall fully acquaint their students with this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 4-33) 
Sec. 14-27. - Responsibility for students. 
    Instructors at the airport shall be responsible for the conduct of their students while under their direction during dual instruction. 
(Code 1971, § 4-34) 
Sec. 14-28. - Contract required for commercial operations. 
    No person may conduct any kind of commercial operation at the airport unless he is the holder of a valid contract with the city authorizing such operation. 
(Code 1971, § 4-35) 
Sec. 14-29. - Vehicles for hire. 
(a)  Operation of buses. No carrier by motorbus for hire shall load or unload passengers at the airport at any place other than that designated by the airport manager, nor shall such conveyance operate on the airport without a contract with the city. 
(b)  Operation of taxicabs. No person shall, within the boundary of the airport, solicit or invite persons to ride in any taxicab or other vehicle used for the purpose of carrying passengers for hire in any manner whatsoever, be it either by visual signal or by the commission of other acts or by the utterance of words which are calculated to induce persons to engage such taxicab or vehicle, unless he is the holder of a contract issued by the city authorizing him to carry passengers from the airport to the city or other destinations. 
(Code 1971, §§ 4-36, 4-37) 
Cross reference- Vehicles for hire, ch. 106. 
Sec. 14-30. - Nondiscrimination, affirmative action required for lessees of facilities. 
(a)  The right to conduct aeronautical activities for furnishing services to the public at the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport is subject to lessees: 
(1)  Furnishing such services on a fair, equal, and not unjustly discriminatory basis to all users thereof; and 
(2)  Charging fair, reasonable and not unjustly discriminatory prices for each unit or service, provided that the lessees may be allowed to make reasonable and nondiscriminatory discounts, rebates, or other similar types of price reductions to volume purchasers. 
(b)  All lessees of the city at the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport of aviation or nonaviation use, land, and premises, for themselves, their personal representatives, successors in interest, and assigns, shall be subject to the following prohibitions of discrimination: 
(1)  No person, on the grounds of race, color, or national origin, shall be excluded from participation in, denied the benefits of, or otherwise subjected to discrimination in the use of such city facilities. 
(2)  In the construction of any improvements on, over, or under such land at the airport and the furnishing of services thereon, no person, on the grounds of race, age, sex, color, or national origin, shall be excluded from participation in, denied the benefits of, or otherwise subjected to discrimination. 
(3)  The lessees shall use the premises in compliance with all other requirements imposed by or pursuant to 49 CFR 21, Nondiscrimination in Federally Assisted Programs, of the Department of Transportation, and as such regulations may be amended. 
(c)  All lessees of the city at the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport of aviation use, land, and premises shall undertake affirmative action programs as required by 14 CFR 152, subpart E, to ensure that no person shall, on the grounds of race, creed, color, national origin, or sex, be excluded from participating in any employment activities covered in 14 CFR 152, subpart E. The lessees shall ensure that no person shall be excluded on these grounds from participating in or receiving the services or benefits of any program or activity covered by this subpart. The lessees shall ensure that they will require that their covered suborganizations provide assurances to the lessee that they similarly will undertake affirmative action programs and that they will require assurances from their suborganizations, as required by 14 CFR 152, subpart E, to the same effect. 
(Code 1971, § 4-38) 
Secs. 14-31-14-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 14-56. - Created; composition; terms. 
(a)  There is created and established an advisory board for the Brownsville International Airport, to be composed of at least seven members, each of whom shall be a resident citizen of the city or own property in or have business interests in the city or be the owner of an airplane based at the airport. The board shall be officially designated as the "airport advisory board." 
(b)  The members shall be appointed by the city commission and shall hold the office for staggered terms of three years or until their successors are appointed by the city commission. Terms of office shall begin on February 1. 
(Code 1971, § 4-97) 
Sec. 14-57. - Ex officio members. 
    Ex officio members shall include: 
City manager 
Brownsville South Padre Island International Airport Director of Aviation 
Mayor or city commissioner as designated by Brownsville City Commission 
City of South Padre Island as designated by city manager or city council of South Padre Island 
    Ex officio members shall have no voting privileges. 
(Code 1971, § 4-102; Ord. No. 2018-1033-A, § 1 8-21-2018) 
Sec. 14-58. - Vacancies. 
    Upon the death, resignation, removal or expiration of the term of office of any member of the airport advisory board, the city commission shall appoint a successor as a member of the advisory board, who shall hold his membership on such board for the unexpired term of the member he replaces. On February 1 of each year or as soon thereafter as possible, the city commission shall appoint new members to the advisory board to take the place of the members whose terms are then expiring. Any member of the advisory board may succeed himself on the board. 
(Code 1971, § 4-98) 
Sec. 14-59. - Compensation. 
    No salary, fees or compensation shall be paid to the members of the airport advisory board for their services thereon. 
(Code 1971, § 4-99) 
Sec. 14-60. - Officers; rules of procedure. 
(a)  When the city commission has appointed the persons to compose the membership of the airport advisory board, those persons shall meet and organize and select one of their members as chairman and one of their members as vice-chairman and may also elect a secretary and/or treasurer. The terms of office shall be for one year, and an annual election of officers shall be held on February 1 or as soon thereafter as practical. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the chairman to preside at all meetings of the airport advisory board and the vice-chairman to preside in the absence of the chairman. If both the chairman and vice-chairman are absent, a quorum of the advisory board can elect a temporary chairman for such meeting. 
(c)  At the organizational meeting, the board shall adopt rules and regulations pertaining to its meetings, organizational setup, time and place of meetings, and related matters. Records shall be kept of all proceedings, or minutes shall be delivered to the city commission as soon after each meeting as possible. 
(Code 1971, § 4-100) 
Sec. 14-61. - Meetings; subcommittees. 
(a)  The airport advisory board shall meet at least once a month or whenever necessary, on call by the chairman, to consider all matters pertaining to the business, operation, conduct, and use of the airport and/or all of its facilities and improvements. This board shall be an advisory board to the city commission. 
(b)  Any member of the board who misses three or more consecutive meetings of the board, without meritorious excuse, shall be automatically dropped from membership thereof. 
(c)  The board may appoint and establish subcommittees from or outside of its membership for specific purposes or functions pertaining to the airport and its use and operations. 
(Code 1971, § 4-101) 
Sec. 14-62. - Functions. 
    One of the specific functions of the airport advisory board is to study, prepare and present to the city commission, after advice and consultation with the director of aviation, a master plan for the operation of the airport; improvements to be made on the airport; a plan of utilization of facilities and hangar space by owners of private airplanes; rules, conditions and regulations under which such private owners shall use and operate their private facilities and the airport facilities in general, taking into consideration maximum and best use of all land areas, facilities and improvements. 
(Code 1971, § 4-104) 
Sec. 14-63. - Recommendations. 
    The airport advisory board will, on a majority vote of a quorum present at any meeting, make recommendations to the city commission concerning supervision, regulation and control of the airport, its facilities and improvements. It shall promulgate and recommend to the city commission reasonable rules and regulations for the operation of the airport and shall make such other recommendations as it sees fit. 
(Code 1971, § 4-103) 
Secs. 14-64-14-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AIRPORT ZONING BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-311 et seq.; zoning, ch. 348. 

Sec. 14-91. - Created. 
    Subject to like provision being made by the county commissioners' court by proper order, duly promulgated and entered on its minutes, and as authorized by chapter 391 of the Acts of the Regular Session of the 50th Legislature, 1947, there is hereby created a airport zoning board, to be known as the Brownsville-Cameron County Joint Airport Zoning Board. 
(Code 1971, § 4-48) 
Sec. 14-92. - Composition. 
    The airport zoning board established by this article shall be composed of five members. 
(Code 1971, § 4-49) 
Sec. 14-93. - Appointment of members. 
    Of the members of the airport zoning board created under this article, two shall be appointed by the city commission and two members shall be appointed by the county commissioners' court. The fifth member shall be elected by a majority of the members so appointed, and such fifth member shall serve as chairman of the airport zoning board. 
(Code 1971, § 4-50) 
Sec. 14-94. - Powers and duties. 
    The airport zoning board created under this article shall have the powers and exercise the duties set forth in sections 2 and 3 of chapter 391 of the Acts of the Regular Session of the 50th Legislature, 1947. 
(Code 1971, § 4-51) 
Secs. 14-95-14-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 14-121. - Contracts authorized. 
    The city, at its discretion, may enter into separate contracts with any certificated air carriers conducting scheduled airline operations at the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 4-63) 
Sec. 14-122. - Charges incorporated into contracts. 
    All fees and charges imposed by this article shall be made a part of and incorporated in all contracts in force between the city and all persons engaged in business and operating at the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 4-64) 
Sec. 14-123. - Due date for payment. 
    All charges imposed by this article shall be paid on or before the 15th day of the calendar month next succeeding that for which payment is being made. 
(Code 1971, § 4-68) 
Sec. 14-124. - Payment required, takeoff restricted. 
    No aircraft may take off or clear from the airport without having first ascertained that all charges or fees due the airport or operators at the airport have been paid. It shall be the pilot's responsibility to ensure that all charges due to the airport have been paid. The airport manager shall have the authority to restrict any flight of aircraft which has not complied with this section. 
(Code 1971, § 4-69) 
Sec. 14-125. - Landing fees. 
    Each and every person operating at or out of the airport shall pay, for each nonscheduled commercial trip arrival, the fee set out in the following schedule by payment made to the airport manager: 
Aircraft Gross 
Landing Weight 
(pounds) Fee 
Per 
Landing Less than 10,000 $ 5.00 10,000 to 20,000   7.50 20,000 to 30,000  10.00 30,000 to 50,000  15.00 50,000 to 70,000  20.00 Over 70,000  25.00  
(Code 1971, § 4-65) 
Sec. 14-126. - Parking fees. 
(a)  After the first 48 hours an aircraft remains parked upon airport property, the following parking fees shall be imposed: 
(1)  Single-engine aircraft, per day ..... $0.50 
(2)  Multiple-engine aircraft: 
a.  Gross weight of 50,000 pounds or less, per day ..... 1.00 
b.  Gross weight over 50,000 pounds, per day ..... 2.00 
(b)  The fees imposed by this section shall not be required of aircraft exempted by law or otherwise or by aircraft, owners of which have a valid contract with the city for conducting commercial aircraft operations. 
(Code 1971, § 4-66) 
Sec. 14-127. - Access to aviation fuels. 
(a)  Lease agreement required. For the right and privilege to sell, store for resale or private use, receive, deliver, furnish and otherwise transport fuels for aviation use onto airport property, a current lease agreement with the city department of aviation is required. 
(b)  Fee. A fee for the right and privilege granted to all such persons engaged in the activity as provided in subsection (a) of this section, denominated "lessees" or "operators" under the required agreement, shall pay to the city department of aviation $0.06 per gallon on the net gallonage of aviation fuels delivered each month at the airport, regardless of ultimate use. 
(c)  Credits. For gallonage delivered to scheduled tenant air carrier aircraft, the lessee or operator will be credited $0.06; for gallonage delivered to U.S. government-owned and -operated aircraft, the lessee/operator will be credited $0.04. 
(d)  Incorporation into contracts. All fees and credits set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section are made a part of and incorporated in all contracts in force between the city department of aviation and all persons engaged in such activity and operating at the airport, effective November 1, 1982. 
(Code 1971, § 4-67) 
Sec. 14-128. - Schedule of charges for scheduled aircraft. 
(a)  Each and every person operating scheduled commercial air carrier operations at or out of the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport under a valid contract with the city shall pay the fee of not less than $0.26 per 1,000 pounds, based on the aircraft's maximum gross landing weight, for each nonscheduled commercial trip arrival, as follows:

(c)  After the first 48 hours parking fees on aircraft except such aircraft exempted by law or otherwise exempted, and aircraft, owners of which have a valid contract for conducting commercial aircraft operations with the airport, shall pay the city, by payment made to the director of such airport, $0.50 per day for single-engine aircraft and $1.00 per day for multiple-engine aircraft. Multiengine aircraft with a gross weight in excess of 50,000 pounds shall pay $2.00 per day. 
(d)  All fees and credits set forth in this section are hereby made a part of and incorporated in all contracts in force between the city department of aviation active and operating at such airport effective October 1, 1983. 
(Code 1971, § 4-67.5) 
Secs. 14-129-14-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REMOVAL OF INOPERATIVE AIRCRAFT 

Sec. 14-156. - Storage of junked aircraft. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to accumulate, gather, maintain or otherwise keep any aircraft which has been wrecked, junked or is otherwise in an inoperative condition upon the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 4-81) 
Sec. 14-157. - Tampering with accident debris. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, rearrange or remove any debris resulting from any accident involving aircraft at the airport until all necessary and required investigations of such accident have been completed. 
(Code 1971, § 4-82) 
Sec. 14-158. - Order to remove. 
    Subject to any applicable federal regulations, the airport manager shall have the authority to order the removal of all wrecked or junked aircraft or the debris resulting from any accident involving aircraft, after the completion of investigations of such accident, from the airport by written notice to the person responsible for the aircraft or debris. 
(Code 1971, § 4-83) 
Sec. 14-159. - Failure to remove. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person ordered to remove any wrecked or junked aircraft or aircraft accident debris to fail to remove the aircraft or debris within the time allowed in the order of removal. 
(Code 1971, § 4-84) 
Sec. 14-160. - Removal by city. 
    If the person responsible for the removal of any wrecked or junked aircraft or aircraft accident debris shall fail to remove the aircraft or debris upon notice or order to do so, the airport manager may remove such aircraft or debris. 
(Code 1971, § 4-85) 
Sec. 14-161. - Recovery of expense. 
    If the airport manager shall remove any wrecked or junked aircraft or aircraft accident debris under this article, the city shall have a lien against the person responsible for such aircraft or debris for all expenses incurred by the airport manager in such removal. Such lien shall be second only to tax liens, and the amount thereof shall bear interest at the rate of ten percent per annum from the date of such removal. Such lien shall be enforced and collected in the same manner as all other liens. 
(Code 1971, § 4-86)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
