ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Minimum standards for off-street parking for type A parks, § 316-101; off-street parking, § 348-1381 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate standing and parking of vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-161. - No stopping, standing, or parking near hazardous or congested places. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine and designate by proper signs places not exceeding 100 feet in length in which the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized, no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1971, § 32-262) 
Sec. 98-162. - Impoundment of standing or parked vehicles. 
(a)  Any vehicle which shall be or remain standing or parked upon any public street, avenue, way, alley or other public place may be removed by or upon order of the chief of police and placed in storage in a privately operated garage or other place designated or maintained by the city, under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When any vehicle is found upon a street, avenue, alley, way, or public place and a report has been previously made that such vehicle has been stolen or a complaint has been filed and a warrant issued thereon, charging that such vehicle has been stolen or converted in violation of law. 
(2)  When any city police officer has reasonable grounds to believe that any vehicle has been abandoned. 
(3)  When a police officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and such officer is or may be required by law to take the one arrested immediately before a magistrate or if the arrested one is immediately taken before a magistrate and when the arrested one is the sole occupant or the owner of the vehicle and is immediately placed in custody. 
(4)  When a vehicle is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical and the person in charge of the vehicle is incapacitated because of physical injury or other causes to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its removal or custody or cannot be found or is not in the immediate vicinity of such vehicle. 
(5)  When such vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, or causeway or in a tunnel or tube and constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(6)  When any such vehicle is illegally parked so as to block the entrance to any private driveway and it is impracticable to move such vehicle from in front of the driveway to any other point on the highway. 
(7)  When any vehicle constitutes a hazard or interferes with the normal function of a governmental agency or because of any catastrophe, emergency, or unusual circumstance the safety of the vehicle is imperiled. 
(8)  When any vehicle is left standing or parked unattended for more than 48 hours in violation of any applicable section of this Code, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations. However, if such vehicle is parked or standing immediately in front of or immediately adjacent to property owned by the owner of such vehicle or property rented by such owner, before such vehicle shall be removed, the owner thereof shall be given written notice after the expiration of 48 hours and shall be given an additional 24 hours to remove or cause to be removed such vehicle. The written notice may be given by depositing the notice in the United States mail, addressed to the owner at the address given on the registration receipt of the vehicle or his last known address. 
(9)  When any vehicle is parked in violation of a metered parking space. 
(10)  When any vehicle lacking the display of current registration and inspection tags (when applicable) in a lawfully acceptable manner has been parked or placed upon any public street or alley. 
(b)  In order to obtain possession of a vehicle stored under this section, the claimant must produce satisfactory evidence of ownership or right to possession within 30 days from the date of such storage and, in addition thereto, must pay all charges for storage and removal of such vehicle, in addition to any fine. 
(c)  If a vehicle removed under this section is not claimed within 30 days from the date of storage, the vehicle may be sold by the city or the garage where the vehicle is stored, for storage charges, as provided by law. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on private property without express permission or authorization from the owner of such property. Any vehicle which shall be or shall remain standing or parked upon any privately owned parking area when the person in charge of or operating the vehicle does not have express permission or authorization to be so parked or standing may be removed by or upon order of the chief of police and placed in storage in a privately operated garage or other place designated or maintained by the city. It shall be the duty of the owner of the private property to erect appropriate signs giving notice that parking is prohibited without express permission or authorization and stating that unauthorized vehicles will be towed away and impounded at the expense of the owner of the vehicle. No regulation of parking of motor vehicles shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(e)  This section shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person who shall leave his vehicle parked on the city streets in such a manner that the vehicle may be impounded, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability because of impounding or causing to be impounded such vehicle. 
(Code 1971, §§ 32-264, 32-265; Ord. No. 2018-736-P, § I, 2-20-2018) 
State Law reference- Removal of illegally parked vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 545.305, 545.306. 
Sec. 98-163. - Special parking. 
(a)  The chief of police, with the approval of the city traffic engineer, may issue special permits for a definite period of time to allow parking of an unusual nature which may be contrary to or in violation of any of the sections of this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use this permit for purposes, places or times other than that clearly indicated in the written permit. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than those named in the permit to use the permit for any purpose whatsoever. 
(Code 1971, § 32-266) 
Sec. 98-164. - Angle parking. 
    Vehicles may be parked at any angle, not to exceed 45 degrees, to the curb or edge of the roadway at those places and angles where signs or markings clearly indicate that it is permissible and that no part or contents of such vehicle shall protrude into or cause a hazard with other vehicles or pedestrians in the nearest adjacent traffic lane, sidewalk or crosswalk. In no case is this to exceed 17 feet from the curb in a perpendicular direction where 30-degree parking is permitted or 19 feet from the curb in a perpendicular direction where 45-degree parking is permitted. 
(Code 1971, § 32-269) 
Sec. 98-165. - Parking in alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1971, § 32-272) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86. 
Sec. 98-166. - Residential parking restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of or operating a vehicle to allow, permit or park such vehicle habitually on that portion of the street abutting residential property when the person in charge of such vehicle does not own or occupy the residence or a portion of the lot in front of which or alongside of which such subject vehicle is parked. 
(Code 1971, § 32-273) 
Sec. 98-167. - Parking more than 72 hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to allow, cause or permit such vehicle to remain standing or parked on any street, alley, avenue or public way within the city for more than 72 hours continuously. 
(Code 1971, § 32-274) 
_____

DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 98-196. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The director of the department of traffic and transportation is charged with the enforcement of this article. Meter patrol officers of the department of traffic and transportation are empowered to issue parking violation notices in metered zones, loading zones or other prohibited parking areas as may be designated from time to time and so posted. 
(b)  Employees of the public health director and the building inspection and code enforcement departments are authorized to issue citations for violations of sections 98-165 and 98-167. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(e)) 
Sec. 98-197. - Violation. 
    Parking in a metered space by a vehicle shall be limited to the maximum time on the parking meter. It shall be a violation of this section for the owner or operator of a vehicle to allow a vehicle to remain in a metered space for a period of time in excess of the maximum time on the meter. This section shall be enforced by the traffic and transportation department, motor vehicle parking system. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(g)) 
Sec. 98-198. - Fee for overparking in metered spaces. 
(a)  The fee for parking in a metered space or stall with the meter indicating no time left (expired) shall be $5.00 if paid within ten days and $10.00 if paid after ten days and before 30 days. Tickets unpaid after 30 days shall subject the owner or operator of the vehicle to payment of $35.00 for each violation and court costs, plus an administration fee of $50.00 each for second and third notices if the fine is not paid prior to these notices being sent. 
(b)  Notice occurs when the department of traffic advises a person by mail that a parking ticket was issued to a vehicle currently registered under that person's name and that the ticket remains unpaid 30 days after its initial issuance. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(f); Ord. No. 92-847-C, § 1, 4-7-1992; Ord. No. 2001-847-D, § 1, 11-20-2001) 
Sec. 98-199. - Collection. 
    The director of the department of traffic and transportation shall process parking violation notices, for the municipal court, for the collection of fees or fines as stipulated in section 98-198 or as may be levied by the judge of the municipal court. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(h)) 
Sec. 98-200. - Collector's bond. 
    Each person designated to collect coins from parking meters and deliver the coins to the director shall, if directed by the city manager, execute a fiduciary bond in the amount of $5,000.00, payable to the city, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties in collecting and delivering all moneys. Such bond shall be executed by a corporate surety which has been duly authorized under state law to execute such bonds. The premium for such bond shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(j)) 
Secs. 98-201-98-225. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Illegal Parking at Metered Spaces 

Sec. 98-226. - Presumption. 
    In any notice requirement or prosecution for an illegally parked car at a metered space, proof that the driver of the particular vehicle described in the parking citation or complaint was either, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle or the person to whom the license plates were issued or the person who had possession or control of the vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that such person was the driver of the vehicle at the point where and for the time during which such violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.1), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-227. - Evidence. 
    For the purposes of this subdivision, the state department of highways and public transportation's computer-generated record of the registered vehicle owner is prima facie evidence of its contents. The original or any copy of the summons or citation is also prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.2), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-228. - Citation on illegally parked vehicles in metered spaces. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle is found parked illegally in any metered parking space, any police officer or traffic enforcement officer finding such vehicle shall take its license plate number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously attach to such vehicle a citation in writing, on a form to be provided by the police department or the director of traffic, for the driver to answer to the charge against him within ten days within the hours and at a place specified in the citation. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.3), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-229. - Failure to comply with citation; penalties and mailings. 
(a)  If, for the third time within any six-month period, a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing or parking at a metered space under the terms of this subdivision has not appeared in response to three notices affixed to such vehicle within the required period of ten days each, the director of traffic, as designee of the municipal court clerk, shall at any time thereafter send to the registered owner (the presumed driver) of the motor vehicle to which the third citation was affixed the first and only mailed notice to inform him of this third violation within a six-month period and the requirement for the violator to pay the fines or fees at the department of traffic. The notice shall include a notice to the violator that failure to do so within ten days thereafter causes the director of traffic to have these three violations to be presented to a municipal court judge at a hearing (noting the date certain at which time the hearing will be held) at which time director of traffic shall ask the court to declare the vehicle a nuisance. When so declared as a nuisance the vehicle will become subject to booting and shall be booted instanter without further notice if found. This notice shall be in English and Spanish. 
(b)  Procedures for penalties and mailings are as follow: 
(1)  Specifically section 98-198 pertaining to the fee for overparking in metered spaces is repealed, and each fee for overparking in a metered space or stall with the meter indicating no time left shall be $5.00; if unpaid after ten days the fee shall be $10.00. 
(2)  In addition to each fee of $10.00, there is assessed one mailing penalty for not paying two or more overparking fees within each prescribed 20-day period. This penalty shall be $35.00, and this shall be the total owed only if the violator presents himself at the department of traffic before any municipal court hearing to declare the vehicle a nuisance. 
(3)  Upon a presentation by the department of traffic to the municipal court judge to declare a vehicle a nuisance, the judge may require an additional court cost up to $100.00 upon the appearance of the violator. If there is no appearance, there may be an additional mailing fee of $25.00 but only if the judge orders a second mailing by registered mail, return receipt requested. 
(4)  Once the vehicle has been declared a nuisance and is booted and/or impounded, the judge shall also have the discretion to assess additional fines up to $50.00 each on those unpaid parking citations in excess of the first three. 
(5)  The data processing department shall send out no more than one regular mailing concerning any one vehicle with the same license plate, as long as the license plate continues to be traced back to the same registered owner. The traffic department shall send out no more than one registered letter, return receipt requested, concerning any one vehicle with the same license plate, and then only if so ordered by a judge which has declared such vehicle a nuisance. 
(6)  Such immobilization by booting shall be in addition to any other penalty provided by this Code, and a fee up to $50.00 for such may be set by the judge for the booting alone, irrespective of other fees. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to tamper with or try to force the device (boot) from the wheel of a vehicle, to remove the booted wheel from a vehicle, to move the booted vehicle, or to disable or damage the booting device. 
(8)  No additional fees may be imposed by the judge if actual impoundment of the vehicle is required except the actual costs of impoundment and storage. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.4), 6-9-1992; Ord. No. 97-1256-A, § 1, 9-16-1997) 
Sec. 98-230. - Nuisance. 
    A vehicle that has received three or more citations, unresolved, pursuant to this subdivision within any six-month period is declared a nuisance. An unresolved parking citation occurs when a citation is issued under section 98-228 and the driver does not respond within ten days as required in such section. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.5), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-231. - Procedure for impoundment or booting of vehicles declared nuisance. 
(a)  After ascertaining that a vehicle has three or more citations unresolved pursuant to this subdivision, within any six-month period, the director of traffic, after the requisite notice required by this subdivision, shall appear before the municipal court for authorization to impound or immobilize by booting such vehicle, it being declared a nuisance. 
(b)  At that time, if evidence shall be presented as to the number of unresolved parking citations and that all notice requirements have been met, the judge may declare the vehicle a nuisance solely on the basis of this evidence and that the vehicle shall be immobilized by booting or impoundment instanter, if such vehicle is found to be standing or parked unlawfully or in or upon any regularly designated parking metered space. In addition the judge has the discretion to order, when possible or practical, such as if a license plate check in the United States can identify the driver and his address, the person appearing to attempt to notify the driver by mailing a certified notice, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the driver as shown by the license plate check, informing such driver/owner that the vehicle has been declared a nuisance and has been ordered by the court to be immobilized instanter by booting or impoundment, if the vehicle is found to be standing or parked unlawfully or in or upon any regularly designated parking metered space. The mailing, if ordered, and the failure to receive this letter is in no way a prerequisite to any vehicle being impounded or booted; however, the judge may also order the traffic department to withhold enforcing its order for a period not to exceed ten days after the date mailed. If the vehicle is immobilized by impoundment or booting, it shall remain at or be taken to a place of immobilization and there kept until application for its redemption shall be made by the owner or his duly authorized agent. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.6), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-232. - Right to redeem immobilized vehicle. 
    When a vehicle is to be immobilized under this subdivision, appendix A attached to Ordinance No. 92-1256 includes a sample of a procedure that may be used as a guideline for the department of traffic to adopt as its procedures. Nothing in the sample shall prohibit the traffic department from adopting a different or similar procedure, with the concurrence of other city departments that are involved, and finally approved by the judge. Until another is adopted, the sample shall constitute the temporary procedure until a different one is adopted. Readoption of a new procedure under this section shall not require an amendment of this section as the sample is strictly advisory. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.7), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-233. - Right to redeem impounded vehicle. 
    When a vehicle is impounded under section 98-162, at any time prior to its sale as an abandoned vehicle, the owner or his duly authorized agent shall be entitled to the possession thereof upon the payment of all the costs of removal and storage that may have accrued thereon, plus any fines or costs owed to the city for parking violations, unless the owner/driver posts a bond under the requirements of section 98-236. If the owner or authorized agent posts a bond, the vehicle shall be released. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.8), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-234. - Notice of violation. 
    After the vehicle has been impounded under section 98-231 and if no owner or driver appears, a notice shall be prepared and sent certified mail by the municipal court to the owner within 48 hours of the impounding of the vehicle, if the address can be ascertained as shown by a United States license number check. If the automobile license check is that of a foreign country, the notice shall be published twice within a 30 day period in the Brownsville Herald. The notice shall specify the procedures for redeeming an impounded vehicle, including the name, address and telephone number of the person to be contacted; the bonding procedure; and the right to a hearing. If no owner/driver comes forward to claim the vehicle after all the notices required by this subdivision, the vehicle shall be treated as an abandoned vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.9), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-235. - Hearing on impounded immobilized vehicle. 
    After the impounding/immobilization of a vehicle, the owner/driver shall have the right to a hearing before a municipal court judge to contest the circumstances surrounding the impounding/immobilization of the vehicle or to present any other defense he might have to the actions taken. An expedited hearing shall be held within 48 hours of the impounding or immobilization or the next municipal court working day after the impounding, whichever is the greater time, if the owner requests such an expedited hearing in writing and if there is an agreement between the owner/driver and the city attorney on evidentiary procedures. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.10), 6-9-1992) 
Sec. 98-236. - Bond for impounded vehicle. 
    The owner or driver of a vehicle which is impounded pursuant to this subdivision may secure release of the vehicle pending the hearing by making an appearance on the unresolved citations and posting a bond in the amount of the fines, court costs, administrative fees, towing fees and storage fees owed. If the municipal court is closed so that the owner or driver cannot make an appearance, the owner/driver may post the bond and obtain release of the vehicle without an appearance. If the owner/driver cannot afford the bond for his vehicle, he shall be allowed a hearing within 24 hours of his request for a hearing or the next municipal court working day after his request, whichever is the greater time, if there is an agreement between the owner/violator and the city attorney on evidentiary procedures. At this hearing, if the owner/driver is found not guilty of the traffic offenses or the court otherwise finds that the vehicle should not be impounded, the court shall order the vehicle released without the payment of any costs or fees. If the owner/driver posts a bond and fails to appear timely at any hearing scheduled to contest the impounding of the vehicle or the underlying traffic violation, the bond shall be forfeited and all fines deemed paid. 
(Ord. No. 92-1256, § 1(32-264a.11), 6-9-1992) 
Secs. 98-237-98-265. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FUND 

Sec. 98-266. - Established. 
    There is established the city motor vehicle parking system fund. Such fund shall be maintained in a separate bank account from all other city funds. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(a)) 
Sec. 98-267. - Deposits. 
    All revenue from the city's parking meters, all revenue derived as a result of issuing meter tickets, all rental of on-street or off-street parking spaces, all interest received from investment of such revenue, and all other incidental revenue derived from operation of the parking system shall be deposited in such account and credited to the motor vehicle parking system fund. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(b)) 
Sec. 98-268. - Authorized expenditures. 
    Expenditures from the motor vehicle parking system fund shall be limited to motor vehicle parking system purposes, including but not limited to expenditures for meter and parking lot operation and maintenance; meter replacement; acquisition by rental, lease or purchase of property to be utilized for parking purposes; construction of parking facilities; and issuance and enforcement of parking meter tickets. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(c)) 
Sec. 98-269. - Disposition of money collected. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of traffic and transportation, with the approval of the city manager, to designate some member of his department to make regular collections of the money deposited in parking meters. In this connection, it shall be the duty of such person so designated to pick up the coins as deposited in the meters and deliver the coins to the director as soon as possible after removal from the meter. It shall be the duty of the director to count the funds and deposit them to the credit of the city in a special fund called Parking Meter Fund, which fund shall be disbursed on order of the city commission. The duties prescribed to the officer under the terms of this section shall be in addition to his regular duties. 
(Code 1971, § 32-275(i)) 
Secs. 98-270-98-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RESTRICTED OR PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS[8]

Sec. 98-296. - Applicability. 
    The sections prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times specified or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1971, § 32-280) 
Sec. 98-297. - Scope. 
    The sections imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive sections prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1971, § 32-281) 
Sec. 98-298. - Parking prohibited on certain streets generally. 
    When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets described by the director of the department of traffic. 
(Code 1971, § 32-282) 
Sec. 98-299. - Parking prohibited on specific streets.

Sec. 98-300. - Parking at United States Post Office Courthouse and city hall. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any vehicle to park or leave the vehicle unattended in the alley situated between Southeast Elizabeth Street and Southeast Washington Street, where it abuts the federally owned property of the United States Post Office Courthouse. 
(b)  Except as provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person in charge of a vehicle to park the vehicle on the southeast side of Southeast 10th Street in the city, from Southeast Elizabeth Street to the alley situated between Southeast Elizabeth Street and Southeast Washington Street, and one parking space on the north side of such alley. 
(c)  Parking on the southeast side of Southeast 10th Street defined in subsection (b) of this section is permitted and restricted to the United States of America, to be used for transportation of prisoners to the United States district court and other federal purposes. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any vehicle to park or leave the vehicle unattended between North Market Square and South Market Square, where it abuts the city hall, except city bus system vehicles. 
(Code 1971, § 32-283.3) 
Sec. 98-301. - Parking time limited on certain streets. 
    Whenever and wherever the congestion of traffic, the frequency of passage of vehicles or pedestrians or both, the direction of the flow of traffic, the dimensions of the streets are such that the director of the department of traffic finds it to be necessary for the free flow and the expeditious handling of traffic and the safety of person and property, such director is authorized to determine and allocate parking time limits between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on any day except Sundays and public holidays designated by the city commission within that portion of the city zoned other than residential and not within a meter zone. 
(Code 1971, § 32-283.4) 
Sec. 98-302. - Parking signs required. 
    Whenever by this division or any city ordinance any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets, it shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1971, §§ 32-283.5, 32-286) 
Secs. 98-303-98-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LOADING AND UNLOADING 

Sec. 98-331. - Designation of curb loading zones. 
    The director, department of traffic and transportation, subject to the approval of the city commission, is authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the zones. 
(Code 1971, § 32-292) 
Sec. 98-332. - Designation of public carrier stops and stands. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized and required to establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus stop, bus stand, taxicab stand, or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(Code 1971, § 32-296) 
Sec. 98-333. - Stopping, standing and parking of buses and taxicabs. 
(a)  The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than a bus stand so designated as provided in this division. 
(b)  The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage other than at a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone so designated as provided in this division, except in an emergency. 
(c)  The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage, shall be in a position with the right front wheel of such vehicle not further than 18 inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(d)  The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than in a taxicab stand so designated as provided in this section. This subsection shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Code 1971, § 32-297) 
Sec. 98-334. - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
    No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle, other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed. However, the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1971, § 32-298) 
Sec. 98-335. - Use of loading zones for loading and unloading. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any operator to stand or park a vehicle in a loading zone for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers for a period in excess of five minutes for passenger vehicles or 30 minutes for commercial vehicles. 
(b)  The use of loading zones for the loading and unloading of merchandise, etc., shall be for handling of heavy or bulky merchandise, supplies and materials. All such loading and unloading must be performed in an expeditious manner. No vehicle may remain in a loading zone either for a period of time longer than necessary to expeditiously load or unload the vehicle or while the operator thereof is soliciting or engaged otherwise than the loading and unloading of the vehicle. However, a reasonable time shall be allowed for giving or securing a delivery receipt. 
(Code 1971, §§ 32-293, 32-294, 32-316) 
Secs. 98-336-98-360. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PARKING METERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, adopted May 6, 2014, repealed the former Div. 6, §§ 98-361-98-381, and enacted a new Div. 6, §§ 98-361-98-383 as set out herein. The former Div. 6 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1971, § 32-301-32-315, 32-317-32-322; Ord. No. 736-L-90(A), § 1-3, 7-10-1990; Ord. No. 736-K-90, § 1, 12-11-1990; Ord. No. 95-736-N, § 1, 11-21-1995; Ord. No. 2012-736-N, § 1, 4-17-2012. 

Sec. 98-361. - Applicability. 
    This division applies on all days between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday, except as to the following: 
(1)  Use of a loading zone, as provided in section 98-376; 
(2)  Use of parking spaces for loading and unloading as provided in section 98-376; 
(3)  Parking over length vehicles and vehicles with trailers attached thereto, as provided in section 98-377; 
(4)  Parking of vehicles adjacent to the post office. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-362. - Standard of time. 
    All hours of time mentioned in this division refer to and shall be determined by Central Standard Time, as commonly known, except when another standard of time is established or proclaimed by law for an area, including the city, in which case all such hours shall be determined by such officially established or proclaimed standard, so long as the standard remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-363. - Designation of parking meter spaces and loading zones. 
(a)  In any parking meter zone authorized under this division, the director of the department of traffic and transportation is authorized to create parking spaces and loading zones to be designated and maintained in and on parking meter zones. The city commission may authorize from time to time in accordance with this division. 
(b)  All spaces for parking vehicles shall be laid out at an angle of approximately 60 degrees to the curb or parallel to the curb, for diagonal or parallel parking, respectively, and shall be designated by lines marked by paint or ceramic buttons on the surface of the street and shall be laid out that there shall be one parking space for and at or near each installed parking meter. 
(c)  Loading zones for handling of passengers and heavy bulky merchandise, supplies and materials shall be laid out and designated by yellow colored lines by paint or marked with ceramic buttons on the surface of the street and/or curb. No parking meter shall be installed in or adjacent to a loading zone. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-364. - Lengths of time and rates charged for parking. 
    The following lengths of time for parking a vehicle in a metered space and the amounts of money charged for such length, respectively, for using parking spaces are established as follows: 
    Sixty minutes (one hour) for $0.50 for any and all areas delineated in section 98-366 which states all areas where a parking meter is located designating a parking meter space. All further increases will be at the discretion of the city commission. 
(1)  Employees and/or owners parking shall be designated separate from their customer parking. Employees and/or owners will have access to city parking lots location on St. Charles, Adams St. and Jefferson St. as described by Exhibit "A". 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-365. - Deposit of legal tender. 
(a)  When any vehicle shall be parked in any place alongside or next to a parking meter, the operator of the vehicle shall, upon entering the marked parking space, immediately deposit in the designated area. 
(b)  The only form of legal tender accepted by parking meters are quarters and dimes. 
(c)  If the vehicle shall remain parked in any parking space beyond the parking time limit for which such deposited legal tender, the parking meter shall display a sign or signal showing illegal parking. Such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the period of time fixed by this division. Such parking of a vehicle shall be a violation of this division, punishable as provided in section 98-375. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-366. - Parking meter zones established. 
    The following described parts of streets and other property in the city are established as parking meter zones:

(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-367. - Installation, operation, and maintenance of parking meters. 
(a)  The director of the department of traffic and the city manager are authorized to install, operate, and maintain parking meters at their discretion. The installation and maintenance of meters may be authorized by the director from time to time, and the director shall provide for the regulation, control, operation and maintenance of such parking meters in full workable condition. 
(b)  Parking meters shall be placed upon the curb, alongside, or next to each of the parking spaces designated. Each meter shall display a signal showing whether the parking space is legally in use and the time purchased. Parking meters shall also indicate when time has expired. 
(c)  The traffic director may establish parking meters along public street right-of-way and on parking lots owned and controlled by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-368. - Report of violations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the meter patrol officers or the police officers to report the following: 
(1)  The number of each parking meter which indicates that the vehicle occupying the parking space is or has been parked in violation of any of the sections of this division. 
(2)  The name of the state and number of the license plate, if any, attached to such vehicle. 
(3)  The length of time during which such vehicle is parked in violation of any of the sections of this division and to the extent the meter shows the time of over parking. 
(4)  Any other fact or knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(b)  Each officer shall attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner that such vehicle has been parked in violation of this division and instructing the owner to report to the municipal court to arrange a court hearing or make payment of the fine indicated on the parking violation notice. Notices shall become delinquent after 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-369. - Overtime parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator of a vehicle in their possession or control to remain in any parking space while the meter is displaying a signal that vehicle has been parked beyond the period of time paid for. Each half-hour period that a vehicle remains standing at a parking meter showing an expired signal shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-370. - Evidence of illegal parking. 
    The display of an expired meter shall be prima facie evidence that the vehicle has been parked overtime. The person in whose name a vehicle unlawfully parked is registered shall be presumed to be the operator of such vehicle at the time the vehicle was illegally parked, but he/she shall have the right to overcome such presumption by lawful evidence in any proceeding involving such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-371. - Parking in no parking zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator in charge or control of any vehicle to park the vehicle in any no parking zone. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-372. - Parking other than wholly within lines or marks on street surface. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense to park any vehicle across lines designating parking spots 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-373. - Defacing or destruction of meters. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under this division. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-374. - Deposit of fraudulent legal tender. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to deposit in any parking meter any fraudulent legal tender, device or substitute for the lawful legal tender of the United States required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-375. - Fines. 
    In any notice requirement or prosecution for an illegally parked car at a metered space, proof that the driver of the particular vehicle described in the parking citation or compliant was wither, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle or the person to which the license plates were issued or the person who had possession or control of the vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that such person was the driver of the vehicle at the point where and for the time during which such violation occurred. 
(1)  Evidence. For the purposes of this subdivision, the state department of highways and public transportation's computer-generated record of the registered vehicle owner is prima facie evidence of its contents. The original or any copy of the summons or citation is also prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein. 
(2)  Citations. Whenever any motor vehicle is found parked illegally in any metered parking space, any police officer or traffic enforcement officer finding such vehicle citation in writing, on a form to be provided by the police department or the director of traffic, for the driver to answer to the charge against him/her within ten days within the hours and at a place specified in the citation. 
(3)  Failure to comply. If, for the third time within any six month period, a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing or parking at a metered space under the terms of this subdivision has not appeared in response to three notices affixed to such vehicle within the required period of ten days each, the director of traffic, as designee of the municipal court clerk, shall at any time thereafter send to the registered owner (the presumed driver) of the motor vehicle to which the third citation was affixed the first and only mailed notice to inform him of this third violation within a six month period and the requirement for the violator to pay the fines or fees at the department of traffic. The notice shall include a notice to the violator that failure to do so within ten days thereafter causes the director of traffic to have these three violations to be presented to a municipal court judge at a hearing (noting the date certain at which time the hearing will be held) at which time director of traffic shall ask the court to declare the vehicle a nuisance. When so declared as a nuisance the vehicle will become subject to booting and shall be booted instantly without further notice if found. This notice shall be in English and Spanish. 
a.  Effective after passage of the ordinance from which this division derives, the fine for parking in a metered space, or stall, with an expired meter, shall be $5.00, if paid after ten days the fine shall increase to $10.00 and vehicle will be subject to booting. If vehicle receives three or more parking violations and each of those violations is not paid within ten days then an additional penalty of $35.00 will be added. 
b.  Ten days after receipt of final notice letter and if no response is received the vehicle will automatically be declared a nuisance and be subject to additional court costs of up to $100.00. Levying of additional penalties shall be at the discretion of the presiding Municipal Court Judge. 
c.  The data processing department shall send out no more than one regular mailing concerning any one vehicle with the same license plate, as long as the license plate continues to be traced back to the same registered owner. 
d.  If booting occurs the fee for that violation shall $50.00 dollars in addition to any outstanding fines and court costs. If boot is installed and fines are not settled then the vehicle will be subject to impoundment by Brownsville police department. Upon impoundment all fines must be settled with the municipal court before vehicle can be released. Boots may only be removed after outstanding fines are settled and the judge orders that the boot be removed. 
e.  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to tamper with or try to force the device (boot) from the wheel of a vehicle, to remove the booted wheel from a vehicle, or to disable or damage the booting device. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-376. - Use of parking spaces for loading and unloading. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any operator of a vehicle to stop or park the vehicle in a parking space for the purpose of loading and/or unloading of merchandise, supplies and materials, except where the place of business where such merchandise, etc., is to be loaded or unloaded does not have either: 
(1)  A usable entrance from an adjoining alley; or 
(2)  An officially designated loading zone on that part of the street adjacent to such place of business the operator of a vehicle may without making deposit in meter or meters, use not to exceed two parking spaces for loading, unloading, construction as such items named above, and give or secure delivery receipt therefore. 
(b)  Where there is neither a usable entrance to a place of business from an alley nor any officially designated loading zone on that part of the street adjacent to a place of business, the operator of a vehicle use two parking spaces without depositing legal tender. However, it shall be unlawful for any operator to use more than two parking spaces for such loading or unloading or for a longer time than necessary to expeditiously load or unload such merchandise, etc., and give or secure a delivery receipt therefore. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-377. - Vending in meter zone prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in a parking meter zone for the purpose of selling or displaying for sale goods or merchandise of any character. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 98-378. - Length of trailered vehicles restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator in charge or control of any vehicle which has an overall length of 19 feet or more or of any vehicle having a trailer attached thereto to park the vehicle in any parking meter space. However, this section shall not prohibit the parking of a motor truck for the purpose of loading or unloading, which is expressly permitted under section 98-375. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, adopted May 6, 2014, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 98-377-98-382. In as much as there were already provisions so designated, Ord. No. 2014-736-O have been codified herein as §§ 98-378-98-383. 
Sec. 98-379. - Special parking. 
    The chief of police or director of the department of traffic and transportation may issue special permits for a definite period of time to allow parking of an unusual nature which may be contrary to or in violation of any of the sections of this division. City parking lot permits can be found under section 98-383 for further information. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Note- See editor's note to § 98-378. 
Sec. 98-380. - Exempt parking. 
    The following individuals or agencies are excused from the payment of parking meter fees while in the conduct of official duties or business for the city: 
(1)  The mayor and members of the city commission. 
(2)  Official vehicles of the United States government, the state, the county and the city. 
(3)  Unmarked police vehicles. 
(4)  Public utilities board vehicles, only when they are working in the downtown area. 
(5)  Board members appointed by the city commission. 
(6)  Consul and vice-consul of Mexico. 
(7)  Private vehicles in use or official business for the city, i.e., state comptroller, county tax appraiser. 
(8)  Disabled veteran vehicles displaying a license plate issued by the state identifying disabled status. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Note- See editor's note to § 98-378. 
Sec. 98-381. - Ticket excusal. 
    The director of the department of traffic and city manager are authorized to excuse parking violations when any of the following circumstances exist: 
(1)  The public interest is being served. 
(2)  A ticket issued was the result of a malfunctioning parking meter. 
(3)  A bona fide emergency condition existed. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Note- See editor's note to § 98-378. 
Sec. 98-382. - Downtown parking permits. 
    The city's traffic department will issue parking permits for $60.00 monthly fee for downtown business owners and renters. The permit will only be valid in city lots demonstrated in Exhibit "B." Conditions for city lot parking permits are: 
(1)  Each business owner or renter may apply for a maximum of three permits. 
(2)  Business owners and renters must show proof of ownership or lease. 
(3)  Spaces may not be used for commercial use or subleased. 
(4)  Unutilized spaces may be revoked by discretion of traffic director or city manager. 
(5)  No soliciting in city parking lots. 
If found in violation of any conditions the permit holder may be declined a parking permit or could be subject to loss of contract. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Note- See editor's note to § 98-378. 
Sec. 98-383. - Motor vehicle parking fund. 
(1)  Established. The City of Brownsville hereby establishes the motor vehicle parking system fund. Said fund shall be maintained in a separate bank account from all other city funds. Revenue derived from meters and spent for traffic department shall be capped at $325,000.00. Additional revenue above that cap will be deposited and restricted in a fashion that downtown improvement projects will receive the priority above any other projects. 
(2)  Deposits. All revenue from the city's parking meters derived as a result of issuing tickets, non-moving violation, rental of or an off-street parking spaces, interest received from investment of said revenue, and all other incidental revenue derived from operation of the system up to an agreed-upon defined bound shall be deposited in said fund and credited to the motor vehicle parking system fund. Revenue in excess of $320,000.00 from parking meters not including fines shall be restricted. 
(3)  Authorized expenditures. 
a.  Expenditures from the vehicle parking fund shall be limited to motor vehicle parking system purposes, including, but not limited to, expenditures for meter and parking lot operation and maintenance, meter replacement, acquisition by rental, lease or purchase of a property to be utilized for parking purposes, construction of parking facilities and issuance and enforcement of parking meter tickets. 
b.  Expenditures above $325,000.00 will be prioritized for downtown improvement projects but shall be limited to the downtown central business district as defined by the following boundary lines: South 6th St., Monroe St., and St. Charles. City planning department will create a committee of downtown stakeholders to identify projects that will contribute to further downtown revitalization. All expenditures that are not downtown related must be approved by city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2014-736-O, pt. 1, 5-6-2014) 
Note- See editor's note to § 98-378. 
Secs. 98-384-98-410. - Reserved.

Secs. 98-415-98-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TRUCK ROUTES 

Sec. 98-441. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial motor vehicle means any motor vehicle, other than a motorcycle, designed or used for the transportation of property, including every vehicle used for delivery purposes. 
    Deviating truck means a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling inside the city. 
    Motor vehicle means a vehicle, as defined in this section, which is self-propelled, except city-owned buses. 
    Semitrailer means every vehicle of the trailer type so designed or used in conjunction with a motor vehicle that some part of its own load rests upon or is carried by another motor vehicle. 
    Trailer means every vehicle without motive power designed or used for carrying property or passengers wholly on its own structure and to be drawn by a motor vehicle. 
    Truck means any and all truck tractors, van trailers, semitrailers, house trailers, and/or any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, whose body weight or whose rated or licensed combined body load weight exceeds 17,000 pounds (81/2 tons), except city-owned buses. 
    Truck route means a way over certain streets, as designated in this article, over and along which trucks coming into and going out of the city must operate. 
    Truck tractor means every motor vehicle designed or used primarily for drawing other vehicles, and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
    Vehicle means every mechanical device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, including motor vehicles, commercial motor vehicles, truck tractors, trailers, and semitrailers severally, as defined in this section, but excepting devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1971, § 32-237) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-442. - Applicability. 
    No trucks within the city shall be operated on streets which are not truck routes as established in this article or shall be operated on streets within the city which have signs posted by the director of traffic which prohibit truck travel thereon. 
(Code 1971, § 32-238) 
Sec. 98-443. - Authority to designate. 
    The chief of police and the director of the department of traffic are authorized to determine and designate truck routes in the city and to determine the route trucks shall take in passing through the city. They shall cause to be erected signs at every such place where a sign is required. 
Sec. 98-444. - Maps. 
    The city secretary shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted. The maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city secretary and shall be available to the public. 
(Code 1971, § 32-245) 
Sec. 98-445. - Posting of signs. 
    The chief of police shall cause all truck routes to be clearly signposted to give notice of this article. All city streets shall be designated as nontruck routes unless otherwise posted. 
(Code 1971, § 32-246) 
Sec. 98-446. - Streets not posted with signs. 
    No person shall be charged with violating this article because of operating a truck upon a street wherein truck travel is prohibited, unless appropriate signs are posted on such street for truck routes as per section 98-445. Nontruck routes are designated, but should not have to be signed for enforcement. 
(Code 1971, § 32-247)
