ARTICLE XI. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL AND BACK FLOW PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 102-700. - General. 
(a)  No water service connection shall be made, or allowed to continue, to any establishment where a potential or actual contamination hazard exists unless the water supply is protected in accordance with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (the "TCEQ") Rules and Regulations for Public Water Systems found in the Texas Administrative Code, Title 30, Part 1, Chapter 290, Subchapter D, §§ 290.38-290.47, as those rules may be amended or superseded from time to time (the "290 Rules") and this article. A retail public utility, as defined in section 102-701 below, providing water service within the corporate limits or extraterritorial limits of the City of Brownsville shall discontinue water service to a customer if a required backflow prevention assembly is not installed, maintained and tested in accordance with this article, the 290 Rules, and the then-current cross connection control and backflow prevention program adopted by the retail public utility. 
(b)  This section shall apply within the corporate limits and the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the City of Brownsville and shall apply to every retail water customer of the retail public utility regardless of the location of the service address. 
(c)  A retail public utility providing water service within the corporate limits or extraterritorial jurisdiction of the City of Brownsville shall adopt and enforce a cross connection control and backflow prevention program in accordance with the 290 Rules, TCEQ Regulatory Guidance 478, and this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-701. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    290 Rules -The rules and regulations for public water systems are established by the TCEQ in Title 30 Texas Administrative Code (30 TAC), Chapter 290, as those rules may be amended or superseded from time to time by the TCEQ. The rules found in 30 TAC Chapter 290, Subchapter D, specify water treatment plant design, operation, and maintenance requirements for public water systems. 
    Auxiliary water supply -Auxiliary water supply means, when applied to premises, any water supply on or available to the premises other than the primary potable water supply for the premises, ex. rain water reclaim, well water, Resaca water, or other water of unknown quality used. 
    Backflow -The reversal of the flow of water or mixtures of water and other liquids, gases, or other substances into the distribution pipes of a public water system. 
    Chief executive officer means the chief executive officer or the general manager of the retail public utility subject to this article, including designated departments and employees of the retail public utility. 
    Customer -The person, organization or corporation responsible for payment for all electric, water or wastewater services used at a specific location and further defined as that person, organization or corporation who signed the application requesting that electric, water and/or wastewater services be made available at the specific location and thereby agreeing to pay for all usage of such services occurring at said location. 
    Cross connection -Is an actual or potential connection between a potable water supply and any non-potable substance or source. 
    Private water supply -A water supply on or available to the premises other than the potable water retailer water supply. These auxiliary waters may include water from another purveyor's public water supply or natural source such as a well, river, Resaca, canal, ponds, etc. 
    Public water system -A system for the provision of water to the public as defined in Title 30 of the Texas Administrative Code, § 290.38. 
    Retail public utility means any person, corporation, public utility, water supply corporation, municipality, political subdivision or agency operating, maintaining, or controlling facilities for providing potable water service for compensation within the corporate limits or extraterritorial jurisdiction of the City of Brownsville, as the terms "facilities" and "service" are defined by V.T.C.A., Water Code, § 13.002. Retail public utility includes, but is not limited to the Brownsville Public Utility Board, Military Highway Water Supply Corporation, El Jardin Water Supply Corporation, and Olmito Water Supply Corporation. 
    TCEQ means the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality or successor agency. 
    Thermal expansion means the hazardous condition described and regulated by section 102-704, below. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-702. - Backflow prevention assembly installation, testing, and maintenance. 
(a)  A person shall not have an unprotected cross connection, plumbing fixture, equipment, or any other device that allows backflow, or fail to install a backflow prevention device that is required by this article. If a backflow prevention device is required by this article, or any other ordinance, or a retail public utility's service policies, then the water customer shall cause a backflow prevention device to be installed in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(1)  Each water customer is responsible for the maintenance and repair of each backflow prevention device that is located on the property. 
(2)  Each water customer shall have each backflow prevention device located on their property inspected and tested in accordance with this article, or the retail public utility's cross connection control and back flow prevention program, whichever is stricter. The person performing the inspection and test shall be licensed by the TCEQ as a backflow assembly tester. The licensed tester performing the inspection and testing shall complete a report of each inspection and testing on a form approved by the retail public utility that provides water to the property where the backflow prevention device is located. 
(3)  Each water customer shall cause a TCEQ licensed backflow assembly tester to repair a backflow prevention device that fails a test before returning the backflow prevention device to service. If the backflow assembly tester identifies that the device requires replacement, the replacement shall be performed by a service provider registered with the retail public utility and qualified under this article to perform the work as follows: 
a.  Landscape irrigators can install, replace or repair devices only on residential and commercial lawn sprinkler systems; 
b.  Master plumbers can install, replace and repair devices on domestic residential and commercial plumbing lines and residential and commercial lawn sprinkler systems; 
c.  Fire line contractors can install, replace, and repair devices on fire systems; and 
d.  Individuals licensed by the TCEQ as a backflow assembly tester who are not a landscape irrigator, master plumber, or fire line contractor can only test and repair backflow devices on landscape residential and commercial lawn sprinkler systems. 
(4)  It is the water customer's responsibility to submit, or cause the inspector to submit, the inspection report that is required by this article to the retail public utility providing service to the property within 30 calendar days of the completion of the inspection. Each water customer shall deliver, or cause to be delivered, the annual report of testing and inspection that is required to be performed by this article to the retail public utility that provides water to the property where the backflow prevention device is located no later than 30 days after the date of the inspection and testing. 
(b)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested upon installation by a TCEQ licensed backflow prevention assembly tester and certified to be operating within specifications. 
(c)  Backflow prevention assemblies which are installed to provide protection against health hazards must also be tested and certified to be operating within specifications at least annually by a TCEQ licensed backflow prevention assembly tester. 
(d)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed and tested in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, the retail public utility's cross connection control and back flow prevention program, and the then-most current edition of The University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control whichever is stricter. In the event of an irreconcilable conflict between the requirements of The University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control and the International Building Code as adopted by Section 18-116 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Brownsville, the stricter requirement shall apply. 
(e)  All failing and/or defective backflow prevention assemblies shall be repaired, overhauled, or replaced at the expense of the customer. It is the customer's responsibility to ensure that all appropriate permits required for the repair, replacement or removal of the backflow prevention assembly are obtained before beginning work. Original forms of such test, repairs, and overhaul shall be kept and submitted to the retail public utility serving the customer, within a reasonable time after receipt of the form, but not more than 30 calendar days after the test, repair or overhaul of each backflow prevention assembly. 
(f)  No backflow prevention assembly or device shall be removed from use, relocated, or other assembly or device substituted without the inspection and approval of the retail public utility serving the customer. Whenever the existing assembly or device is moved from the present location or cannot be repaired, the backflow assembly or device shall be replaced with a backflow prevention assembly or device that complies with this article, the then-current edition of The University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control and the retail public utility's cross connection control and back flow prevention program, whichever is stricter. In the event of an irreconcilable conflict between the requirements of The University of Southern California Manual of Cross-Connection Control and the International Building Code as adopted by section 18-116 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Brownsville, the stricter requirement shall apply. 
(g)  Test gauges used for backflow prevention assembly testing shall be tested for accuracy annually in accordance with the then-current edition of The University of Southern California's Manual of Cross-Connection Control. The original gauge accuracy test form must be submitted to the retail public utility serving the customer within a reasonable time after receipt of the form, but not more than 30 calendar days after the gauge has been tested for accuracy. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-703. - Customer service inspections. 
(a)  The customer shall allow his property to be inspected by the retail public utility providing service to the customer for possible cross-connections and other potential contamination hazards. These inspections shall be conducted by a TCEQ licensed customer service inspector or an individual with the credentials described under section 102-703(c) below prior to initiating new water service; when there is reason to believe that cross-connections or other potential contamination hazards exist; or after any major changes to the private water distribution facilities. The inspections shall be conducted during normal business hours. 
(b)  A customer service inspection shall be completed prior to providing continuous water service to all new construction, on any existing service when the retail public utility serving the customer has reason to believe that cross-connections or other contaminant hazards exist, or after any material improvement, correction, or addition to the private water distribution facilities. A customer service inspection shall be performed every ten years thereafter. 
(c)  Only individuals with the following credentials shall be recognized as capable of conducting a customer service inspection: 
(1)  Plumbing inspectors and water supply protection specialists that have been licensed by the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners. 
(2)  Customer service inspectors that have been licensed by the TCEQ. 
(d)  Commercial and residential customers that have a private water supply for a lawn irrigation system shall have an inspected and approved backflow prevention assembly at the service connection. The backflow prevention assembly must be maintained and tested in accordance with the 290 Rules. In addition, a customer that utilizes Resaca, well water, or auxiliary water for lawn irrigation systems shall register that system with the Brownsville Public Utilities Board Cross Connection Control Department. The Brownsville Public Utilities Board may discontinue water service to any customer who fails to register as required by this subsection after the Brownsville Public Utilities Board provides the customer notice and a reasonable opportunity to comply. 
(e)  The customer service inspection must certify that: 
(1)  No direct connection between the potable water retailer water supply and a potential source of contamination including any auxiliary sources of water is permitted. Potential sources of contamination shall be isolated from the potable water retailer by a properly installed air gap or an appropriate backflow prevention assembly. 
(2)  No cross-connection between the potable water retailer and a private water source including any auxiliary sources of water exists. Where an actual properly installed air gap is not maintained between the potable water retailer and a private water supply, an approved reduced pressure-zone backflow prevention assembly is properly installed and a service agreement exists for annual inspection and testing by a TCEQ licensed backflow prevention assembly tester. 
(3)  No connection exists which allows water to be returned to the public drinking water supply. 
(4)  No pipe or pipe fitting which contains more than eight percent lead may be used in private water distribution facilities installed on or after July 1, 1988 and prior to January 4, 2014. Plumbing installed after January 4, 2014 that bears the expected label indicating less than 0.25% lead (or the most current TCEQ-approved value for lead concentrations) may be used for the installation or repair of plumbing at any connection that provides water for human use. 
(5)  No solder or flux which contains more than 0.2% lead (or the most current TCEQ-approved value for lead concentrations) can be used for the installation or repair of plumbing at any connection that provides water for human use. A minimum of one lead test shall be performed for each inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-704. - Thermal expansion. 
(a)  With the installation of backflow prevention assemblies at the service connection a "closed-system" is created. This closed system could result in injury to the water system customer or damage to the customer's property if adequate safety measures, such as the installation of thermal expansion tanks, are not implemented. 
(1)  Thermal expansion may cause damage ranging from leaking faucets to a ruptured water heater if the condition is not addressed. 
(2)  The retail public utility shall provide its customers with information regarding thermal expansion when a backflow prevention assembly is required to be installed at the customer's service connection. 
(3)  Neither the City of Brownsville nor the Brownsville Public Utilities Board shall be liable for any damage, personal injury, or death resulting from thermal expansion at a customer's property. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-705. - Fire hydrant protection. 
(a)  Reduced-pressure principle backflow prevention assembly (RPBA) shall be the minimum protection for fire hydrant water meters which are used as a temporary water supply during any construction or other use which would pose a potential hazard to the potable water retailer. 
(1)  An RPBA must be installed if any solution other than potable water can be introduced into the system. 
(2)  It is the responsibility of all persons engaging in the use and rental of a fire hydrant water meter to abide by the conditions of this article. All fire hydrant meter rentals shall meet the current requirements as provided for by the City of Brownsville and the retail public utility that owns the fire hydrant. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-706. - Full flow testing and/or backflow prevention assembly tear down requirements for fire lines. 
(a)  The Brownsville Public Utilities Board requires backflow prevention assemblies installed on fire-lines to be completely disassembled at a minimum of every five years, if full flow testing cannot be accomplished. The assembly will be cleaned and rubber parts replaced when deemed necessary by the TCEQ licensed backflow prevention assembly tester and/or manufacturer. Assemblies should be appropriately labeled and tagged by the tester to indicate last tear down date. The Brownsville Public Utilities Board Cross Connection Control Department will track individual assemblies over a five year period to ensure provisions are met. 
(b)  A backflow prevention assembly found to be malfunctioning should be completely disassembled, repaired, reassembled and tested by a fire line contractor and certified that the backflow preventer is operating as specified by manufacture's specifications. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-707. - Requirements for chemical dispensers. 
    All chemical dispensers will require the use of a testable backflow prevention assembly. Backflow prevention assemblies installed on chemical dispensers will be subject to all of the requirements described in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-708. - Emergency suspension. 
(a)  The chief executive officer of a retail public utility may suspend water service and disconnect service to a customer if the chief executive officer determines that contamination or pollution due to backflow presents an imminent threat to the portable water retailer, presents an imminent danger to public health or safety, or threatens to interfere with the operation of the portable water retailer. 
(b)  A customer notified of the suspension of the person's service by a retail public utility pursuant to this article shall immediately stop the use of the potable water system. If a person fails to immediately suspend use of the potable water retailer water, the retail public utility may take action it deems necessary to prevent contamination or pollution, or to minimize damage to the potable water retailer system. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-709. - Testing and inspection notices and enforcement. 
(a)  All retail public utilities shall send customers cross connection control backflow prevention test and inspection notices. It is the customer's responsibility to comply with the necessary process required by the retail public utility serving the customer. 
(b)  Cross connection controls and backflow preventions are to be inspected and tested as specified by the retail public utility serving the customer's premises. 
(c)  The failure to perform the required testing and inspection as required by the customer's retail public utility may result in the retail public utility to solicit the City of Brownsville's assistance with enforcement. 
(d)  When the City of Brownsville is solicited to assist with enforcement by any retail public utility, the planning and development services department director, assistant director, or building official will authorize a code enforcement officer to issue citations as needed. The citation issued shall state the alleged violation, the date of such violation, and the section of the code or section violated. Such citations are returnable to the municipal court, and each violation cited shall be a finable offense, not in excess of $2,000.00 per violation per day. 
(e)  The failure to perform any action that is required by this article or the performance of any action that is prohibited by this article shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(f)  A conviction for a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a Class C misdemeanor. A person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be fined an amount of not less than $200.00 per violation and a maximum not to exceed $2,000.00 per violation. Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense, and each day a violation continues shall be considered a new offense. 
(g)  Civil penalty. A civil penalty may be imposed for each violation of any provision of this article in an amount not to exceed $5,000.00 per violation. Each violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a separate violation, and each day a violation continues shall be considered a new violation. 
(h)  Authorization to enforce. The Brownsville Public Utilities Board is authorized to take any action authorized by this article against any person committing a violation of this article who is a water customer of the Brownsville Public Utilities Board. The grant of authority set out in this article does not in any way diminish the authority of the City of Brownsville, to take any action necessary to enforce the terms of this article, to prosecute violations of this article, and to defend the legality of this article, if challenged. 
(i)  Additional enforcement remedies. In addition to any other remedies provided in this article for violations of this article that occur within its service area, the City of Brownsville or Brownsville Public Utilities Board at any time, pursue any other legal and/or equitable remedy to require compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-710. - Potable water retailer fees. 
    The Brownsville Public Utilities Board's governing body is authorized to adopt fees for services provided by the Brownsville Public Utilities Board in accordance with this article in an amount determined to be sufficient to recover potable water retailer's costs. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-711. - Effective date. 
    Pursuant to the Brownsville City Charter Sections 14, 17 and 18, this article, once passed by the City Commission and signed by the mayor and city secretary within two days of any such passage, shall then be immediately recorded by the city secretary in the city's Official Ordinance Book for public records, and then become immediately effective and lawfully enforceable. Non-conforming cross-connections and backflow devices shall not be grandfathered. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-712. - Repeal. 
    That all ordinances that are in conflict with the provisions of this article be, and the same are hereby repealed and all other ordinances of the city not in conflict with the provisions of this article shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 102-713. - Severability. 
(a)  All of the regulations provided in this article are hereby declared to be governmental and for the health, safety and welfare of the general public. 
(b)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission of the City of Brownsville that the phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, and sections of this article are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this article shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, and sections of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-983-DD, pt. 1, 12-4-2018) 
Chapter 106 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 106-1-106-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of taxicabs, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.004. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dispatch log means a record kept by each taxicab company showing the following: 
(1)  The name of the taxicab company; 
(2)  The date; 
(3)  The cab number; 
(4)  The description of each trip; 
(5)  The giving of the beginning and ending time of such trip; 
(6)  The origin and destination of each trip; 
(7)  The number of passengers; 
(8)  The total amount of fare for each trip; and 
(9)  The names of dispatchers on duty. 
Each trip shall be recorded at the time such trip is completed. The dispatch log shall be maintained by the taxicab company for a minimum period of one year, and it shall be on a form approved by the chief of police. 
    Driver and taxicab driver mean any person duly licensed as a chauffeur by the state who has registered as a taxicab driver with the city and has received a city chauffeur's license from the city as required by this article and has been duly employed to drive a taxicab by the holder of a taxicab permit, in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
    Manifest means a record kept by each and every driver for each shift he works showing the following: 
(1)  The description of each trip, giving the beginning and ending time of such trip, its origin and destination. The number of passengers. The amount of fare for each trip; and 
(2)  The number of trips and units as shown by a taximeter, the cab number and the name of the driver and the date. 
Each trip shall be recorded at the time such trip is completed. 
    Permit means an authority duly GRANTED by the chief of police, or his designee, based upon the findings of public convenience and necessity as determined by the city commission. Such permit shall be evidenced by the issuance, by the chief of police or his representative, of a numbered motor cab permit. 
    Permittee means the person to whom a permit has been duly issued by the chief of police, or his designee. 
    Public Cabstand or taxicab stand means a public place designated by proper markings alongside the curb or curb line by the department of traffic and transportation as reserved exclusively for use by taxicabs. This shall also apply to taxicab stands located on private property. 
    Stool light means an instrument or an accessory to be permanently attached to the outside top of a duly licensed taxicab and at midpoint between the front doors and not more than 30 inches to the rear of the top most part of the windshield. 
    Street means any public street, road, boulevard, alley, lane, highway, sidewalk, park roadway, railway station, bus station or other place under control of the city or other public authority and established by it for the use of vehicles not otherwise controlled by law or ordinance. The property constituting the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport is not designated as "streets" under this definition. 
    Taxicab means every automobile or motor-propelled vehicle used for the transportation of passengers for hire whether such vehicle is identified or not as a taxicab as set forth herein, with the exception listed in this section, over the public streets of this city, whether or not the operation extends beyond the city limits. The term "taxicab" shall not apply to limousines, school buses, emergency vehicles or sight-seeing autos or buses that operate under a permit, franchise or license issued to and regulated by the city or other regulatory authorities, and provided further that said term shall not apply to limousines which are chartered, hired or provided in connection with funeral services. 
    Taximeter means a recording, mechanical or electrical instrument, or both, to record miles or distances traveled or time consumed, or both, during the period of engagement of taxicab service, and so constructed as to visibly record the cumulative charges to the person engaging such service. 
    Taximeter flag means that portion of the taximeter that is used manually or otherwise to engage or disengage the taximeter from vacant position to recording position and back to vacant position. Positions of the taximeter are indicated by the taximeter flag and have the following meanings: 
(1)  Vacant position the position where the taximeter does not record distance or time. 
(2)  Recording when the taximeter is recording both distance and waiting time, but not the time consumed or lost or occasioned by mechanical failure of the taxi cab. 
(Code 1971, § 35-1; Ord. No. 318-J, § 1, 3-27-1990; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-1, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-1, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-27. - Operation by permittee; responsibility of permittee; presumption of employment or agreement. 
(a)  No taxicab for which a permit has been issued under this chapter shall be operated by anyone except the permittee or an employee of the permittee or other person who may be operating such vehicle under a written agreement specifically incorporating therein such rules, regulations and conditions as may be required by the chief of police. 
(b)  The permittee shall be responsible for anyone operating under his permit whether he is an employee or another person operating under such written agreement. 
(c)  Any person driving or operating a taxicab upon the streets or other public property of the city is -presumed to be an employee of the permittee or to have entered into such written agreement. 
(Code 1971, § 35-2; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-2, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-2, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-2, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-2, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-28. - General prerequisites to putting vehicle in service. 
    Before any permittee may put a taxicab into service or replace a taxicab, he shall furnish to the chief of police, for his approval, the following: 
(1)  The vehicle; 
(2)  The certificate of title showing the then-current true ownership of such vehicle; 
(3)  His public liability insurance policy, insurance endorsement or evidence of self-insurance; and 
(4)  For a leased vehicle, the written lease contract. 
(Code 1971, § 35-3; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-3, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-3, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-3, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-3, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-29. - Payment of ad valorem taxes required. 
    No person shall use the streets of the city for the operation of a taxicab unless the ad valorem taxes due and owing on all properties used in the furnishing of taxicab service shall have first been paid. 
(Code 1971, § 35-4; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-4, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-4, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-4, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-4, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-30. - Passenger's right of selection. 
    Each and every person shall be permitted to select a taxicab of his choice at any place in the city. However, selection of taxicabs at the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport shall be limited to those authorized by the city to pick up passengers and baggage at the airport and shall be regulated by fees and standards as may be established for the operation of the airport. 
(Code 1971, § 35-9; Ord. No. 90-1223, § 1, 9-25-1990; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-9, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-9, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-9, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-9, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-31. - Plaza District and University Boulevard taxi terminal operation. 
(a)  Permit required. Only taxicabs operating under an approved Plaza District/University Boulevard taxi terminal permit issued by the city and assigned to a particular terminal shall be authorized to pick up passengers at the Plaza District and University Boulevard taxi terminals unless a person selects a particular taxi cab company, in which section 106-30, Passengers' right of selection, shall be followed. Said permit shall be issued by the city chief of police and will contain rules and regulations pertaining to the terminal permit system, which is also set out in subsection (b) below. The chief of police shall also have the right and authority to revoke or suspend said permit if any violations described in this section occur. 
(b)  Permit fee; cancellation of permit. The Plaza District/University Boulevard permit will be purchased at the rate of $50.00 per month. This sum is due and payable on the first day of each month. 
(1)  If a permit holder does not pay the required $50.00 within five working days of the first day of the month, such permit will be assessed a $25.00 late fee in addition to the permit fee. If the permit fee and late fees are not paid by the tenth business day of that month, the permit for the delinquent taxi cab company will be cancelled for that month and said company will not be allowed to park at any of the Plaza District or University Boulevard taxi terminals. 
(2)  If a holder of a cancelled permit pursuant to subsection (1) above wishes to contest the cancellation, the burden will be on the holder of the cancelled permit to conclusively establish that the holder did in fact pay the required $50.00 within the allotted time. 
(3)  Permits will automatically be cancelled when the owner to whom the permit is issued sells, transfers, or assigns the taxi cab company or when voluntarily surrendered by the permit holder. 
(c)  La Plaza/University Boulevard Rotation list. Taxi cab businesses for which permits have been provided by the Brownsville Chief of Police may, upon request, be placed on the La Plaza/University Boulevard Rotation list. Said list shall designate, on a rotating basis by month, which taxi cab businesses may use the 15 (ten at University Boulevard; five at La Plaza) spaces for taxi cab business purposes. 
(1)  Initial selection of the rotation list order shall be established via a lottery system. All permit holding taxi companies shall be given the same opportunity to be granted a position on the rotation list to use the La Plaza and University Boulevard terminals. The rotation order will provide each taxi company on the list two months at the University Boulevard taxi terminal, and one month at the Plaza District taxi terminal. 
(2)  The La Plaza/University Boulevard Rotation list shall be maintained and updated as necessary by the city police department, and may change as new taxi cab companies are added to or removed from the list. The La Plaza/University Boulevard Rotation list shall be posted on the city police department website. 
a.  New taxi cab companies. If a new taxi cab company receives a permit to do business in the city, the company may request to the city police chief to obtain a La Plaza/University Boulevard permit and be placed on the list. If the new taxi cab company is placed on the list, it shall be placed at the end of the rotation list as it exists at the time of placement. 
b.  Former taxi cab companies. If a taxi cab company goes out of business or for any other reason is removed from the list, the remaining taxi cab companies on the list shall all be moved up one position on the list but otherwise keep the same rotation list order, to account for the vacancy left by the departing company. 
(d)  Only one taxi cab per company per space at the Plaza District and University Boulevard terminals may be allowed at any one time. 
(e)  Manner of operation. At either the Plaza District or University Boulevard terminal, all cabs must be parked, in a single file, within the designated terminal area and in the parking lane designated as the taxi lane. No more than five taxi cabs shall be in the designated parking lane at one time in the La Plaza terminal, and no more than ten taxi cabs shall be in the University Boulevard terminal parking area. Only one taxi cab per company may be allowed in such lane at any one time. All taxi cabs leaving the designated taxi lane for any reason shall upon their return enter the terminal area at the end of the taxi lane. Taxi cabs situated in the parking lanes shall only move forward as taxi cabs in front of them leave the lane. 
(f)  Violations causing revocation of permit. Fighting, loud and abusive language, and other unnecessary or boisterous conduct on the part of the taxi drivers while at either terminal shall constitute grounds for suspension of the permit. Violators of the permit system will lose their privilege to service the terminals for a period of six months. 
(Ord. No. 90-1223, § 2, 9-25-1990; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-9.1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-9.1, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-9.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-9.1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2012-318-KK, § 2, 5-1-2012) 
Sec. 106-32. - Special pickup and parking areas. 
    The chief of police or his designated representative may designate specially demarcated pickup and parking areas near bus terminals and international bridges. The chief of police or his designated representative may further choose to designate a separate, specially demarcated area for touring vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-9.2, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-9.2, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-33. - Carrying additional passengers. 
(a)  Any passenger who engages the services of a taxicab shall have the exclusive right to the passenger compartment of the taxicab and it shall be unlawful for a taxicab driver or permittee to carry additional passengers unless specific permission is obtained from the passenger who originally engaged the taxicab. 
(b)  No driver shall permit more persons to be carried as passengers than the rated passenger capacity of the vehicle. It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section that except for the carrying of a person under two years of age, the rated passenger capacity would not have been exceeded. 
(Code 1971, § 35-10; Ord. No. 318-K, § 35-10, 3-26-1991; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-10, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-10, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-10, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-10, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-10, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-34. - Fares and rates. 
(a)  The city commission fixes, authorizes, establishes and approves the maximum schedule of taxicab rates and charges in this subsection. Taxicab permittees and drivers shall not establish charges or rates in excess of those established as follows: 
(1)  Drop off charge (includes first ? mile) ..... $3.50 
(2)  Additional one-fifth mile ..... 0.50 
(3)  Each additional person ..... 0.50 
(4)  Additional passengers, in excess of two ..... 1.00 
(5)  Waiting time ..... 20.00 
(6)  No charge shall be made for hand luggage. 
(b)  If two or more passengers are going to the same destination, the driver shall collect only one fare as recorded on the taximeter. If the passengers are going to different destinations, the driver shall clear his meter at the first destination and charge the first passenger the amount recorded on the taximeter and proceed to the next destination as though it were a completely new trip. Other destinations shall be treated likewise. 
(Code 1971, § 35-12; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-12, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-12, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-12, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-12, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005; Ord. No. 2008-318-II, § 1, 6-3-2008) 
Sec. 106-35. - Refusal to convey at posted rates; receiving more than posted rates. 
    If any permittee or operator of any taxicab shall refuse to convey a passenger at the rate specified on the rate card displayed in such taxicab or shall demand or receive an amount in excess of the rates displayed on such card, he shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $10.00 but not more than $200.00. 
(Code 1971, § 35-14; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-14, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-14, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-14, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-14, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-36. - Receipt for payment of fare. 
    No driver of any taxicab, upon receiving full payment for a fare as indicated by the taximeter, shall refuse to give a receipt upon the request of any passenger making such payment. 
(Code 1971, § 35-15; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-15, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-15, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-15, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-15, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-37. - Refusal to pay fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any taxicab after having hired the same, and any person who shall hire any taxicab with the intent to defraud the person from whom it is hired shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $10.00 but not more than $200.00. 
(Code 1971, § 35-16; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-16, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-16, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-16, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-16, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-38. - Soliciting business prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to seek or solicit a passenger or passengers for hire, whether or not such vehicle is identified as a taxicab, at, in or near any passenger depot, hotel, airport, bus stop or station, or upon any sidewalk or street or any other place in the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to call out "taxicab", "limousine", "auto for hire", "carriage", "bus", "baggage", "hotel", or any other words or gesture that could be construed as soliciting a passenger for hire. Violators of this section, upon conviction, shall be fined at least $50.00 but not more than $200.00, and in case of violators of this section, the chief of police may suspend, for a period not exceeding 15 days, the taxicab permit for the taxicab for which such solicitation was made and the city chauffeur's license of the driver of such taxicab. 
(Code 1971, § 35-22; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-22, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-22, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-22, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-22, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-318-KK, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, repealed § 106-39 which pertained to operation at Brownsville Multimodal Terminal and derived from Ord. No. 2011-318-JJ, § 1, adopted Nov. 1, 2011. 
Secs. 106-40-106-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLES 

Sec. 106-66. - Condition and inspection for compliance with standards. 
(a)  The city shall establish requirements for condition and accessories of taxicabs used by a holder. 
(b)  The city shall inspect each taxicab before it is placed in service and at other times when determined to be necessary, for compliance with this article. No taxicab shall be operated which does not comply with all of the following standards and requirements: 
(1)  The taxicab shall meet minimum state motor vehicle inspection standards. 
(2)  The taxicab shall be reasonably free of dust, dirt or rubbish, and be otherwise clean and sanitary. 
(3)  The taxicab shall have no part of the body missing or unreasonably bent or dented out of shape, and effective September 1, 1999, shall not utilize "mag" wheels or other non-original equipment. 
(4)  The taxicab shall contain no rips, tears or places of wear through the covering material. 
(5)  A permit holder shall make a taxicab available for inspection when ordered by the chief of police or his designee. 
(6)  If a permit holder fails to make a taxicab available for inspection or if the city determines that a taxicab is not in compliance, the chief of police may order the taxicab removed from service until it is made available for inspection and brought into compliance. 
(7)  The last day on which an automobile may be used as a taxicab is December 31 of the year model of the automobile plus twelve. For example, the last day on which a 2002 model automobile may be used as a taxicab is December 31, 2014. 
(8)  No automobile may be used as a taxicab if any part of the windshield or windows of that automobile are tinted with window tinting or window coating material other than that placed on the windshield or windows by the manufacturer of the automobile. 
(Code 1971, § 35-5; Ord. No. 318-J, § 2, 3-27-1990; Ord. No. 92-318-L, § 35-5, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-5, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-5, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-5, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-5, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-5, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-67. - Annual inspection. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause to be inspected each and every taxicab for which a permit has been issued at least once a year or at any other time he deems advisable. Such inspection shall be made to determine that all taxi-cabs are in a reasonably good state of repair are clean and that the vehicles are equipped and are being operated in compliance with all requirements of this article. Such inspection shall be made at a place designated by the chief of police. The chief of police shall cause the record of such inspection to be reduced to writing and a permanent record made thereof. Such record shall be kept for a period of at least two years. 
(b)  If the inspection reveals that any such vehicle is not in a reasonably good operating condition, from the standpoint of the safety, health and comfort of passengers, the taxicab shall be ordered out of service until such time as remedial repairs and corrections have been made. When such repairs and corrections have been made, such vehicle shall be re-inspected to determine whether proper repairs and corrections have been made, and in no case shall the taxicab be permitted to resume its operation until such repairs and corrections have been made. 
(c)  Such inspection shall include but not be limited to the following items: 
(1)  Vehicle identification number. 
(2)  Date of purchase. 
(3)  Foot brakes. 
(4)  Emergency brake. 
(5)  Headlamps. 
(6)  Tail lamps. 
(7)  License plate lights. 
(8)  Stool light. 
(9)  Dome light. 
(10)  Horn. 
(11)  Windshield wipers. 
(12)  Current state inspection sticker. 
(13)  Rearview mirror 
(14)  All glasses. 
(15)  Cleanliness. 
(16)  Safety. 
(17)  Condition of paint. 
(18)  Color scheme. 
(19)  Taximeter seals and readings. 
(20)  Rate card. 
(21)  Fumes. 
(22)  State license plates. 
(23)  Speedometer readings. 
(24)  Mileage. 
(25)  Steering. 
(26)  Tires. 
(27)  Muffler and tailpipe. 
(28)  Accuracy of taximeter. 
(29)  Condition of the body of the vehicle and fenders. 
(Code 1971, § 35-19; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-19, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-19, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-19, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-19, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-68. - Failure to submit vehicle for inspection. 
    Failure to submit a taxicab requested for inspection by the police department shall be cause for the suspension of the permit assigned to the vehicle for a period not to exceed 15 days for the revocation upon the third offense. 
(Code 1971, § 35-19(d); Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-19(D), 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-19(D), 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-19.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-19.1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-69. - Inspection after accident. 
    A taxicab involved in an accident shall not thereafter be used in taxicab operations until it has been inspected by the chief of police or his representative. If the inspection reveals that the taxicab has been damaged to an extent that it is not in reasonably good operating condition from the standpoint of the safety, health and comfort of passengers, or that the taxicab has suffered damage in excess of $250.00, the taxicab shall be ordered out of service until the chief of police or his representative has authorized the return of the vehicle to taxicab operations. The authorization shall not be given until proper repairs or corrections have been made. 
(Code 1971, § 35-20; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-20, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-20, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-20, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-20, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-70. - Identification of vehicles generally. 
(a)  No permittee shall drive or cause to be driven or operate or cause to be operated a taxicab in the city unless the taxicab shall have signs on the front doors on each side of the taxicab stating the telephone number and the name of the partnership, co-partnership, association, society or corporation under which the owner operates such taxicab, as is on file with the chief of police. Such name and number shall be in letters of eight inches in height and two inches in width. Company phone numbers may appear on the taxicab in numbers of one and one-half inches in height and three and one-half inches in length. Said letters and numbers shall be colored white, black, or two-tone in accordance with the color scheme of the automobile, must appear in either script or block font, and must be approved by the chief of police or his designee. The telephone number shall also be placed on the rear of the taxicab and be plainly visible. 
(b)  No permittee shall operate or cause to be operated a taxicab in the city until a permit number has been assigned by the chief of police, or his representative. Such number shall remain in full force and effect for each permit so long as the permit remains valid. The number shall be displayed on the taxicab in three separate locations as follows: One shall be placed on the trunk where plainly visible; one shall appear on the front fender, and one on the rear bumper of the taxicab. Such number, in each instance, shall be three inches in height and one-half of an inch in width. 
(Code 1971, § 35-6; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-6, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-6, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-6, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-6, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-71. - Color scheme. 
(a)  No driver or permittee shall drive or cause to be driven any taxicab in the city until the permittee has filed with the chief of police, for his approval, the color scheme that he proposes to use under his ownership. In approving or disapproving the color scheme submitted, the chief of police or his designee shall consider: the color scheme proposed to be used by the permittee; the color scheme of other permittees; and which permittee first has used the color scheme. If the chief of police or his designee finds that the permittee is entitled to the use of the requested color scheme because of the first or prior use and that it does not deceptively resemble the approved color scheme of another permittee, he shall approve its use by the permittee. 
(b)  All taxicabs serving the Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport must have a single-tone, solid-color paint job. Single-tone taxicabs must be colored white, red, blue, yellow, or green. Taxicabs serving the city, but not the airport, must have a single-tone, solid-color paint job as described above, or a two-tone paint job in which one of the colors must be white. The second color on a two-tone car must be red, blue, yellow, or green. Letters and numbers may be placed at appropriate locations on the body of the taxicab in accordance with this article. 
(c)  If the chief of police determines that a taxicab company has violated subsection (b) of this section, he may take administrative action to address the violation. Such administrative action may include a warning, suspension, or revocation of the company license. 
(Code 1971, § 35-7; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-7, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-7, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, §§ 35-7-35-7.2, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, §§ 35-7-35-7.2, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-72. - Stool light. 
(a)  No permittee shall operate or cause to be operated any taxicab within the city unless it is equipped with a stool light which shall have lights of amber color thereon to be operative when the taxicab is vacant and is available for hire. Such stool light shall be controlled by the taximeter flag. When the taximeter flag is in the recording position, the stool light shall be off, and when such flag is in the vacant position, such stool light shall be on and shall illuminate a vacant sign contained thereon. 
(b)  The first violation of this section by a permittee shall cause his permit for the taxicab used in the violation to be suspended for three days, the second violation 15 days, and the third violation shall be cause for revocation. 
(Code 1971, § 35-8; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-8, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-8, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-8, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-8, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-73. - Taximeters. 
(a)  No driver or permittee shall drive or cause to be driven a taxicab in the city unless it is equipped with a taximeter of a type approved by the chief of police. No driver shall carry a passenger, whether for hire or not, in such taxicab unless the meter flag is in the recording position. All charges and maximum collections for hire shall be based upon the meter recording. The dial showing the fare shall be in full view and readable by the passenger at all times as such service is being rendered. 
(b)  The first violation of this section by a permittee shall cause the permittee's taxicab permit for the vehicle used in the violation to be suspended for three days, the second offense 15 days, and the third offense shall cause for revocation. 
(Code 1971, § 35-11; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-11, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-11, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-11, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-11, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-74. - Posting of driver's identification and rates. 
    Each licensed taxicab shall be equipped with a holder of a type approved by the chief of police and such holder shall be mounted on the meter or dashboard of the taxicab in a conspicuous location where the contents thereof may be seen by the passengers. It shall be the duty of the permittee and the taxicab driver to display in this holder the city chauffeur's license identification card, containing a picture of the drive, the driver's name and description and a rate card showing the name of the taxicab operator and the approved taxicab rates. The size and contents of the city chauffeur's license identification card and the rate cards shall be specified by the chief of police. 
(Code 1971, § 35-13; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-13, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-13, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-13, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-13, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-75. - Required operation; taking vehicles out of service. 
(a)  Taxicab permit holders are required to operate their taxicabs whenever public convenience and necessity requires that the taxicabs be in operation. The chief of police may order all taxicab permit holders to put into operation any taxicab not presently in operation whenever public convenience and necessity requires that all licensed taxicabs be in operation. 
(b)  Subject to the minimum taxicab requirements of public convenience and necessity, taxicab permit holders may take out of service those taxicabs requiring repairs which need to be taken out of service for any other reason, with the exception that operators having five or more taxicab permits must have 80 percent of their taxicabs in operable condition at all times. Operators having less than five taxicabs permits must operate each taxicab a minimum of 13 days per month. 
(c)  All taxicab permits that are not operated in accordance with this section may be suspended by the chief of police. 
(Code 1971, § 35-17; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-17, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-17, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-17, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-17, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-76. - Removal of identification marks when vehicle retired from service. 
    No owner of a taxicab shall dispose of a taxicab which is being retired from service until all marks of identification have been removed therefrom. 
(Code 1971, § 35-18; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-18, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-18, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-18, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-18, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-77. - Accident reports. 
    When a taxicab is involved in an accident or collision with any other vehicle of any kind, whatsoever which results in any injury or damage to any person or property, including the taxicab, the driver of the taxicab, if a person other than the permittee, shall report the accident to the permittee without delay. The permittee shall report all accidents or collisions to the chief of police. The report shall include the following information: 
(1)  The owner of the taxicab; 
(2)  The driver's name and his city chauffeur's license number, and 
(3)  The time and location of the accident. 
(Code 1971, § 35-21; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-21, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-21, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-21, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-21, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-78. - Advertising on taxicabs permitted. 
    Subject to requirements of identification and provisions of this article, this Code, and any other ordinance of the city regulating the use of the public streets, holders of permits for taxicab services may allow advertising matter to be affixed on any taxicab, provided, however, that such advertisement does not block from view the "vacant" or "stool light". Furthermore, no stickers, flyers, papers, posters, nor any other material may be displayed anywhere on a taxicab if such material relates to an upcoming, present, or past election, and such material advertises the candidacy of one or more individuals for public office, or if such material promotes or advertises any political party. 
(Code 1971, § 35-23; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-23, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-23, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-23, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2001-318-EE, § 1, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-23, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-79. - Certain commercial advertising prohibited. 
    Holders of permits for taxicab services shall not allow any advertising to be affixed on or to any taxicab if such advertising pertains to or promotes the purchase or consumption of alcoholic beverages or tobacco products of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-23.1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-23.1, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-23.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-23.1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Secs. 106-80-106-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VEHICLE PERMIT 

Sec. 106-106. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive or cause to be driven any taxicab upon and over the streets of the city unless a current permit has been issued for such taxicab by the chief of police in accordance with this division. Violators of this section, upon conviction, shall be fined as provided in section 1-13. In addition, the city attorney is authorized to file suit in any court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin any person from violation or causing to be violated this section. 
(Code 1971, § 35-24; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-24, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-24, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-24, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-24, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-107. - Restriction on number of permits. 
    The total number of taxicab permits that may be issued in the city is 125. 
(Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-24.1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-24.1, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-24.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-24.1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-108. - Number of taxicab companies. 
    The total number of taxicab companies that may apply to the chief of police for an annual permit pursuant to section 106-110 is 12. However, all companies existing prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives (March 2, 1999) may continue to do business. 
(Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-24.2, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-24.2, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-109. - Purchases or mergers of taxicab companies. 
    One taxicab company may purchase another taxicab company, may purchase the assets of such other company, or may merge with another taxicab company. However, such action must result in the dissolution and elimination of one of said companies, including the name and color scheme of the company to be dissolved. 
(Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-24.3, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-24.3, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-110. - Application. 
(a)  Contents. To obtain an annual taxicab permit, a person shall make application to the chief of police in the manner prescribed by this section. The applicant must be the person who will own and/or operate the proposed ground transportation service. An applicant shall file with the chief of police a written, sworn application containing the following: 
(1)  The form of business of the applicant; if the business is a corporation or association, a copy of the documents establishing the business and the name, address and citizenship of each person with a direct interest in the business; notice of any change in an applicant's form of business shall be provided to the chief of police in writing and with supporting documentation within five business days of the change; 
(2)  The name, street address, phone number and verified signature of the applicant and of the applicant's proposed business; an applicant shall notify the chief of police, in writing, of any change in this information within five business days of the change. Phone number may be a cell phone number and calls may be transferred to such; 
(3)  A representation of whether the applicant is a citizen of the United States of America by birth or naturalization, or, if alien, evidence of the applicant's legal residence in the United States and of the applicant's legal right to engage in employment in the United States; 
(4)  A description of any past business experience of the applicant, particularly in providing ground transportation services; 
(5)  An identification and description of any revocation or suspension of an annual permit held by the applicant or the applicant's business which occurred prior to the date of filing the application; 
(6)  The number of vehicles to be used by the applicant in the operation of the proposed ground transportation service as well as documentation evidencing each vehicle's ownership, identification number and registration; notice of any change in the foregoing shall be provided to the chief of police, in writing and with supporting documentation with five business days of the change; 
(7)  A description of each of the vehicles the applicant proposes to use in providing ground transportation services including, but not limited to, each vehicle's make, model, type, and seating capacity; 
(8)  All permittees must provide a description of the operation of the proposed ground transportation service and the location of the fixed permanent facilities to be used in the operation. No dispatching personnel is required to man a base station; 
(9)  A description of the proposed insignia and color scheme for the applicant's vehicles; 
(10)  Documentation from an insurance company authorized to do business in the state evidencing a willingness to provide, prior to commencement of the annual permit, the insurances required by this division; 
(11)  Documentation evidencing timely payment of all city taxes, fees and assessments which have been levied on the business and/or property to be used in connection with the proposed ground transportation service; 
(12)  Written authorization for the provision to the city of any and all information which an organization or entity may have concerning the applicant and a release to such organization or entity from all liability which may result from the furnishing of such to the city; 
(13)  Such additional information as the applicant desires to include to aid in the determination of whether the requested operating authority should be granted; and 
(14)  An applicant for an annual taxi cab permit must provide, at his/her expense, a certified copy of his/her criminal history and traffic history report obtained from the state department of public safety. 
(b)  Effect of past criminal activity of applicant. In the case where an applicant has a background of past criminal activity, application denial based solely thereon is warranted if and only if the past criminal activity is directly related to the duties and responsibilities of a holder as more fully described in this section. Accordingly, the following shall be considered in making a determination of job-relatedness: 
(1)  The nature and seriousness of the crime; 
(2)  The relationship of the crime to the purposes of requiring the city's approval prior to engagement in the ground transportation service; 
(3)  The extent to which the individual's engagement in the ground transportation service might offer an opportunity for further criminal activity of the same type as that which the individual previously had been involved; and 
(4)  The relationship of the crime to the ability, capacity or fitness required of the individual to perform the duties and discharge the responsibilities of the ground transportation service, including the following: 
a.  The extent and nature of the individual's past criminal history; 
b.  The age of the individual at the time of the commission of the crime; 
c.  The amount of time that has elapsed since the individual's last criminal activity; 
d.  The conduct and work activity of the individual prior to and following the criminal activity; 
e.  Evidence of the individual's rehabilitation or rehabilitative effort while incarcerated or following release; and 
f.  Other evidence of the individual's present fitness, including letters of recommendation from: prosecutorial, law enforcement and correctional officers who prosecuted, arrested or had custodial responsibility for the individual; and any other person in contact with the individual. 
(c)  Applicant's appearance before city commission. Upon the scheduling of the city commission's public hearing for determination of whether the granting or denial of the application is warranted, the applicant shall be given an opportunity to appear before said city commission and present to them any information, including witnesses, which the applicant feels may be of assistance in arriving at a decision on the matter. 
(d)  Denial generally. An application for an annual permit shall be denied where the applicant: 
(1)  Is under indictment for or has been convicted of the offense of criminal homicide including murder, capital murder, voluntary manslaughter, or involuntary manslaughter, but excluding criminally negligent homicide; 
(2)  Has falsified or materially altered or omitted pertinent information in any governmental record, including an application for an annual permit; or 
(3)  Has not met the requirements for obtaining an annual permit as set forth in this division. 
(e)  Denial for certain offenses. An application for an annual permit may also be denied where the applicant is under indictment or has been convicted or any of the following: 
(1)  Any offense involving fraud or theft; 
(2)  Any offense involving the unauthorized use of a motor vehicle; 
(3)  Any violation of state or federal laws regulating firearms; 
(4)  Any offense involving violence to any person except conduct classified as no greater than a Class C misdemeanor offense under the state law; 
(5)  Any offense involving prostitution or the promotion of prostitution; 
(6)  Any offense involving rape, sexual abuse, or indecency; 
(7)  Any offense involving the illegal use, sale, or possession of drugs (controlled substances); 
(8)  Any offense involving driving while intoxicated; or 
(9)  Any other job-related offense. 
(Code 1971, § 35-25; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-25, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 318-N, § 35-25, 11-16-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-25, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-25, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-25, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-25, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2008-318-II, § 2, 6-3-2008) 
Sec. 106-111. - Address of proposed business. 
    Every business that operates taxicabs must maintain office at a permanent physical address at all times. Such businesses may not share an address with another business. The residential address of a private individual or individuals may not serve as the business address of such a company. All such businesses must maintain a valid certificate of occupancy issued by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-25.5, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-25.5, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-25.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-25.1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-112. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, adopted May 17, 2005, repealed § 106-112, which pertained to qualifications of applicant; denial of application and derived from the Code of 1971, § 35-26; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-26, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 318-N, § 35-26, 11-16-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-26, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-26, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-26, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-26, 3-4-2003. 
Sec. 106-113. - Certificate of public convenience and necessity required. 
(a)  No permit to operate a taxicab shall be issued by the chief of police until the city commission, after a hearing, has duly declared that the public convenience and necessity require a permit to be issued for the proposed service. 
(b)  The declaration of public convenience and necessity required by this section shall not be required for: 
(1)  The licensing of the same number of taxicabs licensed for operation and operated by the applicant under the same name on the date of passage of the ordinance from which this article derives (April 8, 1976) or the renewal of the same number of licenses annually thereafter. 
(2)  The renewal of licenses to the applicant for the number of taxicabs for which the city commission shall have at any time prior to the application for such renewal made a declaration of public convenience and necessity; provided, however, such taxicabs shall have been duly licensed and operated by the applicant during the year prior to that for which the renewal is sought. 
(3)  The licensing of the same number of taxicabs licensed for operation and operated on the date of passage of the ordinance from which this section derives or the renewal of the same number of licenses annually thereafter. 
(4)  The transfer of permits when such transfer will not increase the number of taxicabs licensed for operation and operated on the date of passage of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(Code 1971, §§ 35-27, 35-28; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-28, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, §§ 35-27, 35-28, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-27, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, §§ 35-27, 35-28, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, §§ 35-27, 35-28, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-114. - Consideration of factors for public convenience and necessity. 
    In determining whether the public convenience and necessity require the licensing of taxicabs for which application may be made, the city commission shall take into consideration the following: 
(1)  Whether the demands for public convenience and necessity require such proposed or such additional taxicab service within the city; 
(2)  The financial responsibility of the applicant; 
(3)  The number, kind, type and ownership of equipment, and the color scheme to be used by the applicant; 
(4)  The increased traffic congestion of the streets of the city which any result, and whether the safe use of the public streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be unduly endangered by the granting of such additional license; and 
(5)  Such other relevant facts as the city commission may deem advisable or necessary which may determine public necessity and convenience. 
(Code 1971, § 35-29; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-29, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-29, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-29, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-6, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-29, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-115. - Notice of hearing. 
    Immediately upon the filing of an application for a permit under this division, the chief of police shall cause a notice to be published in one of the daily newspapers in the city for three consecutive days. The cost of such publication shall be paid in advance by the applicant. The notice shall state that an application has been filed for a taxicab permit and shall set for the name of the applicant, the kind and number of taxicabs, and the ownership of the taxicabs. Such publication shall constitute a notice to all holders of existing taxicab licenses that a public hearing will be held by the city commission at a public place in the city. The designated time given in the notice shall not be less than five days nor more than 45 days after the date of the first publication of the notice. 
(Code 1971, § 35-30; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-30, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-30, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-30, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-30, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-116. - Attendance and proof at hearing. 
    After issuance of the notice of public hearing as provided in section 106-115, all holders of taxicab licenses and any other citizen shall thereupon be entitled to file any complaint or protest which the party may see fit. In all such hearings the burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish by clear, cogent and convincing evidence that the public convenience and necessity require such operation of the vehicle for which application has been made. 
(Code 1971, § 35-31; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-31, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-31, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-31, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-31, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-117. - Additional information. 
    If the city commission determines that the public convenience and necessity justify the operation of the vehicle for which a taxicab permit is desired, the chief of police shall notify the applicant in writing of the finding. Within five days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish to the chief of police any and all relevant information which may be required by the city commission. If the chief of police then finds that the applicant has complied with all the sections of this article and relevant city ordinances, he shall issue a permit to the applicant as determined by the city commission. 
(Code 1971, § 35-32; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-32, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-32, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-32, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-32, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-118. - Insurance required. 
(a)  Before any taxicab permit shall be issued to any person, or before renewal of such permit shall be granted, the applicant shall file an insurance policy with the chief of police or his designee evidencing insurance coverage complying with the requirements contained in subsection (b), or give proof that he has qualified as a self-insurer, as the term is defined in the Texas Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act as now in force or hereafter amended and such insurance shall remain in full force and effect for so long as he or his assignee shall lawfully operate a taxicab in this city as required by all sections of this article. 
(b)  Insurance coverage in subsection (a) means an insurance policy or policies covering all licensed taxicabs of the insured issued by a company or companies qualified to do business in Texas and performable in Cameron County. Such policy or policies must contain a provision or an endorsement requiring, that the chief of police be given 15 days' notice before the policy can be canceled for any cause. Such policy shall provide the minimum coverage required to show proof of financial responsibility as that term is defined in the Texas Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility as that term is defined in the Texas Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act as now in force or hereafter amended; however, in no event shall insurance coverage of each taxicab be less than the amount of $20,000.00 for bodily injury to or death of one person; in the amount of $40,000.00 for bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident; and in the amount of $15,000.00 for injury to or destruction of property of others in any one accident. 
(c)  Neither the city nor any officer thereof shall be held liable for the pecuniary responsibility or solvency of any insurer under the provisions of this article, or in any manner become liable for any sum on account of any such claim or act or omission relating to the insured vehicle, nor shall the liability of the owner of any such vehicle be in any manner limited or changed by reason of the provisions of this article, but the judgment creditors having causes of action secured thereby shall be authorized to sue directly on such policy of insurance without impleading the city, and all persons known to any insurer to have been injured or damaged in the same accident and claiming damages thereunder may be made parties without priority of claim on payment in any suit had or instituted on account of such matters. 
(Code 1971, § 35-33; Ord. No. 318-J, § 3, 3-27-1990; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-33, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-33, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-33, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-33, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-33, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-119. - Annual fee. 
    The annual fee for a permit and/or permits under this Article shall be $125.00 for the first permit or taxicab and $75.00 for each subsequent taxicab owned by the same applicant.
