(Code 1971, § 35-34; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-34, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-34, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-34, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-34, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-120. - Issuance. 
    Taxicab permits shall be issued by the chief of police or his representative when it is determined that the applicant has qualified to receive a taxicab permit or permits and has otherwise complied with all of the requirements of this chapter, and upon payment by the applicant of the fee prescribed by section 106-119. 
(Code 1971, § 35-35; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-35, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-35, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-35, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-35, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-121. - Term; renewal. 
    A permit issued under this article shall be valid for one calendar year and may be renewed each year by payment of the annual fee prescribed in section 106-119 on or before December 31st of the year for which renewal is sought, providing the permittee complies with all applicable provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the city. If such renewal is not made by or on December 31 of any year, then the former permit holder must reapply to the chief of police as if he never held such a permit and a new application fee of $30.00 will be charged. 
(Code 1971, § 35-36; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-36, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-36, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-36, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-36, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-122. - Changes in associates, partners or officers after issuance. 
    All changes in associates, partners and officers of the business entity holding taxicab permits issued by the city must be reported to the chief of police or his designee within ten days after such change. Such new associates, partners or officers shall complete and file the forms and supply the information required of applicants for taxicab permits. 
    Immediately upon the filing of an application for a permit under this section, the chief of police shall cause a notice to be published in one of the daily newspaper in the city for three consecutive days. The cost of such publication shall be paid in advance by the applicant. The notice shall state that an applicant has been filed for a taxicab permit, setting forth the name of the applicant, kind and amount of taxicabs, and ownership of the taxicabs. Such publication shall constitute a notice to all holders of existing taxicab licenses that a public hearing will be held by the city commission at a public place in the city. The designated time given in such notice shall not be less than five days nor more than 15 days after the date of the first publication of such notice. 
(Code 1971, § 35-37; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-37, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-37, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-37, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-37, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-123. - Transfer or assignment. 
(a)  No person holding a taxicab permit shall transfer, rent, lease, loan or assign a permit to any other person or allow its use by any other person unless such transfer, rent, lease, loan, assignment or other use is under written agreement specifically incorporating therein such rules, regulations and conditions as may be required by the chief of police. If such transfer, rent, lease, loan, assignment or other use occurs under such written agreement, the permittee shall at all times be responsible for the operation of such permit in compliance with this article. The permit and all rights therein may be permanently transferred pursuant to application jointly by the permittee and the proposed transferee upon a finding by the city commission that public convenience and necessity require such transfer. Such public convenience and necessity shall be determined as specified and set out in sections 106-113 through 106-117. 
(b)  Such joint application for transfer of a taxicab permit shall be submitted on forms to be furnished by the chief of police. The applicant shall meet all standards and requirements and shall furnish all items of information as required of the applicant for taxicab permits by this article; provided, however, that sections 106-114 and 106-115 pertaining to publication, and public hearing, are not made applicable to an applicant for a transfer of a permit. 
(c)  Applicants shall have the burden of satisfying the city commission, by clear, cogent, and convincing evidence, that public convenience and necessity require the requested transfer. The application shall be denied unless the city commission so finds. In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the requested transfer, the city commission shall take into consideration those items designated in section 35-28. 
(d)  Within 60 days of the date the properly completed application for such transfer is received the city commission shall make a finding as to whether public convenience and necessity require the requested transfer. Such finding shall be communicated in writing to the applicants. 
(e)  Permits so transferred shall expire at the same date and shall be subject to the same suspension, revocation and fee provisions and all other sections of this article the same as they would had they not been transferred. 
(Code 1971, § 35-38; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-38, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-38, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-38, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-38, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-124. - Suspension or revocation. 
    The chief of police is authorized to hear and consider evidence on any and all suspensions or revocations of a taxicab permit. He shall be empowered to hear such evidence and shall recommend to the city commission his findings, on evidence presented orally or otherwise, whether to suspend or revoke a taxicab permit. 
(Code 1971, § 35-39; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-39, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-39, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-39, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-39, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-125. - Hearing on suspension or revocation. 
    Upon complaint being filed by any person with the chief of police of any violation for which a permittee's taxicab permit is subject to suspension or revocation or the chief of police charging a violation of any of the terms of this article, city ordinance or state law regulating motor vehicles, the chief of police, after giving ten days' notice to the permittee of the grounds of such complaint, any conduct a hearing to hear evidence with reference to such complaint. For any violation of the sections of this article for which specific provisions are not prescribed for suspension or revocation or upon conviction of any violation of the laws of the United States, of the state or city ordinances involving moral turpitude or felony, the chief of police may recommend to the city commission that the permit shall be suspended for a period of time not to exceed 15 days or the chief of police may recommend to revoke the permit authorized for the vehicle involved in such violation. The decision of the city commission shall be final. 
(Code 1971, § 35-40; Ord. No. 318-N, § 35-40, 11-16-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-40, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-40, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-40, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-40, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Secs. 106-126-106-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE 

Sec. 106-151. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a taxicab on the city streets without having first obtained a city chauffeur's license. Violators of this section, upon conviction, shall be fined as provided in section 1-13. 
(b)  No permittee shall allow any vehicle used or operated by him in the taxicab business to be driven by anyone who does not possess a valid, current and un-revoked city chauffeur's license. 
(Code 1971, § 35-41; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-41, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-41, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-41, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-41, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-152. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a license required by this division shall be submitted to the chief of police on a form provided by the chief of police. The following information shall be given on such application: 
(1)  The applicant's full name; 
(2)  The applicant's residence and places or residence for five years prior to moving to his present address; 
(3)  The applicant's age, race, height, weight, color of eyes and hair, place of birth, length of time he has resided in the city, and whether a citizen of the United States; 
(4)  The applicant's record of employment for the past five years, 
(5)  The applicant's social security number; 
(6)  The applicant's marital status; 
(7)  Whether he has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor in this state or any other state; 
(8)  Whether he now stands charged with the commission of a felony or misdemeanor in this state or any other state; 
(9)  Whether he has ever been denied a taxicab driver's license or had one revoked or suspended; 
(10)  Whether he has ever had a private passenger vehicle commercial license or a Class C driver's license or a chauffeur's license revoked; 
(11)  What taxicab firm he intends to work for; and 
(12)  Any other relevant information that may be requested by the chief of police. 
(b)  The application shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant and filed, together with a nonrefundable application fee of $30.00 with the chief of police. If license is not renewed by December 31st of that same year, then a new application fee of $30.00 is to be charged. Such fees are independent, separate, and apart from the fees mentioned in other sections of this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 35-42; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-42, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-42, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-42, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-42, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-153. - Qualifications of applicant. 
(a)  The applicant for a city chauffeur's license, at the time of application and at the applicant's own expense, shall: 
(1)  Be 18 years of age or older; 
(2)  Be a citizen of the United States of America by birth or naturalization, or, if alien, submit evidence of legal residence in the United States and legal right to engage in employment therein; 
(3)  Possess the classified state driver's license required for the class of vehicle to be operated by the applicant as defined in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. § 6687b § 4A. 
(4)  Be able to read and speak the English language; 
(5)  Be sanitary and well-groomed in dress and person; 
(6)  Provide the chief of police with a street address and phone number. An applicant shall notify the chief of police, in writing, of any change thereto within five business days of the change; 
(7)  Execute an authorization in writing for the provision to the city of any and all information which an organization or entity may have concerning the applicant and a release to said organization or entity from all liability which may result from the furnishing of such to the city; 
(8)  Be approved for employment by a permit holder. An applicant shall provide the chief of police with the name and business address of said prospective employer and shall, upon transfer of employment from one holder to another, notify the chief of police of such in writing within five business days of the transfer and further, pay the fee as required. 
(9)  Execute an agreement and waiver in writing by which the applicant authorizes the chief of police to permit a holder to in good faith examine the applicant's license file for the purpose of determining whether, in the judgment of the prospective employer, the applicant should be employed to drive a vehicle for hire from within the city; 
(10)  Submit to a medical examination by a Texas licensed physician on forms provided. For first time applicants, such examination shall include a test for controlled substances as prohibited by law and such test shall be of the same type and quality as administered to the bus drivers of the city bus drivers. 
(11)  Provide the department director with a certificate executed by the physician provided in subsection (a)(10) of this section stating that the applicant is not afflicted with any disease or disability which would prevent him from exercising ordinary and reasonable control over a motor vehicle or which would otherwise endanger the public health or safety. Such certificate shall also state specifically the condition of the applicant's hearing and eyesight including, without limitation, color perception; 
(b)  An application for a city chauffeur's license shall be denied where the applicant: 
(1)  Is under indictment for or has been convicted of the offense of criminal homicide including murder, capital murder, voluntary manslaughter, or involuntary manslaughter, but excluding criminally negligent homicide; 
(2)  Has been convicted of four or more moving violations of the traffic laws of this or any other city or state within the 12-month period immediately preceding the date of application; 
(3)  Has falsified or materially altered or omitted pertinent information in any governmental record, including an application for a city chauffeur's license; or 
(4)  Has not met the requirements for obtaining a city chauffeur's license as set forth in this division. 
(c)  An application for a city chauffeur's license may also be denied where the applicant is under indictment for or has been convicted of any of the offenses listed in section 106-110(e). 
(d)  The chief of police shall approve an application meeting the requirements for obtaining a city chauffeur's license as set out in this section and shall disapprove any application not meeting said requirements. 
(e)  If the chief of police disapproves an application for a city chauffeur's license, then same shall notify the applicant. 
(f)  In the case where an applicant has a background of past criminal activity, license denial based solely thereon is warranted if and only if the past criminal activity is directly related to the duties and responsibilities of a driver as more fully described in this chapter. Accordingly, the factors set forth in section 35-25(b) of this chapter shall be considered in making a determination of job-relatedness; to this regard, however, it shall be the applicant's responsibility to secure and provide proof that he has otherwise maintained a record of steady employment and good conduct, that he has supported his dependents, and that he has paid all outstanding court costs, supervision fees, fines and restitution as may have been ordered in all criminal cases in which he has been convicted. 
(Code 1971, § 35-43; Ord. No. 318-M, § 35-43, 2-9-1993; Ord. No. 318-N, § 35-43, 11-16-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-43, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-43, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-43, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-43, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-154. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, adopted May 17, 2005, repealed § 106-154, which pertained to orientation class and derived from Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-43.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2001-318-FF, § 1, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-43.1, 3-4-2003. 
Sec. 106-155. - Photographs and thumbprint required. 
    Each applicant for a city chauffeur's license shall submit three passport size photographs of himself to the chief of police and shall submit himself to a thumbprint for identification at the police department. 
(Code 1971, § 35-44; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-44, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-44, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-44, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-44, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-156. - Issuance or denial. 
    The chief of police, or his representative, upon consideration of the application and reports submitted under this article, the applicant's driving record and criminal record as reflecting his character, and the applicant's reputation in the community for character, shall issue the license or deny the application. If the application is denied, the applicant shall be notified in writing by the chief of police, or his representative, within five days that his application has been denied. 
(Code 1971, § 35-45; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-45, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-45, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-45, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-45, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-157. - Term; renewal. 
    A city chauffeur's license shall be issued for the calendar year and can be renewed before December 31st of each year by making application to the chief of police. If such renewal is not made by or on December 31 of any year, then the former permit holder must reapply to the chief of police as if he never held such a permit. 
(Code 1971, § 35-46; Ord. No. 318-N, § 35-46, 11-16-1993; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-46, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-46, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-46, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-46, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-158. - Suspension or revocation. 
    Except when specific provisions are prescribed for the suspension or revocation of a city chauffeur's license for violations of this article, the chief of police may suspend for a period not exceeding 15 days, or revoke the license of any taxicab driver for any violation of any of the sections of this article or upon conviction of any violation of the laws of the United States, the state or city ordinances involving moral turpitude or felony in this state or any other state or upon conviction for driving while intoxicated or habitual traffic violations of four or more in 12 months or seven in 24 months. In suspension or revocation for a license under any section of this article, the decision of the chief of police is subject to appeal to the city commission. This appeal procedure shall follow the same appeal measures as set out in other sections of this article 
(Code 1971, § 35-48; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-48, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-48, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-48, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-48, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-159. - Records to be kept. 
    The chief of police or his designee shall keep a permanent record of the applications, pictures, affidavits and medical reports on each taxicab driver licensed under this article and a record of the suspension or revocation of such licenses. These records may be examined by any person during the ordinary hours of business in the presence of the chief of police. 
(Code 1971, § 35-49; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-49, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-49, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-49, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-49, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Secs. 106-160-106-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DRIVERS 

Sec. 106-186. - Physician's certificate; medical examinations. 
    Each person under the age of 65 who is licensed to drive a taxicab shall have at all times on file in the office of the chief of police a certificate from a duly licensed physician, which certificate is not more than three years old, showing that such physician has examined such applicant and that such applicant is not disabled by reason of defective sight or hearing that such applicant is not crippled in any of his limbs and that he has no ailment which would prevent such applicant from safely operating a taxicab. Licensed taxicab drivers over the age of 65 must have physician's certificate to be no more than one year old for drivers 60 years of age or older. The chief of police shall have the authority to require a medical examination and the issuance of a certificate at any time that he sees fit by giving at least five-days' notice in writing to the licenses of such requirement. 
(Code 1971, § 35-50; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-50, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-50, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-50, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-50, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-187. - Limitation on hours of work. 
(a)  No taxicab driver shall drive more than 12 hours in any one consecutive twenty-four hour period. A violation of this subsection shall be cause for suspension of such driver's city chauffeur's license for a period of three days for the first offense, 15 days for the second offense, and for the third offense, his license may be revoked. 
(b)  No taxicab permittee shall allow any taxicab driver to drive a taxicab for more than 12 hours in any consecutive 24-hour period. A violation of this subsection shall be cause for suspension of such permittee's permit for the vehicle used in the violation for a period of three days for the first offense, 15 for the second offense, and for the third offense, such permit shall be revoked. 
(Code 1971, § 35-51; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-51, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-51, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-51, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-51, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-188. - Transporting passengers to designated point by most direct and shortest route. 
    Each driver of a taxicab in the city shall transport his passengers to definite points designated by the passengers, and he shall take the most direct and shortest route to deliver such passenger safely and expeditiously to his destination. 
(Code 1971, § 35-52; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-52, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-52, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-52, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-52, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-189. - Loading and unloading passengers. 
    It shall be the duty of each taxicab driver to pull his vehicle to the curb when loading or unloading passengers. 
(Code 1971, § 35-53; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-53, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-53, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-53, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-53, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-190. - Refusal to discharge passengers at designated place. 
    No taxicab driver shall refuse to discharge a passenger at any place designated by the passenger upon the street of the city, except when the place so designated is at a point not easily accessible by reason of an obstruction, a no-parking zone, or conditions rendering the designated place or access to such designated place unreasonably hazardous. 
(Code 1971, § 35-54; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-54, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-54, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-54, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-54, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-191. - Trip manifest. 
    Every taxicab driver on every shift shall make and sign a manifest showing a description of each trip by origin and destination, the number of passengers handled, and the amount of money collected or charged for each trip. The manifest shall also show for each day the number of trips, as shown by the taximeter, the number of flat rates charged, the taxicab number, the name of the driver and the date. Every taxicab driver must maintain the trip manifests for a period of 30 days; and every taxicab company must maintain a copy of the dispatcher log for a period of one year. Trip manifests shall be made available at the request of the chief of police, for his review and inspection. A violation of this section shall be cause for suspension of the violator's city chauffeur's license for a period of three days for the first offense, 15 days for the second offense, and for the third offense his license may be revoked. 
(Code 1971, § 35-55; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-55, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-55, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-55, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-55, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-192. - Leaving taxicab while waiting at depot, airport or hotel. 
    No taxicab driver shall leave his taxicab for any purpose, except in emergencies, while he is waiting at a depot, airport or hotel. A violation of this section shall be cause for suspension of the violator's city chauffeur's license for a period of two days for the first offense, 15 days for the second offense, and for the third offense his license may be revoked. This section does not prohibit the driver from assisting passengers in loading and unloading. 
(Code 1971, § 35-56; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-56, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-56, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-56, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-56, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-193. - Transportation of criminals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver or owner to knowingly transport any person committing a crime or infraction of the law in any manner. 
(Code 1971, § 35-57; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-57, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-57, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-57, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-57, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-194. - Acting on behalf of prostitutes or unlawful establishment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver or owner to act in any manner as a panderer or pimp for prostitutes or as contact for unlawful establishments of any character, or to knowingly transport any passenger to the abode of a prostitute. 
(Code 1971, § 35-58; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-58, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-58, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-58, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-58, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-195. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages in vehicle and at taxistands. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver or passenger of any taxicab to drink alcoholic beverages of any kind while inside a taxicab or for any person to drink at a taxicab stand. 
(Code 1971, § 35-59; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-59, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-59, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-59, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-59, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-196. - Smoking of tobacco products in vehicle and at taxistands. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver or passenger of any taxicab to smoke cigarettes, cigars, or any other tobacco products of any kind while inside a taxicab or for any person to smoke any of the aforementioned products while at a taxicab stand. 
(Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-59.1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-59.1, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-59.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-59.1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-197. - Inspect of vehicle; procedure when passengers leave article in cab. 
(a)  Each taxicab driver is required to inspect his taxicab before going on duty and after discharging each passenger to see that the cab is free of cigars, cigarettes, papers, bottles and anything that could cause offensive or objectionable odors. He is also required to check the trunk to see that no articles have been left in the trunk after each passenger reached his destination. If a passenger should leave any article in the taxicab, the taxicab dispatcher shall be notified immediately by the driver, and the drive shall immediately return the article to the owner, the company dispatcher or a company representative before making another trip. When a driver delivers such article to the owner or the dispatcher, a receipt for the article shall be prepared in triplicate. The original copy of the receipt shall be emailed to the chief of police, the second copy retained by the driver of the taxicab and the third copy shall be furnished the taxicab company. 
(b)  The permittee shall keep the article for a period of not more than ten days. If the owner of such article has not called for it within that period of time, the permittee shall deliver the lost article to the office of the chief of police. The chief of police shall give the permittee a receipt for such article giving a full description, shall make a record in a bound book for that purpose, and shall hold the article for a period of two years. At the end of the two-year period, if the chief of police shall not have delivered the article to its rightful owner, he shall dispose of such article as provided by law. 
(c)  If a driver of a taxicab shall fail to comply with this section, the chief of police shall suspend his city chauffeur's license for the third subsequent offense. The suspension or revocation of such driver's license does not in any manner relieve the driver of liability for civil or criminal actions. 
(Code 1971, § 35-60; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-60, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-60, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-60, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-60, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Secs. 106-198-106-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIMOUSINES AND TOURING VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-226. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Limousine. Any vehicle other than one rented without a driver, or a taxicab, or a touring vehicle or publicly franchised bus, used for the transportation of passengers for hire, other than for funeral service, not upon a fixed schedule or over a fixed route, the change for which is determined by the length of time for which the vehicle is engaged, the distance traveled, a fixed fee or any combination of such methods of determining such charge. 
    Touring vehicle. Any vehicle other than one rented without a driver, or a taxicab, or a limousine, or a publicly franchised bus, used for the transportation or passengers for hire for sightseeing or other purposes, other than for funeral services, the charge for which is determined by a length of time for which the vehicle is engaged, the distance traveled, a fixed fee, or any combination of such methods of determining such charge. 
(Code 1971, § 35-61; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-61, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-61, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-61, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-61, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-227. - Compliance with article required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any limousine or touring vehicle to be rented, hired or operated upon the city streets unless this article has first been complied with. 
(Code 1971, § 35-62; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-62, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-62, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-62, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-62, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-228. - Condition and inspection of vehicles. 
    Any and all limousines and touring vehicles must comply with and are subject to section 106-66 pertaining to condition and inspection of vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-63.2, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-63.2, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-63.2, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-63.2, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-229. - Charge for use of streets. 
    In addition to all other charges and payments, every person maintaining and operating within the city a limousine or touring vehicle shall pay the city for the use of the streets and other thoroughfares of the city, a fee of $10.00 per year. 
(Code 1971, § 35-65; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-65, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-65, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-65, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-65, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Secs. 106-230-106-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 106-256. - Required; application; fee. 
(a)  Every person desiring to engage in the business of operating any limousine or touring vehicle shall make application, in writing, to the chief of police on a form provided for that purpose for the required permit, which must be displayed on the rear window, specifying in which business the vehicle is engaged. 
(b)  Such application shall: 
(1)  Contain the name, address and telephone number of the applicant: 
(2)  Contain the number, type and seating capacity of each vehicle to be operated; 
(3)  Contain the true owner of the business; 
(4)  Be sworn to by the applicant and 
(5)  Be accompanied by a nonrefundable permit fee of $125.00 for each vehicle for which a permit is requested. 
(c)  If the state license number of any vehicle is changed during the permit period, such changed number shall be immediately reported to the chief of police. 
(Code 1971, § 35-63; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-63, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-63, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-63, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-63, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-257. - Number restricted; expiration for nonuse. 
(a)  The total number of limousine or touring vehicle permits that may be issued in the city is 15. 
(b)  If a permittee under this division fails to operate a limousine or touring business for a period of a year or more, the permit issued to such holder will expire. 
(Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-63.1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-63.1, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-63.1, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-63.1, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Sec. 106-258. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
(a)  The chief of police shall issue a limousine or touring vehicle permit to every applicant complying with this article and shall issue a permit for the operation of all vehicles complying with this article. No permit shall be issued unless every vehicle proposed to be used complies with the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Each vehicle shall comply with all the safety requirements imposed by all state, federal or local laws applicable to the vehicle involved. 
(2)  Each applicant shall procure and keep in full force and effect a policy of liability and property damage insurance issued by a casualty insurance company authorized to do business in the state and in the standard form required pursuant to the laws of the state, with insured, and the covered provision insuring the public from any laws or damage that may arise to any person or property because of the operation of a vehicle of such applicant and providing that such applicant and providing that the amount of recovery of each vehicle shall be in limits of not less than the following: 
a.  For damage arising out of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one accident; $20,000.00. 
b.  For damages arising out of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident; $40,000.00. 
c.  For injury to or destruction of property in any one accident; $15,000.00. 
d.  The owner shall have rendered each vehicle for which a permit is sought for ad valorem taxation and shall have paid all delinquent tax charges owned the city upon every such vehicle. 
(Code 1971, § 35-64; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-64, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-64, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-64, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-64, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Secs. 106-259-106-285. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PASSENGER BUSES 

Sec. 106-286. - Maximum passenger rating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator, or driver of any bus, under the provision of this article, to operate, or cause to be operated, upon any city street, any bus loaded with passengers in excess of the seating capacity rating of the bus, as established by the manufacturer, plus 75 percent of said seating capacity to be allowed as standing passengers. 
(Code 1971, § 35-66; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-66, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-66, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-66, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-66, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Secs. 106-287-106-315. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SPECIAL FUND ACCOUNT 

Sec. 106-316. - Taxicab revenue fund account. 
(a)  All revenues derived from permit fees, license fees, supervision and enforcement of this chapter are charged as police regulation as described in this section. 
(b)  Such revenue shall be deposited in the special fund account of the city under the subtitle account "taxicab revenue." Said funds shall be designated for the use of the police department for the purchase of necessary supplies and equipment to be used for administering said ordinance. It shall also be used to meet salaries, and/or wages, and other expenditures deemed necessary by the chief of police to maintain, supervise and enforce the taxicab ordinance, and related articles. 
(Code 1971, § 35-67; Ord. No. 98-318-AA, § 35-67, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 98-318-BB, § 35-67, 12-30-1998; Ord. No. 99-318-DD, § 35-67, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2003-318-GG, § 35-67, 3-4-2003; Ord. No. 2005-318-HH, 5-17-2005) 
Chapter 110 - WRECKERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-919-J, adopted Nov. 5, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 110, §§ 110-1-110-165, and enacted a new Ch. 110 as set out herein. The former Ch. 110 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1971, § 36-1-36-10, 36-12-36-33; Ord. No. 92-919-E, § 1, 4-21-1992; Ord. No. 92-919-F, §§ 1(36a-6), (36a-7), (36a-10), (36a-12), (36a-16), 2-2-1993; Ord. No. 2006-919-G, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 2008-919-H, § 1(App. A), 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 2012-919-I, App. A, 3-6-2012. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; vehicles for hire, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Wrecker service, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 643.201. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 110-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certificate means authorization granted by the city, under this chapter, to use a designated vehicle as a wrecker. 
    Manufacturer's certificate means a plate permanently affixed to either a truck, wrecker equipment (winch and boom), and a towing sling by the manufacturer of the equipment which states the vehicle's or equipment's gross poundage capacity. 
    Owner means any person who holds the legal title to a motor vehicle or who has the legal right of possession thereof or is the legally authorized agent of such person. This does not include any person who has gained possession of a motor vehicle only as a result of wrecker services performed. 
    Parking facility means any public or private property used, in whole or in part, for restricted and/or paid parking of vehicles. The term "parking facility" includes but is not limited to commercial parking lots, parking garages, and parking areas serving or adjacent to businesses, churches, schools, homes, and apartment complexes. The term "parking facility" also includes a restricted portion of an otherwise unrestricted parking facility. 
    Parking facility owner means any operator or owner, including lessee, employee or agent thereof, of a parking facility. 
    Pecuniary interest means money, property or commercial interests, the primary significance of which is economic gain. 
    Permit means authorization granted by the city under this chapter or any city ordinance to engage in the towing company/wrecker business in the city. 
    Permit holder means any person possessing a current, valid permit to engage in the towing company/wrecker business in the city. 
    Towing company/wrecker business means any person engaged in the business of towing vehicles on a public street in the city for compensation or with the expectation of any type of compensation for the towing, storage or repair of vehicles or acting as the towing agent for anyone having the expectation of receiving compensation for the towing, storage or repair of vehicles. The term "towing company/wrecker business" includes the owner, operator, employee or agent of a towing/wrecker business, but does not include the city. 
    Unauthorized vehicle means any vehicle parked, stored or situated in or on a parking facility without the consent of the parking facility owner. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway or street, including but not limited to motor vehicles, but not including devices moved only by human power or used exclusively on stationary rails or tracks. 
    Vehicle depository means the site to which a permit holder tows and stores vehicles. The site may consist of one lot or more, but all such lots must be a minimum of 6,000 square feet in size and enclosed by a fence of a least six feet in height, with three-strand barbed/razor wire; access shall be controlled in order to provide maximum security for stored vehicles. The parking area within the depository shall be stabilized to prevent growth of weeds and grass as a fire preventive measure and safety to personnel, with caliche, shale, rock, gravel or stabilizing materials, and within the depository no trees, brush or shrubs will be permitted. The depository entrance shall have a sign with letters and numbers at least three inches in height on a contrasting background indicating the location of the permittee's office and telephone numbers. 
    Wrecker means any motor vehicle equipped with hoisting apparatus used for the purpose of towing or removing wrecked or disabled vehicles or freeing vehicles. 
    Wrecker rotation lists means lists prepared in accordance with this chapter of wrecker companies which have requested and qualified to appear thereon and which maintain a certified wrecker of a capacity required to be on such list. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 110-2-110-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 110-31. - Administrative disposition of violations. 
    In lieu of or in addition to any criminal prosecution or civil remedy for the violation of any section of this chapter, the director of the department of traffic shall have, as to the holders of any permit or certificate or as to any applicant therefor, the duty and authority to enforce this chapter by administrative action in accordance with the following principles and procedures: 
(1)  The proper and safe functioning of the wrecker business has critical impact on the health, safety and welfare of the public. It involves use of the public streets of the city, often in circumstances that necessitate prompt removal of dangerous obstructions to traffic on such streets; therefore, the privilege of any person to engage in the wrecker business in the city shall be subject to strict regulation in order to protect the public. 
(2)  For purposes of invoking any administrative violation against a permit holder, the acts or omissions of any agent or employee of the permit holder shall be considered to be the acts or omissions of the holder. 
(3)  Administrative action which the director of the department of traffic may employ to enforce this chapter include but are not limited to the following: 
a.  Suspension or revocation of any certificate. This power includes the authority to remove or to cause to be removed any sticker or other evidence of a certificate from any wrecker. 
b.  Removal of a permit holder from the wrecker rotation list. 
c.  Suspension or revocation of any wrecker permit. 
(4)  The certificate for a wrecker may be suspended based upon the following conditions: 
a.  The wrecker is not covered by insurance as required; 
b.  It is in such condition that it cannot safely tow a vehicle; or 
c.  It does not presently meet all requirements of certification. 
(5)  Grounds for removal of a permit holder from any wrecker rotation list include the following: 
a.  Failure to meet at all times the requirements for a permit; 
b.  Failure to maintain at all times at least one wrecker in such condition that it meets the requirements for certification and for eligibility to be on a particular rotation list; 
c.  Driving any wrecker to or from the scene of a collision in a manner which endangers any person; 
d.  When the police communications center calls a particular permit holder pursuant to the wrecker rotation list procedure to perform certain wrecker service at a particular location, and a wrecker belonging to a permit holder not requested by the police communications center to perform such service is driven to and stops at the location, the permit holder owning that wrecker shall be subject to removal from the wrecker rotation list. If the permit holder who was called is shown to have called for another wrecker on his own to the location, the permit holder who was called by the police communications center shall be subject to removal from the wrecker rotation list; 
e.  Collecting or charging any fees or charges in excess of those set out in this chapter; or 
f.  Violation of the zoning ordinance in chapter 348 or the fire prevention ordinance in chapter 50 as determined by the director of building inspection department or the fire marshal, respectively, upon written communication to the director of the department of traffic of such determination. 
(6)  For justifiable reasons, if any permit holder on a wrecker rotation list is unable to answer within the proper time when called by the police communications center, the permit holder forfeits that call but is not subject to having his permits or certificates suspended or revoked for that reason. But, if it is apparent that this is occurring repeatedly (more than three times per month), consideration for removal from the wrecker rotation lists will be necessary. 
(7)  Grounds for suspension or revocation of a permit include the following: 
a.  Conduct in the wrecker business which endangers the life or safety of any person. 
b.  Repeated violations of this chapter, violation of the zoning ordinance in chapter 348 or fire prevention code in chapter 50 for one week after notice of the violation has been given to the wrecker business by a building inspector or the fire marshal, respectively. 
c.  Failure to maintain in effect any insurance required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-32. - Procedures; appeals. 
(a)  Suspension or revocation of any certificate, permit, or removal of a permit holder from a wrecker rotation list may be accomplished by the director of the department of traffic. The reasons for suspension or revocation of any certificate, permit, or removal of a permit holder from a wrecker rotation list shall be given in writing to the permit holder at least ten days prior to the suspension or revocation of any certificate, permit or removal of a permit holder from the wrecker rotation list. Mailing of such notice to the last known business address of the permit holder shall constitute sufficient notice. Appeal from a suspension or revocation of any certificate, permit, or removal of a permit holder from a wrecker rotation list by the director of the department of traffic shall be made in writing to the city manager within five working days of notice of such suspension or revocation of any certificate, permit, or removal of a permit holder from a wrecker rotation list. A hearing within ten days of such notice of appeal shall be held by the city manager unless continued at the request of the person filing the appeal; pending such appeal the suspension, revocation and/or removal from the rotation lists shall be held in abeyance. Written notice of the outcome of the hearing shall be given to the permit holder within five days of such hearing. 
(b)  If, after any certificate has been suspended or revoked, the condition for which it was suspended or revoked has been corrected, a new certificate shall be issued upon proper application, fee payment and proof of meeting all requirements therefor. 
(c)  If, after removal of a permit holder from a wrecker rotation list, application for reinstatement on such list has been made, the permit holder shall be reinstated after being removed for three rotation days if the condition for which the removal was accomplished has been corrected and if the director of the department of traffic has determined that the permit holder will properly perform thereafter. However, upon the second such removal within a four-month period, no reinstatement shall be had until at least seven rotation days after the removal, and upon the third removal within a 12-month period, no reinstatement shall be had until 14 rotation days after the third removal. Repeated violations shall be grounds for declining to reinstate any company to the wrecker rotation list. 
(d)  If a permit holder's permit is revoked, no permit shall be given to that holder for a period of at least six months from the date of revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-33. - Fines, offenses and penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any holder of a permit under this chapter to store any vehicles on the public streets or rights-of-way. 
(b)  Except in the conduct of intercity towing where there is no involvement with the police communications center, it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in a wrecker or towing business in the city unless such person possesses a current, valid permit. 
(c)  Except in the conduct of intercity towing where there is no involvement with the police communications center, it shall be unlawful to drive or to cause to be driven, in the wrecker business as a wrecker, any vehicle for which no certification has been issued. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a police officer investigating or present at the scene of any wreck or collision to directly or indirectly recommend to any person the name of any towing company/wrecker business, auto repair shop or automobile dealer engaged in the towing company/wrecker business; nor shall any such police officer influence or attempt to influence in any manner the decision of any person in choosing or selecting a towing company/wrecker business, auto repair shop, or automobile dealer. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any permit holder or employee of a permit holder to knowingly or intentionally charge or attempt to charge more for any wrecker service than the maximum charge set forth in this chapter or to charge or attempt to charge any fee not specifically authorized by this chapter for any service covered under this chapter. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person driving a certified wrecker to drive such wrecker without the wrecker having the name of the permit holder, to which it is exclusively registered, prominently displayed on the wrecker. At a minimum, such name shall appear in clearly legible letters at least three inches high, which are permanently painted on the vehicle on a contrasting background. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any permit holder or employee of a permit holder to solicit in any manner, directly or indirectly, on the city streets towing company/wrecker business involving any vehicle which is either wrecked on a public street or detained on a public street by a police officer. 
(h)  Violators of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in Section 1-13. In addition, the city attorney is authorized to file suit in any court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin any person from violating or causing to be violated any of the subsections of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-34. - Rights of owner of stored vehicle. 
(a)  Right to hearing. If a vehicle has been moved and placed in a vehicle storage facility without the consent of the owner, the owner is entitled to a hearing to determine whether or not probable cause existed for the removal and placement of the vehicle. A hearing under this section shall be before a city magistrate in whose jurisdiction the vehicle storage facility is located. 
(b)  Request. The request for the hearing shall be made as follows: 
(1)  A person entitled to a hearing under this section must deliver a written request for the hearing to the court before the sixth day after the date the vehicle was placed in the vehicle storage facility. In computing time under this subsection, Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays are excluded. A person who fails to deliver the request within the specified time period waives the right to the hearing. 
(2)  A written notice under this subsection must contain the following information: 
a.  The name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the vehicle; 
b.  The date and location from which the vehicle was removed; 
c.  The name, address, and telephone number of the person or law enforcement agency who authorized the removal; and 
d.  The name, address, and telephone number of the vehicle storage facility where the vehicle was placed. 
(c)  Hearing. Procedures for the hearing are as follows: 
(1)  A hearing under this section shall be held before the fourth working day after the date the request for the hearing was received by the court. 
(2)  The court shall notify the vehicle's owner and the person or law enforcement agency that authorized the removal of the vehicle of the date, time, and place of the hearing. 
(3)  The court may charge a filing fee of $50.00 for a hearing under this section and may award court costs to the prevailing party. 
(4)  The sole issue in a hearing under this section is whether probable cause existed for the removal and placement of the vehicle. 
(5)  The court shall make written findings of fact and a conclusion of law regarding the issue in the hearing. 
(d)  Payment of storage costs. Payment of storage costs shall be in accordance with the following: 
(1)  If the court determines that probable cause existed for the removal and placement of the vehicle, the owner of the vehicle shall pay the costs of removing and storing the vehicle. 
(2)  If the court does not determine that probable cause existed for the removal and placement of the vehicle, the person or law enforcement agency who authorized the removal shall pay the costs of removing and storing the vehicle. If the vehicle's owner paid removal and storage costs before the hearing, the person or law enforcement agency shall fully reimburse the owner. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 110-35-110-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS 

Sec. 110-60. - Persons eligible. 
(a)  No permits shall be issued to any applicant unless the applicant's vehicle depository is located within the incorporated limits of the city or in the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city as defined in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 242.001. If such vehicle depository is not owned by the permit holder, then the permit holder shall demonstrate its right of use of such depository by filing with the director of the department of traffic a copy of a written agreement with the owner of such premises permitting such use by the permit holder. 
(b)  No permit shall be granted to any person who had a pecuniary interest in a towing company/wrecker business permit which has been revoked within the preceding six months; nor shall a permit be granted to any entity in which such a person has a pecuniary interest. 
(c)  No permit shall be granted to any person who, during the preceding six months, as the employee of another, was directly responsible for any action resulting in the revocation of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-61. - Classes. 
    There shall be two classes of permits to engage in the towing company/wrecker business as follows: 
(1)  Class I, collision hauling (light-duty) which shall entitle the holder to tow vehicles away from the scene of a collision and to be listed on the appropriate police department collision wrecker rotation list. 
(2)  Class II, collision hauling (heavy-duty) which shall entitle the holder to tow vehicles away from the scene of a collision and be listed on the police department heavy-duty wrecker rotation list. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-62. - Application. 
    An applicant for a permit required under this article shall submit, on a form provided by the director of the department of traffic, a verified application containing or accompanied by the following: 
(1)  The true name, the trade name, the address and telephone number of the towing company/wrecker business. 
(2)  The number, types and manufacturer's rating of wreckers proposed to be operated. 
(3)  The true name, address and telephone number of the owner of the towing company/wrecker business to be operated under the permit. If the towing company/wrecker business is owned by a corporation, the true names of the registered agents, directors and officers of the corporation; if any stockholder of the towing company/wrecker business is itself a corporation, the true name of this stockholding corporation, its registered agents, directors, and officers of the one or more corporations must be given on the permit application. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-63. - Procedure. 
    The director of the department of traffic shall issue a permit in the name of the towing company/wrecker business to all applicants complying with this article upon proper approval from the city commission as follows: 
(1)  Upon receipt of the application, the director of the department of traffic shall cause a public hearing to be scheduled within a period not to exceed 30 days with the city commission and at that hearing present the application with copies of all materials required by section 110-62. 
(2)  Upon conclusion of the public hearing, the city commission shall advise the applicant as to the approval or disapproval of the application based on the doctrine of public convenience and necessity and all relevant laws. 
(3)  If approved, the director of the department of traffic shall issue a permit to such company and begin inspection of wreckers so that, upon compliance with section 110-62, each wrecker passing inspection shall be certified in the proper class size. 
(4)  The penalty provision in section 110-33(b) is applicable to this section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-64. - Term, renewal and fees. 
    The permit issued pursuant to this article will run from January 1 to December 31, and the annual fee for each permit holder shall be $325.00. The fee for any permit which is filed by an applicant after June 30 shall be one-half of the normal fee. Any permit will be renewable 30 days before expiration at the end of each year or any reasonable time thereafter upon payment of the applicable annual fee and the execution of a verified statement that the information on the original permit or application continues to be valid, and it meets all the requirements of this chapter. If any of the information is no longer valid, the permit or certificate holder must present the corrected information appropriately sworn to at the time of renewal of the permit or certificate. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-65. - Minimum number of vehicles per business; location; one company per business location. 
(a)  Each person holding a permit under this article shall have exclusively registered to it at least one wrecker. Such wrecker must be based primarily at his business location within the city limits or in the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction as defined in V.T.C.A. Local Governmental Code § 42.001. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for more than one permitted wrecker company to operate a wrecker business or storage facility at the same business address and/or location whether or not both companies are owned by the same person. Any violation of this section shall be punishable under section 110-33. Two or more permitted wrecker companies in operation at the same business address prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives are exempted from this section. Any such permit holder who has the permit suspended or revoked by the director of the department of traffic after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives may not resume operation after the term of the suspension or the re-issue of a permit at a business address or location being utilized by any other permit holder, whether or not both companies are owned by the same person. Each auto wrecker permit holder may operate only those auto wreckers that are registered under the wrecker permit number in response to any call for service from the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-66. - Display of name of permit holder. 
(a)  Each certified wrecker shall have the name of the permit holder to which it is exclusively registered prominently displayed on the wrecker. At a minimum, such name shall appear in clearly legible letters at least three inches high, which are permanently painted on the vehicle on a contrasting background. 
(b)  A permit, when granted, shall be prominently displayed at the permit holder's place of business and shall be no smaller than 81/2 inches by 11 inches and shall be supplied by the director of the department of traffic. 
(c)  The penalty provision in subsection 110-33(f) is applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-67. - Duty of permit holder to provide safe, efficient service. 
(a)  It shall be the obligation of every permit holder under this article to operate the towing company/wrecker business so as to provide safe and prompt removal of wrecked or disabled vehicles from the public streets when properly called upon to do so in accordance with this chapter. 
(b)  The duty to provide safe and prompt wrecker service upon call includes but is not limited to the following specific duty: 
(1)  Upon receiving a call from the police communications center, code enforcement division, and any other city department, in need of wrecker towing service by the use of one of the wrecker rotation lists, the permit holder shall, in accordance with this chapter, dispatch the requested class of wrecker to the desired location. 
(2)  Towing company/wrecker business personnel of a permit holder who hauls any vehicle from the scene of a collision within the city limits shall remove the debris of the collision from the public streets. This duty specifically includes removal of broken glass and metal fragments from the street and the removal of any load of any vehicle from the traveled portion of the street, so as to eliminate any hazard to vehicular traffic. This does not include the responsibility to unload cargo from the wrecked vehicle in order to permit hauling. Such debris should be disposed of in a manner which will keep it out of gutters, storm sewers, streams, public rights-of-way, and property not belonging to the towing company/wrecker business, without the consent of the property owner. The police officer on the scene of the accident may provide assistance in locating a place for disposal of such debris. 
(3)  Any permit holder on the wrecker request list or a wrecker rotation list must tow or have towed the damaged vehicle to a repair shop or to a place designated by the owner. If the towing services are to be performed when the repair shop or other designated place is not open for business, charges may be made by the permit holder to store the vehicle until the tow is completed at the earliest possible time to the designated place. 
(4)  Each permit holder shall maintain adequate records for the operation of his vehicle depository to include at least a numbered statement system in which carbon or other copies are made and a statement or copy thereof offered to the vehicle owner at the time he redeems the vehicle. Such statement must include at least the following information: 
a.  The nature and amount of the specific charges and total of all charges made. 
b.  The date, time, and street address of the origin of the tow. 
c.  The name of the permit older. 
d.  The name of the wrecker driver. 
e.  The license number, color, make and model of the towed vehicle. 
(5)  A permit holder shall not request the owner of a vehicle removed to the permittee's vehicle depository to sign a release from liability for damages unless and until the owner has inspected or has been given the opportunity to inspect the vehicle. 
(c)  The penalty provision in subsection 110-33(a) is applicable. 
(Ord.  No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-68. - Insurance. 
    All current classes of wrecker permit holders and any renewal by all classes of permit holders shall carry public liability and property damage insurance in the following minimum amounts: 
(1)  For damages arising out of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one collision, for damage arising out of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one collision, and for damage to or destruction of property in any one collision, $500,000.00. 
(2)  A certificate of general garage liability (broad form property damage) to cover any damage or theft to any vehicle stored within the permittee's vehicle depository. This coverage will be in the minimum amount of $25,000.00. 
(3)  A certificate of cargo insurance to cover damage to a towed vehicle during hookup and/or towing in the minimum amount of $25,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 110-69-110-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CERTIFICATION OF WRECKERS 

Sec. 110-96. - Request. 
    Any permit holder desiring that a specified vehicle, owned or leased by the permit holder, be certified as a wrecker shall: 
(1)  Submit a request for certification on a form provided by the director of the department of traffic. 
(2)  Submit a verified statement that the vehicle is owned or leased by the permit holder and primarily based at a business location within the city; any vehicle not meeting these requirements shall not be so certified. 
(3)  Submit or exhibit the manufacturer's certificate for each vehicle for which certification is sought in the class I category. 
(4)  Submit a certificate that each proposed vehicle is insured as per the appropriate requirements of this chapter. 
(5)  Submit a certificate or verify in writing that no city taxes are presently due on any vehicle for which certification is sought. 
(6)  Submit each vehicle for inspection by the director of the department of traffic. 
(7)  Submit a verified statement that the applicant will operate a 24-hour wrecker service if the application is for a class I or II permit. 
(8)  Pay a fee of $200.00 per vehicle for which certification is sought as a designated wrecker. This is an annual charge for as long as the designated vehicle is maintained as a wrecker under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-97. - Vehicle categories and requirements. 
(a)  A vehicle used as a wrecker shall be certified as either class I or class II. 
(b)  A class I wrecker shall: 
(1)  Be in such condition that it can safely and reliably be used as a wrecker and be no less than one ton in capacity. 
(2)  Be equipped with a power-operated winch, winch line, and boom, with a related lifting capacity of not less than 6,000 pounds single line capacity, as reflected on the manufacturer's certificate. 
(3)  Carry as standard equipment the following: tow sling with manufacturer's rated capacity of at least 3,000 pounds, two safety chains, one set of "J" hooks and chains, one "T" hook and grab hook on both sets of chains and one five-pound ABC fire extinguisher. Wreckers certificated to be used for hauls for which class I or II permits are required shall also carry as standard equipment a dust pan, wrecker bar, broom, axe, one pair of scotch blocks and a set of dollies. 
(4)  Be equipped with operable booster brakes. 
(5)  Be equipped with amber rotating emergency lights. The use of red, blue and white emergency rotating lights is prohibited. 
(c)  A class II wrecker shall: 
(1)  Not be less than five tons (minimum 22,500 pounds gross vehicle weight) in capacity. 
(2)  Be in such condition that it can safely and reliably be used as a wrecker. 
(3)  Be equipped with a power-operated winch, winch line and boom, with a rated or tested lifting capacity of not less than 30,000 pounds single or double line capacity, as reflected on the manufacturer's certificate. In the absence of a manufacturer's certificate concerning the capacity of the wrecker bed, winch line, or boom, the director of the department of traffic shall test such bed, winch line, or boom at the time of issuance of the certificate for such wrecker and at the time of each certificate renewal thereafter to determine if each meets the requirements stated in this subsection. 
(4)  Carry as standard equipment at least one of each of the following: tow bar, two safety chains, five-pound ABC fire extinguisher, dust pan, wrecker bar, broom and axe, one set of hook-up chains, and one pair of scotch blocks. 
(5)  Be equipped with operable booster brakes. 
(6)  Be equipped with amber rotating emergency lights. The use of red, blue and white rotating lights is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-98. - Display. 
    A certificate issued pursuant to this article shall be evidenced by a windshield sticker supplied and affixed to the wrecker by the director of the department of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-99. - Exemption. 
    In the conduct of intercity towing, where there is no involvement with the police communications center, equipment other than a wrecker certified under this article may be employed to remove vehicles from or to transport on the public right-of-way, except the following: 
(1)  Any vehicle, equipment, structure or other object which is of such size, weight or nature that is beyond the towing capacity of a wrecker meeting the standards for class II wreckers as set forth in this article; or its size or shape make it impractical or unsafe to transport. 
(2)  Any motorcycle, motor scooter, motorbike, motor-assisted bicycle or similar vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 110-100-110-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ROTATION LISTS 

Sec. 110-126. - Rotation lists and systems. 
(a)  The director of the department of traffic shall establish two wrecker rotation lists and shall be responsible for seeing that both lists are correct and are forwarded to the chief of police as necessary. The lists are as follows: 
(1)  A class I wrecker rotation list, composed of the names of all entities having a class I wrecker registered to them. 
(2)  A class II wrecker rotation list, composed of the names of all entities having a heavy-duty wrecker registered to them, which wrecker is operated by a class II permit holder. 
(b)  Class I wrecker rotation list; shall have no more than 16 wreckers. As wreckers are retired from such list, new wreckers shall be added from a waiting list when the number on the rotation list falls below 12. 
(c)  The director of the department of traffic shall issue a wrecker rotation permit in the name of the towing company/wrecker business in addition to applicants complying with this article. 
(d)  The wrecker rotation permit will run from January 1 to December 31 and the annual fee for each rotation permit shall be: 
(1)  Wrecker rotation fee per wrecker company ..... $50.00. 
(2)  Wrecker and vehicle depository inspection fee per Wrecker Company per year ..... $25.00. 
(3)  Fee for each re-inspection if they fail to pass inspection the first time ..... $15.00. 
The fee for any permit for which an application is filed after June 30 shall be one-half of the annual fee. 
(e)  A permit holder is qualified to be on such list if: 
(1)  He or she maintains 24-hour wrecker service and has a telephone number, which number can be answered 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 
(2)  He or she meets all other requirements of this chapter. 
(3)  He or she can respond within 20 minutes for a class I wrecker and 30 minutes for a Class II Wrecker to a call from the police department. 
(4)  The number on the list drops below ten and such holder is at the top of the waiting list. 
(f)  Each permit holder will be scheduled for a complete 24-hour period beginning at 7:00 a.m. on the assigned day. At the conclusion of that time period, the next permit holder on the list will be scheduled for service. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-127. - Operation and use of lists; fees. 
(a)  When a police officer investigating a collision determines that any vehicle involved in such collision is unable to safely proceed under its own power or when such police officer determines that the driver of any vehicle involved in such collision is physically unable to safely move the vehicle to a location where it will not create a traffic hazard, or violate Occupations Code Sec. 2308.252. Removal and Storage of Unauthorized Vehicles, pertaining to private parking, such officer shall request the driver to designate either the towing company/wrecker business, automotive repair shop, automobile club or automobile dealer which he desires to remove the vehicle in accordance with the following: 
(1)  When the designation has been properly made, the police officer shall communicate the name of the designated towing company/wrecker business, automotive repair shop, automobile club or automobile dealer, and class of wrecker required to the police communications center. 
(2)  The police communications center shall cause the designated towing company/wrecker business, automotive repair shop, automobile club or automobile dealer to be called and directed to send to the scene of the collision a certified wrecker registered to his company of the class required to move the appropriate vehicle. 
(3)  If the designated towing company/wrecker business, automotive repair shop, automobile club or automobile dealer is not a class I or II holder or does not have available a certified wrecker of the required class, the driver will be requested to make another designation. 
(b)  If the owner of a vehicle involved in a collision is physically unable to designate the towing company/wrecker business, automotive repair shop, automobile club or automobile dealer he desires to remove the vehicle, or fails or refuses to designate one or has no preference, the police officer shall communicate that fact immediately to the police communications center in accordance with the following: 
(1)  The police communications center shall call the name next in line on the appropriate wrecker rotation list and request the permit holder to tow the vehicle from the scene of the accident. 
(c)  Should the permit holder be called pursuant to subsection (a) or (b) of this section and refuse or be unable to send a wrecker or store the vehicle, the succeeding name shall be called in order of its appearance on the list until a permit holder agrees to send a certified wrecker; after the last name on such list has been called, the next such call shall go to the first name on the list. 
(d)  If the permit holder, after arrival at the scene, determines, in conjunction with the police officer in charge, that an additional wrecker is needed, the police officer in charge will immediately communicate to the police communications center that an additional wrecker is to be summoned to the scene, and the police communications center shall proceed under section 110-126. 
(e)  Failure of any permit holder selected under subsection (a) or (b) of this section to deliver a wrecker of the class required to the scene within 20 minutes of notification for a class I wrecker and 30 minutes for a class II wrecker without justification acceptable to the police communications center shall cause the permittee to forfeit the call. If selection of the permit holder occurred under subsection (a) of this section, the police communications center shall proceed as it would under subsection (a)(3) of this section, so notifying the requesting police officer. 
(f)  A police officer at his or her discretion can cancel a wrecker prior to arrival. 
(g)  If the driver makes his own arrangements to transport his vehicle, it must be moved immediately from the public street with all debris being picked up. The vehicle must be removed from the adjacent area within an hour. 
(h)  Only the maximum rates established in this article may be charged by permit holders for the use of the class of wrecker designated. 
(i)  The penalty provisions in subsections 110-33(d) and (e) are applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-128. - Rates and charges generally. 
    The maximum fees in this section may be charged by permit holders under this chapter for the uses of a wrecker, when the request is made to have a vehicle towed from the scene of a collision where the request is made, either through the police communications center, or by any person when the request concerns a motor vehicle involved in collision, and in this event no other additional charges may be made. A review of fees and charges will be made periodically after the majority of wrecker owner's petition for such a request to the city manager. The fees and charges shall be as follows: 
(1)  Between the hours from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, except legal holidays: 
a.  Any vehicle up to but not including a 21/2-ton bobtail truck: 
1.  Collision haul ..... $115.00 
2.  Each hour, not to include the first hour, spent by each wrecker at the scene where the vehicle is picked up, same time spent due to the nature of the particular type of haul ..... $ 35.00 
3.  Use of dollies ..... $ 35.00 
4.  Use of additional wrecker due to particular type of haul ..... $ 35.00 
5.  Removal of waste or debris generated by the collision, not including the first hour ..... $ 25.00 
6.  Storage of towed vehicles, per day (no charge if vehicle is stored for less than 24 hours) ..... $ 20.00 
7.  Preservation of a stored motor vehicle (one time only) ..... $ 10.00 
8.  Impoundment fee ..... $ 20.00 
b.  Two and one-half ton trucks to tractor-trailer: 
1.  Collision haul, 21/2 ton trucks ..... $115.00 
2.  Each hour, not to include the first hour, spent by each wrecker at the scene where the vehicle is picked up, same time spent due to the nature of the particular type of haul, 21/2 ton trucks ..... $115.00 
3.  Use of additional wrecker due to particular type of haul, 21/2 ton trucks ..... $115.00 
4.  Removal of waste or debris generated by the collision, not including the first hour ..... $ 25.00 
5.  Preservation of a stored motor vehicle ..... $ 10.00 
c.  Eighteen-wheel tractor-trailer: 
1.  Collision haul 18-wheel tractor-trailer and use of additional wrecker due to particular type of haul, 18-wheel tractor-trailer ..... $425.00 
2.  Removal of waste or debris generated by the collision, not including the first hour (per hour) ..... $ 50.00 
3.  Storage of towed 18-wheel tractor-trailer, per day (if longer than 25 feet) ..... $ 35.00 
4.  Preservation of a stored motor vehicle ..... $ 10.00 
5.  Impoundment fee ..... $ 20.00 
(2)  Between the hours from 6:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. and all day Saturday and Sunday and legal holidays: 
a.  Any vehicle up to but not including 21/2 ton bobtail trucks: 
1.  Collision haul ..... $115.00
