2.  Each hour, not to include the first hour, spent by each wrecker at the scene where the vehicle is picked up, same time spent due to the nature of the particular type of haul ..... $ 50.00 
3.  Use of dollies ..... $ 35.00 
4.  Removal of waste debris generated by the collision, not including the first hour ..... $ 25.00 
5.  Use of additional wrecker due to particular type of haul and/or circumstance ..... $ 50.00 
6.  Storage of towed vehicles, per day (no charge if vehicle is stored for less than 12 hours) ..... $ 10.00 
7.  Preservation of a stored motor vehicle (one time only) ..... $ 20.00 
8.  Preservation fee ..... $ 20.00 
b.  Two and one-half ton truck to tractor-trailers: 
1.  Collision haul, 21/2 ton trucks ..... $115.00 
2.  Each hour, not to include the first hour, spent by each wrecker at the scene where the vehicle is picked up, same time spent due to the nature of the particular type of haul, 21/2 ton trucks ..... $115.00 
3.  Use of additional wrecker due to particular type of haul, 21/2 ton trucks ..... $115.00 
4.  Removal of waste or debris generated by the collision, not including the first hour ..... $ 25.00 
5.  Storage of towed 21/2 ton trucks, per day (12 hours or more; per unit) ..... $ 35.00 
6.  Preservation of a stored motor vehicle ..... $ 10.00 
(3)  Labor fees: 
a.  Rollover vehicle (any type), maximum ..... $250.00 
b.  Winch ..... $150.00 
c.  Vehicle in ditch, maximum ..... $250.00 
d.  Waiting time (J.P.), per hour ..... $50.00 
e.  Labor (miscellaneous), (take pictures, if possible) ..... $150.00 up to $250.00 maximum 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-129. - Soliciting business on city streets. 
(a)  No wrecker permit holder, or employee of a permit holder, shall solicit in any manner, directly or indirectly, on the city streets, towing company/wrecker business involving any vehicle which is wrecked on a public street. This prohibition applies regardless of whether the solicitation is for the purpose of soliciting the business of towing, removing, repairing, wrecking, storing, trading or purchasing such vehicle. 
(b)  The penalty provision in subsection 110-33(g) is applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-130. - Tenure of vehicles, company uniforms. 
    No wrecker should be older than 12 years old or the director of traffic may extend a wrecker by its condition not to exceed more than five years. All wrecker employees must wear company uniforms. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Secs. 110-131-110-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - LICENSE TO OPERATE VEHICLE DEPOSITORY 

Sec. 110-156. - Exception. 
    This article does not apply to a vehicle parked or stored at a vehicle depository with the consent of the vehicle's owner. This article does not apply to a vehicle depository operated by a person licensed pursuant to state law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-157. - Authority. 
(a)  The director of the department of traffic is authorized to issue licenses to operate vehicle depositories. 
(b)  The director of the department of traffic shall adopt rules establishing requirements for the licensing of persons to operate vehicle depositories to ensure that vehicle depositories maintain adequate standards for the care of stored vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-158. - Prohibition. 
    A person may not operate a vehicle depository unless the person holds a current license to operate a vehicle depository issued to the person by the director of the department of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-159. - Application. 
(a)  The director of the department of traffic by rule shall determine the types of information to be supplied on an application for a license under this article, but the rules must require that an application be made under oath, and list: 
(1)  Each conviction of a felony, or a misdemeanor for which the maximum punishment is by confinement in jail or by a fine exceeding $200.00, that was obtained against the applicant or a partner or officer of the applicant in the three years immediately preceding the date of the application; 
(2)  The name and address of each partner, if the applicant is a partnership; and 
(3)  The name and address of the president, secretary, and treasurer of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation. 
(c)  The application of a corporation must be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-160. - Approval. 
    The director of the department of traffic shall approve an application that is submitted as provided by section 110-159 for a license to operate a vehicle depository unless it is determined that: 
(1)  The applicant knowingly supplied false or incomplete information on the application; 
(2)  The applicant, one of the applicant's partners, or one of the applicant's officers has been convicted of a felony, or a misdemeanor for which the maximum punishment is by confinement in jail or by a fine exceeding $500.00, in the three years preceding the date of the application; or 
(3)  The vehicle depository for which the license is sought does not meet the standards for storage facilities established by the rules of the director of the department of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-161. - Notice of denial. 
    If the director of the department of traffic denies an application for a license under this article, the director of the department of traffic shall send written notice of his decision to the applicant, at the address shown on the application, by certified mail, return receipt requested. The notice shall state the reason for his decision and that the applicant is entitled to a hearing before the director of the department of traffic under section 110-164. The notice may state that the decision is temporary pending compliance by the applicant. If the decision is temporary and the applicant complies with the requirements of this article and rules of the director of the department of traffic before the 15th day after the date the applicant received the notice, the director of the department of traffic shall then approve the application. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-162. - Term; renewal. 
(a)  A license issued under this article expires on December 31 of the year in which it is issued. 
(b)  A person may apply to the director of the department of traffic to renew the license on an application form approved by the department. An application for renewal of a license must be accompanied by a fee of $100.00. 
(c)  If an application for renewal of a license is not submitted before the 31st day after the expiration date of the license, the license may not be renewed. 
(d)  A person whose license expires, and is not renewed under this section, may apply for a new license under section 110-159. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-163. - Revocation. 
(a)  The director of the department of traffic may revoke a license or deny an application to renew a license issued under this article if the department determines that: 
(1)  The licensee, one of the licensee's partners, or one of the licensee's officers has been convicted of a felony, or a misdemeanor for which the maximum punishment is by confinement in jail or by a fine exceeding $500.00, which directly relates to a duty or responsibility of an operator of a vehicle depository; 
(2)  The vehicle depository for which the license was issued does not meet a standard for a vehicle depository set by rules of the director of the department of traffic; or 
(3)  The licensee knowingly violated a rule of the director of the department of traffic or an employee of the licensee, with the licensee's knowledge, violated a rule of the director of the department of traffic. 
(b)  The director of the department of traffic shall send notice of the revocation or denial to the licensee by certified mail, return receipt requested, before the eighth day after the date of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-164. - Hearing on revocation or denial. 
(a)  A person whose application for a license to operate a vehicle depository has been denied, whose license has been revoked, or whose application to renew a license has been denied may, before the 15th day after the date the person receives notice of the revocation or denial, request in writing a hearing before the director of the department of traffic on the revocation or denial. 
(b)  A hearing under this section is an exhaustion of administrative remedies, and an appeal from a hearing is to the district court having jurisdiction over the applicant or licensee. Such appeal shall be within 15 days after the final decision of the director of the department of traffic is mailed to the licensee or applicant by mail, return receipt requested. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Sec. 110-165. - Validity. 
(a)  A license issued under this article is not valid for any person other than the person who applied for the license. 
(b)  A license issued under this article applies only to a single vehicle depository named on the license. 
(Ord. No. 2013-919-J, 11-5-2013) 
Subpart B - DEVELOPMENT CODE 
Chapter 300 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 30; code of ethics, ch. 38; library, ch. 62; municipal court, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 102; planning and development, ch. 320. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 4, adopted Oct. 30, 2007, renumbered the former §§ 320-1-320-5 as 300-1-300-5 as set out herein. The historical notations have been retained with the renumbered provisions. 

Sec. 300-1. - Applicability of article. 
    The sections of this article shall be applicable to every chapter in this development code. 
(Code 1971, § 26-1; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 4, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  In the construction of this development code and any subsequent amendments, the usages and definitions contained in this subsection shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
(1)  The term "section" shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "of the city Code." 
(2)  The term "article" shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "of this development code." 
(3)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense. The masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. Words used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural number shall include the singular. 
(4)  The term "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary; the term "may" is permissive. 
(5)  The term "lot" shall include the terms "parcel," "piece," and "plot." 
(6)  The term "building" shall include the term "structure" and shall include all other improvements of every kind, regardless of similarity to buildings. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "or part thereof." 
(7)  The term "used" or "occupied" shall include the term "arranged," "designed," "intended," "maintained," "occupied," or "used." 
(8)  The term "person" shall include a natural person; a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, foundation, company, or corporation; a nonprofit group; or an elected or appointed body; his, its, or their successors, assigns, heirs, executors, or administrators; or the agent of any of such. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this development code, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City Code means the Code of Ordinances of the city, including but not limited to the city Charter. 
    City manager means: 
(1)  The chief executive officer and head of the administrative branch of the city government; 
(2)  The acting city manager; or 
(3)  Any employee or administrative officer of the city to whom such chief executive officer or acting city manager shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
    Council means the city heritage council. 
    Development code means Subpart B of Part II of the Code of Ordinances, Brownsville, Texas. 
    Director means: 
(1)  The head or acting head of the city planning and community development department; or 
(2)  Any employee or administrative officer of the city to whom such head or acting head shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
    Extraterritorial jurisdiction means a geographic area identical to the extraterritorial jurisdiction defined by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 42. 
    Planning commission means the city planning and zoning commission. 
    Taxing unit means the county, an incorporated city or town including a home-rule city, a school district, a special district or authority, or any other political unit of this state, whether created by or pursuant to the constitution or a local, special, or general law, that is authorized to impose and is imposing ad valorem taxes on property. 
(Code 1971, § 26-3; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 4, 10-30-2007) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 300-3. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any person who fails to comply with or who violates any of the sections of this development code or any rules or permits issued under this development code or any conditions attached to such permits shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined for each offense. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any contrary provision in the city Charter, whenever in this development code an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor or wherever in this development code the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such section of this development code shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 for each offense nor more than the following: 
(1)  Two thousand dollars for each offense under a rule, ordinance, or police regulation that governs fire safety, zoning, or public health and sanitation, including dumping of refuse; or 
(2)  Five hundred dollars for each offense under any other rule, ordinance, or police regulation. 
(c)  Whenever state law conflicts with this section, state law shall govern. 
(d)  Each day of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(e)  Under no circumstances shall the imposition of any such fine for any violation constitute an estoppel for other relief against any such violation available at law. 
(f)  For each violation, the city shall issue a citation stating the alleged violation, the date of the violation, and the section of the Code violated. The municipal court shall have exclusive original jurisdiction over all such citations. 
(g)  The following persons shall each have independent authority to issue any such citation: 
(1)  City manager. 
(2)  Building official. 
(3)  City forester. 
(4)  City engineer. 
(5)  Greens division head. 
(6)  City code officer/inspector. 
(h)  If any such violation is designated as a nuisance under this development code, such nuisance may be summarily abated by the police department. 
(Code 1971, § 26-8; Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 4, 8-3-1999; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 4, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-4. - Amendments. 
(a)  The city commission may from time to time amend this development code by ordinance. 
(b)  Before enacting any ordinance that constitutes such an amendment, the city commission shall hold and close a public hearing thereon. The city manager shall cause notice of such hearing to be given in the manner specified by subsection (f) of this section. 
(c)  The initiator for any such amendment shall be limited to being either the city commission or the city manager. Any person may, by letter to the city manager, make a nonbinding request that one of the potential initiators cause such an amendment to be initiated. Only the initiator may cause a draft of such an amendment to be prepared. 
(d)  After such a draft has been prepared, the initiator may cause such draft either to be submitted to the planning commission for its nonbinding recommendation or to be submitted directly to the city commission without such recommendation. 
(e)  The planning commission shall make no recommendations on any such amendment, unless: 
(1)  The initiator has formally requested the planning commission's recommendation thereon; 
(2)  The planning commission's secretary has caused notice of the planning commission's public hearing thereon to be given in the manner specified by subsection (f) of this section and has caused copies of the complete text of such draft or amendment to be submitted to each member of the planning commission at least four working days before such hearing; and 
(3)  The planning commission has held and closed such hearing. 
(f)  Notice of a public hearing on such amendment or draft shall be given in a newspaper of general circulation in the city's territorial and extraterritorial jurisdiction at least ten days before the opening of such hearing. Such notice shall include the publication of a descriptive caption or title stating in summary the purpose of the amendment and the penalty for violation thereof. Such notice shall also state that such amendment or draft is available for public inspection, during normal working hours, commencing with the publication date of such notice. 
(Code 1971, § 26-9; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 4, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-5. - Interpretation of development code. 
(a)  In their interpretation and application, the sections of this development code shall be held to be minimum requirements. 
(b)  Whenever any section of this development code conflicts with any other section of this development code, the more restrictive provision shall govern, unless otherwise explicitly specified in this development code. 
(c)  Whenever any applicable section of this development code conflicts with any section of any other law that has been lawfully adopted by any political subdivision of the state or county, the more restrictive section shall govern. 
(d)  Whenever any applicable section of this development code conflicts with any rule or other policy adopted pursuant to authority delegated by this development code, the sections of this development code shall govern. 
(e)  Whenever the provisions of one policy lawfully adopted pursuant to authority delegated by this development code conflict with the provisions of another such policy, the provisions that govern shall be those that are adopted by the entity listed sooner on the following list: 
(1)  City commission. 
(2)  Planning commission. 
(3)  Heritage council. 
(4)  Public utilities board. 
(5)  Chief executive officer of the city. 
(6)  Heritage officer. 
(7)  Plat administrator. 
(8)  Other city employee. 
(9)  Relevant executing entity. 
(10)  Any other entity. 
(f)  If any section of this development code or the application of such section to a particular set of persons or circumstances should for any reason be held by the courts to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the remaining portions of this development code, and to such end each section of this development code is declared to be severable. 
(Code 1971, § 26-10; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 4, 10-30-2007) 
Secs. 300-6-300-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-311 et seq.; planning and development, ch. 320. 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et seq. 

Sec. 300-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Body means the city planning and zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-16(F)), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 98-1100.17, pt. 1, 1-7-1998; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 3, 10-30-2007) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 300-27. - Created. 
(a)  There is created a municipal planning commission under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 212. 
(b)  The municipal planning commission is appointed to serve as the comprehensive zoning commission under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 211. 
(c)  The comprehensive zoning commission is designated as the airport zoning commission under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 241. 
(d)  There is created a city planning and zoning commission consisting of the municipal planning commission and the comprehensive zoning commission and the airport zoning commission. 
(Code 1971, § 26-16; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-16(A)-(E)), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 98-1100.17, pt. 1, 1-7-1998; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 2, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-28. - Composition. 
    The body created under this article shall consist of seven regular members and one special member, for a total of eight members. 
(Code 1971, § 26-17; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-17), 1-26-1993) 
Sec. 300-29. - Qualifications of members. 
(a)  Each member of the body created under this article shall meet all of the following qualifications at all times: 
(1)  Possess an outstanding and unselfish interest in civic affairs. 
(2)  Comply with all laws applicable to a city officer. 
(3)  Comply with the conflict of interest provisions of both V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 171 and 212. 
(b)  Each member of the body shall meet all of the following additional requirements at all times: 
(1)  Reside inside this city's territorial jurisdiction, except one member shall reside in the city's extra-territorial jurisdiction. 
(2)  Comply with all laws applicable to a member of a deliberative, nonadvisory board. 
(Code 1971, § 26-18; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-18), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pts. 2, 3, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-30. - Appointment. 
    Any of the members of the city commission may make nominations for any vacant or expiring position on the body created under this article. The acts of nomination and appointment may be combined in a single motion and may be done at a single meeting. In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 395.058(b), members of the body shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city commission. 
(Code 1971, § 26-19; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-19), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 98-1100.18, pt. 1, 1-27-1998) 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning commission may act as capital improvements advisory committee, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 395.058. 
Sec. 300-31. - Terms. 
(a)  The term of office for each position on the body created under this article shall be three years, commencing on February 12. 
(b)  Regular members of the body shall be appointed to staggered terms in accordance with Ordinance Number 727. 
(Code 1971, § 26-20; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-20), 1-26-1993) 
Sec. 300-32. - Removal. 
    Any member of the body created under this article may be removed from office at any time by a majority vote of the city commission. 
(Code 1971, § 26-21; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-21), 1-26-1993) 
Sec. 300-33. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring in the membership of the body created under this article shall be filled for the unexpired term only and shall be processed in accordance with section 300-30. 
(Code 1971, § 26-22; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-22), 1-26-1993) 
Sec. 300-34. - Compensation. 
    The members of the body created under this article shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1971, § 26-23; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-23), 1-26-1993) 
Sec. 300-35. - Officers. 
    The city planning and zoning commission's regular members shall select from themselves a chair, vice-chair, and secretary. 
(Code 1971, § 26-24; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-24), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 2, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-36. - Authority. 
    The body created under this article shall have all the functions and duties outlined in and prescribed for such body by state law. 
(Code 1971, § 26-25; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-25), 1-26-1993) 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning commission, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et seq. 
Sec. 300-37. - Rules. 
    The city [planning and zoning] commission adopts rules for the efficient transaction of all its business. 
(Code 1971, § 26-26; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-26), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 3, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-38. - Meetings. 
    All members of the city planning and zoning commission shall be eligible to vote during commission meetings except for the special member. A quorum shall consist of four regular members. At least one meeting of the commission shall be held each month. The chair may call all additional meetings deemed necessary. Should a regular member of the commission fail to attend three consecutive regular monthly meetings of the commission, that member's office shall automatically be vacated and a vacancy declared in such member's office. 
(Code 1971, § 26-27; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-27), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 2, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 300-39. - Alternate. 
    Notwithstanding any other section of this article, the special member of the body created under this article shall temporarily have the same authority as a regular member of the body during the period of time when any regular member is not present and voting at a meeting of the body. 
(Code 1971, § 26-28; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-28), 1-26-1993; Ord. No. 98-1100.19, pt. 1, 1-27-1998) 
Sec. 300-40. - Expenditures restricted. 
    No expenditure shall be made by the body created under this article unless the expenditure shall have been submitted to and approved by the city commission. 
(Code 1971, § 26-29; Ord. No. 93-1100.16, pt. 1(26-29), 1-26-1993) 
Secs. 300-41-300-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CLASS PERMITS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Procedure for issuance of certain local permits, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 245.001 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 300-66. - Applicability. 
    This article shall be applicable to the entire city Code, except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(Code 1971, § 26-200) 
Sec. 300-67. - Intent. 
(a)  In addition to all other procedures and standards relating generally to the issuance of permits and certificates, a system of class permits is established. 
(b)  Such system is intended to: 
(1)  Require special examination, review, and findings by appropriate city entities in connection with certain proposed actions; 
(2)  Relate to use, occupancy, location, construction, design, character, color, scale, manner of operation, or the necessity for making complex or unusual determinations; 
(3)  Allow consideration of the particular circumstances of each case and the establishment of such conditions as are reasonably necessary for protection of the public interest generally and for protection of adjacent properties, the neighborhood, and the city as a whole; and 
(4)  Increase efficiency and reduce time required for processing applications by relating administrative responsibilities and procedural requirements to the degree of complexity and potential impact of the matters being considered. 
(c)  A permit is a grant of authority under the terms of the city Code from and by a designated city entity to an applicant for the use of property in the manner set out in the grant of such permit. Developments requiring a permit under this system and the specific class permit required in each instance are set out in the city Code. 
(d)  Several class permits are established, ranging from those dealing with substantial effects on neighborhoods of the city to those dealing with potentially temporary or small adverse impacts on adjacent or nearby properties. 
(e)  Procedures, standards, and determinations range accordingly from complex to simple. Formal public notice and hearing are only required for certain class permits. 
(f)  Specific class permits, their intent, the entity responsible for granting each, and any referrals thereunder are as summarized in section 300-68 and as detailed in division 2 of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 26-201) 
Sec. 300-68. - Summary of specific class permits. 
    Class W permit (zoning administrator). The summary for a class W permit is as follows: 
(1)  It is intended that class W permits be required when compliance with the zoning ordinance in chapter 348 needs to be monitored or checked more thoroughly than usual. 
(2)  The zoning administrator shall be solely responsible for determinations on applications for class W permits, under section 300-103. 
(3)  The zoning administrator may refer any such application to any entities, through the director, for nonbinding recommendations and findings on such application. 
(Code 1971, § 26-202; Ord. No. 99-1100.27, pt. 4, 6-1-1999) 
Sec. 300-69. - Sequence. 
(a)  Where permits or certificates are required by chapter 18, articles II through V, no such permit or certificate shall be issued where the city Code requires class permits unless and until any and all class permits required have been obtained. 
(b)  Where developments do not require permits or certificates under chapter 18, articles II through V, but are otherwise subject to requirements of the city Code, no such development shall be initiated or maintained unless and until any and all class permits required in relation thereto have been obtained. 
(Code 1971, § 26-203) 
Sec. 300-70. - Applications. 
(a)  Except when specifically set out otherwise in the city Code, applications for class permits shall be filed with the director. The director is charged with responsibility for their receipt, fee collection, processing, and/or distribution. 
(b)  For class permits affecting a property, applications may be filed only by the property owner, his formally designated agent, or a lessee with formal and legally sufficient consent of the property owner, and applications may be made only for class permits specifically authorized and/or required by the city Code. 
(c)  Applications for class permits shall be made on forms provided for the purpose and shall be accompanied by such plans, reports or other information, exhibits, or documents as may be reasonably required to make the necessary findings in the case. 
(d)  For purposes of establishing time limitations on processing, no application shall be deemed to have been filed unless and until: 
(1)  The applications shall have been completed; 
(2)  All plans, reports or other information, exhibits, or documents required by the city Code or administrative rules adopted pursuant thereto shall have been provided; and 
(3)  All fees due at time of filing shall have been paid. 
(e)  During processing of any application, if it is determined by the designated city entity that in the particular circumstances of the case additional information is required to make necessary findings bearing on its approval, denial, or conditions to be attached, such information may be requested. Failure to supply such supplementary information may be used as grounds for denial of the permit. 
(Code 1971, § 26-205) 
Sec. 300-71. - Standards. 
    As appropriate to the nature of the class permit involved and the particular circumstances of the case, the standards in this section shall apply generally, in addition to any other standards set forth concerning the class permit being considered. City entities charged with decisions concerning class permits shall make or cause to be made findings and determinations concerning such of the matters in this section as are applicable in the case; shall reflect such standards specifically in the record; and shall be guided by such standards in their decisions to grant, grant with conditions, or deny class permits. The standards are as follow: 
(1)  In addition to consideration of detailed elements indicated in this section, as appropriate to the specific class permit and the circumstances of the particular case, due consideration shall be given to potentially adverse effects generally on adjoining and nearby premises, the area, the neighborhood, or the city of the proposed use or its location, construction, design, character, color, scale, or manner of operation. Where such potentially adverse effects are found, consideration shall be given to special remedial measures appropriate in the particular circumstances of the case, including screening or buffering, landscaping, control of manner or hours of operation, alteration of proposed design or construction of buildings, relocation of proposed open space or alteration of use of such space, or such other measures as are required to ensure that such potential adverse effects will be eliminated or minimized to the maximum extent reasonably feasible and to ensure that the use will be compatible and harmonious with other development in the area to a degree which will avoid substantial depreciation of the value of nearby premises. 
(2)  Due consideration shall be given to the number, size, character, location, and orientation of proposed signs and of proposed lighting for signs or premises, with particular reference to traffic safety, glare, appearance, and compatibility and harmony with adjoining and nearby premises, the character of the area, and the function or value of nearby roads. 
(3)  Due consideration shall be given to utilities required, with particular reference to availability and capacity of systems, location of connections, and potentially adverse appearance or other adverse effects on adjoining and nearby premises and the character of the area. 
(4)  Due consideration shall be given to the location, scale, design, and screening of refuse and service areas; to the manner in which refuse is to be kept; and to the manner and timing of refuse collection and deliveries, shipments, or other service activities, as such matters relate to the location and nature of uses on adjoining premises and to the location and character of uses on adjoining premises and to the location and character of adjoining roads. 
(5)  Due consideration shall be given to adequacy of ingress to and egress from the premises, with particular reference to automotive and pedestrian safety and convenience, traffic flow and control, and access during a fire or other emergency. 
(6)  Due consideration shall be given to off-street parking and loading facilities as related to adjacent streets, with particular reference to automotive and pedestrian safety and convenience, internal traffic flow and control, arrangement in relation to access during a fire or other emergency, and screening and landscaping. 
(7)  Due consideration shall be given to provision for drainage, with particular reference to effects on adjoining and nearby premises and on general drainage systems in the area. Where major drainage volumes appear likely and capacity of available systems is found marginal or inadequate, consideration shall be given to possibilities for detention or other remedial measures. 
(Code 1971, § 26-206) 
Sec. 300-72. - Conditions. 
(a)  Each entity responsible for issuance or denial of a class permit established by this article shall have authority to attach to the grant of the class permit such conditions as may be necessary for the purposes of the city Code in the particular case. 
(b)  Any such attached conditions shall be based upon and consistent with standards applicable to the class permit involved as set out in section 300-71 and in other sections relating to the specific class permit. The attachment of any such conditions shall be supported by stated reasons therefor, based upon such standards. No such condition shall impose requirements beyond those reasonably necessary for the accomplishment of the purpose for which attached. 
(c)  Failure to comply with any such attached conditions shall be deemed a violation of the relevant parts of the city Code. 
(Code 1971, § 26-207) 
Sec. 300-73. - Devolution. 
    When granted, a class permit, together with any conditions attached thereto, shall apply to the premises or development for which it was issued and shall be binding upon heirs and assigns, unless abrogated or altered in the manner set forth in this article. 
(Code 1971, § 26-210) 
Sec. 300-74. - Appeals. 
    Each binding decision of the city commission relative to a class permit may be appealed directly to either the district court or county court at law in the county. The procedures governing such appeals shall be similar to the procedures described in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1011g(j)-(n), except that the city commission, instead of the board of adjustment, shall be the entity from which such appeals are taken. 
(Code 1971, § 26-212) 
Secs. 300-75-300-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPECIFIC CLASS PERMITS 

Sec. 300-101. - Class A permits; review authority. 
    For procedural purposes, class A permits are divided into two types as follows: 
(1)  Type A1. Class A permit. 
a.  Shall be all permits not considered a Type A2 class A permit. 
b.  The heritage council shall review Type A1 class A permits. 
(2)  Type A2. Class A permit (Routine maintenance and replacement). 
a.  This permit is for routine maintenance and replacement as defined in section 348-1520. Generally, this shall include: cleaning, painting, duplicating, stabilizing deteriorated or damaged architectural features and to slow deterioration. 
b.  The heritage review committee shall review Type A2 class A permits. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.27, pt. 3, 6-1-1999; Ord. No. 2006-1100.38, § 1, 8-15-2006) 
Sec. 300-102. - Class L permit. 
(a)  For procedural purposes, class L permits are divided into two types as follows: 
(1)  Class L permits shall be called class L1 permits if they are not heritage related. The review body for class L1 permits shall be the city commission. 
(2)  Class L permits shall be called class L2 permits if they are heritage related. The review body for class L2 permit shall be the heritage review committee. However, if the proposed development requires both a class A1 permit and a class L2 permit, the sole review body for such class permits shall be the heritage council. 
(3)  A class L permit shall be deemed to be heritage related if the site is inside any of the following areas: 
a.  Heritage screening area, as defined by section 18-120. 
b.  HD (heritage) overlay district, as shown on the official zoning atlas. 
c.  HL (landmark) overlay district, as shown on the official zoning atlas. 
d.  Downtown, as defined by section 348-2. 
e.  Mitte cultural district, as defined by Resolution No. 99-021. 
(4)  If a proposed development would have required both a class A permit and a class L permit, the class L permit shall not be required, but the class A permit shall be subject to all provisions applicable to class A permits and shall be subject to all provisions applicable to class L permits, except that the class A permit shall be voted on by the heritage council and shall not be voted on by the heritage review committee. 
(b)  Issuance, issuance with conditions attached, or denial of class L permits is governed by regulations applicable to class permits generally as set out in division 1 of this article, regulations set out in this section, and all other applicable regulations set out in the city Code. 
(c)  It is intended that class L permits be required where development is regulated under general criteria involving broad discretion or where development affects matters deemed to be of citywide or areawide importance. 
(d)  An application for a class L permit shall be filed at least seven calendar days before the review body meeting at which it shall be considered. 
(e)  The director shall submit the application and the director's recommendations thereon to the review body at or before such meeting. 
(f)  The review body shall hold a public hearing thereon before taking final action on the permit. Notice thereof shall be posted at City Hall and Market Square at least 72 hours before such hearing. Additional notice thereof shall be mailed by the heritage officer to the representative of each qualified neighborhood organization (QNO) under section 324-3, and each cultural district created by city commission resolution whose boundaries include or are within a radius of 300 feet from any property subject to such permit application. 
(g)  The review body shall take final action on the application promptly after closing the hearing thereon. Such hearing may be continued for not more than 35 calendar days when the review body deems it necessary to require additional information from the applicant or from referrals to other entities in order to have sufficient basis for taking final action. 
(h)  Applications for class L permits dealing solely with demolition or moving of buildings shall not be denied, but may be granted with reasonable conditions such as a delay of the demolition or moving for up to 60 days after final action by the review body on the class L permit. 
(i)  By paying an appeal fee of $50.00, any person may appeal only to the heritage council, or city commission, any binding decision of the heritage review committee related to a class L2 permit. The appeal shall be filed within 30 days of the decision being appealed. If the decision being appealed is a positive decision, the appeal shall be filed before the adjournment of the meeting at which such decision was made. At the public hearing on an appeal, the heritage review committee's recommendation shall be presented by the historic downtown district manager. All other procedures for processing the appeal shall be identical to the procedures for processing a class L1 permit. 
(Code 1971, § 26-232; Ord. No. 99-1100.27, pt. 1, 6-1-1999; Ord. No. 2000-1100.31, pt. 2, 12-19-2000; Ord. No. 2001-235.53, pt. 2, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 2006-1100.38, § 2, 8-15-2006) 
Sec. 300-103. - Class W permit. 
(a)  Applicable regulations. Issuance, issuance with conditions attached, or denial of class W permits is governed by regulations applicable to class permits generally as set out in division 1 of this article, regulations set out in this section, and all other applicable regulations set out in this Code. 
(b)  Fee. Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, a fee in the amount of $10.00 shall be paid into the general fund of the city for each application for a class W permit. 
(c)  Application for wet restaurant. If the application is for a wet restaurant, other than a nonconforming use, on a lot where bars are prohibited, the applicant shall: 
(1)  Include a statement that was duly notarized or signed in the presence of the zoning administrator during the immediately preceding 300 days and that acknowledges the applicant's responsibility to be aware of all applicable laws, rules, regulations, and binding decisions; 
(2)  Provide any pertinent records, including documents submitted to taxing authorities, within 15 days after being requested by the zoning administrator for cause upon written complaint; and 
(3)  At all times have available updated records with separate account categories for all alcoholic beverage purchases, all alcoholic beverage sales, all cover charges, and total sales of all foods and all beverages. 
(d)  Action by zoning administrator. Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, the zoning administrator shall take final action on the application within seven working days after it is filed. 
(e)  Issuance. A class W permit shall be issued if, and only if, the zoning administrator determines that the premises and use thereof would comply with all applicable sections of the zoning ordinance in chapter 348 and with all laws, rules, regulations, and binding decisions directly applicable to chapter 348. 
(f)  Expedited service. Payment of an expedited-service fee of $250.00 shall require a decision on the class W permit within two working days of the application's being complete. 
(Code 1971, § 26-243; Ord. No. 2002-235.58, pt. 13, 11-5-2002) 
Chapter 304 - ANNEXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- It should be noted that section 2 of Ord. No. 88-1200 from which this chapter derives, adopted July 12, 1988, provides, "That all provisions of Section 26-10 [now section 320-5] of the City Code are incorporated herein by reference and declared to be a part hereof; and that this ordinance shall become effective immediately after being signed, attested, and recorded in an Ordinance Book of the City as specified by the City Charter." 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; zoning, ch. 348. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 304-1. - Applicability. 
    This article shall be applicable to every article in this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 10-1) 
Sec. 304-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building includes the term "structure" and includes all other improvements of every kind, regardless of similarity to buildings. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the term "or part thereof." 
    City Code means the city's Code of Ordinances, including but not limited to the city Charter. 
    City manager means: 
(1)  The chief executive officer and head of the administrative branch of the city government; 
(2)  The acting city manager; or 
(3)  Any city employee or administrative officer to whom such chief executive officer or acting city manager shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
    Council means the city heritage council. 
    Director means: 
(1)  The head or acting head of the city planning and community development department; or 
(2)  Any city employee or administrative officer to whom such head or acting head shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
    Extraterritorial jurisdiction means a geographic area identical to the extraterritorial annexation jurisdiction defined by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 42. 
    Lot includes the words "parcel," "piece," and "plot." 
    Planning commission means the city planning and zoning commission. 
    Shall is mandatory and not discretionary; may is permissive. 
    Taxing unit means the county, an incorporated city or town including a home-rule city, a school district, a special district or authority, or any other political unit of this state, whether created by or pursuant to the constitution or a local, special, or general law, that is authorized to impose and is imposing ad valorem taxes on property. 
    Territorial jurisdiction means the entire geographic area within the corporate city limits. 
    Used and occupied include the words "arranged," "designed," "intended," "maintained," "occupied," or "used." 
(Code 1971, § 10-4) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 304-3. - Authority. 
    This chapter is adopted under the authority of the constitution and laws of the state, including particularly V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 41-62 and 372. This chapter is adopted pursuant to the city Charter. 
(Code 1971, § 10-5) 
Sec. 304-4. - Amendments. 
(a)  The city commission may from time to time amend this chapter by ordinance. 
(b)  Before enacting any ordinance that constitutes such an amendment, the city commission shall hold and close a public hearing thereon. The city manager shall cause notice of such hearing to be given in the manner specified by subsection (d) of this section. 
(c)  The initiator for any such amendment shall be limited to being either the city commission or the city manager. Any person may, by letter to the city manager, make a nonbinding request that one of the potential initiators cause such an amendment to be initiated. Only the initiator may cause a draft of such an amendment to be prepared. 
(d)  Notice of a public hearing on such amendment or draft shall be given in a newspaper of general circulation in the city's territorial and extraterritorial jurisdiction at least ten days before the opening of such hearing. Such notice shall include the publication of a descriptive caption or title stating in summary the purpose of the amendment and the penalty for violation thereof. Such notice shall also state that such amendment or draft is available for public inspection, during normal working hours, commencing with the publication date of such notice. 
(Code 1971, § 10-8) 
Sec. 304-5. - Interpretation. 
(a)  In their interpretation and application, the sections of this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements. 
(b)  Whenever any section of this chapter conflicts with any other section of this chapter, the more restrictive section shall govern, unless otherwise explicitly specified in this chapter. 
(c)  Whenever any applicable section of this chapter conflicts with any section of any other law that has been lawfully adopted by any political subdivision of the state or country, the more restrictive shall govern. 
(d)  Whenever any applicable section of this chapter conflicts with any rule or other policy adopted pursuant to authority delegated by this chapter, the sections of this chapter shall govern. 
(e)  Whenever the provisions of one policy lawfully adopted pursuant to authority delegated by this chapter conflict with the provisions of another such policy, the provisions that govern shall be those that are adopted by the entity listed sooner on the following list: city commission, planning commission, heritage council, public utilities board, chief executive officer of the city, heritage officer, plat administrator, other city employee, relevant executing entity, any other entity. 
(f)  If any section of this chapter or the application of the section to a particular set of persons or circumstances should for any reason be held by the courts to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the remaining portions of this chapter, and to such end each section of this chapter is declared to be severable. 
(Code 1971, § 10-9) 
Sec. 304-6. - Filing with city. 
    Unless otherwise specified by law, documents required under this chapter shall be deemed not to have been filed with the city unless they are submitted directly to the city manager by hand delivery or by certified mail, with return receipt requested. 
(Code 1971, § 10-12) 
Secs. 304-7-304-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS IN EXTRATERRITORIAL JURISDICTION 

Sec. 304-36. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Industrial means characterized by a use which, if inside the city, would be allowed only in a commercial D or less restrictive base zoning classification. 
    Manufacturing means engaged in a process included under division D (manufacturing) of the latest edition of the Standard Industrial Classification Manual as published by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget. 
(Code 1971, § 10-101) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 304-37. - Designation of industrial districts. 
(a)  Each proposed industrial district shall: 
(1)  Be located wholly within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction;. 
(2)  Conform to the city's comprehensive plan; 
(3)  Be primarily utilized for existing or proposed industrial purposes; and 
(4)  Contain at least 500,000 square feet of contiguous land. 
(b)  The city commission shall have exclusive authority to designate such industrial districts. Each such designation shall be by ordinance amending section 304-38. 
(Code 1971, § 10-102) 
Sec. 304-38. - List of designated districts. 
    The names and legal descriptions of industrial districts currently designated by the city are as follow: DANA/FM802, being all of block 22 of El Jardin Subdivision (in share 19 of E.S.G.) (C.C.M.R. vol. 4, p. 60). 
(Code 1971, § 10-103) 
Sec. 304-39. - Procedures for annexation-immunity contracts. 
(a)  In order to be eligible for negotiation of an annexation-immunity contract for a particular site pursuant to this article, the applicant shall submit to the city manager a complete contract application consisting of all of the following: 
(1)  A legal description of the site, verifying that the site is located wholly within the boundaries of an industrial district listed in section 304-38 and verifying that the site contains at least 100,000 square feet of contiguous land; 
(2)  Documentation that the applicant is the site owner or the owner's duly authorized agent; 
(3)  An application form that has been completely filled out by the applicant, using the blank forms specified by the city manager; and 
(4)  Full payment of the nonrefundable contract-application fee in the amount of $100.00. 
(b)  The city manager shall have authority to negotiate an annexation-immunity contract with any such eligible applicant. 
(c)  Upon completion of such negotiations, the city manager shall submit his recommendations and the proposed contract to the city commission. 
(d)  The city commission shall have exclusive authority to approve the annexation-immunity contract. 
(e)  Such contract shall be approved if, and only if, the city commission determines that: 
(1)  The contract would comply with all sections of this article; and 
(2)  The contract would be in the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 10-105) 
Sec. 304-40. - Content of annexation-immunity contracts. 
    Each annexation-immunity contract issued under this article shall be in written form and shall include all of the following: 
(1)  The parties to the contract shall be the city and the site owner or agent. On behalf of the city, the contract shall be executed by the city manager, attested by the city secretary, and approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(2)  The contract period shall be longer than six years but not longer than seven years. The contract shall continue until December 31 in the last year of such period. 
(3)  The city shall guarantee the site's immunity from consummated annexation for such period. 
(4)  Not later than the 18th month of a site's initial contract, the site owner shall cause at least 25 manufacturing workers to be continuously employed on the site for at least 40 hours a week per worker. 
(5)  The site owner shall comply with all laws applicable in the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction, including but not limited to subdivision regulations. 
(6)  Standard clauses shall address issues such as liability, venue, devolution, termination, amendment, and renewal. 
(Code 1971, § 10-106) 
Sec. 304-41. - Renewal of contracts. 
(a)  A contract given pursuant to this article may be renewed for successive periods not to exceed seven years each. 
(b)  Renewals shall be subject to all applicable laws, rules, and regulations in existence on the date of renewal. 
(c)  Renewals shall comply with all applicable provisions of sections 304-39 and 304-40 and shall comply with the following additional requirements: 
(1)  The site owner shall pay an immunity fee to the city manager on February 1 in each year of the renewed contract. 
(2)  The immunity fee shall amount to the sum of 100 percent of the revenue that would be produced if the city imposed a property tax on the site's land and 50 percent of the revenue that would be produced if the city imposed a property tax on the site's improvements. 
(3)  The immunity fee shall be waived for each year in which the city limits did not touch the site boundaries on February 1. 
(Code 1971, § 10-107) 
Chapter 308 - FLOOD DAMAGE AND PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, adopted Feb. 6, 2018, repealed the former Ch. 308, §§ 308-26-308-29, 308-30-308-36, 308-56-308-62, 308-89-308-92, and enacted a new Ch. 308 as set out herein. The former Ch. 308 pertained to floods and derived from Ord. No. 2013-1586, adopted Dec. 3, 2013. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 102; mobile homes and manufactured homes, ch. 316; planning and development, ch. 320; subdivisions, ch. 332; zoning, ch. 348. 

Article I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 308-1-308-25. - Reserved. 
Sec. 308-26. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Protect human life and health; 
(2)  Minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(3)  Minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(4)  Minimize prolonged business interruptions; 
(5)  Minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(6)  Help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood-prone areas in such a manner as to minimize future flood blight areas; and 
(7)  Ensure that potential buyers are notified that property is in a flood area. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-27. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this chapter shall be interpreted to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this chapter its most reasonable application. 
    Alluvial fan flooding means flooding occurring on the surface of an alluvial fan or similar landform which originates at the apex and is characterized by high-velocity flows; active processes of erosion, sediment transport, and deposition; and unpredictable flow paths. 
    Apex means a point on an alluvial fan or similar landform below which the flow path of the major stream that formed the fan becomes unpredictable and alluvial fan flooding can occur. 
    Appurtenant structure means a structure which is on the same parcel of property as the principal structure to be insured and the use of which is incidental to the use of the principal structure. 
    Area of future conditions flood hazard means the land area that would be inundated by the one-percent-annual chance (100-year) flood based on future conditions hydrology. 
    Area of shallow flooding means a designated AO, AH, AR/AO, AR/AH, or VO zone on a community's flood insurance rate map (FIRM) with a one percent or greater annual chance of flooding to an average depth of one to three feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable and where velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow. 
    Area of special flood hazard is the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. The area may be designated as Zone A on the flood hazard boundary map (FHBM). After detailed rate making has been completed in preparation for publication of the FIRM, Zone A usually is refined into Zones A, AO, AH, A1-30, AE, A99, AR, AR/A1-30, AR/AE, AR/AO, AR/AH, AR/A, VO, V1-30, VE or V. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Base flood elevation (BFE) means the elevation shown on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM) and found in the accompanying flood insurance study (FIS) for Zones A, AE, AH, A1-A30, AR, V1-V30, or VE that indicates the water surface elevation resulting from the flood that has a one percent chance of equaling or exceeding that level in any given year-also called the base flood. 
    Basement means any area of the building having its floor subgrade (below ground level) on all sides. 
    Breakaway wall means a wall that is not part of the structural support of the building and is intended through its design and construction to collapse under specific lateral loading forces, without causing damage to the elevated portion of the building or supporting foundation system. 
    Critical feature means an integral and readily identifiable part of a flood protection system, without which the flood protection provided by the entire system would be compromised. 
    Development means any man-made change to improved and unimproved real estate, including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations or storage of equipment or materials. 
    Elevated building means, for insurance purposes, a non-basement building, which has its lowest elevated floor, raised above ground level by foundation walls, shear walls, posts, piers, pilings, or columns. 
    Existing construction means for the purposes of determining rates, structures for which the "start of construction" commenced before the effective date of the FIRM or before January 1, 1975, for FIRMs effective before that date. "Existing construction" may also be referred to as "existing structures." 
    Existing manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed before the effective date of the floodplain management regulations adopted by a community. 
    Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision means the preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads). 
    Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(1)  The overflow of inland or tidal waters. 
(2)  The unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood elevation study means an examination, evaluation and determination of flood hazards and, if appropriate, corresponding water surface elevations, or an examination, evaluation and determination of mudslide (i.e., mudflow) and/or flood-related erosion hazards. 
    Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means an official map of a community, on which the Federal Emergency Management Agency has delineated both the special flood hazard areas and the risk premium zones applicable to the community. 
    Flood insurance study (FIS) see flood elevation study. 
    Flood proofing means any combination of structural and non-structural additions, changes, or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities, structures and their contents. 
    Flood protection system means those physical structural works for which funds have been authorized, appropriated, and expended and which have been constructed specifically to modify flooding in order to reduce the extent of the area within a community subject to a "special flood hazard" and the extent of the depths of associated flooding. Such a system typically includes hurricane tidal barriers, dams, reservoirs, levees or dikes. These specialized flood modifying works are those constructed in conformance with sound engineering standards. 
    Floodplain or flood-prone area means any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source. (See definition of flooding.) 
    Floodplain management means the operation of an overall program of corrective and preventive measures for reducing flood damage, including but not limited to emergency preparedness plans, flood control works and floodplain management regulations. 
    Floodplain management regulations means zoning ordinances, subdivision regulations, building codes, health regulations, special purpose ordinances (such as a floodplain ordinance, grading ordinance and erosion control ordinance) and other applications of police power. The term describes such state or local regulations, in any combination thereof, which provide standards for the purpose of flood damage prevention and reduction. 
    Floodway, see regulatory floodway. 
    Functionally dependent use means a use, which cannot perform its intended purpose unless it is located or carried out in close proximity to water. The term includes only docking facilities, port facilities that are necessary for the loading and unloading of cargo or passengers, and ship building and ship repair facilities, but does not include long-term storage or related manufacturing facilities. 
    Highest adjacent grade means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface prior to construction next to the proposed walls of a structure. 
    Historic structure means any structure that is: 
(1)  Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the Department of Interior) or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the Interior as meeting the requirements for individual listing on the National Register; 
(2)  Certified or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the Interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the Secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; 
(3)  Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places in states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the Secretary of the Interior; or 
(4)  Individually listed on a local inventory or historic places in communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either: 
a.  By an approved state program as determined by the Secretary of the Interior or; 
b.  Directly by the Secretary of the Interior in states without approved programs. 
    Levee means a man-made structure, usually an earthen embankment, designed and constructed in accordance with sound engineering practices to contain, control, or divert the flow of water so as to provide protection from temporary flooding. 
    Levee system means a flood protection system which consists of a levee, or levees, and associated structures, such as closure and drainage devices, which are constructed and operated in accordance with sound engineering practices. 
    Lowest floor means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement). An unfinished or flood resistant enclosure, usable solely for parking or vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement area is not considered a building's lowest floor; provided that such enclosure is not built so as to render the structure in violation of the applicable non-elevation design requirement of Section 60.3 of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations. 
    Manufactured home means a structure transportable in one or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and is designed for use with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. The term "manufactured home" does not include a "recreational vehicle". 
    Manufactured home park or subdivision means a parcel (or contiguous parcels) of land divided into two or more manufactured home lots for rent or sale. 
    Mean sea level means, for purposes of the National Flood Insurance Program, the North American Vertical Datum (NAVD) of 1988 or other datum, to which base flood elevations shown on a community's flood insurance rate map are referenced. 
    New construction means, for the purpose of determining insurance rates, structures for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after the effective date of an initial FIRM or after December 31, 1974, whichever is later, and includes any subsequent improvements to such structures. For floodplain management purposes, "new construction" means structures for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after the effective date of a floodplain management regulation adopted by a community and includes any subsequent improvements to such structures. 
    New manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed on or after the effective date of floodplain management regulations adopted by a community. 
    Primary frontal dune means a continuous or nearly continuous mound or ridge of sand with relatively steep seaward and landward slopes immediately landward and adjacent to the beach and subject to erosion and overtopping from high tides and waves during major coastal storms. The inland limit of the primary frontal dune occurs at the point where there is a distinct change from a relatively steep slope to a relatively mild slope. 
    Recreational vehicle means a vehicle which is (i) built on a single chassis; (ii) 400 square feet or less when measured at the largest horizontal projections; (iii) designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light duty truck; and (iv) designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use. 
    Regulatory floodway means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. 
    Riverine means relating to, formed by, or resembling a river (including tributaries), stream, brook, etc. 
    Sand dunes mean naturally occurring accumulations of sand in ridges or mounds landward of the beach. 
    Special flood hazard area, see area of special flood hazard. 
    Start of construction (for other than new construction or substantial improvements under the Coastal Barrier Resources Act (Pub. L. 97-348)), includes substantial improvement and means the date the building permit was issued, provided the actual start of construction, repair, reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition placement, or other improvement was within 180 days of the permit date. The actual start means either the first placement of permanent construction of a structure on a site, such as the pouring of slab or footings, the installation of piles, the construction of columns, or any work beyond the stage of excavation; or the placement of a manufactured home on a foundation. Permanent construction does not include land preparation, such as clearing, grading and filling; nor does it include the installation of streets and/or walkways; nor does it include excavation for basement, footings, piers or foundations or the erection of temporary forms; nor does it include the installation on the property of accessory buildings, such as garages or sheds not occupied as dwelling units or not part of the main structure. For a substantial improvement, the actual start of construction means the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of a building, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the building. 
    Structure means, for floodplain management purposes, a walled and roofed building, including a gas or liquid storage tank, that is principally above ground, as well as a manufactured home. 
    Substantial damage means damage of any origin sustained by a structure whereby the cost of restoring the structure to its before damaged condition would equal or exceed 50 percent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. 
    Substantial improvement means any reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, or other improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds 50 percent of the market value of the structure before "start of construction" of the improvement. This term includes structures which have incurred "substantial damage", regardless of the actual repair work performed. The term does not, however, include either: (1) any project for improvement of a structure to correct existing violations of state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which have been identified by the local code enforcement official and which are the minimum necessary to assure safe living conditions or (2) any alteration of a "historic structure", provided that the alteration will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a "historic structure." 
    Variance means a grant of relief by a community from the terms of a floodplain management regulation. (For full requirements see Section 60.6 of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations.) 
    Violation means the failure of a structure or other development to be fully compliant with the community's floodplain management regulations. A structure or other development without the elevation certificate, other certifications, or other evidence of compliance required in Section 60.3(b)(5), (c)(4), (c)(10), (d)(3), (e)(2), (e)(4), or (e)(5) is presumed to be in violation until such time as that documentation is provided. 
    Water surface elevation means the height, in relation to the North American Vertical Datum (NAVD) of 1988 (or other datum, where specified), of floods of various magnitudes and frequencies in the floodplains of coastal or riverine areas. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 308-28. - Methods of reducing flood losses. 
(a)  In order to accomplish its purposes, this chapter uses the following methods: 
(1)  Restrict or prohibit uses that are dangerous to health, safety or property in times of flood, or cause excessive increases in flood heights or velocities; 
(2)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(3)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of flood waters; 
(4)  Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage; 
(5)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert flood waters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-29. - Applicability. 
    The chapter shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the jurisdiction of the City of Brownsville. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-30. - Basis for establishing the areas of special flood hazard. 
    The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the current scientific and engineering report entitled, "The Flood Insurance Study (FIS) for Cameron County, Texas and Incorporated Area" dated February 16, 2018 with accompanying flood insurance rate maps (FIRM) dated February 16, 2018 and any revisions thereto are hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-31. - Establishment of development permit. 
    A floodplain development permit shall be required to ensure conformance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-32. - Compliance. 
    No structure or land shall hereafter be located, altered, or have its use changed without full compliance with the terms of this chapter and other applicable regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-33. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
    This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this chapter and another ordinance, easement, covenant, or deed restriction conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-34. - Interpretation. 
    In the interpretation and application of this chapter, all provisions shall be; (1) considered as minimum requirements; (2) liberally construed in favor of the governing body; and (3) deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under State statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-35. - Warning and disclaimer or liability. 
    The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. On rare occasions greater floods can and will occur and flood heights may be increased by man-made or natural causes. This chapter does not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazards or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This chapter shall not create liability on the part of the community or any official or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision lawfully made hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Secs. 308-36-308-86. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 308-87. - Designation of the floodplain administrator. 
    The planning and development services director or designee is hereby appointed the floodplain administrator to administer and implement the provisions of this chapter and other appropriate sections of 44 CFR (Emergency Management and Assistance-National Flood Insurance Program Regulations) pertaining to floodplain management. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-88. - Duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator. 
(a)  In order to accomplish its purposes, this chapter uses the following methods: 
(1)  Duties and responsibilities of the floodplain administrator shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
a.  Maintain and hold open for public inspection all records pertaining to the provisions of this chapter. 
b.  Review permit application to determine whether to ensure that the proposed building site project, including the placement of manufactured homes, will be reasonably safe from flooding. 
c.  Review, approve or deny all applications for development permits required by adoption of this chapter. 
d.  Review permits for proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been obtained from those federal, state or local governmental agencies (including Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334) from which prior approval is required.
