e.  Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of the boundaries of the areas of special flood hazards (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the floodplain administrator shall make the necessary interpretation. 
f.  Notify, in riverine situations, adjacent communities and the state coordinating agency which is the Texas Water Development Board (TWDB) and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse, and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
g.  Assure that the flood carrying capacity within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse is maintained. 
h.  When base flood elevation data has not been provided in accordance with section 308-30 the floodplain administrator shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation data and floodway data available from a federal, state or other source, in order to administer the provisions of article III. 
i.  When a regulatory floodway has not been designated, the Floodplain Administrator must require that no new construction, substantial improvements, or other development (including fill) shall be permitted within Zones A1-30 and AE on the community's FIRM, unless it is demonstrated that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one foot at any point within the community. 
j.  Under the provisions of 44 CFR Chapter 1, Section 65.12, of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations, a community may approve certain development in Zones A1-30, AE, AH, on the community's FIRM which increases the water surface elevation of the base flood by more than one foot, provided that the community first completes all of the provisions required by Section 65.12. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-89. - Permit procedures. 
(a)  Application for a floodplain development permit shall be presented to the floodplain administrator on forms furnished by him/her and may include, but not be limited to, plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the location, dimensions, and elevation of proposed landscape alterations, existing and proposed structures, including the placement of manufactured homes, and the location of the foregoing in relation to areas of special flood hazard. Additionally, the following information is required: 
(1)  Elevation (in relation to mean sea level), of the lowest floor (including basement) of all new and substantially improved structures; 
(2)  Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any nonresidential structure shall be floodproofed; 
(3)  A certificate from a registered professional engineer or architect that the nonresidential floodproofed structure shall meet the floodproofing criteria of section 308-143(a)(2); 
(4)  Description of the extent to which any watercourse or natural drainage will be altered or relocated as a result of proposed development; 
(5)  Maintain a record of all such information in accordance with section 308-88(a)(1)a. 
(b)  Approval or denial of a floodplain development permit by the floodplain administrator shall be based on all of the provisions of this chapter and the following relevant factors: 
(1)  The danger to life and property due to flooding or erosion damage; 
(2)  The susceptibility of the proposed facility and its contents to flood damage and the effect of such damage on the individual owner; 
(3)  The danger that materials may be swept onto other lands to the injury of others; 
(4)  The compatibility of the proposed use with existing and anticipated development; 
(5)  The safety of access to the property in times of flood for ordinary and emergency vehicles; 
(6)  The costs of providing governmental services during and after flood conditions including maintenance and repair of streets and bridges, and public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems; 
(7)  The expected heights, velocity, duration, rate of rise and sediment transport of the floodwaters and the effects of wave action, if applicable, expected at the site; 
(8)  The necessity to the facility of a waterfront location, where applicable; 
(9)  The availability of alternative locations, not subject to flooding or erosion damage, for the proposed use. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-90. - Variance procedures. 
(a)  The board of adjustment shall hear and render judgment on requests for variances from the requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  The board of adjustment shall hear and render judgment on an appeal only when it is alleged there is an error in any requirement, decision, or determination made by the floodplain administrator in the enforcement or administration of this chapter. 
(c)  Any person or persons aggrieved by the decision of the board of adjustment may appeal such decision in the courts of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  The floodplain administrator shall maintain a record of all actions involving an appeal and shall report variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. 
(e)  Variances may be issued for the reconstruction, rehabilitation or restoration of structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places or the State Inventory of Historic Places, without regard to the procedures set forth in the remainder of this chapter. 
(f)  Variances may be issued for new construction and substantial improvements to be erected on a lot of one-half acre or less in size contiguous to and surrounded by lots with existing structures constructed below the base flood level, providing the relevant factors in section 308-89(b) of this article have been fully considered. As the lot size increases beyond the one-half acre, the technical justification required for issuing the variance increases. 
(g)  Upon consideration of the factors noted above and the intent of this chapter, the board of adjustment may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purpose and objectives of this chapter section 308-26. 
(h)  Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. 
(i)  Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of historic structures upon a determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure and the variance is the minimum necessary to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. 
(j)  Prerequisites for granting variances: 
(1)  Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief. 
(2)  Variances shall only be issued upon: (i) showing a good and sufficient cause; (ii) a determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship to the applicant, and (iii) a determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisances, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(3)  Any application to which a variance is granted shall be given written notice that the structure will be permitted to be built with the lowest floor elevation below the base flood elevation, and that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. 
(k)  Variances may be issued by a community for new construction and substantial improvements and for other development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use provided that (i) the criteria outlined in section 308-90(a) through (i) are met, and (ii) the structure or other development is protected by methods that minimize flood damages during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Secs. 308-91-308-141. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROVISIONS FOR FLOOD HAZARD REDUCTION 

Sec. 308-142. - General standards. 
(a)  In all areas of special flood hazards the following provisions are required for all new construction and substantial improvements: 
(1)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be designed (or modified) and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure resulting from hydrodynamic and hydrostatic loads, including the effects of buoyancy; 
(2)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage; 
(3)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be constructed with materials resistant to flood damage; 
(4)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be constructed with electrical, heating, ventilation, plumbing, and air conditioning equipment and other service facilities that are designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding; 
(5)  All new and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system; 
(6)  New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system and discharge from the systems into flood waters; and, 
(7)  On-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-143. - Specific standards. 
(a)  In all areas of special flood hazards where base flood elevation data has been provided as set forth in (i) section 308-30, (ii) section 308-88(a)(1)h., or section 308-144(c), the following provisions are required: 
(1)  Residential construction. New construction and substantial improvement of any residential structure shall have the lowest floor (including basement), elevated to or above the base flood elevation. A registered professional engineer or land surveyor shall submit a certification to the floodplain administrator that the standard of this subsection as proposed in section 308-89(a)(1), is satisfied. 
(2)  Nonresidential construction. New construction and substantial improvements of any commercial, industrial or other nonresidential structure shall either have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood level or together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, be designed so that below the base flood level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall develop and/or review structural design, specifications, and plans for the construction, and shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice as outlined in this subsection. A record of such certification which includes the specific elevation (in relation to mean sea level) to which such structures are floodproofed shall be maintained by the floodplain administrator. 
(3)  Enclosures. New construction and substantial improvements, with fully enclosed areas below the lowest floor that are usable solely for parking of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement and which are subject to flooding shall be designed to automatically equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the entry and exit of floodwaters. Designs for meeting this requirement must either be certified by a registered professional engineer or architect or meet or exceed the following minimum criteria: 
a.  A minimum of two openings on separate walls having a total net area of not less than one square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding shall be provided. 
1.  The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one foot above grade. 
2.  Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves, or other coverings or devices provided that they permit the automatic entry and exit of floodwaters. 
(b)  Manufactured homes. 
(1)  Require that all manufactured homes to be placed within Zone A on a community's FHBM or FIRM shall be installed using methods and practices which minimize flood damage. For the purposes of this requirement, manufactured homes must be elevated and anchored to resist flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This requirement is in addition to applicable state and local anchoring requirements for resisting wind forces. 
(2)  Require that manufactured homes that are placed or substantially improved within Zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM on sites (i) outside of a manufactured home park or subdivision, (ii) in a new manufactured home park or subdivision, (iii) in an expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision, or (iv) in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision on which a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as a result of a flood, be elevated on a permanent foundation such that the lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated to or above the base flood elevation and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
(3)  Require that manufactured homes be placed or substantially improved on sites in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision with Zones A1-30, AH and AE on the community's FIRM that are not subject to the provisions of section 308-143(b) of this section be elevated so that either: 
a.  The lowest floor of the manufactured home is at or above the base flood elevation; or 
b.  The manufactured home chassis is supported by reinforced piers or other foundation elements of at least equivalent strength that are no less than 36 inches in height above grade and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
(c)  Recreational vehicles. 
(1)  Require that recreational vehicles placed on sites within Zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM either (i) be on the site for fewer than 180 consecutive days, or (ii) be fully licensed and ready for highway use, or (iii) meet the permit requirements of section 308-89(a)(1) and the elevation and anchoring requirements for "manufactured homes" in section 308-143(b) of this section. A recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is on its wheels or jacking system, is attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached additions. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-144. - Standards for subdivision proposals. 
(a)  All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall be consistent with sections 308-26 and 308-28 of this chapter. 
(b)  All proposals for the development of subdivisions including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall meet floodplain development permit requirements of section 308-31; section 308-89; and the provisions of article III of this chapter. 
(c)  Base flood elevation data shall be generated for subdivision proposals and other proposed development including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions which is greater than 50 lots or five acres, whichever is lesser, if not otherwise provided pursuant to section 308-30 or section 308-88(a)(1)h. of this chapter. 
(d)  All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(e)  All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-145. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO/AH Zones). 
(a)  Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 308-30 are areas designated as shallow flooding. These areas have special flood hazards associated with flood depths of one to three feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable, and where velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow; therefore, the following provisions apply: 
(1)  All new construction and substantial improvements of residential structures have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation or the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two feet if no depth number is specified). 
(2)  All new construction and substantial improvements of non-residential structures: 
a.  Have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation or the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two feet if no depth number is specified), or 
b.  Together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities be designed so that below the base specified flood depth in an AO Zone, or below the base flood elevation in an AH Zone, level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads of effects of buoyancy. 
(3)  A registered professional engineer or architect shall submit a certification to the floodplain administrator that the standards of this section, as proposed in section 308-89 are satisfied. 
(4)  Require within Zones AH or AO adequate drainage paths around structures on slopes, to guide flood waters around and away from proposed structures. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-146. - Coastal high hazard areas. 
(a)  Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 308-30 are areas designated as coastal high hazard areas (Zones V1-30, VE, and/or V). These areas have special flood hazards associated with high velocity waters from tidal surges and hurricane wave wash; therefore, in addition to meeting all provisions outlined in this chapter, the following provisions must also apply: 
(1)  Obtain the elevation (in relation to mean sea level) of the bottom of the lowest structural member of the lowest floor (excluding pilings and columns) of all new and substantially improved structures, and whether or not such structures contain a basement. The floodplain administrator shall maintain a record of all such information. 
(2)  All new construction shall be located landward of the reach of mean high tide. 
(3)  All new construction and substantial improvements shall be elevated on pilings and columns so that: 
a.  The bottom of the lowest horizontal structural member of the lowest floor (excluding the pilings or columns) is elevated to or above the base flood level; 
b.  The pile or column foundation and structure attached thereto is anchored to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement due to the effects of wind and water loads acting simultaneously on all building components. Water loading values used shall be those associated with the base flood. Wind loading values used shall be those required by applicable state or local building standards. A registered professional engineer or architect shall develop or review the structural design, specifications and plans for the construction, and shall certify that the design and methods of construction to be used are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions of subsection (3)a. and b. of this section. 
c.  Provide that all new construction and substantial improvements have the space below the lowest floor either free of obstruction or constructed with non-supporting breakaway walls, open wood lattice-work, or insect screening intended to collapse under wind and water loads without causing collapse, displacement, or other structural damage to the elevated portion of the building or supporting foundation system. 
(4)  For the purpose of this section, a breakaway wall shall have a design safe loading resistance of not less than ten and no more than 20 pounds per square foot. Use of breakaway walls which exceed a design safe loading resistance of 20 pounds per square foot (either by design or when so required by local or state codes) may be permitted only if a registered professional engineer or architect certifies that the designs proposed meet the following conditions: 
a.  Breakaway wall collapse shall result from a water load less than that which would occur during the base flood; and 
b.  The elevated portion of the building and supporting foundation system shall not be subject to collapse, displacement, or other structural damage due to the effects of wind and water loads acting simultaneously on all building components (structural and nonstructural). Water loading values used shall be those associated with the base flood. Wind loading values used shall be those required by applicable state or local building standards. Such enclosed space shall be useable solely for parking of vehicles, building access, or storage. Such space shall not be used for human habitation. 
(5)  Prohibit the use of fill for structural support of buildings. 
(6)  Prohibit man-made alteration of sand dunes and mangrove stands that increase potential flood damage. 
(7)  Manufactured homes. Require that manufactured homes placed or substantially improved within Zone V1-30, V, and VE on the community's FIRM on sites (i) outside of a manufactured home park or subdivision, (ii) in a new manufactured home park or subdivision, (iii) in an expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision, or (iv) in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision on which a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as the result of a flood, meet the standards of paragraphs (1) through (6) of this section and that manufactured homes placed or substantially improved on other sites in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision within Zones V1-30, V, and VE on the community's FIRM meet the requirements of section 308-143(b) of this chapter. 
(8)  Recreational vehicles. Require that recreational vehicles placed on sites within Zones V1-30, V, and VE on the community's FIRM either (i) be on the site for fewer than 180 consecutive days, or (ii) be fully licensed and ready for highway use, or (iii) meet the requirements in section 308-31 of this ordinance and paragraphs (1) through (6) of this section. A recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is on its wheels or jacking system, is attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached additions. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-147. - Severability. 
    If any section, clause, sentence, or phrase of this chapter is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 308-148. - Penalties for noncompliance. 
    No structure or land shall hereafter be constructed, located, extended, converted, or altered without full compliance with the terms of this court order and other applicable regulations. Violation of the provisions of this court order by failure to comply with any of its requirements (including violations of conditions and safeguards established in connection with conditions) shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who violates this court order or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall upon conviction thereof be fined not more than $500.00 for each violation, and in addition shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the City of Brownsville from taking such other lawful action as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1638, § 1, 2-6-2018) 
Chapter 310 - GRANTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 310-1-310-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BROWNSVILLE CITIZENS' ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 310-26. - Purpose. 
    The Brownsville Citizens' Advisory Committee (BCAC) contributes to public participation by helping to: 
(a)  Identify housing and community development needs; and 
(b)  Establish priorities relating to those needs; and 
(c)  Provide guidance, evaluation and recommendations regarding funding prospective programs/projects. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1570, § 1, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-A, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-B, § 1, 6-3-2014; Ord. No. 2015-1570-C, § 1, 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 310-27. - Composition and term of office. 
    The composition will be as follows: 
(1)  There shall be seven voting members of the committee; 
(2)  Membership shall be by appointment of the city commission of Brownsville; and 
(3)  At least 1/3 of the committee members will be required to represent areas that are designated as low- or moderate-income areas, and may do so by either having a business interest or by living in the low- or moderate-income area; and 
(4)  Each member of the city commission shall appoint one member to the Advisory Committee. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1570, § 1, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-A, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-B, § 1, 6-3-2014; Ord. No. 2015-1570-C, § 1, 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 310-28. - Organization and staff. 
(a)  The committee members shall elect a chair and a vice-chair from the seven member committee; and 
(b)  The term of the chair and vice-chair shall be one year; and 
(c)  Members will serve a two year term and may be reappointed to a second two year term; and 
(d)  Members shall attend 75 percent of the Advisory Committee's meetings to be considered for reappointment; and 
(e)  In the event a person is appointed to fill a vacancy, that person shall serve for the unexpired portion of that term; and 
(f)  Members may only serve a total of two terms be they consecutively or non-consecutively. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1570, § 1, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-A, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-B, § 1, 6-3-2014; Ord. No. 2015-1570-C, § 1, 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 310-29. - Compensation. 
    Members of the BCAC shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1570, § 1, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-A, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-B, § 1, 6-3-2014; Ord. No. 2015-1570-C, § 1, 2-3-2015) 
Sec. 310-30. - Meetings. 
(a)  The Brownsville Citizens' Advisory Committee shall meet on call by director of office of grant management and community development. All meetings shall be open to the public and notice thereof given as required by the Texas Open Meeting Act, T.V.C.A., Government Code, § 551. The time and place of the meeting shall be posted on the main bulletin board at City Hall and at the usual place the committee meets. 
(1)  A quorum consisting of a minimum of four voting members shall be required to conduct business. 
(2)  If a member has three absences within a year, that member shall be deemed to have resigned, leaving that position vacant. 
(Ord. No. 2013-1570, § 1, 2-19-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-A, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2015-1570-B, § 1, 6-3-2014; Ord. No. 2015-1570-C, § 1, 2-3-2015) 
Chapter 314 - IMPACT FEES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 314-1. - Purpose and authority. 
(a)  The purpose of this chapter is to comply with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 395. 
(b)  This chapter is adopted under the authority of the constitution and laws of the state, including particularly V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 395, 42, and 51-54. This chapter is adopted pursuant to the city Charter. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1100.39, 8-8-2006) 
Sec. 314-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BPUB means Brownsville public utilities board. 
    CIAC means the capital improvements advisory committee created under this chapter. 
    General manager means: 
(1)  The chief executive officer and head of the administrative branch of the "BPUB"; or 
(2)  The acting general manager; or 
(3)  Any employee or officer of the BPUB to whom such head or acting general manager shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
    Planning director means: 
(1)  The head or acting head of the city planning and community development department; or 
(2)  Any employee or administrative officer of the city to whom such head or acting head shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1100.39, 8-8-2006) 
Secs. 314-3-314-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 314-20. - Created. 
(a)  There is created a capital improvements advisory committee under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 395. 
(b)  The CIAC is composed of seven members, who shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city commission for indefinite terms, who may be replaced at any time by a majority vote of the city commission, and who shall serve without compensation. 
(c)  Not less than 40 percent of the membership of the CIAC must be representatives of the real estate, development, or building industries who are not employees or officials of a political subdivision or governmental entity (other than being a member of this CIAC). 
(d)  One member of the CIAC must be a representative from this city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(e)  All other members of the CIAC must reside inside Brownsville city limits. 
(f)  One member of the CIAC shall be selected by the CIAC membership to serve as the CIAC Chairman. 
(g)  The planning director and general manager have ex officio status. Neither the planning director nor the general manager may vote, make motions, or be counted as one of the seven members. However, in all other respects they have the same rights as the seven members. 
(h)  The city shall make available to the CIAC any professional reports with respect to developing and implementing the capital improvements plan. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1100.39, 8-8-2006; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 1, 10-30-2007) 
Sec. 314-21. - Procedural rules. 
(a)  This section constitutes the procedural rules required under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 395.058(e). The CIAC shall follow these rules in carrying out its duties. 
(b)  The CIAC serves in an advisory capacity and shall have only the authority granted to it by those provisions of state law or city ordinance which mention the CIAC by name. 
(c)  The CIAC shall not hold any meeting during any period when it is out of compliance with section 314-20(c) or (d). 
(d)  A quorum shall consist of four members. Voting by proxy is not allowed. Each member attending a CIAC meeting in person or by two-way speakerphone shall be eligible to vote in the absence of a conflict of interest. 
(e)  The CIAC and each of its members shall be subject to the same conflict-of-interest, nepotism, public-meetings, public-records, and other due-process standards as the city commission. 
(f)  The CIAC shall select from its membership a secretary and at least one vice-chair. A CIAC meeting may be called by any CIAC officer or by the city manager or by the general manager. 
(g)  Whenever the CIAC submits a report, advice, or comments to the city commission, that submission may take the form of one majority report, seven minority reports, or any combination or variant thereof. The preferred format is one majority report. 
(h)  In September and March of each year, the CIAC shall submit a report under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 395.058(c)(4). 
(i)  No expenditure shall be made by the CIAC without the prior written authorization from the general manager or city manager. 
(j)  After holding a public hearing advertised at least 72 hours in advance in a newspaper of general circulation, a supermajority vote of the CIAC may adopt and enforce the CIAC rules as previously promulgated by ordinance of the city commission, for the purpose of more efficiently carrying out its duties. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1100.39, 8-8-2006; Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 1, 10-30-2007) 
Secs. 314-22-314-29. - Reserved.

Chapter 316 - MOBILE HOMES AND MANUFACTURED HOMES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 102; floods, ch. 308; planning and development, ch. 320; subdivisions, ch. 332; supplemental subdivision rules, ch. 336; vegetation, ch. 344; zoning, ch. 348. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 316-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home means a transportable single-family dwelling unit which is or may be mounted on wheels suitable for year round occupancy and containing the same water supply, waste disposal and electrical conveniences as immobile housing. 
    Mobile home park A means a parcel of land under single ownership which has been planned and improved for the placement of mobile homes for transient use, supplementary structures and accessory uses not otherwise prohibited by this chapter, this Code or any other city ordinance. 
    Mobile home park B means a parcel of land which is: 
(1)  Under multiple ownership or which may be developed under multiple ownership; 
(2)  Recorded in its entirety as a subdivision plat with the appropriate right-of-way dedications for streets, alleys and/or easements, lots and blocks; and 
(3)  For the placement of mobile homes for nontransient use, supplementary structures and accessory uses not prohibited by this chapter, this Code or any other city ordinance. 
    Site plan means a line drawing clearly describing the mobile home park and its environs and includes adequate labeling and dimensioning of all fundamental features of the project, the legal description of the property, the north point, the date, and shall be drawn to engineering scale. 
(Code 1971, § 19-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 316-2. - Enforcing officer. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief building inspector to make inspections to determine the existence of violations of this chapter. A complete report of any violations discovered shall be made to the city manager for further handling. 
(Code 1971, § 19-2) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-56 et seq. 
Sec. 316-3. - Abatement of violations. 
    If any building, structure or mobile home is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained or any building, structure, mobile home or land is used in violation of this chapter, the city manager, in addition to other remedies, may institute any proper action or proceeding in the name of the city to: 
(1)  Prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance or use; 
(2)  Restrain, correct or abate such violations; 
(3)  Prevent the occupancy of such building, structure, mobile home, or land; or 
(4)  Prevent any illegal act, conduct, business or use in or about such premises. 
(Code 1971, § 19-3) 
Sec. 316-4. - Parking on public streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any mobile home on any street, highway, alley, sidewalk, or other public place in the city for a longer period than three hours. 
(Code 1971, § 19-4) 
Sec. 316-5. - Parking in mobile home parks. 
(a)  Required. No mobile home shall be parked for use or occupancy on any tract of ground within the city except in a duly authorized mobile home park A or B. 
(b)  Temporary use outside park. The building inspector may permit the parking, use and occupancy of a mobile home outside of a duly authorized mobile home park for a period of time not exceeding ten days, when such mobile home is occupied by persons employed in the operation of a temporary recreational, amusement, or civic activity. Such temporary parking, use, and occupancy of a mobile home shall be permitted only when the mobile home is parked on the same premises on which the activity is located and only when adequate sanitary facilities are available upon the premises for the use of the occupants of the mobile home. 
(c)  Outside duly authorized mobile home parks. Permits for the location of mobile homes outside duly authorized mobile home parks may be granted by the city manager for special hardship, upon evidence to such effect presented to him by the applicant for such permit. The decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(Code 1971, §§ 19-5-19-7) 
Sec. 316-6. - Procedure during periods of high winds or hurricanes. 
    In order to safeguard the lives and properties of the city residents during periods of high winds or hurricanes, all mobile homes within the corporate city limits which are located either within the site of a mobile home park or on any other site within the city shall be secured, tied down or anchored in accordance with the following specifications and requirements: 
(1)  Anchorage-foremost minimum hurricane tiedown requirements. The number of ties shall be as follows: 
a.  Up to 30 feet, two frame ties per side. 
b.  Thirty feet to 50 feet, three frame ties per side. 
c.  Fifty feet to 70 feet, four frame ties per side. 
d.  Over 70 feet, five frame ties per side. 
e.  Plus over-the-home ties as close to each end as possible with straps at stud and rafter locations. 
(2)  Anchors. A soil test shall be performed to ensure that the following will withstand 3,750 pounds of pull per ten feet of mobile home: 
a.  Auger or deadman shall be six inches in diameter; arrowhead eight inches. 
b.  Auger or arrowhead shall have a depth of four feet; deadman five feet. 
c.  Anchor rod shall be five-eighths inch in diameter with a welded eye at the top. It must be hooked into concrete when used in deadman anchors. 
d.  Anchors to slabs must equal the requirements in this subsection in pull resistance. 
(3)  Connectors. Specifications for connectors shall be as follows: 
a.  Galvanized or stainless steel cable: three-eighths inch (seven by seven, seven wires each). 
b.  Galvanized aircraft cable: one-fourth inch (seven by 19, seven strands of 19 wires each). 
c.  Steel strap, 11/4 inches by 0.035 inch: galvanized, with tensioning device. 
d.  Cable ends secured by two U-bolt clamps. 
e.  Steel rods with ends welded closed to form an eye. 
f.  Turnbuckles five-eighths inch drop forged, closed eyes. Other tensioning devices of similar strength may be approved. 
(4)  Piers and footings. Standards for piers and footings shall be as follows: 
a.  They shall be spaced at ten-foot intervals on both frame rails with end ones no further than five feet from the end of the mobile home. 
b.  Footings shall be of solid concrete 16 inches by 16 inches by four inches. 
c.  Piers shall be of standard solid concrete block, eight inches by eight inches by 16 inches. 
d.  Treated trim shingles shall be used for leveling. 
e.  Other similar piers may be accepted. An adjustable screw anchor-type column fastened to both the frame rail and to a concrete pad of four-inch thickness extending the length and width of the mobile home is especially recommended. 
(5)  Patio awnings and cabana roofs. Specifications for patio awnings and cabana roofs shall be as follows: 
a.  There shall be two rows of vertical support bars with a spacing of 12 feet. The second row is to be down the middle or at the mobile home edge, anchored to a concrete floor or equivalent footings. 
b.  Other structures on the lot must be secured. 
c.  A tip-out room is to be held by an over-the-home tie at the outer edge. 
d.  A clerestory roof requires over-the-home ties at the end of each raised section. 
(Code 1971, § 19-8) 
Secs. 316-7-316-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 316-36. - Uses permitted. 
    Upon issuance of a mobile home park permit, type A or B, by the city commission, no use except the following shall be permitted in any mobile home park, type A or B: 
(1)  Single-family mobile homes. 
(2)  Accessory uses providing service to the occupants of the mobile home park. Such uses may include recreational facilities, central or community garages, storage buildings and washaterias. 
(3)  Supplementary structures. 
(Code 1971, § 19-25) 
Sec. 316-37. - Register of occupants. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each mobile home park type A permittee to keep a register containing a record of all mobile home owners and occupants located within the mobile home park. The register shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of each mobile home occupant; 
(2)  The name and address of the owner of each mobile home and the motor vehicle by which it is towed. 
(3)  The make, model, year and license number of each mobile home and motor vehicle. 
(4)  The state, territory or country issuing such license. 
(5)  The date of arrival and of departure of each mobile home. 
(6)  Whether each mobile home is a dependent or independent mobile home. 
(b)  The park shall keep the register available for inspection at all times by law enforcement officers, public health officials and other officials whose duties necessitate acquisition of the information contained in the register. 
(c)  The register record for each occupant registered shall not be destroyed for a period of three years following the date of departure of the registrant from the park. 
(Code 1971, § 19-27) 
Secs. 316-38-316-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 316-66. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct or otherwise establish a mobile home park, type A or B, without first obtaining a permit from the city commission. 
(Code 1971, § 19-21) 
Sec. 316-67. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a permit required by this division shall be made in writing to the city manager, signed, and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The location and address of the mobile home park; 
(3)  A legal description of the property to be used for the mobile home park; and 
(4)  A site plan which shall accompany the application. 
(b)  The city commission shall reserve the right to refuse to examine any incomplete, unintelligible or indefinite drawings or plans, and such proposed plans for a mobile home park, type A or B, shall conform to the minimum standards as set out in this article. 
(Code 1971, § 19-22) 
Sec. 316-68. - Fee. 
    At the time of making application for a permit required by this division, the applicant shall pay a fee of $150.00. 
(Code 1971, § 19-23) 
Sec. 316-68.5. - Special use permit. 
    The special use permit is designed to provide for the use of a mobile home park A or B, which, different characteristics or potential impacts on adjacent land uses are not permitted in certain zoning districts, but which may, under the proper set of circumstances and conditions, be acceptable in certain specific locations. A mobile home park A or B would be permitted only with the approval of a special manufactured home permit by the city commission. 
    Upon recommendation of the city planning and zoning commission, and after public notice and hearing, the City Commission of the City of Brownsville may grant a special use permit allowing a mobile home park A or B in any use district. Before granting said permit, the governing body shall ascertain and determine, that 
(1)  The use of such mobile home park A or B at the proposed location will be in accordance with the comprehensive plan of the city established for the purpose of promoting the health, safety, morals, and general welfare thereof, and that necessary safeguards to effect such purpose may be made a condition for granting of such permit. 
(2)  The applicant seeking such permit has fully complied with all provisions of the ordinances governing the establishment of a mobile home park A or B. 
(3)  The planning and zoning commission shall conduct a least one public hearing in accordance with V.T.C.A. Local Government Code, after which the planning and zoning commission shall transmit its final report to the city commission. 
(4)  The city commission may impose conditions or requirements, in addition to, or which supersede, any standards specified in the city ordinances, such as setbacks, increased screening or landscaping, wider streets, identification of mobile home stand location, traffic analysis to establish traffic flow, circulation, and access, and must comply with the latest HUD code and International Building Construction Code (IBCC). 
(5)  Any changes of less then five percent, for enlargement, expansion, or increase of density originally approved, may be authorized by the director of the planning and community development. All other changes shall be considered major changes and shall be approved in the same manner and under the same procedures as are applicable to the approval of the original permit. 
(Ord. No. 2008-235.78, 10-21-2008) 
Sec. 316-69. - Building permit required. 
    No person shall erect or construct or proceed with the erection or construction, add, to enlarge, improve, alter, repair, convert, extend or demolish any mobile home park, type A or B mobile home stand, building, structure, fence or any part thereof or install any plumbing, electrical or mechanical equipment as a part of the site, building or structure or make any other improvements to any mobile home lot A or B or cause such to be done within a mobile home park, type A or B, without obtaining a building permit from the building inspector. Such permit shall be granted only after a specific use permit be granted and such conforms to the permit approved and/or granted by the city commission. 
(Code 1971, § 19-24; Ord. No. 2008-235.78, 10-21-2008) 
Sec. 316-70. - Revocation of type A permit. 
    A mobile home park permit type A, as issued by the city commission, may be revoked or suspended by the building inspector for any period of time, after written notice to the permit holder and upon a determination by him that: 
(1)  The permit holder, an employer, or any employee of the permit holder has violated any section of this chapter or any section of the law, this Code or ordinances relating to mobile home parks within 60 days immediately preceding the date of revocation. 
(2)  The permit holder or owner of the mobile home park for which the permit is issued is failing to comply and maintain the mobile home park in compliance with the requirements set forth in this article providing for certain minimum standards for type A parks. 
(3)  The permit holder, an employer, or any employee of the permit holder has refused to allow the public health director or any of his inspectors, the chief of police, the chief of the fire department, or any other duly authorized city employee to enter upon the mobile home park at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspecting the park for compliance with this chapter and any other applicable section of this Code or city ordinance. 
(Code 1971, § 19-28) 
Secs. 316-71-316-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR TYPE A PARKS 

Sec. 316-96. - Compliance required. 
    Any mobile home park type A established, constructed, erected, extended, altered, expanded and/or improved within the city shall conform to and comply with the minimum standards provided by this division. 
(Code 1971, § 19-36) 
Sec. 316-97. - Area. 
    Each type A mobile home park shall provide a minimum of two acres in area. 
(Code 1971, § 19-37) 
Sec. 316-98. - Density. 
    Each type A mobile home park shall not exceed a maximum density of ten home mobile home lots per acre, as determined by the total area bounded by the mobile home park property lines. 
(Code 1971, § 19-38) 
Sec. 316-99. - Mobile home lot generally. 
(a)  Each and every mobile home lot in a type A mobile home park shall: 
(1)  Be served with sanitary sewer, water and electrical power. 
(2)  Provide an average minimum width of 35 feet and an average minimum depth of 75 feet, or 2,625 square feet. 
(3)  Abut and/or have access to a private street for a minimum distance of 12 feet. 
(b)  No physical structure, dumpmaster, container, carport, cabana, awning, fence, or storage locker shall be permitted within ten feet of a private street, provided the setbacks from the sides and rear shall be three feet, save and except a fence, from any mobile home lot line not adjacent to the private street. 
(c)  Double frontage of mobile home lots should be avoided. 
(Code 1971, § 19-40) 
Sec. 316-100. - Vehicular access restricted. 
    No vehicular access to a mobile home lot in a type A mobile home park shall be permitted from a public, dedicated street. 
(Code 1971, § 19-41) 
Sec. 316-101. - Off-street parking. 
    Each mobile home lot in a type A mobile home park shall provide a minimum of two off-street parking spaces. Such spaces shall: 
(1)  Have a permanent all-weather surface. 
(2)  Have dimensions of not less than eight feet six inches by 18 feet or 300 square feet. 
(3)  Be accessible to an all-weather-surfaced private street. 
(4)  Be appropriately defined and marked. 
(5)  Be so located and regulated that no parking or maneuvering incidental to parking shall be on any public street or walk. 
(6)  Provide adequate barriers to keep any parked vehicle from extending into or overhanging any public, dedicated street or private street. 
(7)  Be so designed that any vehicle may be parked and unparked without requiring the moving of any other vehicle. 
(Code 1971, § 19-42) 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking, § 98-161 et seq. 
Sec. 316-102. - Mobile home stand. 
    Every mobile home lot in a type A mobile home park shall provide a mobile home stand which shall provide an adequate foundation for the placement of one single-family mobile home. The mobile home stand shall be: 
(1)  Impervious to plant material such as weeds, grass and shrubs. 
(2)  A minimum of 11 feet in width and 50 feet in length. 
(3)  Located not closer than three feet from the mobile home lot line, located at least ten feet from any private street and located a minimum of five feet from the rear mobile home lot line (the end of the mobile home stand opposite the end adjacent to the private street). 
(Code 1971, § 19-43) 
Sec. 316-103. - Setbacks. 
(a)  All mobile home stands and attached mobile homes in a type A mobile home park shall be located as follows: 
(1)  A minimum of 25 feet from any mobile home park property boundary line abutting upon a publicly dedicated street, and five feet from residentially used or zoned residential A or B property, as set out in the zoning ordinance in chapter 348. 
(2)  A minimum of five feet from any mobile home park property boundary line, not abutting upon a publicly dedicated street, when the abutting property is used or zoned as industrial or commercial property. 
(b)  All accessory uses shall be located a minimum of ten feet from any mobile home lot line. 
(Code 1971, § 19-44) 
Sec. 316-104. - Drainage. 
    The ground surface in all parts of every type A mobile home park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner so as not to permit water to stand or become stagnant. 
(Code 1971, § 19-45) 
Sec. 316-105. - Lighting. 
    The private streets, parking lots, walks and service areas in a type A mobile home park shall be kept properly and adequately lighted at all times so the mobile home park shall be safe for occupants and visitors. All entrances and exits shall be lighted, and all lighting shall be at the expense of the mobile home park operator. 
(Code 1971, § 19-46) 
Sec. 316-106. - Refuse pickup. 
    A refuse pickup easement shall be granted by the owner of the type A mobile home park to the city if these facilities are located so as to require the entrance of a municipal vehicle into the mobile home park. 
(Code 1971, § 19-47) 
Sec. 316-107. - Private streets. 
(a)  Required. Private streets shall be provided in a type A mobile home park and shall extend continuously from the public street right-of-way so as to provide suitable access to all mobile home lots and other facilities or uses permitted in the mobile home park as well as to provide adequate connection to future streets at the boundaries of the mobile home property line. 
(b)  Specifications. Private streets in mobile home parks shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  The minimum pavement widths for private streets which provide direct access to five or more mobile home lots shall be 20 feet. 
(2)  Private street intersections shall generally be at right angles. Offsets at intersections of less than 125 feet (centerline to centerline) should be avoided. Intersections of more than two streets at one point shall be avoided. 
(3)  Dead-end private streets shall be limited to a maximum length of 1,000 feet and shall be provided with a vehicular turning space, with a turning circle of 80 feet in diameter. 
(4)  All private streets shall be provided with a smooth, hard, and dense surface, which shall be durable and well drained under normal use and weather conditions. The base must have at least six inches of compacted material with a double course of inverted penetration or two inches of hot-mix or cold-mix asphalt. 
(5)  Private streets which may connect two public street rights-of-way shall, by the use of curves, offsets, location, and/or the use of two or more streets, be located to discourage through traffic. 
(Code 1971, §§ 19-48, 19-49) 
Secs. 316-108-316-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR TYPE B PARKS 

Sec. 316-136. - Compliance required. 
    Any mobile home park type B established, constructed, erected, extended, altered, expanded and/or improved within the city shall conform to and comply with the minimum standards provided by this division. 
(Code 1971, § 19-54) 
Sec. 316-137. - Area. 
    Each mobile home park type B shall provide a minimum of two acres in area. 
(Code 1971, § 19-55) 
Sec. 316-138. - Layout of streets and blocks. 
    Within a mobile home park type B, no block shall be longer than 1,320 feet in length, and streets shall be laid out to provide a minimum distance of 250 feet, center of street to center of street, between intersections. 
(Code 1971, § 19-56) 
Sec. 316-139. - Mobile home lot standards. 
    Each and every mobile home lot in a type B mobile home park shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  The lot shall be served with sanitary sewer, water and electrical power. 
(2)  The lot shall provide for the placement of one single-family mobile home with all garages, carports, enclosed rooms and porches being subordinate to this primary use. 
(3)  No average dimension (width or depth) shall be less than 50 feet. 
(4)  The lot shall abut and/or have access to a publicly dedicated street for a minimum distance of 20 feet. 
(5)  The lot shall provide a minimum area of 5,400 square feet, determined by the lot lines. 
(6)  Double frontage of mobile home lots should be avoided. 
(7)  The lot shall be officially recorded in a subdivision plat. 
(Code 1971, § 19-57) 
Sec. 316-140. - Mobile home stand. 
    Prior to occupancy of any mobile home lot in a type B mobile home park, it must be provided with a mobile home stand or foundation for the placement of a single-family mobile home. The mobile home stand shall be impervious to plant material such as weeds, grass and shrubs. The minimum stand shall be the same size as the mobile home to be placed on the lot. The stand may be provided by either the developer or the owner. 
(Code 1971, § 19-58) 
Sec. 316-141. - Traffic access. 
    No vehicular or pedestrian access to a mobile home lot in a type B mobile home park shall be permitted from a publicly dedicated street not completely contained or located within the tract of land authorized as a mobile home park. No access to a mobile home lot shall be permitted except when the lot directly across the public street is located in the mobile home park and designated as and complying with the standards for a mobile home lot. 
(Code 1971, § 19-59) 
Sec. 316-142. - Off-street parking. 
    Off-street parking in a type B mobile home park shall be provided at a minimum rate of two spaces for each mobile home lot, prior to occupancy of any mobile home. 
(Code 1971, § 19-60) 
Sec. 316-143. - Setbacks. 
    All mobile home stands and attached mobile homes and all other structures in a type B mobile home park shall be located a minimum of: 
(1)  Fifteen feet from any mobile home park property or boundary line adjacent to a publicly dedicated street not providing access to the mobile home lot; fences are excluded. 
(2)  Twenty feet from the front lot line. 
(3)  Ten feet from the rear lot line. 
(4)  Five feet from the side lot line. 
(Code 1971, § 19-61) 
Sec. 316-144. - Public facilities. 
    Public facilities in a type B mobile home park shall be provided as required by the subdivision ordinance in chapter 332. 
(Code 1971, § 19-62) 
Sec. 316-145. - Additional land uses. 
    Notwithstanding any other section of this chapter, in a mobile home part type B the dwelling units shall be allowed to include only mobile homes and federal or state-approved manufactured or industrialized housing, all subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  No lot shall contain more than one dwelling unit; and 
(2)  Each dwelling unit shall comply with all standards set out in this chapter for mobile homes in mobile home parks type B, except that sections 316-1, 316-5, 316-6 and 316-140 shall be applicable only to mobile homes. 
(Code 1971, § 19-63; Ord. No. 2008-235.78, 10-21-2008) 
Chapter 320 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]

IX. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 320-1-320-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-1100.44, pt. 4, adopted Oct. 30, 2007, renumbered the former §§ 320-1-320-5 as §§ 300-1-300-5. The historical notations have been retained with the renumbered provisions. 
Sec. 320-6. - Public hearing to review subdivision plats for approval or rejection. 
(a)  A public hearing shall be held by the planning and zoning commission to review for approval or rejection all subdivision plats. Such authority to approve subdivisions plats and permit their development is vested in the planning and zoning commission by the city commission. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall bar the applicant from submitting a new subdivision plat for the property which is the subject of the suggested plat to the planning and zoning commission if such plat is rejected. 
(Code 1971, § 26-12) 
Sec. 320-7. - Transportation plan. 
    The city's transportation plan shall consist of all the following documents, which are hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this Code and to be a part of the city's comprehensive plan: 1995-2015 Brownsville Urban Transportation Plan, as amended from time to time by the city metropolitan planning organization. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13; Ord. No. 94-1100.19, pt. 1, 11-29-1994; Ord. No. 96-1100.22, pt. 1, 7-23-1996) 
Secs. 320-8-320-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK FACILITIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, adopted Dec. 13, 2011, repealed art. II and enacted a new article as set out herein. The former art. II, §§ 320-36-320-38 and 320-66-320-68, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 98-1259, pt. 2(26-600, 26-601, 26-641, 26-642, 26-644), adopted Aug. 4, 1998; and Ord. No. 99-1100.28, pt. 1(26-601, 26-602), pts. 2-4, adopted July 6, 1999. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86. 

Sec. 320-36. - Generally. 
    This chapter provides for the construction and maintenance of sidewalks on private property throughout the city for the safety and convenience of pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 320-37. - Design standards. 
(a)  All sidewalks installed within the city shall comply with city design standards for width, location, construction material, finish, appearance and structural quality. City design standards, as that term is used in this chapter, shall mean the following: 
(1)  Sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete unless otherwise approved by the engineering department 
(2)  Sidewalks shall be four feet in width, and located adjacent and parallel to the property line with a minimum unpaved parkway width of four feet. The parkway width is the distance from the back of curb to the leading edge of the sidewalk. 
(3)  If physical constraints, sidewalk continuity, urban type development or other factors require sidewalks to be placed against the back of curb, the width of sidewalk shall be increased to a minimum of five feet. In locations where buildings are typically constructed at the property line (for example, in the downtown area), the minimum sidewalk width shall either be (a) seven and one-half feet; or (b) the distance between the property line and the leading edge of the street or the back edge of the curb if applicable if said distance is less than seven and one-half feet. 
(4)  Wherever sidewalks are constructed, the remaining parkway width, whether between the curb and sidewalk or sidewalk and property line, shall remain unpaved. 
(5)  "Meandering" sidewalks are permitted but shall be no closer than four feet from the back of the curb at the nearest point. 
(6)  If any connection opportunities exist, sidewalks must be connected. Additionally, it shall be the duty of the developer or owner of the lot or parcel of land to ensure the continuation of all existing sidewalks and shall match existing widths and dimensions. The lot owner shall assume the responsibility of installation, maintenance and repair of the required sidewalks along the frontage(s) upon occupying the structure on the lot. 
(b)  Sidewalks and related sidewalk ramps shall conform to Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Texas Accessibility Standards requirements. 
(c)  All sidewalks shall be setback/offset a minimum of two feet from street curbs, edges of asphalt or grade lines. Sidewalks shall be at least four feet wide and shall be located between the street curb, edge of asphalt or grade line of the public street and the ROW line or public access easement if approved by the city. The city engineer may alter alignment so that the sidewalk meanders within the area between the curb and right-of-way line. 
(1)  In the event that an owner of a lot or parcel of land cannot install the sidewalks with the two-foot setback/offset, then the owner must contact the city in writing and consult with the planning or engineering department, and obtain a written notice allowing for an alternative design. 
(d)  The specific design and location of all sidewalks must be in accordance with the current subdivision sidewalk plan however if no such plan exists as part of the subdivision, the design and location shall be reviewed by the building, engineering, and planning departments before being approved. The city engineer, planning and building official must be in agreement and may alter alignment so that the sidewalk meanders within the area between the curb and right-of-way line. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011; Ord. No. 2016-1600.02, 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 320-38. - Newly-developing areas. 
(a)  Sidewalks are required on both sides of all publicly-maintained streets within the city. 
(b)  The location and design of sidewalks shall normally be determined during the subdivision process or if subdivision has already occurred then at the site review/building permit process. 
(c)  Due to the potential damage sidewalks can incur during the construction of homes and other buildings, sidewalks should not be installed until building work has been completed on individual properties. Exceptions may be made for streets that are without direct property access. 
(d)  Implementation and construction costs of all sidewalks in newly developing areas shall be paid for by the developer, builder or property owner. The city shall not be liable for any sidewalk implementation or construction costs. 
(e)  All required sidewalks shall be installed prior to final inspection or issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 320-39. - Redeveloping areas. 
(a)  A redeveloping or redeveloped area, as those terms are used in this chapter means the issuance of a building permit for construction that equals or exceeds 50 percent of the appraised value of any existing improvements as determined by the appraisal district in which the property is located. 
(b)  Sidewalks shall be required in redeveloping areas in the same manner as in "newly developing areas" when redevelopment occurs. 
(c)  The cost of required sidewalks shall be paid for by the developer, builder or property owner; the city will not participate in the cost. 
(d)  When the development is single family residential and in an existing subdivision the requirement for sidewalks will be determined as follows: If sidewalks already exist on more than 40 percent of the street frontage then a sidewalk will be required. If no sidewalks exist on that particular street and no connections can be made then sidewalks will not be required. 
(e)  All required sidewalks shall be installed prior to final inspection or issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 320-40. - Existing developed areas. 
(a)  New sidewalks. New sidewalks may be installed in existing developed areas by either of the following methods: 
(1)  By the property owner at property owner's expense. Property owners may construct sidewalks along their property frontage at their expense. Sidewalks constructed by individual property owners shall conform to city design standards and will be inspected by the city at no expense to the property owner. 
a.  Sidewalks constructed by private property owners must be constructed by qualified bonded contractors under permit by the city building department. 
(2)  By the city at city's expense. The city may install sidewalks to enhance the safety and convenience of pedestrians. Priority is given to continuous sidewalks that serve a higher number of pedestrians on more heavily-traveled streets or where children typically walk to schools, parks and community centers. City staff prioritizes locations and these are approved by city commission annually. The number of sidewalks constructed each year is dependent upon funding availability. The city may also install sidewalks as part of a city-funded street reconstruction or public building construction project. 
(b)  Replacement sidewalks. The maintenance and repair of sidewalks is the responsibility of each individual property owner. The city reserves the right to inspect all sidewalks within city rights-of-way and to notify property owners to make repairs when their sidewalks become unsafe. 
(1)  Examples of conditions rendering sidewalks unsafe shall include but not be limited to: 
a.  Uneven sidewalks. 
b.  Broken concrete. 
c.  Overgrown weeds. 
(2)  Where sidewalk repair or replacement is impractical due to physical conditions or lack of right-of-way, the city may elect to remove the sidewalk and return the property to grass. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 320-41. - Sidewalk plans. 
(a)  Sidewalk plans shall be required for any new subdivision and shall be submitted during platting process and shall also contain the following information: 
(1)  Location of sidewalks, landings, and curb ramps. 
(2)  Design specifications and details. 
(3)  Identify the party responsible for the construction of the sidewalks. 
(b)  Sidewalk plans will be reviewed during the subdivision process and approved by the city engineering and planning departments. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 320-42. - Special provisions. 
    If special conditions make sidewalk construction infeasible, unnecessary or undesirable, and such conditions have been verified by city staff, the sidewalk requirement may be waived. Such waivers shall be only be granted by the board of adjustments upon submission of an application requesting a hearing before the board of adjustments. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 320-43. - Enforcement and penalties; severability. 
    A violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable in accordance with section 1-13. The terms and provisions of this article are severable in accordance with section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1600.00, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Chapter 324 - QUALIFIED NEIGHBORHOOD ORGANIZATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Planning and development, ch. 320. 

Sec. 324-1. - Duties of city manager. 
(a)  The city manager shall be responsible for administering this chapter. 
(b)  The city manager shall give technical assistance to persons attempting to start a qualified neighborhood organization. 
(Code 1971, § 26-250) 
Sec. 324-2. - Authority. 
(a)  Each neighborhood organization qualified under this chapter may exercise all rights guaranteed by law as well as such other rights as may be granted thereto by city ordinance. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter shall restrict the power of the city to allow organizations not qualified under this chapter to participate in hearings or receive notices. 
(c)  Each qualified neighborhood organization shall receive one free copy of each public document requested by such organization if the document concerns any area inside or within a radius of 500 feet from the boundaries of such organization and if the pages are no larger than 11 inches by 17 inches. 
(Code 1971, § 26-251) 
Sec. 324-3. - Qualification order. 
(a)  A neighborhood organization shall be qualified under this chapter if the city manager issues an order designating it as a qualified neighborhood organization. 
(b)  The city manager shall not refuse to designate a neighborhood organization as representative of a particular area merely because one or more other neighborhood organizations represent part or all of the same area as long as each complies with the requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  The city manager shall issue an order designating a neighborhood organization as qualified under this chapter if he finds that: 
(1)  The neighborhood organization has submitted to the city manager a completed application for a qualification order; 
(2)  Such application is filed using a form specified by the city manager; 
(3)  Such application form includes: 
a.  The exact name of the organization; 
b.  The exact boundaries of the area represented by the organizations; 
c.  The current names and addresses of its officers and directors; 
d.  The name, address, and phone number of its representative or office for the receipt of notices and other communications; and 
e.  The frequency, time, and place of its regular meetings; 
(4)  Attached to such application form are all of the following documents: 
a.  The bylaws of the organization; and 
b.  A certified copy of a duly filed assumed name certificate filed with the county clerk by the organization pursuant to V.T.C.A., Business and Commerce Code ch. 36, title 4, with the period during which the particular assumed name certificate may be used extending at least two years into the future; 
(5)  The organization's name is reasonably unique; 
(6)  The organization's boundaries facilitate the efficient administration of this chapter by: 
a.  Minimizing the number of boundary calls; 
b.  Generally following streets, alleys, platted lot lines, or similar features; 
c.  Generally avoiding the splitting of blocks; 
d.  Generally following front lot lines instead of rear or side lot lines; and 
e.  Generally following rear lot lines instead of side lot lines; 
(7)  The area inside such boundaries consists of one contiguous area which contains no outparcels and which has a minimum width of no less than 200 feet; 
(8)  The organization represents at least 25 percent of the tax accounts, other than rights-of-way, within its boundaries; 
(9)  The organization represents at least three of the tax accounts, other than rights-of-way, within its boundaries; and 
(10)  Such representation is shown by membership or other evidence satisfactory to the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 26-252) 
Sec. 324-4. - Suspension. 
    The city manager may suspend an organization's qualification order under this chapter if such organization fails to continue to comply with the requirements of section 324-3. 
(Code 1971, § 26-253) 
Sec. 324-5. - Expiration. 
(a)  Qualification orders issued under section 324-3 shall automatically expire on March 1 of every odd-numbered year unless renewed by the city manager. 
(b)  Not more than six months nor less than three months before such expiration date, the city manager shall give notice to each qualified neighborhood organization of the need to file a renewal application in order to remain qualified. 
(Code 1971, § 26-254) 
Chapter 328 - SIGNS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2006-1452-A, adopted Dec. 5, 2006, amended Ch. 328 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 328, §§ 328-1-328-36, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1971, §§ 71/2-3.1, 71/2-3.3, 71/2-3.4, 30-3; and Ord. No. 2006-1452, adopted Mar. 7, 2006. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86; planning and development, ch. 320; zoning, ch. 348. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 328-1. - Title. 
    Chapter 328 of the Brownsville Code of Ordinances shall be known, cited and referred to as the "Sign Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 2006-1452-A, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 328-2. - Purpose 
    The purpose of this chapter shall be to coordinate the type, placement, and scale of signs within the different land-use zones to recognize the commercial communication requirements of all sectors of the business community; to encourage the innovative use of design; to promote both renovation and proper maintenance to allow for special circumstances; and to guarantee equal treatment under the law through accurate record keeping and consistent enforcement. These shall be accomplished by regulation of the display, erection, use, and maintenance of signs. The use of signs is regulated primarily by type and length of street frontage, though lot size, investment, and surrounding conditions must also be considered. No sign shall be permitted as a main or accessory use except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1452-A, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 328-3. - Jurisdiction and authority. 
(a)  This chapter shall apply to all property within the corporate city limits. 
(b)  The application of this chapter is hereby extended to all of the area under the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction and the provisions of this chapter shall prevail over any county prohibition or regulation imposed or adopted under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 394 if there is a conflict. 
(c)  This chapter is adopted under the authority of the constitution and laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1452-A, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 328-4. - Scope. 
    This chapter shall not relate to building design. Nor shall the chapter regulate official traffic or government signs; the copy and message of signs; signs not intended to be viewed from a public right-of-way; window displays; product dispensers and point of purchase displays; scoreboards on athletic fields; flags of any nation, government or noncommercial organization; gravestones; barber poles; religious symbols; commemorative plaques; the display of street numbers; or any display or construction not defined herein as a sign. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1452-A, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 328-5. - Signs covered. 
    Signs and sign structures, unless exempted under section 328-6, shall comply with the provisions of this chapter, except that all signs and sign structures must comply with the following provisions: 
(1)  Section 328-12 (Illegal signs). 
(2)  Section 328-16 (Encroachments within public right-of-way). 
(3)  Section 328-17 (Existing sign encroachment). 
(4)  Section 328-18 (Removal of encroachment constituting obstructions). 
(5)  Section 328-19 (Unsafe signs declared nuisances; abatement). 
(Ord. No. 2006-1452-A, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 328-6. - Signs not requiring permits. 
    The following types of signs are exempted from permit requirements but must be in conformance with all other requirements of this chapter. 
(1)  Signs required by law. 
(2)  Signs or lettering on busses, taxis, or other vehicles operating during the normal course of business (this does not apply to portable signs or other signs which are parked or located for the primary purpose of displaying, said sign). 
(3)  Signs used by churches, synagogues, or civic organizations. 
(4)  Temporary construction signs of 32 square feet or less. 
(5)  Temporary directional/information signs of 12 square feet or less. 
(6)  Holiday or special events decorations including state or country flags. 
(7)  Nameplates of three square feet or less. 
(8)  Political signs. 
(9)  Public signs or notices, or any sign relating to an emergency, including signs erected by local, state, or federal government. 
(10)  Real estate signs located on the property advertised by the sign. 
(11)  Window signs. 
(12)  Incidental signs. 
(Ord. No. 2006-1452-A, 12-5-2006) 
Sec. 328-7. - Definitions. 
    Certain terms are defined for the purposes of this chapter as follows: 
    Abandoned sign means a sign which no longer identifies or advertises a bona fide business, lessor, service, owner, product, or activity, and/or for which no legal owner can be found. 
    Address means a number placed on the front and back where alley is located. 
    Administrator means the code administrator or his designated representative. 
    Animated sign means a sign or display manifesting either kinetic or illusionary motion occasioned by natural, manual, mechanical, electrical, or other means (see also and note difference from changeable sign). Animated signs include the following types: 
(1)  Naturally energized: Signs whose motion is activated by wind or other atmospheric impingement. Wind driven signs include flags, banners, pennants, streamers, spinners, metallic disks, or other similar devices designed to move in the wind.
