viii.  Complete lot, block and reserve-area numbers; 
ix.  The edge of water for all rivers, lakes and resacas; 
x.  The boundaries of all flood areas; 
6.  For the area that is outside the boundaries of the proposed subdivision and that is within 25 feet thereof: 
i.  All existing easements that are recorded in the county map records; 
ii.  All existing nonroad rights-of-way that are recorded in the county map records; 
7.  For the area that is outside the boundaries of the proposed subdivision and that is within 125 feet thereof: 
i.  All existing road rights-of-way that are recorded in the county map records or used as state road rights-of-way; 
ii.  The names and boundaries of all subdivisions recorded in the county map records, with their page numbers and volume or cabinet numbers; 
8.  For a sufficiently large area: 
i.  A corner of the survey or subdivision of which the proposed subdivision is a part; 
ii.  At least one tie from such corner to a corner of the proposed subdivision; 
d.  With the final plat showing all of the following nonmapped information in the manner specified by this chapter, the planning commission, and the relevant executing entity: 
1.  On each sheet of the final plat: 
i.  A plat caption located in the lower righthand corner of the sheet; 
ii.  A blank planning commission certificate; 
2.  On one or more sheets of the final plat: 
i.  A narrative metes and bounds description of the entire boundary of the proposed subdivision; 
ii.  Surveyor's certificate; 
iii.  Blank county clerk's certificate; 
iv.  Certificates for all owners of the proposed subdivision; 
v.  Acknowledgements for all such owners' certificates; 
vii.  Certificates for all lienholders of the proposed subdivision; 
viii.  Acknowledgements for all such lienholders' certificates; 
ix.  Certificates for all general purpose tax collectors having any jurisdiction over property within the proposed subdivision, with each such certificate stating only that all taxes owed to the taxing unit represented by such tax collector are currently paid in full for the area inside the boundaries of the proposed subdivision; 
x.  Certificates for all utility districts within which the proposed subdivision is located; 
xi.  At least one potable water retailer's certificate; 
xii.  Certificates for all local health departments, if on-site wastewater disposal is proposed; 
e.  With all the information that is required by subsections (4)c and (4)d of this section being shown in a manner consistent with the following criteria: 
1.  The vicinity map shall be at a scale of one inch equals 2,000 feet; 
2.  Tie lines located more than 125 feet from the boundary of the proposed subdivision may include any necessary breaks; 
3.  All other mapped information shall be at a scale of one inch equals 100, 60, 50, 40, 30, 20, or ten feet; 
4.  For all rights-of-way and all easements shown inside the proposed subdivision or within 125 feet thereof, the plat shall show all width dimensions and all existing street names; 
5.  For all straight lines, the information shall be sufficient to determine readily the location, bearing and length of all such lines and sufficient to reproduce such lines upon the ground; 
6.  For all curved lines other than flood area boundaries or edges of water, the information shall be sufficient to determine readily the location of the end points of such lines and to determine readily the following curve data: central angle, radius, tangent length, and arc length; 
7.  All nonmapped information shall be separated from all mapped information by blank spaces at least one-half inch wide; 
8.  All information shall be precise, accurate, unambiguous, and clearly legible at one-half reduction; and 
9.  Each statement on the face of the plat shall be contained within the body of one of the nonmapped items required by subsection (4)d of this section. No such item shall refer to any document being attached to the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 24, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(24), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-O, §§ 1, 2, 4, 5-8-1984; Ord. No. 567-R, §§ 3, 4, 2-5-1986; Ord. No. 99-567-KK, pt. 2, 9-7-1999; Ord. No. 2001-567-NN, pt. 2, 9-26-2001; Ord. No. 2003-567-RR, pt. 1, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 332-74. - Primary screening. 
(a)  The planning commission shall hold approximately 26 regular meetings per year. Such meetings shall be scheduled so as to be ten to eight working days apart. 
(b)  At least 14 working days before the planning commission meeting at which the complete and fully executed final plat application shall be considered, each final plat applicant shall submit the following items to the plat administrator: 
(1)  Full payment of the initial screening fee; 
(2)  An application form that provides enough information to determine the exact name of the proposed subdivision and to determine the address and telephone number of the applicant; 
(3)  A sufficient number of copies of the final plat: 
a.  With the number of copies being specified by the plat administrator; 
b.  With the final plat not necessarily meeting all the requirements of section 332-73(4); 
(4)  A sufficient number of copies of the construction documents: 
a.  With the number of copies being specified by the planning commission; 
b.  With the construction documents being reasonably complete, as specified by the city manager and the public utilities board; and 
(5)  Enough information to allow the plat administrator to advertise the location of the proposed subdivision in the newspaper. 
(c)  At least 11 working days before such meeting, the plat administrator shall make available to the applicant written notification of his nonbinding opinion as to whether or not the final plat application is complete. Such written notification shall include an unofficial checklist citing any unsatisfied subsections of section 332-73. 
(d)  At least six working days before such meeting, each applicant shall have submitted a complete and fully executed final plat application to the plat administrator. Thereafter, no changes of any nature shall be made to the final plat application unless secondary screening is repeated. 
(e)  A final plat shall be deemed to be fully executed if all of the following entities or their duly authorized agents have properly executed their respective certificates and acknowledgements on the face of the final plat in the manner specified by this chapter, the planning commission, and the relevant executing entity: 
(1)  The surveyor. 
(2)  All owners of the proposed subdivision. 
(3)  All lienholders of the proposed subdivision. 
(4)  Notarizing officers for all of such owners and lienholders. 
(5)  All general purpose tax collectors having any jurisdiction over property within the proposed subdivision. 
(6)  All nondrainage districts within which the proposed subdivision is located. 
(7)  The potable water retailer. 
(8)  All local health departments, if on-site wastewater disposal is proposed. 
(f)  At least four working days before such meeting, the plat administrator shall transmit all applications, as defined by subsection (b) of this section, to each member of the planning commission for review and shall transmit copies of all construction documents to the public utilities board and the city engineer for review. 
(g)  All other primary screening procedures shall be as specified by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 25, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(25), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-O, § 3, 5-8-1984; Ord. No. 99-567-KK, pt. 3, 9-7-1999) 
Sec. 332-75. - Review. 
    The final plat application shall be reviewed in accordance with the procedures specified by the planning commission, city manager and public utilities board. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 26, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(26), 8-5-1981) 
Sec. 332-76. - Secondary screening. 
(a)  At the planning commission meeting at which the complete and fully executed final plat application shall be considered, the plat administrator shall present to the planning commission his nonbinding opinions on completeness and execution. Then all persons in the audience shall be entitled to make comments concerning the execution and completeness of the application. Then the planning commission shall decide whether or not the final plat application was simultaneously complete and fully executed, as defined in sections 332-73 and 332-74(e). The planning commission shall make no other decisions or commitments with respect to the application during secondary screening. 
(1)  If the planning commission decides that the application was not simultaneously complete and fully executed as of the deadline specified in section 332-74(d), the applicant shall repeat secondary screening by complying with section 332-74(d). The applicant shall submit full payment of a repeat screening fee to the plat administrator either before the adjournment of such meeting or at least ten working days before the subsequent regular meeting at which secondary screening is to be repeated. 
(2)  If the planning commission decides that the application was simultaneously complete and fully executed as of the deadline specified in section 332-74(d), then, and only then, the planning commission chairman shall open a public hearing on the final plat application. Such hearing shall be opened at the same meeting, after all screening of applications has been finished. 
(b)  All other secondary screening procedures shall be as specified by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 27, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(27), 8-5-1981) 
Sec. 332-77. - Approval of final plat. 
(a)  Before voting on the final plat, the planning commission shall advertise and hold a public hearing as required by section 320-6 of the city Code. If the proposed subdivision is located within a drainage district, then the planning commission shall not close such public hearing unless either: 
(1)  The drainage district has fully executed its approval certificate on the face of the final plat; or 
(2)  The next regularly scheduled planning commission meeting would be more than 30 days after the date on which such public hearing was first opened. 
(b)  When the planning commission closes the public hearing on a final plat application, the planning commission shall either: 
(1)  Approve the final plat without conditions and without modifications; or 
(2)  Reject the final plat. 
(c)  The planning commission shall not reject the final plat if the final plat application conforms to all applicable comprehensive plans and all applicable city ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(d)  If a final plat application is submitted, such application and all actions pertaining thereto shall become null and void unless the corresponding final plat is approved by the planning commission on or before the one-year anniversary date of such submittal. 
(e)  Upon approval of a final plat application by the planning commission, the city shall be responsible for filing said plat with the appropriate county office(s) and providing any required related information in accordance with county regulations. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 28, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(28), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 98-567-II, pt. 4, 8-4-1998; Ord. No. 2003-567-RR, pt. 2, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 2008-567-TT, art. I, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 332-78. - Approval of construction documents. 
(a)  No construction documents shall be officially approved by the city engineer or the public utilities board prior to planning commission approval of the corresponding final plat, except as provided in section 332-256. 
(b)  All other construction documents procedures shall be as specified by the city manager and the public utilities board. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 29, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(29), 8-5-1981) 
Sec. 332-79. - Filing with plat administrator. 
    Any tract of land situated within the city's jurisdiction and proposed to be subdivided under the conditions set out below may file a plat directly with the plat administrator. The plat administrator, upon the receipt of plat filed under this section, shall verify the conditions set out below and upon verification thereof is hereby authorized to approve such plat as specified in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.0065. Upon approval, the signature and recording requirements for other plats covered by this section shall be carried out. 
(1)  In order to qualify for approval under this section, the minor plat must conform to the following requirements: 
a.  There will be no more than four lots in the subdivision, including reserved areas; 
b.  All lots front on an existing dedicated public street; 
c.  The subdivision does not require the creation of any new street; 
d.  All lots will be served by existing municipal facilities (water, sewer, drainage); and 
e.  The plat must limit the use of lots for single family residential units or be limited under the appropriate zoning limitation, if in city limits. 
(2)  It is the subdivider's responsibility to satisfy all outside agency requirements including, but not limited to drainage and irrigation districts, Cameron County, the state department of transportation, the Environmental Protection Agency, the state commission on environment quality and the agency on international boundaries water commission. Approval of subdivision by planning and community development director or his designee does not represent that the subdivider has met the requirements of any other agency. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1100.45, pt. 1, 1-8-2008) 
Secs. 332-80-332-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 332-106. - Procedures generally. 
(a)  No construction work shall start or continue within any subdivision before the construction documents have been approved and before the city engineer and the public utilities board engineer have issued notices to proceed. The applicant shall construct all proposed items included in the construction documents. 
(b)  All other procedures governing the construction of improvements shall be as specified by section 332-166 and by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 30, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(30), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 99-567-JJ, pt. 2, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 332-107. - Procedures for acceptance of dedication and improvements. 
    For the purposes of this article, the procedures governing the acceptance of offers of dedication and governing the acceptance of improvements shall be as specified by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 50, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(50), 8-5-1981) 
Secs. 332-108-332-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADDITIONAL PROCEDURES 

Sec. 332-136. - Scope. 
    The additional procedures set forth in this article shall supplement rather than replace the basic procedures of article II of this chapter. Whenever this article and article II of this chapter conflict with each other, the conflicting sections of this article shall govern. Procedural flexibility is allowed by article V of this chapter in certain cases. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 60, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(60), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-O, § 6, 5-8-1984) 
Sec. 332-137. - Extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(a)  This section shall be applicable to any subdivision which is wholly or partly within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(b)  Proposed final plats shall comply with all subsections of section 332-73(4)d.2.i-xii and shall also comply with the following supplemental subsections of such section: 
xiii.  Blank county commissioners court's certificate; 
xiv.  Blank county building official's certificate; and 
xv.  Blank county engineer's certificate. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 65, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(65), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-O, § 6, 5-8-1984; Ord. No. 99-567-KK, pt. 4, 9-7-1999; Ord. No. 2003-567-RR, pt. 3, 9-16-2003) 
Secs. 332-138-332-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 332-166. - General standards. 
(a)  General requirements. General requirements for subdivisions are as follow: 
(1)  Streets. Streets in general must conform to the following: 
a.  The minimum width of right-of-way or right-of-way easement for any nonarterial street shall be 50 feet. 
b.  Streets shall be in line with existing arterial streets in adjoining subdivisions, unless a junction with existing streets will be harmful to the character of the subdivision. The minimum width of arterial streets shall be 80 feet. 
c.  Streets shall be named to provide continuity with existing streets. 
d.  Dead-end streets shall be avoided, except for future planning or for protection of the character of the subdivision. 
e.  Streets shall platted with appropriate regard to all topographical features lending themselves to attractive treatment and layout of utilities. All approaches to arterial streets shall be perpendicular for safety purposes. 
f.  Street curb height shall be as specified by the city engineer. However, such height shall never be greater than six inches and shall never be less than four inches, except for the actual width of any sidewalk curb ramp, driveway, alley, or similar feature. 
g.  All intersecting streets shall be perpendicular to each other. 
(2)  Parcels. Parcel dimensions shall be as follows: 
a.  In no case shall any parcel be less than 3,000 square feet in net area. 
b.  In no case shall any parcel's average length be more than four times greater than such parcel's average width, as calculated by the city engineer for such parcel's net area. (See the exception under section 332-224.) 
c.  In no case shall the average width of any parcel be less than 40 feet. 
d.  In no case shall any parcel's front width be narrower than 20 feet on a curbed street or on any private street or narrower than 100 feet on a noncurbed public street. Each parcel shall abut a street. (See the exceptions under sections 332-224, 332-226 and 332-227.) 
(b)  Improvements. Standards for improvements are as follows: 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section and sections 332-167(b), 332-223 and 332-229, the construction documents shall include all of the following items: road pavement, stand-up curb and gutter, sidewalk curb ramps and landings, proposed or potential sidewalks and passing spaces, water lines, fire hydrants, sanitary sewer lines, manholes, laterals, storm drainage facilities, street signs, streetlights, utility easements, drainage easements, corner clips, monuments, and other appropriate items. 
(2)  Except as otherwise specified, the city engineer shall have authority to waive one or more of the items listed in subsection (b)(1) of this section if, and only if, the item does not need to be constructed because the item already exists or because such construction would be contrary to good engineering practice. 
(3)  All items included in the construction documents shall be designed in accordance with good engineering practices acceptable to the city engineer and the public utilities board. 
(4)  The subdivider shall provide at his expense the proper size of utilities improvements as outlined in this subsection for his subdivision. If the planning and zoning commission, in cooperation with the city engineer and the public utilities board, believes that the lines need to be larger to provide for future growth of other subdivisions, the public utilities board shall pay for the difference in cost in order to get the larger lines. 
(5)  The minimum width of the pavement shall be 32 feet back to back of curb. If it is deemed by the planning and zoning commission that such street shall carry through traffic and therefore needs to be wider, the subdivider shall pay for the 32 feet, including curb and gutter, and the city shall pay for whatever additional width it deems necessary for good planning and future growth. If such street may have traffic heavier than residential traffic with through traffic, the subdivider shall pay for the thickness as outlined in the schedule for pavement of streets for residential streets, and the city shall pay for any additional thickness that is deemed desirable. 
(6)  This subsection shall be applicable to any dedicated or prescriptive street right-of-way which abuts the outside boundary of the proposed subdivision and which provides ingress to any parcel of the subdivision in accordance with the following: 
a.  If the subdivision is a minor plat, the only applicable pavement standards for such abutting right-of-way shall be as follows: 
1.  Compacted caliche at least four inches deep and at least 20 feet wide complying with state specifications; or 
2.  Equivalent standards acceptable to the city engineer. 
b.  If the subdivision is not a minor plat, the only applicable pavement standards for such abutting right-of-way shall be as follows: 
1.  Hot mix asphalt concrete at least two inches deep and 24 feet wide plus prime coat and/or tack coat plus caliche base course at least six inches deep and at least 28 feet wide plus subbase course at least six inches deep and at least 32 feet wide, with all of such adhering to state specifications; or 
2.  Equivalent standards acceptable to the city engineer. 
c.  Before final plat approval, the applicant shall show that: 
1.  Such abutting right-of-way already met applicable standards; 
2.  The applicant has already improved such abutting right-of-way to applicable standards; or 
3.  The applicant has promised to improve such abutting right-of-way to applicable standards and has provided a cash deposit or letter of credit acceptable to the city engineer and city attorney for 100 percent of the cost of meeting applicable standards. If any such promised improvements are not completed by the applicant during the first year after plat approval, the city shall use those financial guarantees to make such improvements during the second year after plat approval. 
(7)  If either the public utilities board or a utility district provides trunk lines for sanitary sewer and water lines to the subdivision property line in accordance with rules established by such entity, such proposed subdivision inside the city's jurisdiction shall have public water and shall connect with the sanitary sewer system in accordance with the rules and regulations established by both such entity and the city engineer. If the public utility board or a utility district refuses for any reason to provide such trunk lines to the applicant, the applicant may seek to apply for the exception provided in section 332-223. 
(c)  Bonds. Bonds shall be given as follows: 
(1)  The subdivider must give a good and sufficient performance bond for the proper construction of such streets and alleys and all improvements in accordance with this chapter. The bond must be executed by some surety company authorized to do business in the state and will be made payable to the city and conditioned that the subdivider will construct streets within such subdivision and improvements in accordance with plans and specifications and in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. The bond shall be in an amount equal to $50.00 for each linear foot of street in the section of the subdivision to be developed. It is the intent of this subsection to allow a subdivider to develop the subdivision by sections, and the subdivider is required only to give bond for the streets and improvements in the section which will be developed immediately; however, the subdivider will be required to give a good and sufficient performance bond to the city for the proper construction of the streets and improvements in any other section of the subdivision which may be developed at a later date in accordance with any final plat which may be approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
(2)  If expense will be incurred by the city in extending either water or sewer or storm sewer trunk lines to serve the subdivision, the subdivider must furnish the following: 
a.  A written estimate, signed by the city manager, of the total expense which will be incurred by the city in extending either water or sewer or storm sewer trunk lines to serve the subdivision. 
b.  A performance bond for the subdivider's development of the proposed subdivision. The bond shall be made payable to the city and conditioned that the subdivider will develop the proposed subdivision in accordance with the terms of his final plat and the minimum subdivision requirements. The bond shall be in an amount equal to 100 percent of the total expense set forth in the estimate which will be incurred by the city in extending either water or sewer or storm sewer trunk lines to serve the subdivision. The bond shall be either from a surety company holding a permit from the state to act as surety or from some other surety acceptable to the city. 
(3)  If a required performance bond amounts to less than $50,000.00, the applicant may submit either such bond or an irrevocable letter of credit in a form acceptable to the city attorney and city engineer. 
(d)  As-built plans. The subdivider must, in writing, agree to present to the city reproducible complete as-built plans for all paving, drainage structures, water lines and sewer lines within 30 days after completion of such improvements. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 70, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(70), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-Q, §§ 1, 2, 4-23-1985; Ord. No. 567-R, § 5, 2-5-1986; Ord. No. 87-567-T, § 1, 7-7-1987; Ord. No. 88-567-U, § 1, 5-10-1988; Ord. No. 90-567-Y, pt. 1, 12-4-1990; Ord. No. 92-567-BB, pt. 5, 11-24-1992; Ord. No. 98-567-II, pts. 1, 3, 8-4-1998; Ord. No. 99-567-JJ, pts. 1, 4, 7(70.A.1.f, 70.A.2, 70.B), 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 2000-567-LL, pt. 1, 4-25-2000) 
Sec. 332-167. - Sidewalk requirements. 
    Sidewalk plans shall be required for all subdivisions. Plans shall be developed pursuant to chapter 320, article II, Sidewalk Facilities. 
(Ord. No. 98-567-II, pt. 2, 8-4-1998; Ord. No. 2011-1600.01, pt. 1, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 332-168. - Additional standards for flood areas. 
(a)  This section shall be applicable to any subdivision which is wholly or partly within a flood area. 
(b)  Article I of chapter 308 is incorporated in this section by reference, is declared to be a part of this chapter, and is made applicable to the city's territorial and extraterritorial jurisdiction, exclusive of building permit provisions and exclusive of other provisions unrelated to subdivisions. 
(c)  Proposed preliminary plats, final plats, their construction documents, and their as-built plans shall comply with all applicable sections of such article. 
(d)  Compliance with city regulations shall not excuse persons from also complying with the applicable regulations of other entities. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 78, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(78), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 87-567-S, § 1, 7-7-1987; Ord. No. 2018-1638, 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 332-169. - Applicability. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), the parkland dedication requirements in this chapter apply to: 
(1)  Residential subdivisions; and 
(2)  Commercial, nonresidential, and multi-family subdivisions or developments. 
(b)  The following are exempt from the requirements of this article: 
(1)  Re-plats of existing subdivided areas which have previously satisfied the requirements of this chapter or that existed before the passage of the ordinance from which this section derives; 
(2)  Plats containing lots of ten acres or larger, provided a note is placed on and below the name of such subdivision, to the effect that the area encompassed within the plat has not satisfied the parking requirements of the ordinance, and the requirements shall be satisfied upon the subdivision of the property; and 
(3)  Land developed which is less than two acres. 
(Ord. No. 2007-1479, pt. 1, 9-18-2007; Ord. No. 2008-1479-A, pt. 1, 12-2-2008; Ord. No. 2010-1479-B, pt. 1, 4-20-2010) 
Sec. 332-170. - Dedication of parkland required. 
(a)  A subdivision application shall provide for the parkland needs of the residents by the dedication of suitable land for park and recreational purposes under this chapter. 
(b)  For a subdivision, the area to be dedicated as parkland shall be included on the preliminary plan and the plat, and included in the dedication statement. 
(c)  The subdivider shall dedicate to the city all parkland required by this chapter as fee simple. 
(d)  The amount of parkland required to be dedicated to the city shall be 0.01 acres of land per dwelling unit in each proposed subdivision. Therefore, if a proposed subdivision is to contain 500 new dwelling units, the total dedicated amount would equal to five acres of parkland. (500 dwelling units × 0.01 acres per dwelling units = five acres). Minimum dedication amount after calculation shall be five acres. 
(e)  Areas designated in the 100-year floodplain may be dedicated in fulfillment of the dedication requirement, but shall amount to no more than 50 percent of the dedicated amount. 
(f)  The area of the parkland to be dedicated shall be measured and calculated to the centerline of any street bounding the dedicated area within the subdivision. 
(g)  Dedicated parkland shall be incorporated into the subdivision design, and shall be one contiguous parcel and not separate parcels throughout the development. 
(h)  When the subdivision is to be developed in sections or units, and the final platting of the parkland is to be included in any later section or unit, the developer shall complete and deliver to the planning and zoning commission prior to the approval of the first section or unit of such subdivision a contract executed by the developer providing for the future dedication of the parkland area. The contract shall be approved by the city attorney and the dedication accepted by the city parks and recreation board. 
(i)  All costs of dedication, including the title survey and land survey, pre-existing taxes, recording fees, and other dedication costs shall be paid by the developer. 
(j)  The following shall be excluded from the calculation for the parkland dedication requirement: 
(1)  Wetlands or resacas which would require a permit from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers for the discharge of fill or dredge material shall not be accepted as satisfaction of parkland dedication requirements. 
a.  Wetlands or resacas which shall not be accepted as satisfaction of the parkland dedication requirement may be donated as a gift to the city for use as recreational open space. 
(2)  Any land where proposed storm water drainage features will be incorporated. This is to include storm water retention ponds, swails, and other engineered drainage features. 
(Ord. No. 2010-1479-B, pt. 1, 4-20-2010) 
Sec. 332-171. - Fees in lieu of dedication. 
    The city will require fees in lieu of dedication of parkland for subdivisions in which dedication amount is calculated to be less than five acres under subsection 332-171(d) as follows: 
(1)  For single-family residential subdivisions, a park fee of equal to fair market value of the required land per dwelling unit requirement. Fair market value will be determined by the land value as shown in the Cameron County Appraisal District records. 
(2)  All land subdivided for commercial, industrial, nonresidential or multi-family uses shall pay a park fee in lieu of parkland dedication equaling the amount of two and half percent of the fair market value as determined by Cameron County Appraisal District records. 
(3)  Should the city accept any monies in lieu of parkland, the finance department shall be responsible for processing and collecting the fees before the approval of such plat. 
(4)  Funds received in lieu of dedication shall be used for acquisition or improvement of park land, preferably located within two miles from the subdivision or for acquisition of park land in highly populated/dense areas without adequate park land available. Acquisition, improvements, and location shall be determined by the city planning and development and parks and recreation departments in accordance with the master parks plan. 
(Ord. No. 2010-1479-B, pt. 1, 4-20-2010; Ord. No. 2016-1479-C, 3-15-2016) 
Secs. 332-172-332-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FLEXIBILITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 332-196-332-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCEPTIONS 

Sec. 332-221. - Issuance of permits. 
    Notwithstanding any other section of this chapter, the approval of a final plat shall not be a prerequisite for the issuance of any permit by the city inspector; provided, however, that all of the following conditions are met prior to such issuance: 
(1)  The city manager shall have prepared and the city attorney shall have approved blank forms to be completed by any person desiring to qualify for the exception described in this section; 
(2)  The person applying for a permit to undertake activities on a certain parcel of land shall have completed such blank forms and submitted them to the city manager along with all documentation requested by the blank forms; and 
(3)  Based on the information provided to him, the city manager shall have either: 
a.  Determined that: 
1.  The boundaries of such parcel were fully described by one or more title transfer instruments executed before September 1, 1995; and 
2.  On or after such date, there have been no executions of title transfer instruments such that these instruments could subject such parcel to boundary alterations; or 
b.  Determined that: 
1.  The existing and proposed structures on such parcel are limited to one single-family detached dwelling and any structures accessory to such dwelling; 
2.  Such parcel has at least 50 feet of frontage on an existing public right-of-way that is at least 40 feet wide and that is presently improved to an extent sufficient to show actual use by the public; 
3.  The owner of such parcel owns no land located within 51 feet of such parcel; 
4.  The owner of such parcel had no ownership interest in the tract from which such parcel was created; 
5.  The owner of such parcel has given the city manager a map that is sealed by a registered public surveyor and that shows the boundaries of such parcel as well as the boundaries of the tract from which such parcel was created; 
6.  The owner of such parcel has given the city manager certified copies of all legal documents that are relevant to the creation of such parcel; 
7.  The city manager has assigned a file number to such parcel and marked the location and number of such parcel on a city map maintained for such purpose; and 
8.  A copy of the completed application forms and all accompanying documentation has been transmitted by the city manager to the city attorney for possible legal action against the parties who sold such parcel to the current owner. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 80(B), 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(80(B)), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-R, § 6, 2-5-1986; Ord. No. 87-567-T, § 3, 7-7-1987; Ord. No. 97-567-EE, pt. 2, 7-15-1997; Ord. No. 2002-567-OO, pt. 2, 6-25-2002) 
Sec. 332-222. - Submission and approval of preliminary plats. 
    If a potential applicant wishes to receive a conceptual commitment from the city concerning the general layout of a proposed subdivision before submitting a final plat application, he shall submit a complete preliminary plat application in accordance with all of the following: 
(1)  Fifteen copies of the preliminary base plat shall be submitted. Both the plat and required pertinent data, as outlined elsewhere in this chapter, shall be submitted to the plat administrator at least ten working days prior to the planning and zoning commission meeting at which such plat is to be considered. The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a scale of 100 feet to one inch or larger and shall show the following information: 
a.  Name of the proposed subdivision. 
b.  Names of the owner and engineer or surveyor responsible for the survey and design. 
c.  Boundary lines, existing building lines, and width and location of platted streets, easements and alleys within and adjacent to the property. 
d.  Width and depth of proposed lots. 
e.  Contours sufficient to accurately show the topography contours, and all grades in the addition must be referred to a U.S. Coastal and Geodetic Survey or state highway benchmark. Contours at one-foot intervals are preferred. 
f.  Physical features of the property, including location of watercourses, culverts, bridges, railroads and present structures. 
g.  A designation of the proposed uses of land within a subdivision; a designation of the existing streets which the subdivider, in order to protect the character of the proposed subdivision, does not propose to extend into the proposed subdivision; and a brief statement of any curative steps proposed by the subdivider for the purpose of protecting the character of the proposed subdivision. A statement as to whether or not the subdivider proposes to construct a storm sewer system to serve the subdivision. 
h.  If there are no adjacent subdivisions, a map on a smaller scale must be presented to show the nearest subdivisions and how the streets, easements, alleys or highways in the proposed subdivision may connect with those in the nearest subdivision. 
(2)  The approval of the preliminary plat does not constitute acceptance of the subdivision but is merely an optional authorization to proceed with the preparation of the final plat. No work shall be done on the subdivision before the final plat is approved by the city. If a preliminary plat is approved by the planning and zoning commission or the city commission, the preliminary plat and all actions pertaining thereto shall become null and void unless the planning and zoning commission opens a public hearing on a corresponding final plat on or before the anniversary date of such preliminary plat approval. 
(3)  The fee in this subsection shall be paid into the general fund of the city when a preliminary plat is tendered to the plat administrator. The fee provided in this subsection shall be paid in advance, and no action of the city planning and zoning commission shall be valid until the fee shall have been paid to the plat administrator. The fee for preliminary plats shall be $25.00 per plat. The fee shall be charged regardless of whether the city planning and zoning commission grants or denies the approval of a plat. It is expressly provided that only one fee shall be charged for a preliminary plat, if one is submitted, regardless of the number of times the plat has to be revised. Further, it is expressly provided that if a subdivider chooses to develop a subdivision by section, only one preliminary plat fee, if one is submitted, will be charged so long as the subsequent development of sections is done in strict accordance with the approved final plat. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 80(D), 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(80(D)), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-R, § 6, 2-5-1986; Ord. No. 87-567-T, § 3, 7-7-1987) 
Sec. 332-223. - On-site wastewater disposal. 
    The applicant for a proposed subdivision need not connect each parcel to centralized sanitary sewer facilities if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Either: 
a.  The closest corner of the proposed subdivision shall be at a distance of more than 500 feet, as measured along the proposed sewer line, from a public gravity sanitary sewer system, and the proposed subdivision shall contain no more than one parcel for each 50-foot length of such distance beyond 500 feet including any fractions of such 50-foot lengths; or 
b.  A connection to such sewer shall involve unusual costs, such as a lift station or street boring, and the initial cost of providing centralized sewer service shall be at least $20,000.00 per parcel, with such initial cost being calculated by the public utilities board and the city engineer and being the sum of public and private costs; and 
(2)  The applicant shall have submitted a preliminary plat showing the ultimate number of parcels for the entire project and meeting all preliminary plat requirements, and the owner of the proposed project shall own no land located within 200 feet of such project, as documented by a title report prepared within 30 days of submittal; 
(3)  The applicant shall comply with all applicable health codes pertaining to sewage and sewage treatment systems if the applicant is to install on-site sewage treatment systems; 
(4)  All components of the sewage disposal system constructed by the applicant shall be in accordance with the latest edition of chapter 285 (On-Site Sewage Facilities) of title 30 of the Texas Administrative Code, as adopted by the state natural resource conservation commission (TNRCC) and as clarified by the state natural resource conservation commission regulatory guidance documents. Such chapter 285 shall be considered as minimum requirements only. Actual field conditions may dictate more stringent requirements as may be determined by the appropriate officials; and 
(5)  All sewage disposal systems not constructed by the applicant and not governed by this criteria shall conform to the regulations of applicable health departments; 
(6)  Each parcel owner shall refrain from ever requesting subsidized public sewer service. If a public gravity sanitary sewer system is subsequently extended to serve such subdivision, the owners of all parcels abutting a gravity sewer main shall connect to the public system within six months of public notification of the availability of such service. The requirements of this subsection shall be stated in the owner's certificate on the face of the final plat of the proposed subdivision at the time it is presented for approval; and 
(7)  Minimum parcel size: 
a.  In no case shall any parcel be less than 21,780 square feet in net area exclusive of flood area and exclusive of any area within 50 feet of the edge of water for any resaca, lake, or river, with each such excluded area being labeled on the final plat as "non-OSSF easement" prohibiting on-site sewer facilities inside such easement; however 
b.  Where the land use proposed by the applicant is not limited to one dwelling unit per parcel, the applicant shall meet all of the conditions of this section plus any other conditions which may be determined to be necessary in accordance with good engineering practice as determined by a nonbinding recommendation by the city engineer and the approval by the planning commission; and 
c.  Provided, further, in a subdivision containing no more than two parcels, if the proposed net area to be subdivided exclusive of flood area is less than 80,000 square feet so that the applicant cannot meet the minimum parcel size requirement in this subsection, the planning commission with the favorable vote of at least five of its members, may allow parcels smaller than 40,000 square feet in net area exclusive of flood area if subsections (1) through (6) of this section are adhered to, all state standards for parcel size are met, and it is not contrary to the public interest. If there is an appeal to the city commission under this subsection, the planning commission's decision on parcel size shall not be reversed without five favorable city commission votes. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 80(E), 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(80(E)), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-R, § 6, 2-5-1986; Ord. No. 87-567-T, § 3, 7-7-1987; Ord. No. 90-567-Z, pt. 1, 12-11-1990; Ord. No. 93-567-DD, pt. 1, 1-19-1993; Ord. No. 2000-567-HH, pts. 1-3, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 2001-567-NN, pt. 1, 9-26-2001) 
Sec. 332-224. - Exceptions for parcels existing before July 1, 1987. 
    The applicant for a proposed subdivision need not comply with section 332-166(a)(2)a or (a)(2)d if the applicant shall have proved that each parcel existed before July 1, 1987, in accordance with applicable procedures contained in section 332-221(1) through (3)a. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 80(F), 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(80(F)), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-R, § 6, 2-5-1986; Ord. No. 87-567-T, § 3, 7-7-1987) 
Sec. 332-225. - Exceptions from section 332-166. 
    The applicant for a proposed subdivision need not fully comply with section 332-166 if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  This city has issued a determination certificate under section 332-228 for each parcel in the proposed subdivision. 
(2)  The planning commission determines that the proposed subdivision would be in the public interest and that the applicant would comply with section 332-166 to the maximum reasonable extent. 
(Ord. No. 97-567-FF, pt. 1, 7-15-1997) 
Sec. 332-226. - Parcel-width exception for minor plat. 
    The applicant for a proposed subdivision on a noncurbed public street need not comply with the 100-foot provision of section 332-166(a)(2)d if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  In no case shall any parcel's front width be narrower than 20 feet on a noncurbed street. Each parcel shall abut a street. 
(2)  The city engineer has determined that there is no existing swale along that side of the street adjacent to the subdivision. 
(3)  The city engineer has determined that there is no foreseeable need for a new swale along that side of the street adjacent to the subdivision. 
(4)  The proposed subdivision constitutes a minor plat. 
(Ord. No. 2000-567-LL, pt. 2, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 2003-567-QQ, pt. 4, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 332-227. - Parcel-width exception. 
    The applicant for a proposed subdivision on a noncurbed public street need not comply with the 100-foot provision of section 332-166(a)(2)d if all the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Each cluster of narrow parcels with abutting side lines shall have a maximum of two parcels. 
(2)  In no case shall any parcel's front width be narrower than 30 feet on a noncurbed public street. Each parcel shall abut a street. 
(3)  Prior to the deadline in section 332-74(d), the proposed final plat's construction documents shall: a) show any existing driveway culverts within a radius of 100 feet from any proposed narrow-parcel frontage on the same side of the street; and b) include a driveway-culvert plan showing how each proposed narrow parcel's driveway will share a driveway culvert with one adjacent parcel. The owner's certificate on the face of the final plat shall make each narrow-parcel grantee responsible for such culvert construction in accordance with the plan. 
(4)  The proposed final plat shall show nondriveway easements along the entire frontage of each such narrow parcel and of any such adjacent parcel except for the frontage where such driveway-culvert plan shows a proposed driveway culvert. 
(5)  If a side line of a narrow parcel abuts a boundary of the proposed subdivision, then such subdivision's application shall include proof of compliance with subsection (1) of this section, regarding property fronting on the same side of the same street within a radius of 200 feet from said subdivision boundary." 
(Ord. No. 2003-567-QQ, pt. 2, 4-15-2003) 
Sec. 332-228. - Survey map. 
(a)  Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.0045(a), the divisions of land defined and classified by subsection (c) of this section shall not be required to be platted under other sections of this chapter or under chapter 336, provided that the following items are submitted to the plat administrator: 
(1)  Survey map signed and sealed by a registered professional land surveyor; 
(2)  Completed exception application form, using forms specified by the planning commission; 
(3)  Title report prepared not more than 30 days before such application form submittal; 
(4)  Proof that each parcel of such land has at least 20 feet of frontage on a street right-of-way or right-of-way easement at least 40 feet wide that is presently improved to an extent sufficient to allow reasonable usage by typical passenger vehicles; provided, however, that, for the purposes of subsection (c) of this section, the minimum frontage shall be 12 feet and the minimum right-of-way width shall be 30 feet; and 
(5)  Section 332-73(2)a, tax certificate forms for all tax collectors. 
(b)  If the planning commission makes the determination under this section that a subdivision of land does not require a plat, it shall issue the applicant a determination certificate under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.0115, so that utility services and/or building permits may be obtained by the applicant, if one of the exceptions in subsection (c) of this section so allows. 
(c)  Grandfather exception. The owner of a parcel of land is not required to file a plat thereof if: 
(1)  The boundaries of such parcel were fully described by one or more title transfer instruments executed before September 1, 1995; 
(2)  On or after such date, there have been no executions of title transfer instruments such that these instruments could subject such parcel to boundary alterations; and 
(3)  There has been full compliance with subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Public-utility-well exception. The owner of a parcel of land is not required to file a plat thereof if all the following conditions are met at the time of determination-certificate-application submittal and at all times thereafter: 
1.  The only purpose for such a plat would be to transfer the record title to a tract containing at least two acres to the Southmost Regional Water Authority or the city public utilities board or the city, where such grantee would use such tract exclusively for drilling and maintaining any water well solely for the production of potable water at any off-site reverse-osmosis treatment plant. 
(2)  Such title transfer would not cause any parcel to be in noncompliance or increase noncompliance with subsection (a)(4) of this section. 
(3)  Each driveway leading to such transferred tract would be gated and locked (except for such well-related use by the grantee) at the point where such driveway intersects a street. 
(4)  There has been full compliance with subsections (a) and (b) of this section, except as follows: 
a.  Such transferred tract need not be in full compliance with subsection (a)(4) of this section; and 
b.  If the original parcel would have qualified for a determination certificate prior to such transfer, then the survey map shall include and identify not only such transferred tract but also the remainder of the original parcel from which such tract is transferred. 
(Ord. No. 92-567-AA, pt. 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 97-567-EE, pts. 1, 3, 7-15-1997; Ord. No. 2002-567-OO, pt. 1, 6-25-2002; Ord. No. 2003-567-PP, 3-18-2003) 
Sec. 332-229. - Rural subdivision. 
(a)  Applicability. The exceptions provided by subsection (b) of this section shall be applicable to a subdivision meeting all of the following criteria: 
(1)  No portion of the proposed subdivision shall be within three miles of the city's territorial jurisdiction, unless such portion is entirely west of the east boundary of Valley Municipal Utility District Number 2. 
(2)  In no case shall any parcel be less than 40,000 square feet in net area. 
(3)  In no case shall the average width of any parcel be less than 125 feet. 
(4)  One or more of the exceptions in subsection (b) of this section shall have been requested in writing by the applicant. 
(b)  Street exception. The applicant for a proposed rural subdivision need not provide curb and gutter or 32-foot pavement width if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The minimum width of right-of-way or right-of-way easement for any nonarterial street shall be 60 feet. A ten-foot-wide drainage/utility easement shall be dedicated abutting each side of such right-of-way. 
(2)  The minimum pavement standards shall be all of the following or shall be equivalent standards acceptable to the city engineer: 
a.  The standards set forth in section 332-166(b)(6)b.1. 
b.  With all of such adhering to state specifications and any supplemental specifications of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 92-567-CC, pt. 1, 12-15-1992) 
Secs. 332-230-332-255. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - APPEALS 

Sec. 332-256. - Filing procedures. 
(a)  Any person, jointly or severally, given standing under subsection (b) of this section shall be entitled to file a notice of appeal with respect to any binding decision, as defined in this subsection; provided, however, that such notice of appeal shall be prepared and reviewed in a reasonable manner, including but not limited to all of the following elements: 
(1)  Binding decisions shall be construed to: 
a.  Be limited to decisions which shall have been made on behalf of the city and which shall have been directly or indirectly concerned with the dividing of land; and 
b.  Include the following: 
1.  Acts of commission; 
2.  Acts of omission; 
3.  Appeal rulings of the planning commission; or 
4.  Any other city commitments concerned with subdividing; but 
c.  Exclude the following: 
1.  All recommendations and opinions; and 
2.  All city commission decisions. 
(2)  Binding decisions made by individuals shall be appealed to the planning commission. 
(3)  Binding decisions made by the planning commission shall be appealed to the city commission. 
(4)  The valid filing of a notice of appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the decision being appealed, unless a stay would likely cause inability to take final action on a plat before the end of the 30-day period allowed by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.009(a). 
(5)  Except as provided in section 332-257: 
a.  Each notice of appeal shall be submitted in writing to the plat administrator within 30 days of the decision being appealed. 
b.  Each submittal of a notice of appeal shall be accompanied by payment of a fee of $100.00. 
c.  Each notice of appeal shall be submitted upon such forms as the planning commission may have prescribed for such purpose, shall include documentation of standing under subsection (b) of this section, and shall include a full and complete statement of the decision being appealed, the relief being sought, and the proposed justification for such relief. 
(6)  Within three working days following receipt of a valid and completed notice of appeal, the plat administrator shall submit to the appeal body, with a copy to the appellant, a written answer to the notice of appeal, which answer shall include findings of fact, conclusions, recommendations, justification for such recommendations, and a copy of the complete notice of appeal. 
(7)  Upon filing of the completed answer to notice of appeal, the matter shall be scheduled for public hearing upon the agenda of the next meeting of the appeal body for which the usual premeeting packets have not yet been delivered to the individual members of the appeal body. 
(8)  The plat administrator shall cause notice of such public hearing to be given in a newspaper of general circulation in the city's territorial and extraterritorial jurisdiction at least four working days before the opening of a planning commission public hearing or at least four calendar days before the opening of a city commission public hearing. 
(9)  If two or more notices of appeal against the same decision are placed on the same agenda of the appeal body, such appeals shall be consolidated into a single public hearing. Under no circumstances shall the processing of a notice of appeal against a given decision be delayed due to the filing or potential filing of another notice of appeal against the same decision. 
(10)  Upon closing such public hearing, the appeal body shall issue its ruling to: 
a.  Affirm, affirm in part, reverse, or reverse in part the decision being appealed; or 
b.  Grant such other relief as it may be empowered to grant and to which the parties may be entitled. Relief shall be granted only to the extent necessary to ensure conformance with all applicable comprehensive plans and all applicable laws, rules, and regulations. 
(b)  A person shall have standing to file a notice of appeal under this section if and only if such person is included in one or more of the following classes of persons: 
(1)  An applicant for a city commitment involving the subject property; 
(2)  A person with a pecuniary interest in any part of the subject property or of any land within 61 feet of such property; 
(3)  A person to whom a letter must be sent under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.015(b) concerning the subject property; 
(4)  The city manager; or 
(5)  A person authorized to file such a notice of appeal by a duly notarized document signed by any of the aforesaid. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 90, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(90), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-P, § 1, 2-5-1985; Ord. No. 92-567-BB, pt. 4(90.A.4, 90.B.3), 11-24-1992; Ord. No. 99-567-JJ, pt. 5, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 332-257. - Appeals of certain positive decisions. 
    Whenever the binding decision being appealed is the approval of a preliminary or final plat or the issuance during a public meeting of any other positive city commitment directly or indirectly concerned with the dividing of land, section 332-256 shall be applicable with the following exceptions: 
(1)  No notice of appeal shall be filed after the adjournment of the meeting at which such decision was made; and 
(2)  When filed, each notice of appeal shall: 
a.  Include tentative proof of standing under section 332-256(b); 
b.  Indicate when and by whom the binding decision was made; 
c.  Be accompanied by payment of a $10.00 fee; and 
(3)  Within two working days of such meeting, each notice of appeal shall: 
a.  Be accompanied by payment of an additional fee of $90.00; 
b.  Include documentation of standing under section 332-256(b); and 
c.  Include a full and complete statement of the decision being appealed, the relief being sought, and the proposed justification for such relief; and 
(4)  Each notice of appeal and each amendment thereto shall be submitted in writing to the plat administrator upon such forms as the planning commission may have prescribed for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 567, § 91, 3-30-1971; Ord. No. 567-N, § 1(91), 8-5-1981; Ord. No. 567-P, § 1, 2-5-1985; Ord. No. 99-567-JJ, pt. 6, 7-6-1999) 
Secs. 332-258-332-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLANNED DEVELOPMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Planning and development, ch. 320. 

Sec. 332-286. - Purpose. 
    The objectives of this division are to: 
(1)  Encourage flexibility in design and permit a greater diversity of building types and lotting arrangements; 
(2)  Promote the efficient use of land to facilitate a more economic arrangement of buildings, vehicular and pedestrian access, land use and utilities; 
(3)  Preserve existing landscape features and amenities and utilize such features in a proper manner; 
(4)  Allow increased usable and suitably located open space, recreation facilities and other public or private common facilities; and 
(5)  Provide a program of operation and maintenance of all such facilities and improvements for the common use of occupants within the planned development. 
(Ord. No. 90-1211, § 95, 3-13-1990) 
Sec. 332-287. - Concept plan. 
(a)  Generally. A developer or owner of land proposing a planned development (PD) is required to submit a concept plan for all the land under his ownership or control prior to subdividing the land or any portion of the land. Property partly developed prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this division derives (March 13, 1990) may qualify as a planned development provided the developer's concept plan for the undeveloped remainder also includes the existing improvements. This concept plan, when approved by the planning commission, constitutes a guide which the planning commission will refer to in the subsequent review of plats that cover all or portions of the land contained within the overall concept plan. Should the developer's future plans change, such changes are to be disclosed to the city by submitting a revised concept plan for planning commission review and approval. 
(b)  Requirements and submissions. Requirements and submissions for the concept plan are as follows: 
(1)  A filing fee of $50.00 plus $5.00 per acre shall be submitted with the concept plan. 
(2)  Fifteen copies of the concept plan shall be submitted to the city for review at least two weeks before the date at which planning commission review is desired. The concept plan should show the following information: 
a.  Name of proposed development if known, which cannot be a duplicate of any other name used within the city's jurisdiction, and the names of owners of property adjoining the tract as disclosed by the most recent ad valorem tax record. 
b.  If practical, a sheet size of 24 inches by 36 inches is preferred. 
c.  Location or vicinity map to show location of the tract within the city or the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
d.  North arrow pointing to the top of the sheet if practical. 
e.  Date; each revision to bear a new date. 
f.  If practical, a scale of one inch equals 100 feet is preferred. 
g.  Property boundary lines to scale and the acreage of the land. 
h.  Existing structures: the approximate locations of all existing structures within the tract. 
i.  Existing features: all existing streets, parking areas, easements, public utilities, drainageways, high banks of watercourses, resacas and other significant physical features or developments both within the tract and within 100 feet of it. 
j.  Flood hazard areas, approximated from flood insurance rate maps. 
k.  Proposed features: the approximate location of proposed streets, parking areas, easements, public utilities, storm drainage outfalls, high banks of watercourses. 
l.  Areas proposed to be conveyed, dedicated or reserved for parks; parkways; compensating open space; and private, public, or semipublic facilities. 
m.  Other information: If known and where applicable, show the location of proposed blocks and lots, reserves, building setback lines, footprints of buildings, number of stories and proposed usage. 
(3)  A set of covenants, restrictions, conditions and reservations shall be filed with the concept plan if the plan proposes any common areas, compensating open space, recreational facilities, private streets or private alleys. The covenants and restrictions shall: 
a.  Provide an association of lot owners charged with the responsibility of promoting the recreation, health, safety and welfare of the association members. 
b.  Provide for the improvement and maintenance of the compensating open space, private streets, alleys, or parking areas, or other private improvements. 
c.  Empower the association to levy assessments for maintenance costs and, in general, enforcing the covenants, restrictions, conditions, and reservations affecting the property. 
d.  Outline design standards to ensure a quality appearance of the proposed development. 
Upon final platting, the assessments levied shall be a continuing lien on the property against which each such assessment is made. The proposed set of covenants, restrictions, conditions, and reservations shall be reviewed by the city to ensure conformance with this division and shall be recorded at the time of final platting. 
(c)  Action by planning commission. All concept plans require approval from the planning commission. Following review of the concept plan, the planning commission shall, within 30 calendar days of the filing date, take one of the following actions: 
(1)  Approve the concept plan as submitted; 
(2)  Conditionally approve the concept plan as submitted, with the reasons for the conditional approval stated in writing and signed by the chairman of the planning commission; 
(3)  Disapprove the concept plan as submitted, with the reasons for such disapproval stated in writing and signed by the chairman of the planning commission. 
Commission action shall be noted on copies of the concept plan, with one copy returned to the developer. Failure of the planning commission to act within 30 days from the date the plan was submitted to the city will cause the plan to be deemed approved. Commission approval of the concept plan authorizes the developer to file a preliminary plat, final plat or development site plan. Conditional approval requires submitting an amended concept plan and additional information as specified by the planning commission for approval. If additional information is required, the information may be submitted concurrently with the preliminary or final plat. Should the developer or subdivision fail to file a preliminary plat, final plat, or development site plan within one year of planning commission approval of the concept plan, approval of such concept plan shall terminate upon written notice to the developer, subdivider, or owner. The developer, subdivider, or owner may request in writing a one-year extension specifying the reason why a preliminary plat, final plat, or development site plan has not been filed. 
(Ord. No. 90-1211, § 96, 3-13-1990) 
Sec. 332-288. - Guidelines. 
(a)  The purpose of the guidelines in this subsection is to establish a general checklist for preparing and reviewing planned development proposals. The guidelines identify minimum site plan requirements as well as maximum variances from existing codes and ordinances. Departures from these requirements may be considered for approval or disapproval by the planning commission or on appeal by the city commission. The guidelines are as follows: 
(1)  Project size. The project size shall be a minimum of five acres, or less if approved by the planning commission. 
(2)  Minimum access. Minimum access to a planned development shall be 50 feet on a dedicated street. 
(3)  Public streets. Public streets shall meet city standards for right-of-way, paving width, pavement thickness, curb and gutter. 
(4)  Private streets. Private streets shall have a minimum pavement width of 20 feet and a pavement thickness equal to city standards for public streets. The easement line may be coterminous with the edge of pavement. Dead-end private streets must be terminated by a circular cul-de-sac having a paving radius of not less than 40 feet or a T-type or L-type turnaround as shown in appendix A to Ordinance No. 90-1211. Private streets are to be designated as "private" on the plat. 
(5)  Driveways. Private drives shall meet city standards for curb cuts, if the intersecting street is curbed, and widths. 
(6)  Alleys. No alleys are required, but if constructed they shall meet city standards. For private alleys, the easement line may be coterminous with the edge of the pavement. Private alleys are to be designated as "private" on the plat. 
(7)  Lot size. A lot may have a gross area of not less than 1,500 square feet with the minimum width not less than 20 feet. 
(8)  Compensating open space. Where a proposed lot will have a gross area less than 3,000 square feet, compensating open space must be established and provided within the final plat boundary. The amount of compensating open space required per platted lot must be no less than the difference between 3,000 square feet and the gross area of the lot. Areas for compensating open space shall be designated on the plan or plat and are restricted to landscaping and recreational uses only. Furthermore, such areas shall be in reasonable proximity to lotted areas and shall be usable for its intended purpose. 
(9)  Building setbacks. A minimum ten-foot setback is required along the planned development boundaries except where adjacent to existing public streets, in which case a minimum 20-foot setback is required. 
(10)  Parking. On-street parking is prohibited along private streets with pavement widths of less than 28 feet. 
(11)  Storm drainage. Storm drainage shall meet city standards per section 332-166(b). 
(12)  Water distribution, sanitary sewer, streetlights. Water distribution, sanitary sewer, and streetlights shall meet standards of the public utilities board or other applicable municipal utility district. 
(b)  Following approval of the concept plan, final platting, pursuant to this chapter, is required. 
(Ord. No. 90-1211, § 97, 3-13-1990)
