ARTICLE II. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMITTEE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-311 et seq. 

Sec. 344-26. - Established. 
    There is established a beautification committee. There shall be a minimum of seven but no more than 12 voting members of the committee who shall meet as provided in this article to consider, recommend and implement programs for the beautification of public spaces and for the increase and preservation of the city's urban tree canopy for the beautification of the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-1234, § 1(26-451), 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1234-A, § 1(26-451), 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2018-1234-B, 5-7-2018) 
Sec. 344-27. - Composition and term of office. 
(a)  The composition of the membership of the beautification committee shall consist of the following: 
(1)  A city commissioner designated by the city commission to serve during the commissioner's term of office. 
(2)  A city employee designated by the city manager as the committee city liaison to coordinate between the two entities. Must remain under city employment at all times. 
(3)  Ten additional members appointed by the city commission for two-year terms. May be citizens, property owners, business operators or city employees without conflict of interest. 
(4)  The city manager shall be a non-voting ex officio member of the committee. 
(b)  The city commission shall fill vacancies for the unexpired terms of any committee member. 
(c)  A member's term in office shall commence with the first regular beautification committee meeting following the appointment and shall terminate with the beautification committee meeting at which the successor takes office. 
(d)  No voting member of the committee may be appointed to more than two consecutive terms, full or partial. An exception may be made upon majority recommendation by the committee to the commission, or by the commission's direct action. 
(e)  Any member may resign by filing a written resignation with the secretary, and any member may be terminated or removed through a majority vote of the membership. 
(Ord. No. 91-1234, § 1(26-452), 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1234-A, § 1(26-452), 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2018-1234-B, 5-7-2018) 
Sec. 344-28. - Compensation. 
    Members of the beautification committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 91-1234, § 1(26-453), 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1234-A, § 1(26-453), 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2018-1234-B, 5-7-2018) 
Sec. 344-29. - Organization and staff. 
(a)  The beautification committee shall elect a chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. Committee members may not serve more than two consecutive terms as chairperson. The city commission representative shall not be eligible for the chair. 
(b)  The beautification committee shall elect a vice-chair from among its members. The term of the vice-chair shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. Committee members may not serve more than two consecutive terms as vice-chair. 
(c)  The beautification committee shall elect a secretary from among its members. The term of the secretary shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. Committee members may not serve more than two consecutive terms as secretary. 
(d)  The beautification committee shall elect a treasurer from among its members. The term of the treasurer shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. Committee members may not serve more than two consecutive terms as treasurer. 
(e)  The beautification committee shall appoint from among them five members to serve as the Keep Brownsville Beautiful Board of Directors through a majority vote. The appointment shall last one year with eligibility for reappointment. Committee members may not serve more than two consecutive terms as a member of the board of directors. 
(f)  The beautification committee may appoint from among them two members to serve as liaisons to the Brownsville Parks and Recreation Board. The appointment shall last one year with eligibility for reappointment. Committee members may not serve more than two consecutive terms as a liaison. 
(g)  The city manager shall be responsible for providing staff support of the beautification committee and shall be responsible for providing city manpower and other resources as requested by the beautification committee as scheduling permits. 
(Ord. No. 91-1234, § 1(26-454), 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1234-A, § 1(26-454), 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2018-1234-B, 5-7-2018) 
Sec. 344-30. - Meetings. 
(a)  The beautification committee shall hold at least one regular meeting per month which shall at all times be open to the public. The time and place of the meeting shall be posted on the main bulletin board at city hall and at an accessible meeting place. 
(b)  The attendance of a majority of the appointed members shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting business at meetings. 
(c)  If a member is absent for three consecutive meetings or three unexcused absences within a 12-month period, that member may be replaced by the city commission. It is the chairman's responsibility to notify the city commission of any member to which this applies. 
(d)  Special meetings may be called by the chair, by any two officers, or by a city official. Such a meeting must abide by the same rules as a regular meeting. 
(e)  All meetings shall adhere to the Texas Opens Meeting Act, and all procedures thereunto pertaining. 
(Ord. No. 91-1234, § 1(26-455), 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1234-A, § 1(26-455), 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2018-1234-B, 5-7-2018) 
Sec. 344-31. - Duties. 
    The beautification committee shall: 
(a)  Be responsible for preparing a five-year plan for the beautification of the city through planting and landscaping. The five-year plan shall be used as a guideline for future programs. The plan shall be presented to the city commission prior to July 31 of each year. 
(b)  Develop and present to the city commission an annual plan outlining the committee's program recommendations for the upcoming fiscal year. This plan shall be presented to the city commission prior to July 31 of each year. 
(c)  Perform any additional duties as determined by the city commission that is related to beautification activities. 
(d)  Maintain affiliation with Keep Texas Beautiful through the creation and implementation of Keep Brownsville Beautiful, and oversee said organization. 
(Ord. No. 91-1234, § 1(26-456), 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1234-A, § 1(26-456), 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2018-1234-B, 5-7-2018) 
Sec. 344-32. - Funding. 
    A special account will be funded by additionally designating one percent of any city general obligation or revenue bonds or certificates of obligation issued to fund other projects. This account shall be designated to fund projects to beautify the city recommended by the beautification committee. The city commission may budget funds annually for the planning, implementation and maintenance of the beautification committee projects. 
(Ord. No. 91-1234, § 1(26-457), 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1234-A, § 1(26-457), 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2018-1234-B, 5-7-2018) 
Secs. 344-33-344-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LANDSCAPING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 344-61. - Applicability and purpose. 
(a)  This article shall apply to the entire geographic area within this city's corporate limits except for road rights-of-way. Road rights-of-way shall be governed by article IV of this chapter instead of this article. Public parks and public parkways shall be governed by both this article and article IV of this chapter. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to this city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(c)  Unless otherwise specified: 
(1)  This division shall apply to any use; 
(2)  Division 2 of this article shall apply to any single-family detached dwelling or any duplex use; and 
(3)  Division 3 of this article shall apply to any use not covered by division 2 of this article. 
(d)  This article may be known and cited as the "landscape ordinance." 
(e)  The purposes of this article are to: 
(1)  Improve the appearance of development areas, including off-street parking. 
(2)  Protect and preserve the appearance, character, and value of surrounding neighborhoods. 
(3)  Promote a positive city image reflecting order, harmony, and pride for new development, thereby strengthening business, cultural, and residential areas and increasing property values. 
(4)  Preserve significant trees and other vegetation as valuable to the general health and welfare of the public. 
(5)  Provide for the installation and maintenance of landscape screening, thereby promoting the general welfare of the public. 
(6)  Enhance the environment by improving air and water quality, reducing pollution and soil erosion, and moderating winds/temperature/humidity. 
(f)  The requirements of this article apply to the entire building site if it is completely developed by new construction and for parking-lot use. For partial development or enlargement, the requirements of this article shall be applied such that landscape improvements are required only with respect to and in proportion to new or increased building area and off-street parking spaces or the approved artificial lot line. This subsection shall control over any conflicting or inconsistent section. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-400), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-62. - Exceptions. 
(a)  This article does not apply to downtown as defined by section 348-2, with the exception of any freestanding parking lot. 
(b)  If the building site is over two acres in size, the applicant may request that the city manager designate an artificial lot to satisfy the requirements of this article. If requested, the city manager shall designate an artificial lot consistent with the purposes and policies of this article as determined from the following criteria. No artificial lot may be delineated by the city manager unless it: 
(1)  Wholly includes the area on which the construction work is to be done; 
(2)  Has an area that does not exceed 50 percent of the area of the building site; and 
(3)  Depicts and includes all proposed and existing buildings and structures, access drives, appurtenant parking required for the building expansion or new building construction and other areas functionally appurtenant to the buildings or structures. 
(c)  The requirements of this article do not apply to the reconstruction of an existing building that was physically destroyed or ruined by flooding, fire, windstorm, or act of God. This exemption shall apply only where reconstruction will not result in an increase in the paving area of the parking facilities to be provided. 
(d)  Variances and appeals under this article shall be governed by the same provisions which control zoning variances and appeals. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-402), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-63. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means the owner or the agent, heir or assign of the owner of the tract of land which is designated on a building permit application. If an agent has been appointed to represent the owner as applicant, the owner shall submit written authorization as part of the application. 
    Artificial lot means an area within a contiguous tract or parcel held under common ownership and designated on the building permit application that is delineated by the city manager for the sole purpose of satisfying the requirements of this article. 
    Buffer tree means an existing or proposed tree belonging to any of the species listed in section 344-161. 
    Caliper means the minimum diameter of a tree as measured six inches above natural ground level. 
    Developed area means that portion of a commercial or multifamily residential tract of land upon which landscape improvements will be placed. 
    Encroachment means any protrusion of a vehicle outside of a parking space, display area or accessway into the required landscaped improvements. 
    Frontage means lineal distance measured along all abutting street rights-of-way. 
    Grandfathered tree means any tree which was growing on the site before the start of designing the development and which is proposed to remain after completion of the development and which is not proposed to be transplanted. 
    Ground cover means an existing or proposed plant belonging to any of the species listed in section 344-164. 
    Historic means any tree found to have been associated with any person, place or event that has been or is likely to be designated in a historic character (age is an important criterion in historic designations). 
    Landmark means any tree found to be associated with any more recent event of profound character (i.e., first tree planted at an important event such as Arbor Day). 
    Landscape improvement means any tree, shrub, ground cover, vine, grass, other approved plant, grandfathered plant, approved mulch, approved landscaping rock, approved paver, and/or approved fountain installed in a planting area for the purpose of fulfilling the requirements of this article and does not mean artificial plants or a concrete/asphalt sidewalk. 
    Landscape plan means the plan or revision of plans that details the landscaping to be installed as required by this article. 
    Landscape screen means a fence, tree, or shrub installed for the purpose of providing screening between residential and nonresidential districts. 
    Maintain means to ensure the proper growth, vitality, and vigor of landscape improvements and to display such improvements in accordance with the letter and the spirit of this article at all times. 
    Multifamily residential means any site occupied by three or more families living independently of each other. 
    Nonresidential means of or relating to property that is zoned to an apartment F classification or zoned to a less restrictive classification. 
    Owner means any person or legal entity with an interest in land, or a lessee, agent, employee or other person acting on behalf of the owner with the owner's authorization. 
    Parking lot means any paved, surfaced, or leveled area designed and ordinarily used for accessory or public parking of motor vehicles, including commercial parking of motor vehicles, commercial parking available for lease and leased premises available for public parking as defined by applicable city ordinance. 
    Parking-lot tree means either a grandfathered tree or a tree belonging to any of the species listed in section 344-161. 
    Passenger vehicle means a motor vehicle for which a class C driver's license is required by the state and which is not being offered for sale on the site of the regulated parking space. 
    Rare means any of the many rare species regardless of their association with the Endangered Species Act (i.e., sabal palm, runyon tree, etc.). 
    Removal means any overt act which causes or may reasonably be expected to cause a plant to die by use of any chemical, machinery, tool, construction, soil compaction, substantial change in the grade (decreasing or increasing water/air supply), girdling, excessive pruning, or paving with any plant-injuring material. 
    Residential means of or relating to property that is zoned to a dwelling/retail G classification or zoned to a more restrictive classification. 
    Road means a street wider than 25 feet and/or alley 25 feet or less. 
    Road right-of-way means a public and/or private road right-of-way or a public and/or private road right-of-way easement. 
    Shall is mandatory, not directory. 
    Shrub means an existing or proposed plant belonging to any of the species listed in section 344-163. 
    Significant vegetation means any tree with a caliper nine inches or greater, except palm; any Sabal texana with a trunk taller than ten feet; any other palm with a trunk taller than 20 feet; and all vegetation listed as historic, landmark, or rare, except Sabal texana. 
    Site means: 
(1)  The tract of land which is designated on a building permit application; or 
(2)  If designated, an artificial lot contained therein and delineated by the city manager, together with all contiguous tracts or parcels of land held under common ownership and any existing buildings and appurtenant parking. 
    Street right-of-way means a public and/or private street right-of-way or a public and/or private street right-of-way easement. 
    Tree means a species of woody perennial plant, including palm, which usually has a single, elongate main stem generally with few or no branches on its lower part and which usually grows to a mature height of at least 12 feet. 
    Valuable means any tree of at least ten years of age. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-404), 8-3-1999) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 344-64. - Incorporation of section 344-132. 
    Section 344-132 is incorporated in this division by reference and is declared to be a part of this division. This section shall be binding on any use except for a single-family detached dwelling or a duplex. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-406), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-65. - City forester. 
(a)  There is created the position of city forester. The city manager shall appoint one city employee to fill such position for an indefinite term. 
(b)  The city forester shall have only the authority that is granted to him by city ordinance or that is delegated to him by the city manager or the city commission. 
(c)  The city forester shall have the authority to adopt written policies for the purpose of exercising the responsibilities assigned to him under subsection (b) of this section. Such policies shall be consistent with the spirit of this article and consistent with any rules adopted by the city manager. The city forester shall take the constitutional oath or affirmation as an officer of the city. 
(d)  All binding policies adopted by the city forester shall be known as rules, and all nonbinding policies adopted by the city forester shall be known as guidelines. 
(e)  The procedures for adopting, amending, or repealing guidelines shall be as specified by the city forester. 
(f)  Each city-forester rule shall become effective immediately after completion of all the following actions: 
(1)  The city forester submits a written rule to the city manager. 
(2)  The city manager signs the concurrence certificate on the face of the rule. 
(3)  The city secretary records such rule in the city's permanent records. 
(4)  The city manager gives notice of such rule to the chief building official and, upon advance request, any person engaged in landscape/development enterprises. 
(g)  The procedures for repealing, readopting, or amending a rule shall be the same as the procedure for the initial adoption of a rule. 
(h)  The following persons shall each have independent authority to enforce the city-forester rules: 
(1)  City forester. 
(2)  Building official. 
(3)  Greens division head. 
(4)  City manager. 
(5)  City engineer. 
(6)  City code officer/inspector. 
(i)  On a case-by-case basis, the city forester shall have authority to waive one or more of the sections of this article, other than this section, if, and only if, the section would be contrary to good landscaping/forestry practice. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-407), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-66. - Enforcement. 
(a)  No building permit shall be issued if the applicant has not complied with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  No certificate of occupancy shall be issued if the applicant has not complied with the requirements of this article. 
(c)  The city manager shall be responsible for the coordination of this article and the application thereof. The city manager shall have the authority to review, approve, or reject landscape plans being submitted for building permits or certificates of occupancy. 
(d)  The city manager shall deny in writing all applications for a building permit or certificate of occupancy which do not comply with this article. 
(e)  The city manager is authorized and directed to lawfully enter in and upon all premises at reasonable times to determine conditions insofar as the requirements of this article are applicable. 
(f)  All violations shall be reported to the city manager and shall be handled in the usual manner as a building code violation. 
(g)  If a building permit or certificate of occupancy is issued inadvertently or by error, it shall not relieve the applicant of the requirements of this article and is voidable. 
(h)  If a building permit or certificate of occupancy is issued through fraud or collusion, it shall not relieve the applicant of the requirements of this article and is void. 
(i)  Form of decision. Upon the filing of a completed landscape plan and/or tree removal application, the city manager shall make a decision regarding the application within 30 calendar days of the filing date. That decision must take one of three forms: 
(1)  Approval, no conditions. 
(2)  Approval, subject to conditions noted. 
(3)  Denial. 
(j)  Enforcement of this article shall be at the direction of the city manager. 
(k)  Dead, damaged, destroyed, or removed landscape improvements shall be replaced at the applicant's expense with other landscape material that complies with the approved landscape plan. The replacement quantity shall be equal to or greater than the original quantity for the required landscape improvements in question. 
(l)  The city manager shall give written notice of noncompliance to the applicant when any landscape improvement is discovered which does not meet the requirements of this article. 
(m)  The applicant shall then replace the landscape improvements within six months from receipt of the written notice and inform the city manager in writing of the replacement within 15 days. If the applicant does not take action, the city manager shall issue citations. 
(n)  Failure to secure a building permit or certificate of occupancy as a condition of this section will not relieve the applicant of the requirements of this article. Failure to comply with any other section of this Code or city ordinance shall not relieve the applicant of complying with the requirements of this article. 
(o)  The city manager shall have the authority to adopt and enforce rules for the purpose of exercising the responsibilities assigned to him by this article. The rules may include provisions related to special circumstances such as drought. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-408), 8-3-1999) 
Secs. 344-67-344-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SINGLE-FAMILY DETACHED DWELLING AND DUPLEX USES 

Sec. 344-96. - Applicability. 
    Unless otherwise specified, this division shall apply to any single-family detached dwelling or any duplex. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 3(26-410), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-97. - General standards. 
(a)  The applicant shall provide landscape improvements to cover a minimum of ten percent of the site. No right-of-way, right-of-way easement, nonintermittent resaca, or similar water body shall be used in any of the calculations in this subsection. 
(b)  The applicant shall maintain all required landscape improvements, which shall be adequately watered using one of the following methods: 
(1)  Automatic irrigation system; or 
(2)  Manual watering, if all parts of the required landscape improvements are within 100 feet of one or more hose bibs. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 3(26-412), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-98. - Existing trees. 
(a)  This section only applies to a site that includes an existing large tree and that requires a building permit due to proposed development of whatever type. As used in this section, the term "large tree" shall mean a tree with a circumference of at least three feet measured at a height of six inches above the ground. 
(b)  The city manager may delay building permit issuance for up to six working days in order to persuade the applicant to protect a large tree voluntarily. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 3(26-416), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-99. - Landscape plan. 
(a)  A landscape plan for the building site shall be submitted to the city manager by an applicant for approval of a building permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The landscape plan may be drawn using either the building site plan or parking plan. The landscape plan shall be at a scale of one inch equals 50, 40, 32, 30, 20, 16, ten, or eight feet and shall clearly demonstrate the requirements and design intent. The landscape plan shall identify and show the location, size, and description of any existing and proposed right-of-way, right-of-way easement, resaca, nonintermittent water body, site boundary, pavement, building, required landscape improvements, and hose bibs or irrigation plan. The landscape plan shall identify the name and telephone number of the person who drew the plan. 
(c)  The landscape plan shall also designate by name and location the plant material to be installed or, if existing, to be used in accordance with the requirements of this division. 
(d)  The city manager shall review the landscape plan to verify compliance with all applicable requirements of this article prior to the issuance of a building permit. If an artificial lot is delineated, it shall be drawn on the building plans prior to the issuance of the building permit. 
(e)  No building permit shall be issued by the city manager unless the applicant has submitted a landscape plan providing for the landscape improvements as required by this article. 
(f)  Within one year after the final inspection of the nonlandscape improvements, the landscape improvements shall fully comply with the approved landscape plan. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 3(26-418), 8-3-1999) 
Secs. 344-100-344-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OTHER USES 

Sec. 344-126. - Applicability. 
    Unless otherwise specified, this division shall apply to any use other than a single-family detached dwelling or other than a duplex. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-420), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-127. - General standards. 
(a)  The applicant shall provide landscape improvements to cover a minimum of ten percent of the site. At least 50 percent of the required landscape improvements shall be visible from existing street rights-of-way. No right-of way, right-of-way easement, existing nonintermittent resaca, or similar existing water body shall be used in any of such calculations. Retention and detention basins and proposed water features shall be used in the calculations unless otherwise specified by the applicant on the landscape plan. 
(b)  No more than 50 percent of the area of the visible landscape improvements shall include lawns containing grass. 
(c)  Except for allowed signs and site-entrance and exit driveways and sidewalks, all parts of the site within six feet of any street right-of-way line or street right-of-way easement line shall consist of nonfenced landscape improvements. 
(d)  Where any landscape improvements consist primarily of ground cover, the plants shall be no more than 18 inches apart and shall have a minimum size equivalent to a four-inch pot. 
(e)  Where any landscape improvements consist primarily of shrubs, the plants shall be no more than 36 inches apart and shall have a minimum size equivalent to a one-gallon pot. 
(f)  Landscape improvements shall not impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(g)  Landscape improvements shall not interfere with public utilities, power lines, drainage structures, and access to rights-of-way or easements. 
(h)  The applicant shall maintain all landscape improvements. 
(i)  All landscape improvements shall be adequately watered using one of the following methods: 
(1)  Automatic irrigation system; or 
(2)  Manual watering, if all parts of the landscape improvements are within 100 feet of one or more hose bibs, and if a nonresidential landscape improvement does not exceed 2,000 square feet. Watering hoses must not cross vehicular or pedestrian traffic during business hours. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-422), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-128. - Buffer trees. 
(a)  Within 25 feet of an existing or proposed street right-of-way line, there shall be buffer trees on the site, with the total number of such trees for each side of each street not being less than the linear feet of the street divided by 50, rounded up to the next whole number. 
(b)  The spacing between required buffer trees shall be a maximum of 100 feet and a minimum of ten feet. 
(c)  At time of final inspection, each required tree (palm) shall have a minimum total caliper of two inches and a minimum height (trunk height) of six feet. 
(d)  All the area within a two-foot radius of each required tree shall be landscaped, shall be free of hanging over vehicles at all times, and shall be located entirely outside of all the following: 
(1)  Any adjacent site belonging to a different owner; or 
(2)  Any right-of-way or easement for a street, alley, waterway, drain ditch, overhead utility line, and/or underground utility. 
(e)  All such distances shall be measured from the center of the tree trunk. 
(f)  Each required tree shall be watered using irrigation facilities or hose bibs in such a way that no hose crosses the top of a sidewalk or the top of a vehicular-use area during business hours. 
(g)  A grandfathered tree may be substituted for a buffer tree, provided that the grandfathered tree meets all buffer-tree requirements other than the definition of buffer tree. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-424), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-129. - Parking-lot trees. 
(a)  If a paved parking space is designed to be used primarily by passenger vehicles, all or part of such parking space shall be within 35 feet of a parking-lot tree. 
(b)  At time of final inspection, each required trunk shall have a minimum caliper of three inches and shall have a minimum clear trunk height of six feet. 
(c)  Required parking-lot trees shall comply with all provisions of sections 344-128(d) through (f). 
(d)  A grandfathered tree may be substituted for a parking-lot tree, provided that the grandfathered tree meets all parking-lot tree requirements other than the definition of parking-lot tree. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-426), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-130. - Existing trees. 
(a)  Building permits with protection of grandfathered trees. The following procedure shall be required when grandfathering of existing trees is being requested to apply toward the tree-planting requirements of this article. Where such grandfathering is being requested, the applicant shall supply a tree preservation plan to the city manager for review with the building plans. The tree preservation plan overlay shall be integrated into the proposed landscape plan and shall include the following: 
(1)  Delineation of tree protection zones which shall extend to just outside the dripline of all trees to be protected. 
(2)  Proposed protection measures; i.e., retaining walls, protection fence, etc. 
(3)  Name or type of trees to be preserved. 
(4)  The proposed finished grade and elevation of land within six feet or within the dripline of any tree to be preserved, whichever is greater. Ground level shall not be raised or lowered more than three inches, unless compensated for by welling or retaining methods. 
(5)  A landscaping tabulation and an itemized list of existing trees to be preserved. 
(6)  Tree preservation details. 
(7)  Specification of ground plane treatment as sod, ground cover, or mulch. If a combination is utilized, the limit of each shall be indicated. 
(b)  Building permits with removal of significant vegetation. All significant vegetation removed or proposed for removal by the applicant shall be described in the landscape plan and shall be mitigated with approved plants (palms) of a combined equal caliper (height) or greater. Each such required mitigation plant shall be in addition to all required buffer, parking-lot, and total trees. Penalties for violations and information required on the plan are as follow: 
(1)  Failure to accurately report significant vegetation shall result in fines equivalent to $75.00 per caliper-inch for trees not reported, $50.00 per trunk-foot for Sabal texana not reported, and $10.00 per trunk-foot for other palms not reported. 
(2)  Historic, landmark, rare, or valuable vegetation not reported shall incur additional fines of up to $1,000.00 per plant. 
(3)  Each such unreported plant shall constitute a separate offense. 
(4)  Each plant removed in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(5)  The following information shall be provided either on the landscape plan or in a report for the relocation or transplanting of existing specimen trees when mitigation is involved: 
a.  Transplanting techniques. 
b.  Equipment to be utilized. 
c.  Delineation of existing and proposed location of all trees and landscape improvements to be relocated. 
d.  Genus and species or common name, caliper, height, and general condition of the existing tree. 
e.  Pruning, watering, and maintenance schedule. 
(c)  Clear-cut permits without building permits. Any person wishing to clear-cut a site for which a building permit is not required shall submit a clear-cut permit application to the city manager at least five working days before such cutting and shall comply with the mitigation requirements of this article. 
(d)  Vegetation-removal permits without building permits. Requirements for a vegetation-removal permit without a building permit are as follow: 
(1)  Any person who wishes to remove any significant vegetation on a site for which a building permit is not required but who does not wish to clear-cut the site shall submit a vegetation-removal permit application to the city manager at least five working days before such removal and shall comply with the mitigation requirements of this article. 
(2)  The following items are required to obtain a vegetation-removal permit: 
a.  The name and address of the applicant. 
b.  The commonly known address of the lot or property where the significant vegetation is sought to be removed. Such vegetation must be tagged with a colored ribbon before on-site inspection. 
c.  A written statement indicating the reason for removal of significant vegetation. 
d.  A general description of the significant vegetation to be removed. 
e.  The name and address of the contractor who is charged with removing the significant vegetation. 
f.  A completed plant survey and scaled drawing identifying the location of all significant vegetation. 
(3)  Emergencies. In an emergency or a hazard to persons or property, immediate cutting or removal may take place without a vegetation-removal permit. Generally, that emergency must be declared by the city police or fire department. All emergencies of this nature must be reported to the city forester within 48 hours. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-428), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-131. - Total trees. 
(a)  At time of issuance of the final certificate of occupancy, the total number of trees on the site shall equal or exceed the total number of square feet of impervious surface on the site divided by 10,000, rounded up to the next whole number. 
(b)  A tree used to satisfy the requirements of this section shall be at least ten feet from all other trees which are used to satisfy the requirements of this section for the same site. 
(c)  Except for Sabal texana, a palm shall not be used to help satisfy the requirements of this section unless the palm is part of a cluster of three palm trees where each tree in the cluster is within three feet of the other two trees in the cluster and where each cluster counts as one total tree. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-430), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-132. - Screening fence. 
(a)  Any applicant in a nonresidential district, which abuts a residential district, shall be required to provide a screening fence between the nonresidential district and any adjacent residential district. The fence shall be constructed in accordance with the following standards: 
(1)  The fence shall be at least six feet in height from the natural ground and shall be capable of withstanding a 25 pound-per-square-foot horizontal wind load from any direction. 
(2)  When construction of a screening fence is required, it shall be located on the lot occupied by a nonresidential use along those portions of the rear or side lot lines that abut or are across a public street or alley from any residential district. The construction of a screening fence shall also be required to screen from public view any trash or storage area in conjunction with such use. When a screening fence is required the fence shall be set back ten feet from the curbline of the property in an effort to allow visual clearance to traffic. The owner of a lot on which a screening fence is required shall maintain the fence so that it will at all times meet the requirements set forth in this subsection. Screening fences shall not be required on sides of property adjacent to resacas. 
(3)  Where a screening fence is required, the material used to construct the fence shall be chosen so as to provide an opaque visual screen between developed and adjacent properties. Examples of materials that may be used to construct screening fences are wood, brick, concrete, masonry, and dense evergreen vegetation. 
(4)  Where a fence is required, the percentage of land the fence shall occupy will not be considered as a part of the ten-percent landscaping requirement. However, trees or shrubs used for landscape screening shall be considered as a part of the required landscaping. 
(b)  Each required screening fence shall be noted on the landscape plan prior to issuance of a building permit for the development of the nonresidential site. Each such fence shall be completed before issuance of the final certificate of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-432), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-133. - Cart-return area. 
(a)  This section shall only be applicable to a site where the site's management provides shopping carts and allows a shopper to have unescorted use of such cart outdoors. 
(b)  If a paved parking space is designed to be used primarily by passenger vehicles, all or part of such parking space shall be within 300 feet of an outdoor cart-return area on the same site. 
(c)  Each outdoor cart-return area shall be at least three feet wide and at least six feet long. 
(d)  Along the entire length of both of the long sides of the cart-return area, there shall be landscaped areas covered with shrubs listed in exhibit 344-163. Each such landscaped area shall be at least two feet wide and shall be separated from the cart-return area by a stand-up curb. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-434), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-134. - Public landscaping controls. 
    Landscaping requirements for city, county, state, and federal development are as follow: 
(1)  All city, county, state, and federal landscape development programs must be in coordination with this article and other established city landscape ordinances. 
(2)  The city shall reserve the right to require specific landscape plans and vegetation on every intersection, every park or public place and every natural area determined to be within the city limits. 
(3)  No landscape plan shall cause a visual blocking of an intersection or become a traffic hazard through the advent of time causing plants or trees to cover portions of the intersections. 
(4)  The city, the city beautification committee and the green division have, from time to time, tree planting themes around the city and on various city rights-of-way and properties. All landscape plans shall be in accordance with these plans. 
(5)  Applicants shall write into every contract or subcontract stipulations that protect rare, valuable, and historic vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-438), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-135. - Landscape plan. 
(a)  A landscape plan for the building site shall be submitted to the city manager by an applicant for approval of a building permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  In order to expedite development, the city manager may allow the landscape plan to be divided into a preliminary phase and a final phase. The preliminary phase shall show building footprints, paved passenger-vehicle parking spaces, areas reserved for compliance with section 344-127, and minimum four-foot-diameter spaces reserved for all required/protected trees. Instead of using actual plant names, the preliminary phase may use generic labels such as "protected tree," "buffer tree," "parking-lot tree," "total tree," and/or "mitigation plant." 
(c)  The landscape plan may be drawn using either the building site plan or parking plan. The landscape plan shall be at a scale of one inch equals 50, 40, 32, 30, 20, 16, ten, or eight feet and shall clearly demonstrate the requirements and design intent. The landscape plan shall identify and show the location of any existing and proposed utility lines, roadways, sidewalks, streetlights, trees, palms, shrubs, ground cover, natural features, other landscape elements, irrigation plan/hose bib locations, and planting or construction details. The plan shall identify the name and telephone number of the person who prepared and/or designed the plan. 
(d)  The landscape plan shall show locations of all preserved trees that satisfy the requirements for preservation established under section 344-130. 
(e)  The landscape plan shall include a schedule of all landscape improvements with quantities, sizes, and botanical and common plant names keyed to the landscape plan. 
(f)  The city manager shall review the landscape plan to verify compliance with all requirements of this article prior to the issuance of a building permit. If an artificial lot is delineated, it shall be drawn on the building plans prior to the issuance of the building permit. 
(g)  No building permit shall be issued by the city manager unless the applicant has submitted a landscape plan or preliminary-phase landscape plan providing for the landscape improvements as required by this article. 
(h)  No final certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the city manager unless the landscape improvements required by this article have been provided. Prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, the city manager shall inspect the landscape improvements to verify compliance with the approved landscape plan or final-phase landscape plan. 
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 2(26-440), 8-3-1999) 
Secs. 344-136-344-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SPECIES OF TREES, SHRUBS AND GROUND COVERS 

Sec. 344-161. - Parking-lot trees. 
    The following tree species are intended to produce the maximum amount of shade, the minimum amount of tree maintenance/replacement, and the minimum amount of vehicle damage: 
Botanical Name Common Name Comments Arecastrum romanzoffianum* Queen palm* Freeze damage Diospyros texana Persimmon Good near power lines, slow growth Ficus retusa "nitida" Ficus Freeze damage, aggressive roots Fraxinus berlandieriana Rio Grande ash Weak branches, pest problems Koelreuteria paniculata Goldenrain tree Freeze damage Livistona chinensis* Chinese fan palm* Good near power lines Parkinsonia aculeata Retama Good near power lines, light shade Populus deltoides Cottonwood Leaf/twig drop, weak branches Pistacia chinensis Chinese pistache Prosopis glandulosa Honey mesquite Light shade, thorns, dripping sap Quercus virginiana Live oak Sabal texana Sabal palm Ulmus crassifolia Cedar elm Ulmus parvifolia Drake elm Washingtonia filifera* California fan palm* Freeze damage Washingtonia robusta* Mexican fan palm* Freeze damage  
* Denotes species which satisfy the parking-lot tree requirement only if planted in a cluster of at least three trees, where each tree in the cluster is within three feet of at least two other trees in the same cluster.  
(Ord. No. 99-1100.26, pt. 5(ex. A-1), 8-3-1999) 
Sec. 344-162. - Buffer trees. 
    The following are species of buffer trees for the purposes of this article:

ARTICLE IV. - TREES, SHRUBS AND OTHER VEGETATION 

Sec. 344-191. - Penalty for violation; enforcement. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the sections of this article or who shall fail to comply with this article or with any of the requirements of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-13. Such fine shall not exceed the maximum fine allowed by both the state and the city Charter for each offense. 
(b)  The police department, the public health director, the director of public works, the director of traffic and the building official are authorized to issue citations to any owner, lessee, or occupant of any premises within the city limits for violations of this article. The citation issued shall state the alleged violation, the date of the violation, and the section of this Code violated. 
(Code 1971, § 33-12) 
Sec. 344-192. - Normal care not affected. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to prohibit the proper and necessary trimming of trees for the reasonable clearance of wires being maintained in, on and over the streets, parks or parkways of the city, under the supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 33-1) 
Sec. 344-193. - Interference with work prohibited. 
    No person shall, by any act done wilfully and purposely, prevent, delay, or interfere with the city manager or any person working under his direction in the planting, pruning, spraying or removing of a tree, shrub, or flower from the public streets, parks or parkways or in the removal of stones, cement, or other substances therefrom. 
(Code 1971, § 33-7) 
Sec. 344-194. - Planting in streets, parks or parkways restricted. 
    No shade tree, shrub or flower shall be planted in any of the public streets, parks, or parkways of the city until such shrub or tree shall have been first approved by the city manager together with the approval of the place where the shrub or tree is to be planted and until a permit is granted by the city manager for such purpose. 
(Code 1971, § 33-2) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86. 
Sec. 344-195. - Protection of roots. 
    No person shall, without the written permission of the city manager, place or maintain upon the ground in a public street, park or parkway any stone, cement or other substance which shall impede the free passage of water and air to the roots of any tree or shrub in such street, park or parkway, unless there shall be left free of such obstruction an open space of ground outside the trunk of such tree or shrub consisting of an area of not less than four square feet. 
(Code 1971, § 33-3) 
Sec. 344-196. - Attachment of wires. 
    No person shall, without the written permission of the city manager, attach any telephone or telegraph wire, electric wires, insulator, or any device for the holding of an electric wire, telephone or telegraph wire to any tree or shrub growing or planted upon any public street, park or parkway of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 33-4) 
Sec. 344-197. - Care in fastening electric wires. 
    Every person maintaining a wire charged with electricity running through a public street, park or parkway shall securely fasten such wire so that the wire shall not come in contact with any tree, shrub, or flower so as to injure the tree, shrub, or flower. 
(Code 1971, § 33-5) 
Sec. 344-198. - Removal of electric wires or current. 
    Every person maintaining any wire charged with electricity running through or over a public street shall temporarily remove any such wire or cause the current to be withdrawn therefrom upon the order and direction of the city manager when in his judgment it is necessary to so remove such wire or to withdraw such current for the purpose of taking down or pruning any trees or shrubs growing in a public street, park or parkway within the city. Such wire shall be removed or the current withdrawn within 24 hours after the service upon the owner of such wire of a written notice. However, the time for such removal may, for proper cause shown to the city manager, be extended. A notice shall be sufficient under this section if the notice is properly executed by the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 33-6) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 102. 
Sec. 344-199. - Clearance over sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any tree, shrub, vine, palm or any similar plant of any description or kind to be grown, maintained or cultivated in such a manner so that any portion of such tree, shrub, vine, palm, etc., may overhang or obtrude upon or over any sidewalk unless there be a full ten-foot clearance between the surface of all portions of such sidewalk and the overhanging tree limb, shrub, vine, palm or plant of any description or kind. 
(Code 1971, § 33-8) 
Sec. 344-200. - Clearance over streets and alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any tree, shrub, vine, palm or any similar plant of any description or kind to be grown, maintained or cultivated in such a manner so that any portion of such tree, shrub, vine, palm, etc., may overhang or obtrude upon or over any street, alley or highway in the city unless there is a full 12-foot clearance between the surface of all portions of such street, alley or highway and the overhanging tree limb, shrub, vine, palm or plant of any description or kind. 
(Code 1971, § 33-9) 
Sec. 344-201. - Proximity to fireplugs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any tree, shrub, vine, palm, hedge, or any similar plant of any description or kind to be planted, cultivated, grown, or permitted to be planted, cultivated or grown between the sidewalk and the curb or ditch line of any street or highway at a lesser distance than 71/2 feet from any fireplug in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 33-10) 
Sec. 344-202. - Proximity to intersections. 
    It shall be unlawful for any tree, shrub, vine, palm or any similar plant of any description or kind to be planted, maintained or cultivated between the sidewalk and the curb on any public street or highway in the city at a lesser distance than 20 feet from the corner of any block on any such public street or highway. Such measurements shall be computed at the point of intersection of two lines extended parallel with the curbline of the streets or avenues intersecting and causing such corners. 
(Code 1971, § 33-11) 
Secs. 344-203-344-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION 

Sec. 344-300. - Purpose. 
(a)  It has been found: 
(1)  That the waters of the City of Brownsville ("the city") are a valuable resource of limited supply and are subject to ever increasing demands. 
(2)  That it is in the best interests of the city to promote the conservation and efficient use of water and to prevent the waste of this valuable resource. 
(3)  That landscapes are essential to the quality of life by providing areas for active and passive recreation, an enhancement to the environment by cooling and mitigating heat-island effect, cleaning air and water, preventing or mitigating erosion, offering areas of respite and protection, assisting with flood control, and providing habitat for wildlife; and 
(4)  That the right to use water is limited to the amount reasonably required for the beneficial use of maintaining a healthy landscape. 
(b)  Consistent with these findings, the purpose of this landscape irrigation ordinance is to: 
(1)  Complement the values and benefits of landscaping practices that integrate the conservation and efficient use of water to maximize the benefits of managed landscapes; 
(2)  Establish a structure for planning, designing, installing, maintaining and managing a water efficient irrigation system in new construction or renovated projects; 
(3)  Establish provisions for water management practices and water waste prevention for existing irrigation systems; 
(4)  Work in conjunction with established landscape provisions and requirements locally and statewide that are in character with the values of the community. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-301. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air gap -A complete physical separation between the free flowing discharge end of a potable water supply pipeline and an open or non-pressure receiving vessel. 
    Atmospheric vacuum breaker -An assembly containing an air inlet valve, a check seat, and an air inlet port. The flow of water into the body causes the air inlet valve to close the air inlet port. When the flow of water stops, the air inlet valve falls and forms a check against back-siphonage. At the same time it opens the air inlet port allowing air to enter and satisfy the vacuum. Also known as an atmospheric vacuum breaker back-siphonage prevention assembly. 
    Backflow prevention -The mechanical prevention of reverse flow, or the back-siphonage, of non-potable water from an irrigation system into the potable water source. 
    Backflow prevention assembly -Any assembly used to prevent backflow into a potable water system. The type of assembly used is based on the existing or potential degree of health hazard and backflow condition. 
    Completion of irrigation system installation -When the landscape irrigation system has been installed, all minimum standards met, all tests performed, and the irrigator is satisfied that the system is operating correctly. 
    Consulting -The act of providing advice, guidance, review or recommendations related to landscape irrigations systems. 
    Cross-connection -An actual or potential connection between a potable water source and an irrigation system that may contain contaminates or pollutants or any source of water that has been treated to a lesser degree in the treatment process. 
    Design -The act of determining the carious elements of a landscape irrigation system that will include but not limited to elements such as collection site specific information, defining the scope of the project, defining plant watering needs, selecting and laying out emission devices, locating system components, conducting hydraulics calculations, identifying any local regulatory requirements, or scheduling irrigation work at a site. Completion of the various components will result in an irrigation plan. 
    Design pressure -The pressure that is required for an emission device to operate properly. Design pressure is calculated by adding the operating pressure necessary at an emission device to the total of all pressure losses accumulated from an emission device to the water source. 
    Double check valve -An assembly that is composed of two independently acting, approved check valves, including tightly closed resilient seated shutoff valves attached at each end of the assembly and fitted with properly located resilient seated test cocks. Also known as a double check valve backflow prevention assembly. 
    Emission device -Any device that is contained within an irrigation system and that is used to apply water. Common emission devices in an irrigation system include, but are not limited to, spray and rotary sprinkler heads, and drip irrigation emitters. 
    Employed -Engaged or hired to provide consulting services or perform any activity relating to the sale, design, installation, maintenance, alteration, repair, or service to irrigation systems. A person is employed if that person is in an employer-employee relationship as defined by Internal Revenue code, 26 United States Code Service, § 3212(d) based on the behavioral control, financial control, and the type of relationship involved in performing employment related tasks. 
    Head-to-head spacing -The spacing of spray or rotary heads equal to the manufacturer's published radius of the head. 
    Health hazard -A cross connection or potential cross-connection with an irrigation system that involved any substance that may, if introduced into the potable water supply, cause death or illness, spread disease, or have a high probability of causing such effects. 
    Hose bib -An outdoor water faucet with a nozzle that is bent downward and has hose threads on the spout. 
    Hydraulics -The science of dynamic and static water, the mathematical computation of determining pressure losses and pressure requirements of an irrigation system. 
    Hydrozone means a portion of the landscaped area having plants with similar water needs and rooting depth, soil type, and exposure. A hydrozone may be irrigated or non-irrigated. 
    Inspector -A licensed plumbing inspector, water district operator, other governmental entity, or irrigation inspector who inspects irrigation systems and performs other enforcement duties of a municipality of water district as an employee or as a contractor. 
    Installer -A person who actually connects an irrigation system to a private or public raw or potable water supply system or any water supply, who is licensed according to Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 30 (relating to Occupational Licenses and Registrations). 
    Irrigation inspector -A person who inspects irrigation systems and performs other enforcement duties for a municipality or water district as an employee or as a contractor and is required to be licensed under Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 30 (relating to Occupational Licenses and Registrations). 
    Irrigation plan -A scaled drawing of a landscape irrigation system which lists required information, the scope of the project, and represents the changes made in the installation of the irrigation system. 
    Irrigation services -Selling, designing, installing, maintaining, altering, repairing, servicing, permitting, providing, consulting services regarding, or connecting an irrigation system to a water supply. 
    Irrigation system -An assembly of component parts that is permanently installed for the controlled distribution and conservation of water to irrigate any type of landscape vegetation in any location, and/or to reduce dust or control erosion. This term does not include a system that is used on or by an agricultural operation as defined by V.T.C.A., Agricultural Code, § 251.002. 
    Irrigation technician -A person who works under the supervision of a licensed irrigator to install, maintain, alter, repair, service or supervise installation of an irrigation system, including the connection of such system in or to a private or public, raw or potable water supply system or any water supply, and who is required to be licensed under Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 30 (relating to Occupational Licenses and Registrations). 
    Irrigation zone -A subdivision of an irrigation system with a matched precipitation rate based on plant material type (such as turf, shrubs, or trees), microclimate factors (such as sun/shade ratio), topographic features (such as slope) and soil conditions (such as sand, loam, clay, or combination) or for hydrological control. 
    Irrigator -A person who sells, designs, consults, installs, maintains alters, repairs, services or supervises the installation of an irrigation system, including the connection of such system to a private or public, raw or potable water supply system or any water supply, and who is required to be licensed under Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 30. 
    Irrigator-in-charge -The irrigator responsible for all irrigation work performed by an exempt business owner, including but not limited to, obtaining permits, developing design plans, supervising the work of other irrigators or irrigation technicians, and installing, selling, maintaining, altering, repairing, or servicing a landscape irrigation system. 
    Landscape irrigation -The science of applying the necessary amount of water to promote or sustain healthy growth of plant material or turf. 
    License -An occupational license that is issued by the commission under Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 30 to an individual that authorizes the individual to engage in an activity that is covered by Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 30, or under any other applicable law. 
    Mainline -A pipe within an irrigation system that delivers water from the water source to the individual zone valves. 
    Maintenance checklist -A document made available to the irrigation systems owner or owner's representative that contains information regarding the operation and maintenance of the irrigation system, including, but not limited to: checking and repairing the irrigation system, setting the automatic controller, checking the rain or moisture sensor, cleaning filters, pruning grass and plants away from irrigation emitters, using and operating the irrigation system, the precipitation rates of each irrigation zone within the system, any water conservation measures currently in effect from the water purveyor, the name of the water purveyor, a suggested seasonal or monthly watering schedule based on current evapotranspiration data for the geographic region, and the minimum water requirements for the plant material in each zone based on the soil type and plant material where the system is installed. 
    Major maintenance, alteration, repair, or service -Any activity that involves opening to the atmosphere the irrigation main line at any point prior to the discharge side of any irrigation zone control valve. This includes, but is not limited to, repairing or connecting into a main supply pipe, replacing a zone control valve, replacement of the system controller, and/or repairing a zone control valve in a manner that opens the system to the atmosphere. 
    Master valve -A remote control value located after the backflow prevention device that controls the flow of water to the irrigation system mainline. 
    Matched precipitation rate -The condition in which all sprinkler heads within an irrigation zone apply water at the same rate. 
    Multifamily residential -Any site occupied by three or more families living independently of each other. 
    New installation -An irrigation system installed at a location where one did not previously exist. 
    Non-health hazard -A cross connection or potential cross connection from a landscape irrigation system that involved any substance that generally would not be a health hazard but would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable if introduced into the potable water supply. 
    Non-potable water -Water that is not suitable for human consumption. Non-potable water sources include, but are not limited to, irrigation systems, lakes, ponds, and streams, gray water that is discharged from washing machines, dishwashers or other appliances, water vapor condensate from cooling towers, reclaimed water, and harvested rainwater. 
    Pass-through contract -A written contract between a contractor or builder and a licensed irrigator or exempt business owner to perform part of all of the irrigation services in relation to an irrigation system. 
    Potable water -Water that is suitable for human consumption. 
    Pressure vacuum breaker -An assembly containing an independently operating internally loaded check valve and an independently operating loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve. Also known as a pressure vacuum breaker back-siphonage prevention assembly. 
    Reclaimed water -Domestic or municipal wastewater which has been treated to a quality suitable for beneficial uses, such as landscape irrigation. 
    Records of landscape irrigation activities -The irrigation plans, contract, warranty information, invoices, copies of permits, and other documents that relate to the installation, maintenance, alteration, repair, or service of a landscape irrigation system. 
    Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly -An assembly containing two independently acting approved check valves together with a hydraulically operating mechanically independent pressure differential relief valve located between the two check valves and below the first check valve. 
    Residential -property that is zoned to a dwelling/retail G classification or zoned to a more restrictive classification. 
    Static water pressure -The pressure of water when it is not moving. 
    Supervision -The on-the-job oversight and direction by a licensed irrigator who is fulfilling his or her professional responsibility to the client and/or employer in compliance with local or state requirements. Also, a licensed installer working under the direction of a licensed irrigator or beginning January 1, 2009, an irrigation technician who is working under the direction of a licensed irrigator to install, maintain, alter repair or service an irrigation system. 
    Water conservation -The design, installation, service, and operation of an irrigation system in a manner that prevents the waste of water, promotes the most efficient use of water, and applies the least amount of water that is required to maintain healthy individual plant material or turf, reduce dust, and control erosion. 
    Zone flow -A measurement, in gallons per minute or gallons per hour, of the actual flow of water through a zone valve, calculated by individually opening each zone valve and obtaining a valid reading after the pressure has stabilized. For design purposes, the flow zone is the total flow of all nozzles in the zone at a specific pressure. 
    Zone valve -An automatic valve that controls a single zone of a landscape irrigation system. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-302. - Valid license required. 
(a)  Any person who designs, provides consultation services, installs, maintains, alters, repairs, services, or connects an irrigation system to the city's water supply within the city must hold a valid license, as defined by Chapter 30, Title 30 of the Texas Administrative Code as amended pursuant to Chapter 1903 of the V.T.C.A., Occupations Code, or as defined by Chapter 365, Title 22 of the Texas Administrative Code and required by Chapter 1301 of the V.T.C.A., Occupations code, as amended. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  A Property owner is not required to be licensed in accordance with the V.T.C.A., Occupations Code, Title 12, § 1903.002(c)(1) if the owner is performing irrigation work in a building or on a premises owned or occupied by the person as the person's homestead. The planning and development services department shall rely on the official county records in determining property ownership, if necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-303. - Permitting. 
(a)  Any person installing, altering, repairing, removing, or performing work on an irrigation system that connects to the city's water supply as outlined within this article is required to obtain the necessary permits from the planning and development services department. 
(b)  Requirements. 
(1)  Any and all new irrigation installations shall be required to provide the following in order to obtain a permit: 
a.  Submit a signed application as provided by the planning and development services department for: 
1.  Irrigation system, and 
2.  Vacuum breaker backflow; 
b.  An irrigation design plan that meets the minimum requirements as referenced in section 344-307; 
c.  A design and installation plan that meets the minimum requirements as referenced in section 344-308; 
d.  Name, address, and contact information for proposed system installer; 
e.  Name, address, and contact information of property owner; 
f.  Payment of the appropriate permit fee as indicated in section 344-314; 
g.  Submit sealed as-built plans prior to final inspection; and 
h.  Submit a set of proposed plans, as-built plans, permit copy, and completed checklist (if required) to water service provider. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-304. - Backflow prevention methods and devices. 
(a)  Any irrigation system that is connected to the potable water supply must be connected through a backflow prevention method approved by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ). The backflow prevention must be approved by the American Society of Sanitary Engineers; or the Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research, University of Southern California; or the Uniform Plumbing Code, or the 2015 International Plumbing Code, or the most current International Plumbing Code, or any other laboratory that has equivalent capabilities for both the laboratory and field evaluation of backflow prevention assemblies. The backflow prevention device must be installed in accordance with the laboratory approval standards or if the approval does not include specific installation information, the manufacturer's current published recommendations. 
(b)  In accordance with regulations based on the Texas Plumbing License Law (8 TAC 1301). Installation of irrigation systems can only be done by the following: 
(1)  A licensed plumber working under a master plumber's license and the assembly is not on a fire-suppression system. 
(2)  A licensed irrigator, and the assembly is on an irrigation system. 
(3)  A water operator, and the assembly is on the water-distribution system and not on an irrigation system. 
(4)  A licensed plumber working for a fire line-contracting company insured and regulated by Texas State Board of Insurance, and the assembly is on a fire line. 
(5)  A licensed water-treatment specialist and the assembly is on equipment for water treatment. 
(6)  A homeowner, the assembly is on your homestead, and you have obtained a permit that meets the exceptions as referenced in section 344-302(b). 
(c)  If conditions that present a health hazard exist, one of the following methods must be used to prevent backflow; 
(1)  An air gap may be used if: 
a.  There is unobstructed physical separation; and 
b.  The distance from the lowest point of the water supply outlet to the flood rim of the fixture or assembly into which the outlet discharges is at least one inch or twice the diameter of the water supply outlet, whichever is greater. 
(2)  Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies may be used if: 
a.  The device is installed at a minimum of 12 inches above the ground in a location that will ensure that the assembly will not be submerged; and 
b.  Drainage is provided for any water that may be discharged through the assembly relief valve. 
(3)  Pressure vacuum breakers may be used if: 
a.  No back-pressure condition will occur; and 
b.  The device is installed at a minimum of 12 inches above any downstream piping and the highest downstream opening. Pop-up sprinklers are measured from the retracted position from the top of the sprinkler. 
(4)  Atmospheric vacuum breakers may be used if: 
a.  No back-pressure will be present; 
b.  There are no shutoff valves downstream from the atmospheric vacuum breaker; 
c.  The device is installed at a minimum of six inches above any downstream piping and the highest downstream opening. Pop-up sprinklers are measured from the retracted position from the top of the sprinkler; 
d.  There is no continuous pressure on the supply side of the atmospheric vacuum breaker for more than 12 hours in any 24-hour period; and 
e.  A separate atmospheric vacuum breaker is installed on the discharge side of each irrigation control valve, between the valve and all the emission devices that the valve controls. 
(d)  Backflow prevention devices used in applications designated as both health hazards and non-health hazards must be tested upon installation and annually thereafter for commercial and industrial use properties. For non-health hazard residential use, a timed testing frequency of every three years is required. It is the property owner's responsibility to hire a licensed inspector and to adhere to the regulations within this article. 
(e)  If there are no conditions that present a health hazard, double check valve backflow prevention assemblies may be used to prevent backflow if the device was tested upon installation and: 
(1)  Backpressure caused by an elevation of pressure in the discharge piping by pump or elevation of piping above the supply pressure which could cause a reversal of the normal flow of water of back-siphonage conditions caused by a reduced or negative pressure in a the irrigation system exist; and 
(2)  Test cocks are used for testing only. 
(f)  If a double check valve is installed below ground: 
(1)  Test cocks must be plugged, except when the double check valve is being tested; 
(2)  Test cock plugs must be threaded, water tight, and made of non-ferrous material; 
(3)  A Y-type strainer is installed on the inlet side of the double check valve; 
(4)  There must be a clearance between any fill material (pea gravel to a depth of one inch) and the bottom of the double valve to allow for space for testing and repair; and 
(5)  There must be space on the side of the double check valve to test and repair or replace the double check valve. 
(g)  If an irrigation system is connected to a potable water supply through a double check valve, pressure vacuum breaker, or reduced pressure principle backflow assembly and includes an automatic master valve on the system, the automatic master valve must be installed on the discharge side of the backflow assembly. 
(h)  The licensed installer shall ensure the backflow prevention device is tested prior to being placed in service and the test results provided to the local water purveyor and the irrigation system's owner or owner's representative within ten business days of testing of the backflow prevention device. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-305. - Specific conditions and cross-connection control. 
(a)  Before any chemical is added to an irrigation system connected to the potable water supply the irrigation system must be connected through a reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly or air gap. 
(b)  Connection of any additional water source to an irrigation system that is connected to the potable water supply through a reduced-pressure principle backflow assembly or an air gap. 
(c)  Irrigation system components with chemical additives induced by aspiration, injection, or emission system connected to any potable water supply must be connected through a reduced pressure principle backflow device. 
(d)  If an irrigation designed system is designed or installed on a property that is served by an on-site sewage facility, as defined in Chapter 285 of Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, then: 
(1)  All irrigation piping and valves must meet the separation distances from the on-site sewage facilities system as required for a private water line in Texas Administrative Code, Title 30, § 285.91(10); 
(2)  Any connections using a private or public potable water source that is not the city's potable water system must be connected to the water source through a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly as defined in Texas Administrative Code, Title 30, § 344.50; and 
(e)  Any water from the irrigation system that is applied to the surface of the area utilized by the on-site sewage facility system must be controlled on a separate irrigation zone or zones so as to allow complete control of any irrigation to that area so that there will not be excess water that would prevent the on-site sewage facilities system from operating effectively. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-306. - Water conservation. 
(a)  All irrigation systems shall be designed, installed, maintained, altered, repaired, serviced, and operated in a manner that will promote water conservation as defined in section 344-301, definitions. The following practices must be implemented to achieve and promote water conservation: 
(1)  Each remote control valve shall irrigate a hydrozone with similar microclimate, soil conditions, slope, and plant materials with similar water demands. 
(2)  Drip irrigation is encouraged instead of pop up sprinkler heads in areas surrounding, bordering, or with impervious surfaces to minimize excess water runoff. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-307. - Irrigation plan design: minimum standards. 
(a)  An irrigator shall prepare an irrigation design plan for each site where a new irrigation system will be installed. A paper copy of the irrigation plan must be on the job site at all times during the installation of the irrigation system. A drawing showing the actual installation of the system is due to each irrigation system owner after all the new irrigation system installations. During the installation of the irrigation system, variances from the original plan may be authorized by the licensed irrigator if the variance from the plan does not: 
(1)  Diminish the operational integrity of the irrigation system; 
(2)  Violate any requirements of this article; and 
(3)  Go unnoted in red on the irrigation plan. 
(b)  The irrigation plan must include complete coverage of the area to be irrigated. If a system does not provide complete coverage of the area to be irrigated, it must be noted on the irrigation plan. 
(c)  All irrigation plans used for construction must be drawn to scale. The plan must include, at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  The licensed irrigators seal, signature, and date of signing; 
(2)  All major physical features and the boundaries of the areas to be watered; 
(3)  A North arrow; 
(4)  A legend; 
(5)  The zone flow measurement for each zone; 
(6)  Location and type of each: 
a.  Automatic controller; and 
b.  Sensor, including, but not limited to, rain, moisture, wind, flow, or freeze. 
(7)  Location, type and size of each: 
a.  Water source, including, but not limited to, a water meter and point(s) of connection; 
b.  Backflow prevention device; 
c.  Water emission device, including, but not limited to, spray heads, rotary sprinkler heads, quick-couplers, bubblers, drip, or micro sprays; 
d.  Valve, including, but not limited to, zone valves, master valves, and isolation valves; 
e.  Pressure regulation component; and 
f.  Main line and lateral piping. 
(8)  The scale used; and 
(9)  The design pressure. 
(10)  Any further information required by the planning and development services department. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-308. - Design and installation: minimum requirements. 
(a)  No irrigation design plan or installation shall require the use of any component, including the water meter, in a way which exceeds the manufacture's published performance limitations for the component. 
(b)  Spacing. 
(1)  The maximum spacing between emission devices must not exceed the manufacturer's published radius or spacing of the device(s). The radius or spacing is determined by referring to the manufacturer's published specifications for a specific emission device at a specific operating pressure. 
(2)  New irrigation systems shall not utilize above-ground spray emission devices in landscapes that are less than 48 inches not including the impervious surfaces in either length or width and which contain impervious pedestrian or vehicular traffic surfaces along two or more perimeters.
