If pop-up sprays or rotary sprinkler heads are used in a new irrigation system, the sprinkler heads must direct flow away from any adjacent surface and shall not be installed closer than four inches from a hardscape, such as, but not limited to, a building foundation, fence, concrete, asphalt, pavers, or stones set with mortar. 
(3)  Narrow paved walkways, jogging paths, golf cart paths or other small areas located in cemeteries, parks, golf courses or other public areas may be exempted from this requirement if the runoff drains into a landscaped area. 
(c)  Water pressure. Emission devices must be installed to operate at the minimum and not above the maximum sprinkler head pressure as published by the manufacturer for the nozzle and head spacing that is used. Methods to achieve the water pressure requirements include, but are not limited to, flow control valves, a pressure regulator, or pressure compensating spray heads. 
(d)  Piping. Piping in irrigation systems must be designed and installed so that the flow of water in the pipe will not exceed a velocity of five feet per second for polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe. 
(e)  Irrigation zones. Irrigation systems shall have separate zones based on plant material type, microclimate factors, topographic features, soil conditions, and hydrological requirements. 
(f)  Matched precipitation rate. Zones must be designed and installed so that all of the emission devices in that zone irrigate at the same precipitation rate. 
(g)  Irrigation systems shall not spray water over surfaces made of concrete, asphalt, brick, wood, stones set with mortar, or any other impervious material, such as, but not limited to, walls, fences, sidewalks, streets, etc. 
(h)  Master valve. When provided, a master valve shall be installed on the discharge side of the backflow prevention device on all new installations. 
(i)  Check valves. Check valves are required where elevation differences result in low head drainage. Check valves may be located at the sprinkler head(s) or on the lateral line. 
(j)  PVC pipe primer solvent. All new irrigation systems that are installed using PVC pipe and fittings shall be primed with a colored primer prior to applying the PVC cement in accordance with the Uniform Plumbing Code (Section 316) or the International Plumbing Code (Section 605). 
(k)  Automatic controllers. All new irrigation systems must include an automatic controller capable of the following features: 
(1)  Multiple programs; and 
(2)  Limiting the irrigation frequency to once every seven days. 
(l)  Operational rain and freeze shut-off devices or other technology. All new automatically controlled irrigation systems must include operational sensors or other technology designed to inhibit or interrupt operation of the irrigation system during periods of rain or freezing weather. Rain and freeze shut-off technology must be installed according to the manufacturer's published recommendations. Repairs to existing automatic irrigation systems that require replacement of an existing controller must include a sensor or other technology designed to inhibit or interrupt operation of the irrigation system during periods of rain and freeze. 
(m)  Isolation valve with lock-out capability. All new irrigation systems must include an isolation valve between the water meter and the backflow prevention device. 
(n)  Depth coverage of piping. Piping in all irrigation systems must be installed according to the manufacturer's published specifications for depth coverage of piping. 
(1)  If the manufacturer has not published specifications for depth coverage of piping, the piping must be installed to provide minimum depth coverage of six inches of select backfill, between the top of the pipe and the natural grade of the top soil. All portions of the irrigation system that fail to meet this standard must be noted on the irrigation plan. If the area being irrigated has rock at a depth of six inches or less, select back fill may be mounded over the pipe. Mounding must be noted on the irrigation plan and discussed with the irrigation system owner or owner's representative to address any safety issues. 
(2)  If a utility, man-made structure or roots create an unavoidable obstacle, which makes the six-inch depth coverage requirement impractical, the piping shall be installed to provide a minimum of two inches of select backfill between the top of the pipe and the natural grade of the topsoil. 
(3)  All trenches and holes created during installation of an irrigation system must be backfilled and compacted to the original grade. 
(o)  Wiring irrigation systems. 
(1)  Underground electrical wiring used to connect an automatic controller to any electrical component of the irrigation system must be listed by Underwriters Laboratories as acceptable for burial underground. 
(2)  Electrical wiring that connects any electrical components of an irrigation system must be sized according to the manufacturer's recommendation. 
(3)  Electrical wire splices which may be exposed to moisture must be waterproof as certified by the wire splice manufacturer. 
(4)  Underground electrical wiring that connects an automatic controller to any electrical component of the irrigation system must be buried with a minimum of six inches of select backfill. 
(p)  Water contained within the piping of an irrigation system is deemed to be non-potable. No drinking or domestic water usage, including, but not limited to, filling swimming pools or decorative fountains, shall be connected to an irrigation system. If a hose bib is connected to an irrigation system for the purpose of providing supplemental water to an area, the hose bib must be installed using a quick coupler key on a quick coupler installed in a covered purple valve box and the hose bib and any hoses connected to the bib must be labeled "non-potable, not safe for drinking." An isolation valve must be installed upstream of a quick coupler connecting a hose bib to an irrigation system. 
(q)  Licensed technician on-site. A licensed irrigator, a licensed plumber, or a licensed irrigation technician shall be on-site at all times while the landscape irrigation system is being installed. When an irrigator is not onsite, the irrigator shall be responsible for ensuring that a licensed irrigation technician is on-site to supervise the installation of the irrigation system. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-309. - Completion of irrigation system installation. 
(a)  Upon completion of the irrigation system installation, a final inspection for both the backflow assembly and the irrigation system must be completed by a licensed plumbing or irrigation inspector. 
(b)  Upon completion of the irrigation system, the irrigator or irrigation technician who provided supervision for the on-site installation shall be required to complete: 
(1)  A final "walk through" with the irrigation system's owner or the owner's representative to explain the operation of the system; 
(2)  The maintenance checklist on which the irrigator or irrigation technician shall obtain the signature of the irrigation system's owner or owner's representative and shall sign, date, and seal the checklist. If the irrigation system's owner or owner's representative is unwilling to or unable to sign the maintenance checklist, the irrigator shall note the time and date of the refusal on the irrigation system's owner or owner's representative's signature line. The irrigation system owner or owner's representative will be given the original maintenance checklist and a duplicate copy of the maintenance checklist shall be maintained by the irrigator and provided to the irrigation inspector at the time of inspection. The items on the maintenance check list shall include but are not limited to: 
a.  Irrigator's name, license number, company name, telephone number, and the dates of the warranty period; 
b.  The manufacturer's manual for the automatic controller; 
c.  A seasonal (spring, summer, fall, winter) watering schedule based on either current/real time evapotranspiration or monthly historical reference evapotranspiration (historical ET) data, monthly effective rain fall estimates, plant landscape coefficient factors, and site factors; 
d.  A list of components, including, but not limited to the nozzle, or pump filters, and other such components; that require maintenance and the recommended frequency for the service; and 
e.  The statement. "This irrigation system has been installed in accordance with all applicable state and local laws, ordinances, rules, regulations or orders. I have tested the system and determined that it has been installed according to the Irrigation Plan and is properly adjusted for the most efficient application of water at this time." 
(3)  A permanent sticker which contains the irrigator's name, license number, company name, telephone number and the dates of the warranty period shall be affixed to each automatic controller installed by the irrigator or irrigation technician. The information contained on the sticker must be printed with waterproof ink. 
(4)  The irrigation plan indicating the actual installation of the system must be provided to the irrigation systems owner or owner representative and the irrigation inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-310. - Maintenance, alteration, or removal of irrigation systems. 
(a)  The irrigator is responsible for all work that the irrigator performed during the maintenance, alteration, repair, or service of an irrigation system during the warranty period. The original irrigator or business owner is not responsible for the professional negligence of any other irrigator who subsequently conducts any irrigation service on the same irrigation system. 
(b)  All trenches and holes created during the maintenance, alteration, repair or service of an irrigation system must be returned to the original grade with compacted select backfill. 
(c)  Colored PVC pipe primer solvent must be used on all pipes and fitting used in the maintenance, alteration, repair, or service of an irrigation system in accordance with the Uniform Plumbing Code (Section 316) or the International Plumbing Code (Section 605). 
(d)  When maintenance, alteration, repair or service of an irrigation system involves excavation work at the water meter or backflow prevention device, an isolation valve shall be installed, if an isolation valve is not present. 
(e)  Removal of full residential irrigation system is allowed and must follow the same process as installation in regards to permitting, proper licensing, and project completion. 
(f)  Commercial and Industrial irrigation systems must be kept up to code even when not in use. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-311. - Duties and responsibilities of irrigation inspectors. 
(a)  The licensed inspector shall enforce the ordinance of the city, and shall be responsible for: 
(1)  Verifying that the appropriate permits have been obtained for an irrigation system and that the irrigator and installer or irrigation technician, if applicable, are licensed; 
(2)  Inspecting the irrigation system; 
(3)  Determining that the irrigation system complies with the requirements of this chapter; 
(4)  Determining that the appropriate backflow prevention device was installed, tested, and testing results provided to the city; 
(5)  Investigating complaints related to irrigation system installation, maintenance, alteration, repairs, or service of an irrigation system and advertisement or irrigation services; and 
(6)  Maintaining records according to this chapter. 
(b)  Registration. 
(1)  All approved and licensed irrigation inspectors and licensed plumbing inspectors must register with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-312. - Advertisement. 
(a)  All vehicles used in the performance of irrigation installation, maintenance, alteration, repair, or service must display the irrigator's license number in tile form of "LI___" in a large visible manner on both sides of the vehicle. 
(b)  All forms of written and electronic advertisement, including business cards, and estimates which displays an entity's or individual's name other than that of the licensed irrigator must also display the name of the licensed irrigator and the licensed irrigator 's license number. Trailers that advertise irrigation services must display the irrigator's license number. 
(c)  The name, mailing address, and telephone number of the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality local regional office must be prominently displayed on a legible sign and displayed in plain view for the purpose of the addressing complaints at the permanent structure where irrigation business is primarily conducted and irrigation records kept. 
(d)  Prominent signage with irrigator's license number, name, company name, and irrigation construction permit number must be displayed at any and all landscape irrigation construction sites until project completion. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-313. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city shall have the power to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter as may be required by governing law. Any person, firm, corporation or agent, who shall violate a provision of this Code, or fails to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, is subject to suit for injunctive relief as well as prosecution for criminal violations. Any violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter is declared to be a nuisance. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined a sum not exceeding $2,000.00. Each day that a provision of this chapter is violated shall constitute a separate offense. An offense under this chapter is considered a Class C misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of up to $2,000.00. 
(c)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as a waiver of the city's right to bring a civil action to enforce the provisions of this chapter and to seek remedies as allowed by law, including, but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Injunctive relief to prevent specific conduct that violated the article or to require specific conduct that is necessary for compliance with the article; and 
(2)  Other available relief. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 344-314. - Fees. 
(a)  The latest adopted fee schedule is as follows: 
(1)  New installations ..... $70.00 
(2)  Major repairs ..... $45.00 
(3)  Removal of irrigation system ..... $45.00 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018; Ord. No. 2018-1100.61, pt. 1, 11-13-2018) 
Sec. 344-315. - Items not covered by this article. 
(a)  Any item not covered by this article and required by law shall be governed by the V.T.C.A., Occupations Code, the Water Code, Title 30 of the Texas Administrative Code, and any other applicable state statute or TCEQ rule. 
(b)  The city may, at any point, adopt more stringent requirements for a home or property owner who installs an irrigation system. 
(Ord. No. 2018-1100.59, pt. 1, 9-18-2018) 
Chapter 348 - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The zoning ordinance of the city is printed in this chapter as adopted on October 28, 1932. The history note following every section "(Code 1971, app. B, § _____)" is used for the purpose of denoting the section number of former appendix B, from which this chapter derives. It is not intended for this history note to have any legal effect; it is used solely for reference purposes, and it precedes all other history of amendatory ordinances. 
Cross reference- Any rezoning ordinance or amendment to the zoning map saved from repeal, § 1-7(a)(10); airport zoning board, § 14-91 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 86; swimming pools, ch. 90; annexation, ch. 304; floods, ch. 308; mobile homes and manufactured homes, ch. 316; planning and development, ch. 320; signs, ch. 328; vegetation, ch. 344; franchises, app. A. 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et seq. 

Appendix A. - Zoning Processing Fees 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 348-1. - Short title. 
    Ordinance Number 235, as amended, shall be known, cited, and referred to as the "City Zoning Ordinance." 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 1.1; Ord. No. 235.1, § 1, 5-12-1980) 
Sec. 348-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory means of or relating to a subordinate use or building customarily incident to and located on the same lot with the main use or building. 
(1)  a.  Retail sale/rental of goods or services shall mean the sale or rental to the general public of goods or services. Wholesale sale/rental of goods or services is permitted if not the primary use. Examples include grocery stores, department stores, superstore and home improvement warehouse. 
b.  Home improvement warehouse shall mean an establishment primarily engaged in the retail sale/rental of goods and services, which may also sales on a wholesale basis to contractors and businesses, including but is not limited to sale of lumber, appliances, paint, hardware and related items, rental of tools and vehicles, a garden center, seasonal sales and outdoor display, storage and sales of building, landscape materials and equipment, barbeque pits, rental items and the alike. A home improvements superstore and/or warehouse is not considered a lumber yard. Accessory uses include garden center and seasonal sales. 
c.  Garden center shall mean an area adjacent to a building engaged in retail sale/rental of goods and services with perimeter enclosed by at least ten foot fence or similar structure or enclosure which may be open air and which area is dedicated to the storage, display and sale landscaping plants, materials and supplies and related items. A garden center is an accessory use to a home improvement superstore and/or warehouse. A garden center is not a violation of any prohibition against (i) sale or storage of goods located outdoors or public view, (ii) bulk storage or bulk sale, (iii) nuisance, or (iv) similar indirect limitations. 
d.  Seasonal sale shall mean the outdoor display and sale of goods of items relevant to the particular season as part of establishment engaged in retail sale/rental of goods and services such as an home improvement superstore and/or warehouse. Examples of goods sold seasonally include, but not limited to, landscaping plants, materials and equipment relevant to the particular season, play equipment, holiday decoration, barbeque pits, and other items of seasonal interest. The period of time during which particular goods may be displayed will not be limited by the strict calendar for a season, but will be limited based on general public interest and demands for such items. Seasonal sale is not a storage, even if certain items are left outdoors for accessory uses to home improvements superstore and/or warehouse. 
e.  Superstore shall mean establishment primarily engaged in retail sale/rental of goods and services with over 50,000 square feet of enclosed condition floor area which carriers a broad array of goods. Seasonal sales are an accessory use to a superstore. 
(2)  a.  Conditional use shall mean any use listed under a particular zoning district. Conditional uses are subject to review and permitted only through the issuance of a specific use permit by the city commission, with the exception of conditional uses for which conditions are already established and required for approval. Conditional uses that are exempted may be approved administratively. 
(3)  a.  Conditional use permit shall mean the permit required by section 348-1420 which is applicable only to the location of liquor servicing establishments, but not to conditional uses. The uses which require conditional use permits are as follow: 
1.  Liquor store. 
2.  Wet restaurant. 
3.  Wet stores. 
4.  Bars. 
    Alcoholic beverage means alcohol or any beverage containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume, which is capable of use for beverage purposes, either alone or when diluted. 
    Alcoholic beverage sales means any providing of the following non-"free" items to a potential consumer: "alcoholic beverages," setups, consumer's alcoholic beverage locker, or similar goods or services. 
    Alley means a road right-of-way or road right-of-way easement not over 25 feet in width. 
    Antique store means a fully enclosed building which: 
(1)  Is used primarily for the retail sale of any of the following items: 
a.  Old furniture, being at least 50 years old and constituting at least 75 percent of the total furniture; 
b.  Reproduction furniture, being clearly marked as a copy of old furniture and constituting no more than 20 percent of the total furniture; 
c.  Clothing, being at least 50 years old and being sold for at least $20.00 for each piece of clothing; 
d.  Work of art, decorative object, or other collectible, being at least 15 years old and being sold for at least $5.00 each; and 
(2)  Is a store where every item being sold is in good condition and where the average age of all such items is at least 50 years and where all signs and advertising prominently use the word "antique" or "antiques"; and 
(3)  Does not involve junk, garage sale, paperback books, or advertising as a used furniture outlet or flea market. 
    Apartment means a room or suite of rooms in an apartment house arranged, designed and occupied as the residence of an individual or family. 
    Apartment house means a building or portion thereof arranged, designed or occupied by three or more individuals or families, living independently of each other. 
    Arterial means the right-of-way of a primary arterial or secondary arterial identified by the legend and map on sheet 1A of the city's transportation plan. 
    Auditorium means a building used for public gatherings and includes but is not limited to theater, library, skating rink, and dancehall. 
    Automobile wrecking yard means the act of or premises used for the dismantling, crushing, shredding, or disassembling of used motor vehicles or trailers or the storage, sale, or dumping of one or more dismantled, partially dismantled, obsolete, or wrecked vehicles, trailers, or their parts if any such storage, sale, or dumping is not conducted inside totally enclosed buildings. 
    Bar means any "cafe" that is neither a "wet restaurant" nor a "dry restaurant." 
    Bed and breakfast means a building having a residential character, other than a hotel or motel, compatible with the neighborhood and providing: 
(1)  Temporary lodging generally for less than one month; 
(2)  Twelve or fewer guestrooms; 
(3)  At least one daily meal for guests; 
(4)  A manager residing on the premises; and 
(5)  None of the accessory uses normally associated with a hotel. 
    Boardinghouse means a building, other than a hotel, where lodging and meals for five or more persons are served for compensation. 
    Building means any roofed structure built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels, or property of any kind which has enclosing walls for at least 50 percent of its perimeter, with such roofed structure including any structures both attached thereto and within six feet thereof. The term "building" includes the term "structure" and includes all other improvements of every kind, regardless of similarity to buildings. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "or part thereof." 
    Bulk apparel store means the wholesale or retail sale, storage, distribution, or handling of new or used clothing, shoes, or accessories, if any such items emit offensive odors or are in a pile on the floor, bale, or disorderly pile inside any container anywhere on the premises at any time. 
    Cafe means any unified premises where any food, any beverage, or any combination of food and beverage is sold for on-premises consumption, excluding any "private club," "city fest," or city park. 
    Car title loan business means a business as defined in section 22-623 of the Brownsville Business Code. 
    Carport means a roofed structure open on three sides when attached to a dwelling and open on four sides when detached from a dwelling, covered with a roof supported by structural steel or wood columns or masonry piers of minimum size for structural safety. 
    Charity means a private nonprofit organization that does not primarily involve recreational or social activities for nonhandicapped adults. 
    Check cashing business means a business as defined in section 22-623 of the Brownsville Business Code. 
    Church means a permanent building used for the practice or teaching of a religion. 
    City Code means the Code of Ordinances, as amended, including but not limited to the city Charter. 
    City fest means an event authorized by city ordinance or resolution specifying a time period of up to 16 consecutive days and specifying a definite location open to the public. 
    City manager means: 
(1)  The chief executive officer and head of the administrative branch of the city government; 
(2)  The acting city manager; or 
(3)  Any city employee or administrative officer to whom such chief executive officer or acting city manager shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
    Class permit means any permit established under article III of chapter 300. 
    Code board means the board of adjustments and appeals established by the standard building and plumbing codes adopted by the city. 
    Code enforcement officer includes but is not limited to any of the following city employees or officers: 
(1)  City manager; 
(2)  Public health director; 
(3)  Building official; 
(4)  Deputy building official; 
(5)  Code enforcement officer; 
(6)  Fire marshal; 
(7)  Fire inspector; 
(8)  Housing officer; 
(9)  Traffic director; or 
(10)  Police chief. 
    Collector means the right-of-way of a collector identified by the legend and map on sheet 1A of the city's transportation plan. 
    Commercial vehicle means any "motor vehicle" other than a "passenger vehicle." 
    Corner lot means a lot situated at the junction of two or more streets. 
    Council means the city heritage council. 
    Country club means a regulation golf course with at least 18 holes, plus adjacent accessory uses open to members and their guests only. 
    Dancehall means any premises advertised as having either dancing or a dance band or any premises with dance floors totalling more than 100 square feet, excluding any private club, city fest, or city park. 
    Delivery service means any use that causes any materials, goods, or products that are physically located on or adjacent to the premises to be transferred to any off-premises site for any purposes other than routine solid-waste disposal, on-premises pickup by a customer, or incidental postal activities. 
    Development means as follows: 
(1)  In the absence of a more limiting section of the city Code, the performance of any building or mining operation, the making of any material change in the use or appearance of any premises, or the creation or termination of rights of access or riparian rights. 
(2)  The following activities or uses shall be taken for the purposes of this chapter to involve development unless expressly excluded by ordinance: 
a.  A change in type of use of the premises. 
b.  A reconstruction, alteration of the size, or material change in the external appearance of the premises, such as a change in the color of more than one square foot of a sign or any other structure. 
c.  A material increase in the intensity of use of the premises, such as an increase in the number of businesses, manufacturing establishments, offices, or dwelling units. 
d.  Commencement of mining or excavation. 
e.  Demolition or moving of a structure or removal of trees. 
f.  Deposit of refuse, solid or liquid waste or fill on a parcel of land. 
g.  In connection with the use of premises, the making of any material exterior change in noise levels, light levels, thermal conditions, or emissions of waste material, such as the installation of a floodlight or blinking or flashing light. 
h.  Commencement or change in the location of an advertising structure or use of land, and the commencement or change in location of advertising on the external part of a structure. 
i.  Alteration of a shore, bank, or floodplain of a river, resaca, stream, lake, pond, artificial water body, or other waterway. 
j.  Reestablishment of a use which has been abandoned for 26 weeks. 
k.  Departure from the normal use for which development permission has been granted or failure to comply with the conditions of an ordinance, rule, order, or permit granting the development permission under which the development was commenced or is continued. 
(3)  The following operations or uses do not constitute development for the purposes of this chapter: 
a.  The maintenance or improvement of a public road or railroad track not involving substantial engineering redesign if the work is carried out on land within the boundaries of the right-of-way. 
b.  Work by any utility not involving substantial engineering redesign for the purpose of inspection, repair, or renewal on established rights-of-way of any sewers, mains, pipes, cables, utility tunnels, power lines, towers, poles, tracks, or the like. 
c.  Work for the maintenance, renewal, improvement, or alteration of any structure, if the work affects only the interior of the structure and does not materially affect the external appearance of the structure. 
d.  A transfer of title to land. 
e.  The creation of time units in existing parcels of land. 
f.  The creation or termination of easements or other rights in land not otherwise involving development. 
(4)  Development as designated in an ordinance, rules, or development permit includes all other development customarily associated with it unless otherwise specified. Activities which may result in development as defined include erection, construction, redevelopment, alteration, or repair. When appropriate to the context, development refers to the act of developing or to the result of development. Reference to any specific operation as not involving development is not intended to mean that the operation or activity when part of other operations or activities is not development. Reference to particular operations is not intended to limit the generality of subsection (1) of this definition. 
    Director means: 
(1)  The head or acting head of the city planning and community development department; or 
(2)  Any city employee or administrative officer to whom such head or acting head shall have delegated certain authority, but only to the extent of such delegation. 
    Downtown means an area with the following clockwise boundaries: East 7th Street, East Adams Street, East 9th Street, middle of alley between East Monroe Street and East Jackson Street, International Boulevard as extended, and East St. Charles Street as extended. 
    Dry restaurant means a "cafe" where "alcoholic beverage sales" are absent. 
    Dwelling unit means one room, or rooms connected together, constituting a separate, independent housekeeping establishment for owner occupancy, or for rental or lease on a weekly, monthly, or longer basis; being physically separated from any other rooms or dwelling units which may be in the same structure; and containing independent and permanent facilities for living, sleeping, eating, cooking, and sanitation. 
    Existing heritage site means a federal, state, or local site listed in the city's heritage plan. 
    Family means any number of individuals living together as a single housekeeping unit. 
    Financial institution means an establishment as defined in section 22-623 of the Brownsville Business Code. 
    Flea market means an open air or partially enclosed space for the wholesale or retail sale, but not bulk storage, of any secondhand goods, other than used motor vehicles, during more than 20 hours in any 14-day period. 
    Floor-area ratio means the quotient, where the divisor is the gross lot area, expressed in square feet, and where the dividend is the combined "gross floor area" of all roofed structures on the lot. 
    Free means not involving any past, present, or future charge or consideration. 
    Front line of the lot means all "lot lines" abutting any street right-of-way or street right-of-way easement. 
    Front on means either abut and have direct public access to or have any private access to. 
    Gaming device means any electronic, electromechanical, or mechanical contrivance that for a consideration affords the player an opportunity to obtain anything of value, the award of which is determined solely or partially by chance, even though accompanied by some skill, whether or not the prize is automatically paid by the contrivance. 
(1)  The term includes, but is not limited to: 
a.  Gaming-device versions of bingo, keno, blackjack, lottery, roulette, video poker, or similar electronic, electromechanical, or mechanical games, or facsimiles thereof, that operate by chance or partially so, that as a result of the play or operation of the game award credits or free games, and that record the number of free games or credits so awarded and the cancellation or removal of the free games or credits; or 
b.  Any electronic, electromechanical, or mechanical contrivance designed, made, and adapted solely for bona fide amusement purposes even if the contrivance rewards the player exclusively with noncash merchandise prizes, toys, or novelties, or a representation of value redeemable for those items, no matter how small their wholesale value may be; or 
c.  Any eight-liner. 
(2)  The term does not include: 
a.  Any device used exclusively by an employee of a location licensed by the state lottery commission; or 
b.  Any device used exclusively for carnival-related bets defined by V.T.C.A. Penal Code § 47.01(1)(C), where the carnival's duration is less than 32 days per year; or 
c.  Any device that affords the player an opportunity to obtain a thing of value, where such thing of value is limited to an unrecorded and immediate right of replay not exchangeable for value. 
    Gross floor area means the total area, in square feet, of all the floors of all the stories of a building as measured to the outside surfaces of exterior walls, inclusive of corridors, stairs, shafts, closets, attached porches or balconies, thickness of walls, columns, or other features, but exclusive of areas open and unobstructed to the sky. 
    Gross lot area means the lot area of the lot plus half the area of any street rights-of-way or street right-of-way easements abutting the lot lines of the lot. 
    Group quarters means the home of any person not living in a household as defined by the United States Census Bureau and includes but is not limited to correctional institution, nursing home, mental institution, hospital for the chronically ill, orphanage, convent, college dormitory, military barracks, and emergency shelter for homeless persons. 
    Half story means a story having an average height of not more than seven feet. 
    Hazardous material facility means any use for which a Tier Two Report must be submitted to the state health department under federal law, excluding the retail sale of passenger-vehicle fuels stored in underground tanks. 
    Height means the vertical distance from the topmost point of any structure to the average natural grade of the lot along the perimeter of such structure, including chimneys, towers, and all other buildings or structures of any kind; but excluding any public-utility poles in a public right-of-way, private road right-of-way, or private road right-of-way easement. 
    Hotel means a building occupied as the more or less temporary abiding place of individuals who are lodged with or without meals, in which, as a rule, the rooms are occupied singly for hire, in which provision is not made for cooking in any individual apartment, and in which there are more than 12 sleeping rooms, a public dining room for the accommodation of more than 12 guests, and a general kitchen. 
    Household items means any goods that are customarily bought by a person for use on the premises of such person's dwelling unit, including but not limited to clothing, jewelry, furniture, carpets, plants, or medications. 
    Lodging house means a building, other than a "hotel," where lodging for five or more persons is provided for compensation. 
    Lot means a parcel of land considered as a unit for a certain purpose dependent upon the context. The term "lot" includes the terms "parcel," "piece," and "plot." 
    Lot area means the total horizontal areas within the "lot lines" of the lot. 
    Lot lines means the lines bounding the lot after any public rights-of-way, private street rights-of-way, and private street right-of-way easements have been excluded from such lot. 
    Manufacture means a process included under division D (manufacturing) of the latest edition of the Standard Industrial Classification Manual as published by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget. 
    Meal means a combination of foods and beverages that includes ample portions from each of the four basic food groups (dairy products, fruits and vegetables, meats and meat alternatives, grains) and includes a choice of at least two distinctly different entrees cooked or heated on the premises but that excludes snacks, candy, desserts, appetizers, hor d'oeuvres, condiments, and similar items. 
    Miniwarehouse means a building containing one or more individual, compartmentalized, and controlled access units available by rent or lease to the general public for the indoor storage of goods hidden from public view, with each such unit's gross floor area being no more than 500 square feet. 
    Money exchange business means an entity jointly defined by sections 22-61 and 22-68. 
    Motor vehicle means a self-propelled vehicle which is capable of travelling on roads and which is at least four feet wide. 
    Nonconforming use means a building or premises occupied by or devoted to a use that does not conform to the regulations of the use district in which it is situated. 
    Nonprofit organization means an entity that is operated primarily for a charitable, philanthropic, social, educational, religious, or recreational purpose; is not motivated by profit; does not primarily render a service which is customarily carried on as a business; and includes but is not limited to all tax-exempt entities. 
    Number of dwelling units per gross acre means the quotient, where the divisor is the "gross lot area," expressed in acres, and where the dividend is the total number of "dwelling units" on the lot. 
    Office means a room, studio, suite, or building or any part thereof in which a person transacts his business or carries on his stated occupation, with such business or occupation not including any of the following uses on the premises: 
(1)  The manufacture, fabrication, production, processing, assembling, cleaning, testing, repair, or storage of materials, goods, or products; or 
(2)  The sale or delivery of any materials, goods or products that are physically located on the premises. 
    One-family dwelling means a detached residential "dwelling unit," other than a mobile home, designed for and occupied by one family only. 
    Passenger vehicle means a "motor vehicle" for which a class C driver's license is required by the state, with such vehicle excluding a motorcycle or moped but including a bus with a seating capacity of less than 24 passengers, or a single two-axle vehicle with a gross vehicle weight that does not exceed 24,000 pounds, alone or towing either a vehicle with a gross vehicle weight that does not exceed 10,000 pounds or a farm trailer with a gross vehicle weight that does not exceed 20,000 pounds. 
    Payday advance or loan business means a business as defined in section 22-623 of the Brownsville Business Code. 
    Person includes a natural person; a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company, or corporation; his, its, or their successors, assigns, heirs, executors, or administrators; or the agent of any of such. 
    Personal service outlet means an establishment that provides personal services for the convenience of the neighborhood, including but not limited to barbershop, beauty shop, shoe repair shop, travel agency, or photographic studio. 
    Place means an open unoccupied space reserved for purposes of access to abutting property. 
    Porch means a roofed structure that is attached to a building and that is completely open on all other sides except for roof supports. 
    Premises means a lot, together with all buildings and structures thereon. 
    Private club means a "nonprofit organization" or a country club. 
    Private garage means a garage that is limited to the storage of motor-driven vehicles for private use, where the total number of storage spaces for such vehicles shall be limited to one per apartment on a lot occupied by apartments and shall be limited to a total of two on all other lots, and where not more than one such space shall be rented to persons not occupying the premises. 
    Professional means of or relating to the occupations of architect, engineer, surveyor, lawyer, accountant, dentist, physician, surgeon, psychologist, insurance agent, realtor, or planner. 
    Public garage means any premises used for storage, housing, or care of motor-driven vehicles, where such vehicles are equipped for operation; repaired; or kept for remuneration, hire or sale. 
    Rear line of the lot means any lot line other than either a "front line of the lot" or a "sideline of the lot." 
    Residential means of or relating to one or more "dwelling units." 
    Residential vehicle sales means the offering for sale of no more than two passenger vehicles per premises in any 12-month period, with the seller having been the registered owner of such vehicle before making such offer, and with the use being located on premises which include the owner's residence but which exclude on-premises advertising. 
    School means an educational institution for grades K-12, college, university, or graduate school. 
    Sexually oriented business means any use that is described by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.002 and that is not exempted by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.004. 
    Shall is mandatory and directive and not discretionary; may is permissive. 
    Sideline of the lot means any "lot line" that touches a "front line of the lot" for the same lot. 
    Sign means any device, letter, figure, character, mark, plane, point, marquee sign, design, poster, banner, flag, pictorial, picture, stroke, stripe, line, trademark, reading matter, display window, or illuminated service that is so constructed, placed, attached, painted, erected, fastened or manufactured in any manner whatsoever, so that such is used to inform or attract the attention of the public to any place, subject, person, firm, corporation, public performance, article, machine or merchandise whatsoever and that is visible to persons off the premises. 
    State-maintained arterial means any of the following arterials: 
(1)  Expressway 77/83. 
(2)  Military Highway; Boca Chica Boulevard. 
(3)  International Boulevard; East 14th Street north of Industrial Drive. 
(4)  Billy Mitchell Boulevard. 
(5)  Southmost Road east of International Boulevard. 
(6)  Central Boulevard; Elizabeth Street from Central Boulevard to East 6th Street. 
(7)  Paredes Line Road north of Boca Chica Boulevard. 
(8)  FM Road 802; FM Road 3248; FM Road 313; FM Road 511. 
    Storage means retention of an item on the premises for more than seven days. 
    Story means that portion of a building, other than a primarily unincorporated attic or cellar located in a one-family dwelling, included between the upper surface of a floor and the upper surface of the floor or roof next above. 
    Street means a road right-of-way or road right-of-way easement more than 25 feet wide. 
    Structural alteration means any change in the supporting members of a building, such as bearing walls, columns, beams or girders. 
    Structure means anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on the ground or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground, including but not limited to buildings, mobile homes, walls, fences, and billboards. 
    TABC means the state alcoholic beverage commission. 
    Territorial jurisdiction means the entire geographic area within the corporate limits of a city. 
    Thoroughfare means an arterial, a collector, or the right-of-way of a federal-aid urban street identified by the legend and map on sheet 1A of the city's transportation plan. 
    Tourist camp means a building or group of buildings designed, arranged or used for temporary occupancy by persons traveling by automobile and having accommodations for housing or parking the automobile in close proximity to the quarters occupied by the owner of the automobile and providing for three or more such quarters. 
    Two-family dwelling means one detached residential building that consists exclusively of two "dwelling units," that is designed and constructed for two families who are to live independently of each other, that is occupied by not more than two such families, and that is designed and constructed in a manner ensuring that: 
(1)  Such units are structurally connected to each other to such an extent that the elimination of such structural connections would be prohibitively expensive; and 
(2)  Any breezeway or other gap between such units has permanent screens, baffles, or other structures that prevent an unobstructed public view through such gap. 
    Used and occupied include the term "arranged," "designed," "intended," "maintained," "occupied," or "used." 
    Warehouse means a building for the indoor storage of goods screened from public view. 
    Wet restaurant means a "cafe" where "meals" are readily available whenever "alcoholic beverages" are sold, the dollar value of the cafe's "alcoholic beverage sales" does not exceed 49 percent of the dollar value of the cafe's total sales of all beverages and all foods, and at least 15 percent of the cafe's "gross floor area" is devoted to food preparation. 
    Wet store means a store with "alcoholic beverage sales" only of sealed containers for off-premises opening. 
    Yard means a required open space, other than a court, that is included as part of the "lot area" and that is unoccupied and unobstructed by any structure or portion of a structure from 30 inches above the general ground level of the graded lot upward, with the exception of fences, walls, poles, posts, and other customary yard accessories, ornaments, and furniture that may be permitted in any yard subject to height and vision-clearance provisions; provided that in no case shall any roofed structure be permitted in any yard in an "X," "Y," "F" or "G" area district, except for a carport in a front yard in a "G" area district. The term "yard" is further defined as follows: 
(1)  Corner yard means all areas that are located within one or more lots and that are bounded by the "front line of the lot" and by the vision line, where the vision line is described as follows: 
a.  The vision line consists of one straight line connecting point X to point Y plus one straight line connecting point Y to point Z; 
b.  Points X and Z are each on the "front line of the lot" at a straight-line distance of 36 feet from point C, with point X touching the first intersecting street and with point Z touching the second intersecting street; 
c.  Point C is the closest point at which the right-of-way lines of the two streets adjacent to such lot would intersect if the right-of-way lines were parallel to the centerlines of the intersecting street; 
d.  Point Y is the point at which two straight lines intersect, with one such line connecting point X to point B and the other such line connecting point Z to point A; and 
e.  Points A and B are each at a straight-line distance of six feet from point C and are each on lines that intersect at point C and that are parallel to the street centerlines adjacent to the lot, with point A touching the first intersecting street and with point B touching the second intersecting street. 
(2)  Front yard means a "yard" extending along the entire length of the "front line of the lot," exclusive of any required side yard. The term "depth of front yard" means the shortest horizontal distance between a building and the "front line of the lot," with the minimum depth being specified in the area district regulations, except that for a corner lot such minimum depth shall apply only along the one principal abutting street, and the minimum front yard along all other abutting streets shall be two-fifths of such depth. 
(3)  Rear yard means a "yard" extending along the entire length of the "rear line of the lot" and including half of any abutting alley. The term "depth of rear yard" means the shortest horizontal distance between a building and either the "rear line of the lot" for a lot not on an alley or the centerline of the alley for a lot on an alley. 
(4)  Side yard means a "yard" extending along the entire length of each "sideline of the lot" outside any "rear yard." The term "width of side yard" means the shortest horizontal distance between a building and the closest "sideline of the lot." 
    Zoning administrator means a city employee appointed by the director to perform duties such as processing rezoning applications. 
    Zoning board means the board of adjustment authorized by Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1011g. 
    Zoning commission means the city planning and zoning commission.

No. 89-235.18, § 8, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 98-235.38, pt. 7, 6-3-1998; Ord. No. 98-235.40, pt. 4, 6-23-1998; Ord. No. 98-235.41, pt. 2, 8-4-1998; Ord. No. 2003-235.57, pt. 4, 3-18-2003; Ord. No. 2006-1468, § 1, 12-5-2006; Ord. No. 2010-1521, § 1, 1-26-2010; Ord. No. 2010-1468A, § 1, 10-19-2010; Ord. No. 2016-235.85, § pt. 1, 8-16-2016) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 348-3. - Purpose. 
(a)  The zoning regulations and districts as established in this chapter have been made in accordance with a comprehensive plan for the purpose of promoting the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the city. They have been designed to: 
(1)  Lessen the congestion in the streets. 
(2)  Secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers. 
(3)  Provide adequate light and air. 
(4)  Prevent the overcrowding of land. 
(5)  Avoid undue concentration of population. 
(6)  Facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements. 
(7)  Protect and preserve places and areas of historical, cultural, or architectural importance and significance. 
(b)  The zoning regulations and districts have been made with reasonable consideration for the character of the districts, their suitability for particular uses, and with a view of conserving the value of buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of the land throughout the city. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 1; Ord. No. 235.7, § 5, 3-26-1986) 
Sec. 348-4. - Interpretation. 
(a)  In their interpretation and application, the sections of this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, or general welfare. 
(b)  In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.013, wherever the provisions of this chapter differ from the provisions of other laws, rules, or regulations, the provisions that control shall be those provisions which: 
(1)  Require a greater width or size of yards, courts, or other open spaces; 
(2)  Require a lower building height of fewer number of stories for a building; 
(3)  Require a greater percentage of lot to be left unoccupied; or 
(4)  Impose higher standards. 
(c)  This chapter is not intended to be construed to be in violation of any federal or state laws, rules, or regulations and should not be interpreted by anyone as encouraging actions contrary thereto. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 22.1; Ord. No. 235.2, § 1, 5-27-1980; Ord. No. 87-235.14, § 3, 9-15-1987; Ord. No. 98-235.35, pt. 2, 2-3-1998) 
Sec. 348-5. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Solely for the purposes of this section, the term "person" shall be defined to include any of the following: 
(1)  Any individual, firm, or corporation with a pecuniary interest in property subject to this chapter; 
(2)  Their agents, engineers, architects, contractors, or builders; or 
(3)  Any lessee or occupier of property subject to this chapter. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any of the sections of this chapter or who shall fail to comply with this chapter or with any of the requirements of this chapter or who shall build or alter any building in violation of any detailed statement or plan submitted and approved under this chapter shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to a fine as provided in section 1-13. 
(c)  Each day that such violation shall be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  However, the imposition of any such fine for any violation shall not constitute an estoppel for other relief against any such violation available at law. 
(e)  For each violation the city shall issue a citation stating the alleged violation, the date of the violation, and the section of this Code or ordinance violated. The municipal court shall have exclusive original jurisdiction over all such citations. 
(f)  Each code enforcement officer shall have independent authority to issue any such citation. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 19; Ord. No. 235.6, § 1, 6-25-1985; Ord. No. 88-235.17, § 1, 5-3-1988) 
Secs. 348-6-348-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 348-31. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This chapter shall be administered by the building inspector under the direction of the city manager in accordance with the city Charter. 
(b)  All applications for building permits shall be accompanied by legible plans and specifications for the building to be erected. The plans shall be drawn to scale and shall include a "lot" plan, which shall disclose the actual dimensions of the lot upon which the proposed building is to be erected, the position of the proposed building upon the lot, its intended use and such other information as the building inspector may require for the proper enforcement of this chapter. 
(c)  Upon receipt of an application for a building permit, the building inspector shall as soon as practicable check the plans and specifications carefully for compliance with the terms of the building code and the terms of this chapter. 
(d)  If the plans and specifications submitted do not comply with the terms of the building code or the terms of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the building inspector to deny the application for the building permit forthwith and so endorse his refusal to issue the building permit upon the written records of his office. It shall be the further duty of the building inspector to advise the applicant for a building permit, whose request has been denied that, under certain conditions as set forth in division 2 of this article, he may refer his application to the board of adjustment for consideration and that such board may grant his request. If the applicant wishes to appeal his case to such board, it shall be the further duty of the building inspector to endorse the certificate necessary to complete the appeal. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 15) 
Sec. 348-32. - State alcoholic beverage commission liaison. 
(a)  The zoning administrator shall have exclusive authority to process and sign late-hours or other state alcoholic beverage commission permit or license applications on behalf of the city and to use the title "deputy city clerk" only for such purpose. 
(b)  No such state alcoholic beverage commission application shall be signed by the zoning administrator until all of the following prerequisites are met: 
(1)  A separate class W permit shall have been issued for each such state application. 
(2)  All city taxes, including occupation taxes, shall have been paid in full. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the permit fee for class W permits shall be waived. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 15.5; Ord. No. 87-235.10, § 11, 3-3-1987; Ord. No. 87-235.14, § 7, 9-15-1987) 
Sec. 348-33. - Zoning map designations. 
(a)  When definite distances in feet are not shown on the zoning map, the district boundaries are intended to be along existing streets, alleys or property lines or extensions of or from the streets, alleys or property lines. When the location of a district boundary is not otherwise determined, it shall be determined by the scale of the map as measured from a given line. 
(b)  Where the street layout on the ground varies from the streets shown upon the zoning map, the board of adjustment may apply the designations shown upon the mapped streets in such a way as to carry out the intent and purpose of the plan for the particular area in question. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 16) 
Sec. 348-34. - Amendments. 
(a)  Generally. The following are applicable to ordinances amending the text of this chapter or other zoning ordinances, ordinances amending the official zoning atlas, and related matters: 
(1)  The city commission may from time to time amend, supplement, or change by ordinance the boundaries of the districts or the regulations established in this chapter. 
(2)  The city commission shall not act on any such ordinance until it has held and closed a public hearing thereon. 
(3)  Under no circumstances shall the city commission close such hearing until it has received the final report of the zoning commission on such ordinance and given the public an opportunity to comment on such report. Thereafter, the city commission may continue its public hearing at its discretion. 
(4)  The city commission may open a public hearing before receiving such final report if and only if both the city commission and the zoning commission hold a joint hearing as authorized at the discretion of the city manager. The zoning commission shall close its portion of such joint hearing before adopting the final report. If the zoning commission continues its hearing, the city commission shall immediately do likewise. 
(5)  Public hearings shall not be continued to an uncertain date, time, or place. 
(6)  Unless such proposed amendment, supplement, or change has been favorably recommended by the zoning commission, such proposed amendment, supplement, or change shall not become effective without the favorable votes of at least five city commission members. 
(b)  Atlas amendments. The following are applicable only to ordinances amending the official zoning atlas and to related matters: 
(1)  When an application for the zoning or rezoning of any property is filed with the zoning commission, the applicant shall pay to the zoning administrator a nonrefundable fixed fee in such sum as the city commission shall have previously determined by motion or resolution as being sufficient to defray any and all expenses incident to the hearing of such application before the zoning commission. 
(2)  Within 30 days of the zoning commission's recommending against a proposed zoning or rezoning of property, any party protesting such recommendation shall pay to the zoning administrator a nonrefundable fixed fee in such sum as the city commission shall have previously determined by motion or resolution as being sufficient to defray any and all expenses incident to the hearing of such protest before the city commission. 
(3)  When the zoning commission favorably recommends a zoning or rezoning of property, the parties entitled by law to protest such recommendation shall pay to the zoning administrator, upon the filing of such protest before the closing of the city commission's hearing, a nonrefundable fixed fee in such sum as the city commission shall have previously determined by motion or resolution as being sufficient to defray any and all expenses incident to the hearing of such protest before the city commission. 
(4)  During any 90-day period no more than one zoning commission public hearing shall be advertised as regards zoning a given parcel, unless each subsequent zoning application for such parcel requests a more restrictive classification or requests the zoning of an area at least 50 percent smaller or larger; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be applicable to city-initiated applications. 
(5)  Before the written notice required by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.007(c) is mailed, the director shall have unilateral authority to convert any owner-initiated application into a combination owner/city-initiated application for the purpose of expanding the geographic area inside the boundaries of the zoning case and/or for the purpose of requesting a base zoning classification less restrictive than the classification requested by such owner-initiated application. 
(6)  At least ten days before any public hearing on an atlas amendment, the zoning administrator shall cause written notice thereof to be mailed to the representative of each neighborhood organization qualified under section 324-3 whose boundaries include or are within a radius of 200 feet from any property to be zoned by such amendment. 
(7)  Each zoning application shall cover a single contiguous geographic area and shall request a single zoning classification. 
(8)  If a zoning application is submitted, such application and all actions pertaining thereto shall become null and void unless the application is approved by the planning commission on or before the one year anniversary date of such submittal. 
(9)  If a protest against an atlas amendment has been filed with the city secretary, duly signed by the owners of 20 percent or more either of the area of the lots or land included in such amendment or of those immediately adjoining the lots or land and extending 200 feet therefrom, such proposed amendment shall not become effective without the favorable votes of at least six city commission members. 
(c)  Joint-hearing notice. Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.007(d), the following prescribe the type of notice to be given of the time and place of a public hearing held jointly by the city commission and the zoning commission. For such a joint hearing, the notice requirements prescribed by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 211.007(b) and (c) and 211.006(a) do not apply: 
(1)  At least ten calendar days before a joint hearing, the zoning administrator shall cause notice thereof to be given by all of the following methods: 
a.  Publishing a display ad in an official newspaper or a newspaper of general circulation in this city. 
b.  Displaying the zoning commission's preliminary report at the public library. 
c.  Mailing the zoning commission's preliminary report to the representative of each neighborhood organization qualified under section 324-3 whose boundaries include or are within a radius of 200 feet from the study area for the proposed ordinance amending the official zoning atlas. 
(2)  In addition to the methods in subsection (c)(1) of this section, one or more other methods of providing joint-hearing notice may be used by the zoning administrator upon authorization from the city manager, such as the following: 
a.  Implementing subsection (c)(1) of this section earlier than ten days before the joint hearing. 
b.  Publishing the newspaper notice on a Sunday instead of a weekday. 
c.  Broadcasting notices on the city-controlled cable television channel. 
d.  Displaying the zoning commission's preliminary report at shopping malls. 
e.  Placing signs in road rights-of-way near the study area covered by the zoning commission's preliminary report for a proposed ordinance amending the official zoning atlas. 
f.  Attaching flyers to doorknobs in the study area. 
g.  Mailing the zoning commission's preliminary report to a representative of a neighborhood organization not yet qualified under section 324-3 whose boundaries are near the study area. 
h.  Including a map in the newspaper notice showing the outer boundaries of the study area. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 20; Ord. No. 235, § 1, 8-19-1959; Ord. No. 235-amend., § 1, 4-12-1962; Ord. No. 235.5, § 6, 6-4-1985; Ord. No. 235.7, § 10, 3-26-1986; Ord. No. 87-235.14, § 2, 9-15-1987; Ord. No. 89-235.18, § 25, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 95-235.25, pts. 1, 2, 10-31-1995; Ord. No. 97-235.34, pt. 2, 7-15-1997; Ord. No. 98-235.40, pt. 5, 6-23-1998; Ord. No. 2001-235.49, pt. 3(20.B.7), 4-24-2001; Ord. No. 2001-235.50, pt. 1, 7-17-2001; Ord. No. 2001-235.51, pt. 1, 7-10-2001; Ord. No. 2008-235.77, art. I, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 348-35. - Nonconforming uses. 
(a)  Any use of property existing at the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter derives which does not conform to the regulations prescribed in this chapter shall be deemed a "nonconforming use." 
(b)  A nonconforming use may be continued subject to such regulations as to the maintenance of the "premises" and conditions of operation as, in the judgment of the board of adjustment, may reasonably be required for the protection of adjacent property. 
(c)  A nonconforming use shall not be extended, but the extension of a use to any portion of a building arranged or designed for such nonconforming use at the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter derives shall not be deemed the extension of a nonconforming use. 
(d)  A nonconforming use shall not be changed, except to a conforming use. A nonconforming use, if changed to a conforming use, may not thereafter be changed to a nonconforming use. 
(e)  A cemetery, a sewage disposal or treatment plant, a public utility plant, or an institution existing in any use district at the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter derives or any medium industrial use district use so existing in a light industrial use district shall be deemed a conforming use upon the lot devoted to such use at the time of passage of the ordinance from which this chapter derives. 
(f)  Additions will be permitted to structures which are nonconforming and which were in existence on or before July 15, 1945, so long as the additions do not encroach on areas on which building is prohibited by city ordinance and provided, further, that such structures meet all city sanitary regulations, conform with the existing building code, and comply with all overlay district provisions. 
(g)  Except as allowed under subsection (f) of this section or section 348-66, a change of use shall be deemed to occur when a nonconforming use undergoes any development, including but not limited to conversion from a dry restaurant to a wet restaurant or from a wet restaurant to a bar, material increase in hours of operation, or material increase in unmet parking demand. 
(h)  If a nonconforming amusement arcade expands, only the new gross floor area shall be subject to sections 348-342(7), 348-343(9) and 348-1381(ff). 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 21.5; Ord. No. 235-A, 10-25-1945; Ord. No. 235.7, § 6, 3-26-1986; Ord. No. 87-235.10, § 6, 3-3-1987; Ord. No. 89-235.18, § 20, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 2001-235.49, pt. 3(21.5(5)), 4-24-2001; Ord. No. 2003-235.57, pt. 5, 3-18-2003) 
Secs. 348-36-348-60. - Reserved.

Sec. 348-65. - Terms of office; alternate members. 
(a)  Each member of the board of adjustment shall be appointed for a term of two years. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member whose term becomes vacant. 
(b)  Alternate members, when appointed, shall serve for the same period as the regular members, and any vacancies shall be filled in the same manner and shall be subject to removal as the regular members. Alternate members shall serve in the absence of one or more regular members when requested to do so by the mayor or city manager, as the case may be. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 17.1(5); Ord. No. 235.3, § 1, 12-16-1980; Ord. No. 235.4, § 8, 5-12-1981; Ord. No. 89-235.18, §§ 21, 22, 1-17-1989) 
Sec. 348-66. - Special exceptions. 
    When in its judgment the public convenience and welfare will not be substantially or permanently injured, the board of adjustment may, in a specific case, after public notice and a public hearing and subject to appropriate conditions and safeguards, authorize special exceptions to this chapter, as will permit the following: 
(1)  The location of a state or municipal building, aviation field, public utility plant, riding academy, commercial greenhouse, athletic field, commercial radio transmitting station, or philanthropic institution in any use district. 
(2)  The reconstruction of a building occupied by a nonconforming use or the extension of a nonconforming use of a building upon the lot occupied by such use or building of the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter derives. 
(3)  The extension of a building or use into a more restricted district immediately adjacent thereto, but not more than 50 feet beyond the boundary line of the district in which such building or use is authorized. 
(4)  In any district, such modification of the requirements of this chapter as the board of adjustment may deem necessary to secure an appropriate development of a lot where adjacent to such lot on two or more sides there are buildings that do not conform to this chapter. 
(5)  In a Dwelling or Dwelling/retail use district, a Medium Commercial use of a lot adjoining a Medium Industrial use district, or an Apartment use of a lot adjoining a Medium Retail, General Retail, Light Commercial, Medium Commercial, or Light Industrial use district, so that there will be stepping down from the more restricted to the less restricted use. 
(6)  Such modification of the yard, lot area or lot width regulations as may be necessary to secure an appropriate improvement of a lot where such lot was separately owned at the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter derives and where such lot is of such size that it cannot be improved without such modification. 
(7)  In a Dwelling or Dwelling/retail use district, any use permitted in an Apartment use district; provided, however, that this special exception shall apply only to areas that are within a perpendicular distance of 100 feet from the sideline of a lot located in a Professional Office, Light Retail, Medium Retail, General Retail, Light Commercial, Medium Commercial, or Light Industrial use district. 
(Code 1971, app. B, § 17.2; Ord. No. 235.3, § 1, 12-16-1980; Ord. No. 235.4, § 8, 5-12-1981; Ord. No. 89-235.18, §§ 21, 22, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 2001-235.49, pt. 3(17.2(5), (7)), 4-24-2001)
