The plan indicates the city should develop a comprehensive preservation plan to aid in the protection and redevelopment of historic properties and establish goals and strategies for preservation, rehabilitation, economic development and tourism expansion. 
    The implementation of the objectives of this article are a critical part of the city's long-term strategic objectives. The economic, environmental, and downtown portions as well as the urban design smart growth principles that underlie the comprehensive plan all rely on the resiliency and strength of the Historic District (HD); this connection cannot be overstated. 
    The following goals, objectives and policies have largely been a part of the ordinances since their inception and are re-affirmed here: 
(a)  The declaration that as a matter of public policy the protection, enhancement, preservation, rehabilitation, and use of the city's historic resources is a public necessity and required in the interest of the culture, education, prosperity, and general welfare of the people of the city; and 
(b)  The provision of long-term regulations for the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of the city's historic resources and districts that represent or reflect elements of the city's cultural, economic, political, social, and architectural history; and 
(c)  The assurance that development and regulation is in accord with established public policy and will protect and enhance the city's historical architectural resources and attractions for the benefit of residents, tourists, and visitors and serve as a support and stimulus to business and industry to strengthen the economy of the city; and 
(d)  The promotion of the use of historic districts and use of the city's historic resources for the education, pleasure, and welfare of the people of the city; and 
(e)  The protection, enhancement, and perpetuation of historic architectural resources which represent or reflect distinctive and important elements of the city, the state, and the Rio Grande Valley in terms of architectural, archeological, cultural, social, economic, ethnic, and political history and develop appropriate settings for such places; and 
(f)  To safeguard the city's historic and cultural heritage as embodied and reflected in historic landmarks and designated historic resources by appropriate regulations; and 
(g)  To stabilize and improve property values in such locations; and 
(h)  To foster knowledge of and civic pride in the beauty and accomplishments of the city's past; and 
(i)  To strengthen the economy of the city; and 
(j)  To strengthen civic pride through neighborhood preservation; and 
(k)  Promote the use of historic resources for the culture, prosperity, education, enjoyment, and general welfare of the people of the city and visitors to the city; and 
(l)  To establish the highest urban design standards for public property including public buildings and public spaces in the HD so the public commitment to quality design and preservation encourages and inspires by example a corresponding commitment by the private sector. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL 

Sec. 348-1490. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    O11 Historic Overlay District is synonymous with Historic District (HD) and refers to the area(s) of the city that is covered by this article. 
    Ad valorem tax component of the historic preservation plan refers to the part of the city's historic preservation plan involving property tax incentive(s). 
    Atlas amendment means adding and showing a boundary of an historic district or historic landmark district on the zoning atlas map or any city base map. 
    Certificate of appropriateness means an order issued by the HPO indicating approval of plans for alteration, construction, or demolition affecting a designated historic resource or a property within the historic district. 
    Contributing building means a historic building that retains a significant amount of its physical integrity and character defining features including location, setting, design, construction, workmanship, and/or association with historical persons or events. 
    Contributing object means an object within the historic district that contributes to the historic character of the district. 
    Contributing property or contributing resource means any building, structure, object, or resource which adds to the historical integrity or architectural qualities that make up the historic district. It also refers to any listed or unlisted property, building, structure, or object which adds to a cluster of properties that as a whole contribute to the historic district 
    Contributing site means a site within the historic district that contributes to the historic character of the district. 
    Contributing structure means a structure within the historic district that contributes to the historic character of the district. 
    Historic site (synonymous with historic resource ) when used in this article refers to any or all of the following: 
(a)  A federal site, state site, primary local site, secondary local site, or a site that contributes to the historic district individually or as part of a cluster of sites as determined by the historic preservation officer (HPO) and prevailing national standards; 
(b)  The location of a historically significant event, a prehistoric or historic occupation or activity; 
(c)  A building or structure, whether standing or ruined, where the location itself possesses historical, cultural, or archeological value regardless of the value of any existing structure; 
    Demolition by neglect is a situation in which a property owner or others having legal possession, custody or control of a property, allow the condition of property located to suffer such deterioration, potentially beyond the point of repair, as to threaten the structural integrity of that structure. 
    Design guidelines means guidelines of appropriateness or compatibility of building design within a community or historic district.. The historic preservation and design review board has authority to administer design guidelines. 
    Design review shall refer to the decision making process conducted by the historic preservation and design review board or by the historic preservation officer of the city that is guided by established terms. 
    Historic designations means an official recognition of the significance of a building, property or district. Designation can occur on three different levels: 
(a)  Federal-The National Register of Historic Places (for both individual buildings and entire districts); 
(b)  State-Recorded Texas Historic landmarks (only for individual buildings) and State Archeological Landmarks; or 
(c)  Local-designated under a municipal historic ordinance either individually as a landmark or as a locally designated district. 
    Historic District (HD) means a geographically and locally defined area that possesses a significant concentration, linkage, or continuity of buildings, objects, sites, structures, or landscapes united by past events, periods, or styles of architecture, and that, by reason of such factors, constitute a distinct section of the Brownsville. Historic sites within a local district need not be contiguous for an area to constitute a district. All sites, buildings, and structures within a local historic district, whether individually contributing or not are subject to the regulations of the district. 
    Historic preservation plan (previously referred to as the heritage plan ) has referred to the list of historic resources that have benefited from the ad valorem tax component of the city's preservation efforts. As of the adoption of the revisions of 2015, the historic preservation plan refers to the documented plan of action, adopted either annually or otherwise, that sets out how the city will accomplish its preservation efforts; further the historical Heritage Plan that used to be the list of historic resources benefitting from the ad valorem tax incentives, will be incorporated in the historic preservation plan as the "ad valorem tax exemption component" of that plan. 
    Historic rehabilitation means the process of returning a property to a state of utility, through repair or alteration, which makes possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions and features of the property which are significant to its historic, architectural and cultural values. 
    Historic resource means any building, structure, object or site that is 50 years or older, any resource that has been identified in the Historic Resources Survey of 2000, and any property that is referred to as an historic site (using the nomenclature preceding the adoption of the ordinance in 2015 from which this article derives). 
    Historic resources survey means a systematic, detailed examination of an area designed to gather information about historic properties sufficient to evaluate them against predetermined criteria of significance. 
    Historic landmark (formerly known as historic site) means a building, structure, object or site that has been designated by the city council as an historic resource or by the State of Texas or by the National Registry of Historic Places. "Historic Site" has been the term used in Brownsville prior to the adoption of the revisions of the ordinance in 2015 from which this article derives. 
    Integrity means the authenticity of a property's historic identity, evidenced by survival of physical characteristics that existed during the property's historic or prehistoric period. 
    Local site means an historic property that has been previously designated by the entity formally knowns as the heritage council and confirmed by the city commission as historically significant but not designated by the State of Texas or the National Registry of Historic Places. 
    National register of historic places means the nation's official list of buildings, districts, and sites (including structures and objects) significant in American history and culture, architecture, archeology, and engineering maintained by the National Park Service and administered on a state-wide basis by the Texas Historical Commission. Restrictions on these properties exist only when there is an undertaking that uses federal funds or that requires a federal permit or license. 
    Preservation means the stabilization of an historic building, its materials, and features, in their present condition to prevent future deterioration. Preservation focuses on the maintenance and repair of existing historic materials and retention of a property's form as it has evolved over time, (protection and stabilization are included here.) 
    Primary local site means a site that meets the qualifications of section 348-1512 and has been listed in the most recent historic preservation plan pursuant to section 348-1504. 
    Recorded Texas Historical Landmark (RTHL) means a state designation for buildings important for their historical associations and which have retained a high degree of their original historic fabric. They must be at least 50 years of age and retain their original exterior appearance. 
    Secondary local site refers to sites assigned a number in the Historic Resource Survey of 2000. The heritage council, the predecessor to the HPDRB designated all such sites as secondary local sites. 
    Local site or resource means a historic resource. 
    Secretary of the Interior Standards for Rehabilitation means the standards established by the Secretary of the Interior for advising federal agencies on the preservation/rehabilitation of historic properties listed or eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1491. - Administrative and advisory boards. 
    This article shall be implemented by the following individuals and boards: 
(a)  The historic preservation officer (HPO), the chief administrative officer under this article. 
(b)  The historic preservation and design review board (HPDRB), which: 
(1)  Sit as an advisory body, gathering evidence and making recommendations to the planning and zoning commission in regard to the HD, the historic preservation plan, any newly created historic districts; and 
(2)  Sits as an administrative body, by screening, rejecting, or approving Class A permits under the guidelines set forth in this chapter. 
(c)  The planning and zoning commission, which, reviews, considers and makes recommendations related to the contents and related zoning for the following: 
(1)  All changes in the historic preservation plan, which includes the ad valorem tax component, and; 
(2)  Any historic overlay district modifications or the addition of historic districts. 
(d)  The city commission, which: 
(1)  Sits in a legislative capacity in regard to passing any new zoning ordinances, and has final authority over review decisions made by the historic preservation officer and or the Historic preservation and design review board; 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1492. - Historic preservation officer (HPO). 
    The HPO, through the office of historic preservation, shall administer this article and shall advise and make a recommendation to the HPDRB on each application that comes before the board The HPO shall have expertise in at least one of the following: architecture, architectural history, historic preservation, design, urban design or city planning. The HPO shall be subject to the following and have the following powers, duties and goals as well as additional duties and responsibilities as specified throughout this article and this Code: 
(a)  Shall be a city employee who is appointed by the city manager; and 
(b)  Shall have the authority that is granted to the appointee by this Code or city ordinance or that is delegated to such appointee by the city manager; and 
(c)  Shall have the authority to issue and enforce written policies for the purpose of exercising the responsibilities explicitly assigned to him or her; and 
(d)  Shall prepare or have prepared carefully written minutes of all HPDRB meetings. The HPO shall distribute copies of each meeting's minutes to all board members and to the Texas Historical Commission within 60 days after the date of such meeting; and 
(e)  Shall cause notice of each public hearing of the board to be given by posting the notice thereof at city hall at least 72 hours before such hearing; and 
(f)  Shall determine whether an application for certificate of appropriateness is to be reviewed under the administrative approval procedure (section 348-1521) or to be reviewed by the HPDRB; and 
(g)  Shall recommend to the board, buildings, objects, sites, structures, and districts for nomination as a RTHL or inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places. Such recommendations shall be guided by the criteria established in the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966; and 
(h)  Shall maintain and hold open for public viewing all historic district guidelines used for review by the HPDRB. Public viewing includes available office of preservation websites; and 
(i)  May file a notice of historic status in the county deed records noting that a property is or may be subject to the city preservation ordinance This notice is for informational purposes only and the failure of the HPO to file the notice does not affect the applicability of the city preservation ordinance to the property; and 
(j)  Is authorized to issue citations, notices to comply, and or stop work orders to any person for violating any section of this article; and 
(k)  Shall convene meetings of the HPDRB. 
(l)  Whenever the HPO, or downtown manager, is unavailable to perform one of the HPO's duties, the planning director, or his or her designee shall temporarily perform such duty. Whomever shall temporarily perform such duty shall adhere to these historic preservation ordinances; and 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1493. - Historic preservation and design review board. 
    The members of the HPDRB are appointed by the city commission. The Board reviews projects that involve exterior changes to historic properties, infill projects located in the historic district & projects in the HD that involve the public right-of-way and parks. They may be called upon to address policy decisions and or to review any property that the HPO seeks input on. 
(a)  Appointment. The HPDRB shall be appointed by the city commission. In appointing members of the commission, the city council shall make appointments that are sensitive to the preservation and development goals of the city, as stated in this article and as part of the comprehensive plan and that will enable the city to retain compliance as a certified local government under the rules incorporating the provisions of the U.S. Historic Preservation Act of 1966, as amended, and Title 13, Texas Historic Commission, chapter 15, specifically 13 TAC 15.6(f)(3)(C), so that all members shall have a demonstrated "interest, competence, or knowledge in historic preservation." 
(b)  Duties and functions. The HPDRB may assist in an advisory capacity to the city director of planning, parks, airport, building permits, city manager, finance, grant management, public health, public works, the HPO and other appropriate heads of municipal departments. The board shall have no authority to bind The city by contract or otherwise. The board shall also have the following duties, responsibilities and functions: 
(1)  The HPDRB members will read and gain a working knowledge of this preservation ordinance and the guidelines referred to in subsection 348-1520(a) and shall be advocates for their application and enforcement. 
(2)  Gathering evidence and making recommendations to the HPO regarding historic preservation planning, any proposed historic overlay district(s), any proposed historic resource designation(s) or for alterations to existing districts. 
a.  The HPDRB shall have the authority to assess the physical conditions of historic sites to: 
i.  Prevent deterioration of historic resources by notifying owners of such sites of good maintenance practices for historic structures; and 
ii.  Assess whether to recommend that a historic site be delisted from inclusion in the ad valorem taxation component of the preservation plan. 
(3)  As to proposed changes to the historic overlay district, the HPDRB shall have the authority to hold public hearings and gather evidence concerning advisability of any amendments or changes to the historic overlay district or the creation of additional historic districts. 
(4)  To approve, deny, or approve with conditions, Certificates of Appropriateness (COAs) concerning any historic resource within any historic overlay district or in the historic preservation plan. Also, the HPDRB shall have the authority to request that the HPO initiate any penalty provisions provided for in this article. Any criminal penalty shall be initiated by written complaint filed by the HPO or building official in the municipal court. This exercise of these administrative powers shall be in public hearings, using the guidelines set forth in this article. 
(5)  The board shall be represented each year at a minimum of one informational or educational meeting which is sponsored by the Texas Historical Commission or another state or national preservation agency and which pertains to the current work and functions of the board or to other related historic preservation topics. 
(6)  The board shall have the authority to adopt and enforce rules for the purpose of exercising the responsibilities explicitly assigned to the board by city ordinance, including by not limited to forming committees charged with specific areas or projects. 
(7)  The HPDRB shall assist the HPO in preparing and presenting the annual report to the city commission, planning commission, and the Texas Historical Commission. 
a.  The annual report shall be prepared by the HPO for consideration and adoption by the HPDRB. Such report shall consist of complete attendance records for each member, a summary and analysis of the board's past activities and a summary and analysis of past historic preservation related activities of the private and public sectors. The annual report shall also consist of a summary and analysis of the HPO's past activities. 
b.  The HPDRB shall assist the HPO in monitoring and reporting to the Texas Historical Commission any actions affecting any county courthouse, Recorded Texas Historic Landmark, State Antiquities Landmark, National Register property, or local historic site. 
(8)  The HPDRB shall assist the HPO in evaluating potential adverse effect(s) on historic properties pursuant to Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966. 
(9)  May increase public awareness of the value of historic, cultural, and architectural preservation by developing and participating in public education programs. 
(10)  Upon request of the city commission, city manager, any taxing unit, or any historical commission, the HPDRB shall have the authority to give nonbinding advice concerning any of the following matters located inside the board's geographic jurisdiction: 
a.  The historic value of specific resources. 
b.  The potential impact of the sale, lease, or rental of certain public property. 
c.  The potential impact of certain proposed expenditures of public funds. 
d.  The historic value of existing or proposed voluntary incentives. 
e.  The potential impact on historic resources of permit applications. 
(11)  Within 120 days of initial appointment, each board member shall attend an orientation training concerning the responsibility, authority, and procedure of the HPDRB. Such training shall be provided by the HPO. 
(c)  Jurisdiction. The jurisdiction of the HPDRB shall be all of the city's historic district(s), as well as over any historic resource that is locally designated or designated by the state or the national register and is within the city limits or further if such extension is requested by a taxing unit and if the extended area is inside such unit's boundaries. 
(d)  Composition and qualifications. Composition shall be up to seven voting members from the following disciplines and backgrounds. While the following positions are preferable, the city commission may appoint individuals with related experience or qualifications that can contribute to the purpose of the HPDRB and who are available, willing, and desire to serve on the board. There shall be only one member from any of the disciplines. 
(1)  Architect. This means an individual who is either licensed to practice architecture in the U.S. and/or associate architect as defined by the American Institute of Architecture. 
(2)  Architectural historian. This means an individual having a graduate degree in architectural history, art history, historic preservation, or a closely related field and having studied such at a post-secondary level. A satisfactory amount of experience may substitute for the required degree. 
(3)  Archeologist. This means a person having post-secondary education in archeology, anthropology, or a closely related field plus: one year of full-time experience or equivalent specialized training in archeological research, administration, or management. 
(4)  Historian. This means a person having a post-secondary education in history or a closely related field, preferably someone with experience in research and writing and or associated with an academic institution, historic organization, museum or other professional institution 
(5)  Heritage tourism professional. This means a person with a post-secondary education in cultural or heritage tourism or a closely related field, preferably a person who is currently employed in the field. 
(6)  Historic property owner. This means a person who owns a property that is either designated in the HD, a Texas Historical Landmark, or a National Registered Historic Place or Landmark and is an outstanding steward of historic preservation, 
(7)  Professional engineer. This means an individual with a post-secondary degree in engineering and is a certified professional engineer by the Texas Board of Professional Engineers. 
(e)  Terms. 
(1)  Each voting member shall be appointed by the city commission for one two-year term, may be appointed to subsequent terms, shall serve without compensation, and shall execute a written oath office similar to that for a city commissioner prior to serving. 
(2)  HPDRB members shall be identified by place numbers one through seven and the terms. 
(3)  The terms of the voting members having odd-numbered positions shall expire on May 1 of every other odd-numbered year; and the terms of the voting members having even numbered positions shall expire on May 1 of every other even numbered year. 
(4)  Any voting member may be removed with or without cause by the city commission. 
(5)  Members shall serve on the board until their terms expire or if they resign, any vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the term by the city commission. 
(6)  Elections of the officers, chair and vice-chair shall be once every two years. 
(7)  Members shall submit a letter of resignation to the HPO if they can no longer fulfill the duties listed in this article. 
(f)  Quorum. A quorum of the board shall require at least four members, a simple majority of the HPDRB. The affirmative votes of a majority of the voting board members regardless of the number present is required for action on most COA reviews. In the case of an application for demolition a two-thirds majority vote of all HPDRB voting members is required for a recommendation of approval. 
(g)  Meetings of the board. The board shall meet at least one time per month. Additional special meetings may be called by the president or upon written request to the HPO signed by a majority of all board members, when a matter requires urgent consideration of the board. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public in accordance with the Texas Open Meetings Act. The place, day and/or hour of meetings may be changed by vote of the commission at any regular meeting. Notice of such action shall be provided in accordance with the Texas Open Meetings Act. Items may be submitted for the agenda to the HPO by any two board members, except in the case of a specific landowner for a specific designation. 
(h)  Meeting procedures. The board shall observe the following procedures: 
(1)  Any motion by a member shall require a second. After a motion has been made and duly seconded, discussion of the motion may be held for a reasonable time with each visitor taking a maximum of three minutes. Discussion by members or visitors of a question before the board shall terminate whenever a member shall call for a vote upon the question or whenever the president shall so rule. 
(2)  Whenever any question of procedure or qualification may be raised at a commission meeting, the president shall rule thereon. A member may move to overrule the president's decision which may be done by a majority vote of the members present. 
(3)  Voting on all matters may be by voice vote provided that a roll call vote shall be taken upon demand of any member. 
(4)  Any question of order or procedure not covered by these rules shall be decided according to the latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order, insofar as they may be applicable. 
(i)  Conflicts of interest. No member of the board shall vote or participate in any discussion as a board member in any matter that materially affects the property, income, or business interest of that member or in which the member holds a substantial interest. 
(j)  Attendance. Regular attendance at all meetings of the board, and conscientious performance of the duties requested of the members, shall be a prerequisite to continued membership on the board. Any member who for reasons other than sickness or bona fide emergencies misses three consecutive regular meetings or thirty percent of all meetings within a year will be recommended for replacement by the board or the HPO. Any member who has three consecutive unexcused absences shall be automatically deemed to have resigned from his or her appointment 
(k)  Special meetings. These may be called by the chairman or a majority of the voting members of the board. 
(l)  Public meetings. The HPDRB shall be subject to the same public meetings and public records standards as the city commission and planning commission. 
(m)  All other board procedures shall be specified by the board. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015; Ord. No. 2017-1606-A, §§ 1-6, 8-15-2017) 
Secs. 348-1494-348-1499. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HISTORIC DISTRICT SURVEYING, AD VALOREM TAX INCENTIVES AND THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION PLAN 

Sec. 348-1500. - Historic preservation plan adoption. 
    The 2019 Preservation Plan, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this article. Said plan shall be available for public inspection in the office of the historic preservation officer. It is hereby declared that each heritage site listed in said plan contains at least one historic structure. 
(Ord. No. 2016-1100.56, pt. 1, 2-2-2016; Ord. No. 2016-1100.57, § pt. 1, 12-13-2016; Ord. No. 2018-1100.58, 4-17-2018; Ord. No. 2019-1652, pt. 1, 2-19-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-1100.56, pt. 1, adopted Feb. 2, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as § 312-153. Inasmuch as this chapter was repealed by Ord. No. 2015-1606, Ord. No. 2016-1100.56, pt. 1, has been codified herein as § 348-1500 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 348-1501. - Historic district surveying. 
    On an ongoing basis, the HPO, with the assistance of the HPDRB, shall survey the city's historic resources, updating, reviewing and utilizing the surveys that were completed in 1975 and 2000. The HPO shall attempt on ongoing basis to accumulate information on the condition of the local landmarks and historic districts to the greatest extent given time and available resources. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1502. - Ad valorem tax incentives and the historic preservation plan. 
    The city has had tax incentives for historic buildings in place since the early 1980s. These tax incentives have proven effective in encouraging historic preservation. The incentives have been supported by the various taxing entities that access taxes on property owners in the HD. The existence of this component of the historic preservation plan encourages socio-economic diversity and stabilizes and lifts property values. 
(a)  Ad valorem tax component of the historic preservation plan. Taxable designated historic resources may qualify for ad valorem property tax relief as described in section 94-57 of this Code. 
(b)  Listing in the historic preservation plan. The recipients of the tax relief described in section 94-57 are determined annually by listing in the ad valorem component of the city's historic preservation plan. 
(1)  The city commission shall readopt or adopt the historic preservation plan at least once a year. Such action shall be by ordinance. 
(2)  The city commission shall not take such action in regards to the historic preservation plan until it has received the recommendation of the planning commission. 
(3)  The planning commission shall not act on the historic preservation plan until it has received the recommendation of the HPDRB. 
a.  The HPDRB shall not act on the historic preservation plan until the board receives a satisfactory survey report on the condition of all locally-designated resources and historic districts and a draft of the annual report required to be presented to the city commission. 
b.  It is the responsibility of the HPO in tandem with the HPDRB to ensure that the money that would have been spent on property taxes is being used for the rehabilitation, restoration and maintenance of historic resources. 
(c)  Failure to maintain properties and deletion of resources from participation in the ad valorem tax exemption component of historic preservation plan because of deterioration. The following sets out the reasons and process for deletion of properties from the list of properties that receive ad valorem tax relief. 
(1)  The HPO shall monitor the following with respect to properties receiving tax relief on an ongoing basis: paint (for peeling, fading, dirt), property or yard maintenance (weeds, overgrowth, edging, improperly trimmed trees, cleanliness), structural conditions, roof conditions, trim conditions, maintenance and other general upkeep that indicates a pride of place. 
(2)  The HPDRB may direct the HPO to request that the owner of a designated historic resource keep and provide the HPDRB on an annual basis accurate information, including receipts, cancelled checks, invoices, and other relevant information, detailing the record of expenditures towards the preservation, restoration, and/or objects at the designated historic resource, for the HPDRB. 
(3)  If the HPO finds that any property (appears to be out of compliance this chapter) then the HPO shall report to the HPDRB on the condition of said property. HPDRB shall make a finding of compliance or noncompliance and direct the HPO to notify the owner of noncompliance and specify a compliance period not to exceed 60 days. The monitoring of all designated historic resources by the HPO and the HPDRB shall take place on a regular basis. The HPO shall notify the owner of record of any historic resource with an object or a structure in need of repair and make recommendations to the property owner about how to accomplish such maintenance and repair in a proper and efficient manner. 
(4)  If the HPO finds that the historic resource is structurally unsound or in imminent danger of becoming structurally unsound he or she shall notify the owner of record by certified mail of such facts and specify the needed repairs and/or maintenance to remedy these conditions and provide a date upon which such repairs must be completed, not to exceed 60 days. Such written notification shall extend to and include other work items if there are reasonable grounds to indicate that the resource is undergoing widespread deterioration and, thus, architectural detailing and elements of the resource are being destroyed. 
(5)  If necessary repairs to the designated historic resource are not completed pursuant to the needed repairs specified to the owner, the HPO shall report on conditions at the resource to the HPDRB and recommend that that the resource be deleted (blocked) from inclusion in the ad valorem taxation component of the historic preservation plan. 
(6)  If the HPDRB agrees with the recommendation of the HPO, then the HPDRB shall have the authority to amend the current historic preservation plan and remove said resource from the ad valorem tax incentive list. 
(7)  Any owner of a historic resource blocked from participation in the ad valorem taxation component of the historic preservation plan adopted by the city commission pursuant to this section shall still have to comply with all other subsections of this section, including prohibitions against demolition by neglect (section 348-1526) and demolition of such a resource without first obtaining valid permission from the city. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1503. - Citizen participation. 
    The city commission and the planning commission shall each hold at least one public hearing on the historic preservation plan before taking final action thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1504. - Historic preservation plan contents. 
(a)  The historic preservation plan shall contain all of the following items: 
(1)  A list of all resources designated by the city as primary local resources and as such able to participate in the ad valorem tax component of said plan. 
(2)  A list of all resources within the city's territorial jurisdiction designated by the state or federal government as state sites or federal resources, respectively. 
(b)  In addition, for each historic resource listed in the historic preservation plan, such plan may include all of the following items: 
(1)  A brief justification for the designations. 
(2)  Identification of any buildings or other improvements on a given site or property that are excluded from such designation or recommendation. 
(c)  The historic preservation plan should also contain the plan of action, adopted either annually or otherwise, that sets out how the city is and will be accomplishing preservation in accordance with the city's comprehensive master plan. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Secs. 348-1505-348-1510. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 348-1511. - Designation process for historic districts. 
(a)  Authority. The city commission may designate, or amend designations by ordinance, certain areas of the city as historic districts and certain places, buildings, objects, sites, and structures, as historic resources. 
    The city commission shall not create or amend an historic district until it has received the nonbinding recommendation(s) of the planning and zoning commission. 
    Processing applications for designation of historic districts or amendments thereof. Historic overlay districts are intended to address geographic areas having special and substantial public interest and historic importance and, within such areas, to further the stated purposes of this article. 
(1)  Initiation. Any person owning property within the proposed area, the HPO, the HPDRB, the zoning commission or the city council may initiate a historic district designation or the amendment of an existing designation by filing a written request with one of the HPDRB members. Such request shall include a petition signed by a majority of property owners in a given area explaining the area desired for designation and the facts supporting such designation. Said board member shall place or submit these items on the agenda. Such requests shall remain valid for two months. 
In addition to any other considerations established by this section, applications for historic designation or amendments shall meet the following criteria: 
a.  Informational meeting and notice. Provided that the HPO and HPDRB agree that the proposed area indicated in the request is appropriate for designation, the HPDRB may hold public hearings on a given historic overlay district before making its recommendation thereon. Any public hearing is to be considered preliminary to the in-depth public hearings which the planning and zoning commission shall hold. It is to give that commission a general reaction as to potential benefit to the city and the owners of property in the area involved. The HPDRB may forward its recommendation to the planning and zoning commission. At least 72 hours before any board public hearing scheduled pursuant to this article, the HPO shall cause written notice thereof to be mailed to the representative of each neighborhood organization qualified under chapter 324 whose boundaries include or are within a radius of 300 feet from any resources scheduled to be discussed there and to each property owner within the proposed district. 
b.  Owners may submit requests with a written description and photographs or other visual material of any buildings or structures that they would like for the HPO to consider for designation as non-contributing to the HD. Requests for determination of whether an object, building, structure or sign are contributing or non-contributing to the HD shall be made on an application obtained from the HPO through the office of historic preservation. The HPO shall review the application for completeness and shall make a determination whether the subject of the application is contributing or non-contributing within 30 days of deeming the application complete. The HPO shall consult with the HPDRB or a subcommittee thereof in these matters. 
(b)  Planning and zoning considerations. The planning and zoning commission shall not act on any historic overlay district designations or amendments until it has received the nonbinding recommendation of the HPDRB. 
(1)  The planning and zoning commission shall hold at least one public hearing on HD overlay districts before taking final action thereon. 
(2)  Property owners of proposed designated resources or resources up for possible inclusion in an historic district shall be notified prior to the planning commission's public hearing on the recommended designation. 
(3)  At the planning commission's public hearing, owners, interested parties, and technical experts may testify or produce documentary evidence which will become part of the record regarding historic, architectural, or cultural importance of the proposed historic overlay district. 
(4)  The owner's consent for their property to be nominated or considered for inclusion in the historic overlay district shall not be required as part of designation. 
(5)  Under no circumstances shall the giving or withholding of consent by any property owner be a factor considered by the city in designating a resource historical. 
(6)  An atlas amendment may put an historic district or historic landmark district in any part of the city; and 
(7)  All provisions of each base zoning classification shall remain in full force and effect. 
(8)  Property inside the boundaries of an historic overlay district may be subject to provisions that are more stringent and/or less stringent than the provisions of any underlying base zoning classifications. 
(9)  If any provision in this article conflicts with overlay provisions in any other zoning ordinance, the provisions in this article shall overrule. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1512. - Criteria for designating primary local sites. 
    For the purposes of this article, all of the following criteria shall be utilized in designating primary local site. 
The resource shall: 
(1)  Possess significance in the history, architecture, archeology, and culture of the Rio Grande Valley or the city; or 
(2)  Be associated with events that have made a significant contribution to the broad patterns of local, regional, state, or national history; or 
(3)  Be strongly associated with the lives of persons significant in the past of the Rio Grande Valley or the city; or 
(4)  Embody the distinctive characteristics of a type, period, architectural style, or method of construction; or 
(5)  Represent the work of a master designer, builder, or craftsman; or 
(6)  Represent an established and familiar visual feature of value to the neighborhood and/or city. 
(7)  The resource need not be significant from a state or federal perspective; 
(8)  The resource need not be in good repair, although the state of repair or the potential permanence of the resource shall be one of the factors considered along with age, uniqueness, and other factors; and 
(9)  The resource shall be at least 40 years old, with resources older than 40 years being subject to preference. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1513. - Criteria for designating secondary local sites. 
    For the purposes of this article, all of the following criteria shall be utilized in designating secondary local resources: 
(a)  Within 300 feet of a federal resource, state resource or primary local resource and makes a significant positive contribution to the historic value of such federal resource or primary local resource; or 
(b)  Part of a geographic grouping of resources that may not qualify as primary local resources and that may not have historic value when each resource is considered individually but that have historic value when each resource is considered as part of such group; or 
(c)  Contributes to the streetscape or sense of place of a neighborhood or area of the city. The site shall be at least 30 years old, with sites older than 30 years being subject to preference. 
(d)  In general the term historic involves a balance of age, integrity and significance. The significance can be of the structure, the site or the individuals associated with the structure or site. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1514. - Effect of property owner's consent in designating primary local resource. 
    Under no circumstances shall the giving or withholding of consent by any property owner be a factor considered by the city in designating a primary local resource. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1515. - Composition of historic resources. 
(a)  Each historic resource not only shall include one or more buildings, structures, or other features having historic, architectural, archeological, or cultural value but also shall include the land necessary for access to and use of such features, with the exact boundaries of such land being delineated in the historic preservation plan. 
(b)  The historic structures present on the parcel or lot shall be listed and described as to their locations on the listed property. 
(1)  This written description and accompanying surveys or maps locating or delineating these buildings shall be part of the documentation of the historic preservation plan listing. 
(2)  Any and all structures considered to have no historic or architectural significance by the HPDRB as part of the designation process shall be described as to their presence on a historic resource. These non-historic structures shall be delineated as to their dimensions and locations within the historic resource property. 
(3)  These delineations of non-historic buildings at the site shall be part of the record as concerns its listing in the historic preservation plan. 
(c)  Non-historic, non-contributing, structures, determined by the HPDRB to have no architectural or historic significance shall not be subject to the demolition prohibitions established by this article. When such determination is made, such determination shall be recognized for only a one year period. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1516. - Reevaluation of designated historic resources. 
(a)  The HPDRB may reconsider a previous evaluation and listing of a property designated as a primary local resource or secondary local resource in a previously adopted historic preservation plan. 
(1)  In any reconsideration of a previous listing or evaluation, the HPDRB shall employ or examine the designation criteria set forth in this division. 
(2)  The HPDRB shall not take final action on such reevaluation without first hearing the recommendation of the HPO on the proposed reevaluation and also giving 25 days' prior notice to the owner of the resource under consideration of the possible change and the date of the HPDRB meeting when the members will consider the proposed reevaluation. 
(3)  The HPDRB may take into account the state of repair of the site in such reevaluation. Further, the board may also consider the extent of the owner's utilization of the tax exemption provisions for any primary local site towards financing the rehabilitation or maintenance of the site. Other considerations are listed in section 348-1502. 
(b)  The HPDRB's reevaluation, if taken, shall list the change in designation and reasons cited for the change in writing. 
(1)  The owner shall be notified in writing at least ten days prior to any public hearing by the planning commission on a proposed, preservation plan recommended by the HPDRB for adoption for the next calendar year. 
(2)  The HPDRB's reevaluation shall be in the form of a recommendation to the planning commission as part of the annual adoption of the preservation plan. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Secs. 348-1517-348-1519. - Reserved. 
Sec. 348-1520. - Certificates of appropriateness (COA). 
(a)  Definition and guidelines for granting. 
(1)  The purpose of a certificate of appropriateness (COA) is to help maintain, return or enhance the lost or diminished architectural significance of Brownsville's tangible past. A COA is required for any project requiring a building permit that is located in the HD or that pertains to a locally-designated landmark located anywhere in the city. This includes alterations, additions, demolitions, or relocations within the HD or new construction in the HD. 
(2)  If a COA is granted, it may be granted with provisions and conditions. Conceptual approval may be granted for general design ideas and principles (such as scale and setback). 
(3)  In previous ordinance versions this was also referred to as a Class A permit (section 348-1701) and is described as the required administrative permit for alterations of an historic resource. 
(b)  Grounds for the granting. The granting of a COA shall be under the guidelines of the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for the Treatment of Historic Properties, guidelines adopted by the city commission, and the guidelines contained herein, the respective knowledge of the HPDRB and it shall be the burden of the owner to so prove that any alteration is in compliance with such standards. The following guidelines are inserted here as a reference: 
(1)  Every reasonable effort shall be made to provide a compatible use for a property which requires minimal alteration of the building, structure, or resource and its environment or to use a property for its originally intended purpose. 
(2)  The distinguishing original qualities or character of a building, structure, or site and its environment shall not be destroyed. The removal or alteration of any historic material or distinctive architectural features should be avoided when possible. 
(3)  All buildings, structures, objects and sites shall be recognized as products of their own time. Alterations that have no historical basis and which seek to create an earlier appearance shall be discouraged. 
(4)  Changes which may have taken place in the course of time are evidence of the history and development of a building, structure, object or site and its environment. These changes may have acquired significance in their own right, and this significance shall be recognized and respected. 
(5)  Distinctive stylistic features or examples of skilled craftsmanship which characterize a building, structure, object, or site shall be treated with sensitivity. 
(6)  Deteriorated architectural features shall be repaired rather than replaced, wherever possible. If replacement is necessary, the new material should match the material being replaced in composition, design, color, texture, and other visual qualities. Repair or replacement of missing architectural features should be based on accurate duplications of features, substantiated by historic, physical, or pictorial evidence, rather than on conjectural designs or the availability of different architectural elements from other buildings or structures. 
(7)  The surface cleaning of structures shall be undertaken with the gentlest means possible. Sandblasting and other cleaning methods that will damage the historic building materials shall not be undertaken. 
(8)  Every reasonable effort shall be made to protect and preserve archeological resources affected by or adjacent to any project. 
(9)  Contemporary design for alterations and additions to existing properties shall not be discouraged when such alterations and additions do not destroy significant historical, architectural or cultural material, and such design is compatible with the size, scale, color, material, and character of the property, neighborhood or environment. 
(10)  Wherever possible, new additions or alterations to structures shall be done in such a manner that if such additions or alterations were to be removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the structure would be unimpaired. 
(c)  Compliance with permit. A person shall not alter a local landmark or a site within the city limits without complying with the COA. The applicant may consult with the planning department, the HPO, or the HPDRB before submitting an application and during the review process. 
(d)  Application. Prior to the commencement of any work requiring a COA under this division, the owner shall file an application for a certificate with the HPO. The application should be accompanied by: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant; 
(2)  Address of the property if different from owner's address; 
(3)  Elevation drawings of the proposed changes, including site plan, sections and floor plans if applicable; 
(4)  Samples and specific description of materials to be used; 
(5)  If the proposal includes signs or lettering, a scale drawing showing the type of lettering to be used, all dimensions and colors, a description of materials to be used, method of illumination if any, and a plan showing the sign's location on the property; and 
(6)  Any other information which the HPO may deem necessary in order to visualize the proposed work; 
(e)  Role of the HPO. It is the role of the HPO to assist whenever possible any citizen of Brownsville in making decisions, designing and in general complying with the historic preservation ordinances and guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015; Ord. No. 2017-1606-A, §§ 7, 8, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 348-1521. - Certificate of appropriateness-administrative approval. 
(a)  Applications for certain minor alterations, additions, ordinary repairs or maintenance may be reviewed and approved administratively by the HPO without review by the HPDRB. Those activities which constitute minor alterations, additions, repairs or maintenance include but are not limited to: 
(1)  Ordinary repair and maintenance. 
a.  Repair using the same material and design as the original and does not require structural modifications. 
b.  Repainting, using the same color. 
c.  Reroofing, using the same type and color of material. 
d.  Repair of sidewalks and driveways using the same type and color of materials. 
(2)  Doors/entrances. 
a.  Removing a non-historic door and replacing it with one in keeping with the character and era in which the building was built. 
b.  Removal of burglar bars. 
c.  Repair or slight modification to exterior steps or stairways using in-kind material. 
d.  Reopening of porch returning a porch to its original appearance by removing non-historic infill material with proper photo documentation or physical evidence.. 
(3)  Windows. 
a.  Removal of non-historic windows to replace with windows that match the original windows as closely as possible in material and design. 
b.  Restoring original window openings with proper photo documentation or physical evidence. 
c.  Removal of residential metal awnings. 
d.  Repairing window framing. 
e.  Removing inappropriate exterior shutters that are not of historic age. 
f.  Louvers and venting in which the vents or louvers are placed in an existing opening, in which there is no change in the configuration of the fenestration and the only modification to the building is the removal of glazing panels. 
g.  Removal of burglar bars. 
(4)  Siding. 
a.  Removing non-historic siding in order to encapsulate historic siding materials. 
(5)  Roofing. 
a.  Removal of composite roof shingles and replacing with clay tiles with documentation that clay tiles were the original roofing material. 
b.  Removal of composite roof shingles and replacing with metal roofing material with documentation that metal was the original roofing material. 
c.  Changing color of composite roofing material. 
d.  Changing color of existing metal roof with appropriate specifications and details. 
(6)  Additions. 
a.  Any rear addition to an non-contributing resource, if the addition is under 200 square feet and uses the same (non-historic) material as the existing structure as well as the existing roof ridgeline; must include plans with specifications. 
(7)  Painting. 
a.  Reasonable changes to paint colors on previously painted surfaces which are consistent with the district or landmark characteristics. 
b.  Paint removal/pressure water washing/graffiti removal if done using the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and if cleaning specifications are submitted for staff review. 
(8)  Landscaping. 
a.  Replacing paved areas with sod or other landscaping. 
b.  Fifty percent or less square feet of front yard replacement. 
c.  Sprinkler system with site map. 
d.  Backyard landscaping. 
e.  Removal of existing landscaping or sod areas and replacing with xeriscaping where not removing character defining landscaping elements. 
f.  New plantings in keeping with the character of neighborhood. 
(9)  Hardscaping with site map and specifications. 
a.  Parking pads under 144 square feet. 
b.  Sidewalks residential/commercial with contextually appropriate placement (such as a traditional planting strip). 
c.  Driveway construction if less than 12 feet in width and consistent with guidelines. 
d.  Parking with appropriate landscaping (non-historic properties). 
(10)  Fencing. 
a.  Removal of chain link, plywood, or vinyl and replacing with wood, wrought iron, garden loop, or masonry. 
b.  Replacing or recreating any fence or handrail with historic documentation of its original appearance. 
c.  Installing or constructing a fence, railing, or wall where none exists (sides and rear only behind front facade plane of historic structure) with specifications supplied to the HPO. 
(11)  Signage. 
a.  Changes in content or configuration (re-facing) that do not involve changes in sign location, dimensions, lighting or total sign, area. 
b.  Signs that are consistent with HPDRB approved master signage plans. 
c.  Temporary banners or signs where allowed by this article. 
d.  Signs that comply with section 348-1519 and have a square footage equal to or less than the requirements outlined. Signage applications above the allowable square footage shall be forwarded to the HPDRB for their recommendation. 
(12)  New construction. 
a.  Rear ADA ramps. 
b.  Rear porch. 
c.  Rear deck. 
d.  Swimming pools, fountains in back yard. 
(13)  Miscellaneous. 
a.  Reasonable changes in color to awning fabric that are consistent with the district or landmark characteristics. 
b.  Renewal of expired certificates of appropriateness. 
c.  Removal of any prohibited element described in city Code. 
d.  Emergency installation of temporary features to protect a historic resource or to weatherize or stabilize. 
e.  Foundation. 
f.  Mechanical units. 
g.  Exterior electrical. 
h.  Exterior plumbing. 
i.  Exterior electrical fixtures. 
j.  Antennas. 
k.  Glass replacement. 
l.  Dumpsters with screening. 
m.  Lighting. 
n.  Rooftop HVAC, mechanical or communication equipment that is not visible from the public right-of-way and results in no modifications to the visible facades of the building. 
(b)  A clear photograph of the building, object, or structure to be repaired, a brief description of the intended work, and samples of replacement materials or paint for comparison with the existing building, object, or structure must be furnished with the application. Site plan and specifications may be required as needed for adequate administrative review as determined by the HPO. 
(c)  The HPO shall review an application for a certificate of appropriateness for administrative approval and shall approve or deny the application within 14 days from receipt. Any interested person may appeal the HPO's decision to the HPDRB by submitting to the HPO a written request for appeal within ten days of the decision. The written request for appeal starts the certificate of appropriateness process by the HPDRB. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1522. - Certificate of appropriateness requiring HPDRB approval. 
(a)  Timeline. Within 35 days of receipt of the transmittal letter requesting a COA, the HPO shall meet with the HPDRB and determine whether to approve or deny the permit. 
(b)  Issuance of permit. If a COA has been approved and granted and all other requirements of the codes are met, the building official shall issue a building permit to the applicant for the proposed work. 
(c)  Resubmission of application after denial. 
(1)  If a COA has been denied without prejudice due to incompleteness or lack of information with the application, the applicant may resubmit his permit request at any time. If a COA has been denied with prejudice, the applicant may not resubmit a permit application for six months from the date of the final decision, unless the applicant files a written request indicating that changes recommended by the HPDRB have been incorporated in the application. 
(2)  If a COA has been denied by the HPDRB, an applicant may appeal this denial to the planning and zoning commission. If the resolution sought is not approved by the planning and zoning commission, an applicant may appeal the planning and zoning commission decision to the city commission. It is not allowed to take steps out of the order of appeal set forth in this section. No person in the city has the authority to make decisions regarding the built environment, whether privately owned or publically owned regarding any property or resource that is covered by Article IX of the ordinances other than by the process of approval set forth herein. 
(d)  Amendment. A COA may be amended through use of the original class A permit application process. 
(e)  Emergency procedure. If an historic resource is damaged by fire, wind, hail, or other natural causes and the HPO determines that the resource will suffer additional damage without immediate repair, the building official is authorized to allow the property owner to temporarily protect the historic structure until the certificate of appropriateness is approved. This certificate of appropriateness must be applied for within ten days of the occurrence which caused the damage. Any protection must be temporary and must not permanently alter the architectural features of the historic resources. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1523. - Relocation of a structure into or out of the historic district. 
(a)  No development that requires the relocation of a historic building, object, or structure that is located to be located in or removed from the HD shall occur until both a COA has been granted and all other applicable sections of the city Code have been met. 
(b)  In considering whether to recommend approval or disapproval of a certificate application to relocate a building, object or structure into or out of the HD, the HPDRB shall be guided by the following considerations: 
(1)  The historic character and aesthetic interest the building, structure or object contributes to its present setting; 
(2)  Whether there are definite plans for the area that will be vacated and what the effect of those plans on the character of the surrounding area will be; 
(3)  Whether the building, structure, or object can be moved without significant damage to its physical integrity; 
(4)  Whether the proposed relocation area is compatible with the historical and architectural character of the building, object, or structure. 
(5)  Balancing the contribution of the property to the character of the HD with the special merit of the application. 
(c)  Should an application to relocate a building, object or structure be approved, the HPO shall ensure that the new location is already zoned historic or shall review whether such location should be designated. 
(d)  The HPO may administratively approve applications for relocation for properties out of the district deemed noncontributing to the historic character of a HD and designated as such. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1524. - Demolition. 
(a)  Intention of this section. This article is intended to provide long-term regulation for the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of the city's historic sites, historic resources and historic clusters that represent elements of the city's cultural, economic, political, social, and architectural history, inside the HD. 
    Since 1971 the city has had preservation ordinances to ensure that development occurs in accord with established public policy and that it will protect and enhance the city's historic/architectural resources for the benefit of residents, tourists, and visitors and serve as a support and stimulus to business and industry, strengthening the economy of the city. 
    Demolition of an historic structure constitutes an irreplaceable loss to the quality and character of the city. Accordingly, these procedures provide criteria to prevent unnecessary damage to the quality and character of the city's historic district character while, at the same time, balancing these interests against the property rights of landowners. 
    This section is also meant to ensure that the city's historic preservation ordinances effectively safeguard areas and sites of historical significance and to ensure that: 
(1)  These resources are not seriously endangered by ill-advised repairs and shoddy construction of inferior quality and appearance and by wholesale alterations that are incompatible with their preservation and enjoyment; 
(2)  These areas and sites are not diminished by relocation or demolition of designated historic resources which destroy or lessen the architectural context of the district or clusters of structures within the district; and 
(3)  The owners of historic resources shall not be denied reasonable use of their property. 
(b)  These ordinances are meant to promote city's heritage and are designed for the education, pleasure, and welfare of the citizens. One or more of the following characteristics may be of significance when considering demolitions. 
(1)  Character, interest or value as part of the historic development, heritage or cultural characteristics of the city, state, or county. 
(2)  Location as the site of a significant historic event. 
(3)  Identification with a person who significantly contributed to the cultural and development of the city. 
(4)  Contribution to the city's economic, social, or historical context 
(5)  Portrayal of the environment of a group of people in an era of history characterized by a distinctive architectural style. 
(6)  Embodiment of distinguishing characteristics of an architectural type or specimen. 
(7)  Identification as the work of an architect or master builder whose individual work has influenced the development of the city. 
(8)  Embodiment of elements of architectural design, detail, materials or craftsmanship which represent a significant architectural innovation. 
(9)  Relationship to other distinctive buildings, sites, or areas which are eligible for preservation according to a plan based on historic, cultural, or architectural motif. 
(10)  Unique location of singular physical characteristics representing an established and familiar visual feature of a neighborhood, community or the city. 
(11)  Archaeological value in that it has produced or can be expected to produce data affecting theories of historic or prehistoric interest. 
(c)  Applicability. The provisions of this section apply to any application for demolition in the HD. No development that constitutes the demolition or partial demolition, substantial alteration, or relocation of a building, object, or structure in the HD shall occur until a COA for demolition has been approved and a permit therefor has been granted by the buildings department and all other applicable sections of the city Code and state law have been met. 
(1)  Historic resource. No certificate shall be issued for demolition of an historic resource as defined in section 348-1502, unless the applicant demonstrates clear and convincing evidence supporting an unreasonable economic hardship on the applicant. If an applicant fails to prove unreasonable economic hardship, the applicant may provide to the HPDRB additional information regarding loss of integrity and/or significance as provided in subsection (c) in order to receive an HPDRB recommendation for a certificate for demolition. 
(2)  Public safety hazards and emergency securing measures. Except in cases of imminent danger to public safety, health, or welfare. No federal, state or local resource nor any structure located within the historic district may be demolished in whole or in part as a hazard to public safety, or for any reason whatsoever until the HPO has been notified by the appropriate municipal official that an order for such demolition is being prepared, and the HPDRB has had 60 days to have an opportunity to discuss with city officials the feasibility of emergency measures to secure the structure in such a manner as to preclude the possibility of injury to the public. If there is any city ordinance that conflicts with this article, this article shall take precedence. 
(d)  Unreasonable economic hardship. 
(1)  Generally. The HPDRB shall be guided in its decision to grant or deny a demolition permit for a given structure in the HD by balancing the historic, architectural, cultural and/or archaeological value of the site against the merit of the proposed replacement project and its potential to contribute to the HD. The HPDRB shall not consider or be persuaded to find unreasonable economic hardship based on the presentation of circumstances or items that are not unique to the property in question (i.e., the current economy). 
(2)  Burden of proof. When a claim of unreasonable economic hardship is made, the owner must provide evidence that: 
a.  The owner cannot make reasonable beneficial use of or realize a reasonable rate of return on a structure or site, regardless of whether that return represents the most profitable return possible, unless the proposed demolition or relocation is allowed; 
b.  The structure and property cannot be reasonably adapted for any other feasible use, whether by the current owner or by a purchaser, which would result in a reasonable rate of return; and 
c.  The owner has failed to find a purchaser or tenant for the property during the previous two years, despite having listed the property on the MLS, or for sale by owner with proof of advertising and or other substantive proof of effort to sell the property during that period. 
d.  The evidence of unreasonable economic hardship introduced by the owner may, where applicable, include proof that the owner's affirmative obligations to maintain the structure or property make it impossible for the owner to realize a reasonable rate of return on the structure or property. 
(3)  Criteria. The public benefits obtained from retaining the cultural resource must be analyzed and duly considered by the HPDRB. 
As evidence that an unreasonable economic hardship exists, the owner may submit the following information to the HPDRB by affidavit: 
a.  For all structures and property: 
i.  The past and current use of the structures and property; 
ii.  The name and legal status (e.g., partnership, corporation) of the owners; 
iii.  The original purchase price of the structures and property; 
iv.  The assessed value of the structures and property according to the two most recent tax assessments; 
v.  The amount of real estate taxes on the structures and property for the previous two years; 
vi.  The date of purchase or other acquisition of the structures and property; 
vii.  Principal balance and interest rate on current mortgage and the annual debt service on the structures and property, if any, for the previous two years; 
viii.  All appraisals obtained by the owner or applicant within the previous two years in connection with the owner's purchase, financing or ownership of the structures and property; 
ix.  Any listing of the structures and property for sale or rent price asked and offers received; 
x.  Any consideration given by the owner to profitable adaptive uses for the structures and property; 
xi.  Any replacement construction plans for proposed improvements on the site; 
xii.  Financial proof of the owner's ability to complete any replacement project on the site, which may include but not be limited to a performance bond, a letter of credit, a trust for completion of improvements, or a letter of commitment from a financial institution; and 
xiii.  The current fair market value of the structure and property as determined by a qualified appraiser. 
xiv.  Any property tax exemptions claimed in the past five years. 
b.  For income-producing structures and property: 
i.  Annual gross income from the structure and property for the previous two years; 
ii.  Itemized operating and maintenance expenses for the previous two years; and 
iii.  Annual cash flow, if any, for the previous two years. 
c.  In the event that the HPDRB determines that any additional information described above is necessary in order to evaluate whether an unreasonable economic hardship exists, the HPDRB shall notify the owner. Failure by the owner to submit such information to the HPDRB within 15 days after receipt of such notice, which time may be extended by the HPDRB, may be grounds for denial of the owner's claim of unreasonable economic hardship. 
When a low-income resident homeowner is unable to meet the requirements set forth in this section, then the HPDRB, at its own discretion, may waive some or all of the requested information and/or request substitute information that an indigent resident homeowner may obtain without incurring any costs. If the HPDRB cannot make a determination based on information submitted and an appraisal has not been provided, then the HPDRB may request that an appraisal be made by the city. 
(e)  Loss of significance. An applicant may provide to the HPDRB information which may show a loss of significance in regards to the subject of the application in order to receive HPDRB of approval of the demolition. 
    If, based on the evidence presented, the HPDRB finds that the structure or property is no longer historically, culturally, architecturally or archeologically significant it may make a recommendation for approval of the demolition. In making this determination, the HPDRB must find that the owner has established by a preponderance of the evidence that the structure or property has undergone significant and irreversible changes which have caused it to lose the historic, cultural, architectural or archeological significance, qualities or features which qualified the structure or property for such designation. Additionally, the HPDRB must find that such changes were not caused either directly or indirectly by the owner, and were not due to intentional or negligent destruction or a lack of maintenance rising to the level of a demolition by neglect. 
    The HPDRB shall not consider or be persuaded to find loss of significance based on the presentation of circumstances or items that are not unique to the property in question (i.e., the current economic climate). 
    For property located within a historic district, the HPDRB shall be guided in its decision by balancing the contribution of the property to the character of the HD with the special merit of the proposed replacement project. 
(f)  Documentation and strategy. 
(1)  Applicants that have received a COA regarding demolition may be required to document buildings, objects, sites or structures which are intended to be demolished with photographs and provide them to the HPO. 
(2)  Applicants may be required to prepare for the HPO a salvage strategy for reuse of building materials deemed valuable by the HPO for other preservation and restoration activities. 
(3)  Applicants that have received an approval of a COA regarding demolition shall be permitted to receive a demolition permit without additional board action on demolition, following the board's recommendation of a certificate for new construction. Permits for demolition and construction shall be issued simultaneously if requirements for new construction are met, and the property owner provides financial proof of his ability to complete the project. 
(4)  When the board recommends approval of a certificate for buildings, objects, sites, structures designated as historic, or for resources in the historic district, permits shall not be issued until all plans for the site have received approval from all appropriate city boards, commissions, departments and agencies. Permits for parking lots shall not be issued, nor shall an applicant be allowed to operate a parking lot on such property, unless such parking lot plan was approved as a replacement element for the demolished object or structure. 
(g)  Issuance of permit. When the board recommends approval of a COA regarding demolition of buildings, objects, sites, or structures in historic districts or historic sites that have been determined to be contributing, permits shall not be issued until all plans for the site have received approval from all appropriate city boards, commissions, departments and agencies. Once the replacement plans are approved a fee shall be assessed for the demolition based on the approved replacement plan square footage. The fee must be paid in full prior to issuance of any permits and shall be deposited into a city account directed by the HPO for the benefit and or rehabilitation of local historic resources including the prevention of demolition by neglect (section 348-1523(c)(3)). 
Fees shall be as follows and are in addition to any fees charged by the building department: 
0-2,500 square feet = $1,500.00 
2,501-10,000 square feet = $4,000.00 
10,001-25,000 square feet = $10,000.00 
25,001-50,000 square feet = $20,000.00 
Over 50,000 square feet = $30,000.00 
(h)  The HPO may use administrative approval for applications for demolition permits for non-contributing minor outbuildings within the HD such as carports, detached garages, sheds, and greenhouses determined by the HPO to not possess historical or architectural significance either as a stand-alone building or structure, or as part of a complex of buildings or structures on the site. 
(Ord. No. 2015-1606, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 348-1525. - Prevention of demolition by neglect. 
(a)  Applicability. The exterior features of any historic resource, objects, sites, or structures (including but not limited to structural elements, building materials, fences, light fixtures, steps, pavement, paths or any other appurtenant feature), or any type of outdoor advertising sign shall be preserved against decay and deterioration and kept free from certain structural defects, the owner thereof or such other person or persons who may have legal custody and control, shall upon written request by the HPO repair such exterior features if they are found to be deteriorating, or if their condition is contributing to deterioration, including but not limited to any of the following defects: 
(1)  Deteriorated or inadequate foundation (including piers, and perimeter beams): Defective or deteriorated flooring or floor supports or flooring or floor supports or joists of insufficient size to carry imposed loads with safety; 
(2)  Members of walls: Members of walls, partitions or other vertical supports that split, lean, list or buckle due to defective material or deterioration. Members of walls, partitions or other vertical supports that are of insufficient size to carry imposed loads with safety;
